webTitle: The best mistaken identity scene: Gangster number one

fields.headline: The best mistaken identity scene: Gangster number one
fields.trailText: 1968. On their way to a Mayfair nightclub, underworld boss Freddie Mays (David Thewlis) has given his lieutenant Gangster (Paul Bettany) his tiepin, emblazoned with the initials "FM". Once inside, they sit at a corner table.
fields.body:
1968. On their way to a Mayfair nightclub, underworld boss Freddie Mays (David Thewlis) has given his lieutenant Gangster (Paul Bettany) his tiepin, emblazoned with the initials "FM". Once inside, they sit at a corner table.

Meanwhile, in a backstage dressing room, the nightclub owner turns to hostesses Mel and Karen (Saffron Burrows).

"Right, I want the pair of you to go out there and keep Freddie Mays and his goon company."

"You didn't mention nothing about that in the ad", protests Karen.

"I'm not asking you to suck him off", snaps her boss. "Just keep him company. He's clean, he's well-mannered, and he's rich. And if you like him, be my guest, fuck off and marry him."

The nightclub owner walks off. Back inside the club, Gangster sits alone while Freddie disappears to the bathroom. At the bar, Mel whispers in Karen's ear.

"Table 2. I'll be over in a minute."

Karen approaches Gangster.

"Mind if I sit down?"

"Suit yourself", he grunts.

"I was told you were well- mannered, Mr Freddie Mays."

She pours herself a glass of wine.

"What makes you think I'm Freddie Mays?"

"Women's intuition."

She points at his tiepin.

"I also heard you were quite the gentleman."

Gangster smiles horribly through a mouthful of food.

"Did you now?"

See also: The Big Lebowski, Some Like It Hot, The Player

Don't see also: The Man Who Knew Too Little

Pointless trivia: Saffron Burrows is currently dating Leaving Las Vegas director Mike Figgis.

webTitle: Labour snoops eavesdropped on Lib Dems

fields.headline: Labour snoops eavesdropped on Lib Dems
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour researchers have admitted regularly snooping on the private conversations in the office of Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, and his predecessor, Paddy Ashdown.
fields.body:
Labour researchers have admitted regularly snooping on the private conversations in the office of Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, and his predecessor, Paddy Ashdown.

The Labour eavesdropping has been most frequent when the Liberal Democrat leaders have been discussing possible lines of attack for prime minister's questions. The researchers passed the information on to Downing Street so that Tony Blair was able to prepare likely lines of defence.

A formal letter of complaint has been lodged by the Lib Dems with Parliament's serjeant-at-arms, Peter Jennings, the man responsible for overseeing the running of the palace of Westminster.

Lord Newby, Mr Kennedy's chief of staff, said yesterday that at first he regarded the eavesdropping as a joke, but then realised that sensitive issues were discussed inside the office and it was a serious breach of faith.

The snooping was carried out by researchers lingering outside a door to Mr Kennedy's office never used by him, or his staff. The door leads onto a corridor of offices of mainly Labour MPs and their staff.

The news that Labour was regularly eavesdropping emerged when a Labour researcher made the admission to a Lib Dem opposite number during a drink. The BBC yesterday persuaded one of the researchers to confess to the eavesdropping on condition that his voice was disguised.

The security conscious Mr Ashdown, a former member of the Special Boat Squadron, developed elaborate precautions to prevent break-ins at his office, but had no idea that his conversations could be heard. When Mr Kennedy's staff investigated they discovered that details of almost all conversations inside the office could be readily overheard outside.

Mr Kennedy made a passing reference to the "high grade intelligence" obtained by Mr Blair at question time in the Commons yesterday.

In a letter to the Commons serjeant, Lord Newby complains: "It has been reported to us that Labour party researchers may be listening to conversations in Charles Kennedy's personal office in the Commons by standing outside the door which links the office to the corridor. It is possible to hear virtually everything which is said in a normal conversation in Charles' office by standing just outside the door.

"I wondered whether it might be possible to do something to soundproof the door."

Mr Jennings is understood to be acting on the request, even though many people felt that the relationship between the leadership of Labour and Liberal Democrats - at least during the Ashdown era - was so intimate that Mr Ashdown would have been happy to give Mr Blair prior details of his intended line of attack.

fields.headline: Los de Abajo
fields.trailText:
Los de Abajo ***
Ronnie Scott's, London
fields.body:
Los de Abajo ***
Ronnie Scott's, London

Salsa, the sound of the summer, is coming in many guises. The elderly best-selling Cubans from the Buena Vista Social Club are back yet again, this time rivalling Elton John with their massive outdoor show at Hyde Park. New bands like the Anglo-Colombian Sidestepper promise to enliven the festival season with their Latin clubland dance fusions.

Here, adding to the mix, is an outfit from Mexico City, dubbed the "first punk salsa band", who bring radical politics back to the dancefloor with a rousing, cheerfully angry style that sounds like a Mexican answer to 2-Tone, with a batch of unexpected influences added in.

Los de Abajo (literally "those from below") are a young nine-piece band who are mostly graduates of Mexico's national university. They take their name from a novel about a disillusioned soldier.

Mexico is a cultural melting-pot, and its North American, South American and Caribbean influences are reflected in the group's wildly varied songs. They mix salsa with cool, slinky or witty political ballads (a reminder of the early work of Ruben Blades, down in Panama), then veer into stomping ska, complete with wild pogoing or skanking from the entire band. Then they add in some reggae and even a Mexican country polka before returning with a vengeance to those Latin rhythms - the basis of their songs.

Arriving at Ronnie Scott's for their first ever London date after having played out of town earlier in the day, they hurled themselves into an exhausting two-hour set that became more frantic by the minute. They started, conventionally enough, with choppy salsa dance songs, with singer and flautist Liber Tiran backed by a slick three-piece brass section, headed by the band's one female member - the inspired singer and trombonist Odisea Valenzuela - along with keyboards, drums and percussion. Then they began branching out, introducing accordion and guitar, throwing in dance routines that would have impressed Madness, and making some attempt to explain in English the rousing songs that apparently dealt with corruption, Aids, the Zapatista uprising and the plight of Mexico's impoverished Indians.

Their debut album, simply called Los de Abajo and released through David Byrne's Luaka Bop label, is a pleasantly rousing introduction to the band but it's not a patch on their live performance. They turned Ronnie Scott's into a dance club and would work wonders at festivals, fiestas or political rallies.

webTitle: MPC game goes into extra time

fields.headline: MPC game goes into extra time
fields.standfirst: Committee minutes shake the notion that British interest rates have peaked
fields.trailText: To paraphrase Britain's most famous piece of football commentary, Britain's manufacturers and exporters thought it was all over. It isn't now. The notion that interest rates had peaked at 6% was shaken yesterday when the Bank of England released the minutes of its monetary policy committee meeting earlier this month.
fields.body:
To paraphrase Britain's most famous piece of football commentary, Britain's manufacturers and exporters thought it was all over. It isn't now. The notion that interest rates had peaked at 6% was shaken yesterday when the Bank of England released the minutes of its monetary policy committee meeting earlier this month.

At that session, the MPC kept the cost of borrowing on hold, but the minutes reveal that the decision was far from unanimous. Three members of the committee voted in favour of a quarter-point rise, and the account of the meeting suggests that there were others who require only the right ammunition to pull the trigger.

That warning was enough to put a floor under sterling yesterday, but a further sharp depreciation in the value of the pound would probably lead to a shift in the balance of power on the MPC in favour of those seeking more aggressive action to control inflation. The Bank is uncertain about the impact on prices of the falling pound, but says that the recent drop - the sharpest since the aftermath of Black Wednesday in 1992 - might imply a rise in inflation in two years of about half a percentage point.

As such there is still all to play for on the nine-strong committee. The trio who voted for a tightening of policy were Mervyn King, the Bank's deputy governor responsible for monetary policy, John Vickers, the Bank's chief economist, and Steve Nickell, one of the two newly appointed external MPC members attending his first meeting.

In the rival camp were the three other externally appointed members - DeAnne Julius, Sushil Wadhwani, and the other new boy, Christopher Allsopp. They were joined by three Bank insiders, the governor, Eddie George, David Clementi, the deputy governor responsible for financial stability, and Ian Plenderleith, the Bank's markets' supremo.

On the face of it, the 6-3 split should be sufficient to keep rates at their current level, but the minutes note that there was a faction who believed that a further rise in interest rates might eventually be necessary but considered that the risks of waiting were low in relation to moving immediately, particularly the threat of exacerbating the overvaluation in sterling.

Key players

What this means is that the committee is now divided three ways - those convinced that the strength of domestic demand poses a threat to the government's 2.5% inflation target, those who believe that the inflation outlook is benign, and those who want the fog to clear before making up their mind. This last-named group - which on past form contains Mr George, Mr Clementi and Mr Plenderleith - holds the key to interest-rate policy.

George Buckley at Deustche Morgan Grenfell said that rates would probably be kept on hold at 6% at the next meeting in July, but that yesterday's revelations shortened the odds on an increase in August to coincide with the release of the Bank's quarterly inflation report.

But according to Robert Barrie at Credit Suisse First Boston, the minutes were not as hawkish as they have appeared, with the market's adverse reaction probably exaggerated by the recent string of good news pointing to a moderating pace in growth.

With the pound showing signs of stabilising, Mr Barrie said the three members voting for a rate rise in June would have further found the recent drop-off in earnings extremely "reassuring".

Both camps on the MPC will now be looking for evidence to back up their case. Since the last meeting, the no-change group will have been bolstered by benign economic data - a pronounced drop in the rate of earnings growth, accompanied by some high-profile job losses at C&A and steel-maker Corus as well as a cooling-off in the housing market and a relatively modest increase in retail spending. They minutes show them making the case that earnings growth - a crucial concern for those concerned about the medium-term inflation outlook - had so far proved less strong than the Bank had been forecasting in its central projections for the economy.

However, the minutes make clear that some of those opposing a rise were doing so far tactical rather than strategic reasons. "There was no need for a rise in interest rates this month, and for some members no presumption that a further rise would be needed. The depreciation of sterling would help bring about a rebalancing of the economy, and that was welcome even if it meant that at some point higher interest rates were needed."

The group including Mr King, Mr Vickers and Mr Nickell said that the impact of the falling pound on prospective inflation was important and was not offset by the other news.

Recent signs of a slowdown in domestic demand were probably partly erratic, and the labour market was tight. "Given the recent depreciation of sterling, the downward pressure on retail prices from the past appreciation of sterling would cease."

While accepting that there were reasons for a delay, this group saw none of them as sufficiently compelling to postpone a rate rise.

But delay the Bank did. And it may procrastinate again next month. But as the hapless England football team discovered to its cost on Tuesday night, the game's not over until the final whistle. The MPC may not be finished yet.

fields.headline: Brussels to scupper £80bn deal
fields.standfirst:
Doubts over MCI and Sprint link
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Speculation that the European commission will block the £80bn mega-merger between MCI Worldcom and Sprint reached fever pitch yesterday ahead of a meeting of competition law experts in Brussels today, which is expected to reject the deal.
fields.body:
Speculation that the European commission will block the £80bn mega-merger between MCI Worldcom and Sprint reached fever pitch yesterday ahead of a meeting of competition law experts in Brussels today, which is expected to reject the deal.

The EC is known to have serious reservations about the tie-up and is adamant that the merged entity would have a virtual stranglehold on the crucial internet infrastructure market. Would-be competitors would not, it says, have a chance against the merged group.

Mario Monti, the EC's most senior anti-monopoly official, yesterday flew to Washington to discuss the deal and other pressing issues with his American counterparts.

He was due to meet America's top telecoms regulator William Kennard, who heads the federal communications commission, and it is likely the two men will discuss the controversial merger.

The US justice department is expected to decide itself in the next few days whether to approve the deal or not and the EC is likely to be heavily influenced by US thinking on this issue.

The EC has already indicated that it is not happy with the deal as it stands and in February extended an investigation into the matter on the grounds that it had "serious concerns" about the impact the merger would have on internet services and long distance telephone calls.

An EC spokeswoman yesterday confirmed that problems still lingered but declined to speculate on whether they prevent the marriage going ahead. The two firms have already offered to sell Sprint's internet business to appease Brussels but Mr Monti has made no secret of the fact that he wants Worldcom to part with its highly successful UUNet subsidiary.

Industry observers believe, however, that Worldcom would rather dump Sprint at the altar rather than give up UUNet.

Hopes that the deal will be approved by the EC are, according to several US papers, fading fast.

Although the result of today's meeting of experts is not final it is thought that the EC will endorse its opinion when it meets on July 5. The deadline for a final decision is July 12.

It is thought that the career of Bernie Ebbers, the charismatic chairman of MCI Worldcom, hangs in the balance. As someone who has built up a reputation for deal brokering, a failure now would be a serious setback.

The EC does not usually block deals outright though it has enjoyed some success in recent years in squeezing concessions out of merger partners. But there is a feeling in Brussels that Mr Monti is keen to play the tough guy and flex the EC's muscles in the only sphere of policy where it wields immediate and immense power.

If the EC does rule against the merger the two companies could try to appeal against the decision at the European court of justice. That would be slow, however, and wildly unpredictable. The EC warned in February that the merged company would carry 45% of the world's internet traffic which, it argued at the time, was far too much.

fields.headline: Cute but not cutting edge
fields.trailText:
Personals
Apollo Shaftesbury, London **
fields.body:
Personals
Apollo Shaftesbury, London **

It is not Closer. It is not even close. This musical comedy about six New Yorkers looking for love through lonely hearts adverts is slick, sassy, very cute and emotionally bloodless.

Let us not kid ourselves. It is not the score, jaunty though it is, nor the reasonably witty lyrics, nor the appealing young cast who portray the gaggle of lonely, professional, affluent New Yorkers on the lookout for love, that have smoothed the passage of this show into the West End. It is the fact that this is an instantly recognisable piece of juvenilia by the team that went on to create and write the TV hit Friends.

But the kind of ironic, neurotic comedy that works in half-hour slots within the relatively trivial medium of TV quickly seems irritating within the more focused and demanding environment of the theatre, even more so when the revue-style format doesn't allow for real development of plot or character.

Sure, you laugh at Louis, the lonely virgin who has a more meaningful relationship with his 78-lesson teach-yourself-dating tape than with any real woman, and at the Typesetter who advertises for a dwarf for his wife as a joke and finds himself living happily in a small ménage à trois, but you are laughing at the gag, not the character. In the same way you don't really care whether cute but bland Sam gets it together with cute but bland Claire, the girl next door, or whether their fear of failure will paralyse them.

Those with infinite patience for the self-absorbed and self-deprecating Bridget Jones style of ditsy humour will probably enjoy themselves heartily. Otherwise, although this show is too good-natured to really hate, you'd be better off getting yourself a life rather than a ticket.

Until August 26. Box office: 020-7494 5070.

fields.headline: Ironic over erotic
fields.trailText:
Secret Garden
Angel Row Gallery, Nottingham ***
fields.body:
Secret Garden
Angel Row Gallery, Nottingham ***

We all need our own secret garden, a haven from the rat race, a private, pretend space where we can indulge in the illusion of harmony with nature, where world weariness can be eased by contact with small-scale demonstrations of nature's mysterious tendency to regenerate. For many of us, wrapped in bedspreads and scented with pot-pourri or, indeed, with pot, it's a dream place.

The artists in Secret Garden cultivate and comment on this virtual allotment of nature-made-safe. Disappointingly, much of the work rather obviously points out the artifice and willing self-deceptions of the pastime. In his photographic series Flora Industrialis, Vik Muniz presents faded black-and-white close-ups of silk roses. Louise Hopkins's canvases are a fake rococo mass of florid wall- paper. Sian Bonnell photographs domestic objects, a butterfly pastry cutter and a rabbit-shaped jelly, displaced in the Dorset countryside. The metaphors are self-conscious, easily interpretable and, of course, ironic. Rob Kesseler's plastic roses are presented in a vase labelled Weed. Elsewhere, thankfully, Kesseler gets somewhat more cryptic with a hybrid sculptural concoction in which flowers piercing a dinner plate and sprouting from a rock are set next to an untitled book on top of a lemon radiator.

Such artists go on about nature as a cultural construct. There's a distrust of the seductive complexities and ambivalences of direct experience (if it's still possible to conceive of such a thing). I get the distinct feeling they are afraid to get their concepts mucky. Furthermore, their secret garden appears to be a thoroughly English, present-day, TV-mediated affair. There's no sign of the Romantic sublime of follies, lunatic ruins and the landscaped wilderness. There's none of the erotic frisson associated with the secret gardens of other cultures (there's a highly popular Japanese comic titled The Garden Party of No-Panty Angels that might have livened the show up considerably).

It's left to just two artists to hint at something lurking behind the decorative borders. Avis Newman's Bird Box, La Sotola Dell'Uccello is a black frame fitted with a lump of old driftwood. It's a dark little area of ultimate uncertainty. Something lives in the gaps between its element and we don't, and can't, know what it is. By contrast, Andy Harper's close-up paintings of thousands of green-as-green-can-be blades of grass are obsessively super-defined. This is certainly a dream of a lawn, with no signs of weeds, fungi, moss or creepy crawlies. So why do I feel that some awfully frustrated thing is just about to burst through the all-too-ordered surface?

Until July 29. Details: 0115- 915 2828.

fields.headline: Blueberry deal for Laura Ashley
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Laura Ashley, the clothing and home furnishing retailer that narrowly staved off bankruptcy two years ago, will enter the world of e-tailing with the launch of a transaction-based website in October.
fields.body:
Laura Ashley, the clothing and home furnishing retailer that narrowly staved off bankruptcy two years ago, will enter the world of e-tailing with the launch of a transaction-based website in October.

It will replace the company's brochure site as part of a five-year deal with Blueberry.com, a London-based, site-building and marketing agency. The agreement gives Blueberry.com an undisclosed share of profit from the enterprise in exchange for waiving set-up costs.

Laura Ashley has seen a turnaround in fortunes in recent months following restructuring with like for like sales growth up 7% for the nine weeks until the end of April. This followed strong Christmas trading and a subsequent increase in share value in January from a record low of 18.75p to 22p.

Shares closed yesterday at 17.25p, up 0.25p.
Useful links
Blueberry.com
Laura Ashley

fields.headline: Barron's dot.com peerage
fields.standfirst:
Losers chosen by how fast they use up their investors' cash

E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Second-guessing which of the dot.com start-ups will survive is exercising the sharpest brains on both sides of the Atlantic. Picking the survivors is the task Barron's, the influential business magazine, has set itself. This week saw its second stab at predicting the winners and losers.
fields.body:
Second-guessing which of the dot.com start-ups will survive is exercising the sharpest brains on both sides of the Atlantic. Picking the survivors is the task Barron's, the influential business magazine, has set itself. This week saw its second stab at predicting the winners and losers.

In contrast to its first analysis three months ago, the paper this time won the tacit support of Henry Blodget, star internet strategist at Merrill Lynch. When Barron's published its first report in March - which caused controversy among some of the companies on the list - high profile start-ups such as Peapod were hit hard.

The magazine knocked billions off Cisco last month when it aired concerns about its accounting practices. The methodology does court controversy, and like last time, some companies on this week's list have already issued clarifying statements. Mr Blodget yesterday said: "It's a good back-of-the-envelope measure."

Barron's picked its losers by calculating how quickly dotcom companies are burning through their precious cash. More than 60 of the 227 dot.coms in its league table could run out money in the coming 12 months, an uncomfortable position since venture captalists have become wary of fresh investments after watching the stock market values of dot.coms plummet to $693bn from $1.4 trillion.

The fall has meant fewer flotations. Only 39, worth $4.2bn, have been made by internet companies since the peak of the Nasdaq hi-tech stock market in March. Investors are already jumpy - Barron's work will panic them. Top of the 227-strong burn list, compiled with research company Pegasus, are GenesisIntermedia.com, Convergent Com, Netzee, Peapod and Bluefly, a discount clothing company which Barron's warns could run of cash in less than a month.

Better-known groups, such as Amazon, the online book seller, are also on the list. Barron's calculated that Amazon, will run of cash in 35 months time. Ask Jeeves, the search engine, is given 23 months. The conclusions are reached by scrutinising the "burn rate" of cash for each company during the first quarter of the year.

The paper tried to take account of action taken by the companies to bolster their financial positions since their last set of reported figures.

Barron's particularly highlights 12 dot.coms which are likely to be making announcements in the coming months about their position.

One company, on line advertising and media network 24/7, ranked 33rd, was forced into making its announcement just hours after the article appeared, pledging that it had "sufficient liquidity to carry the company to a break-even on a cash basis" by the first half of 2002. By Barron's calculations, it will run out of cash in a little over six months.

It is not all doom and gloom, however. Barron's calculates that e-companies are burning up their cash slightly less quickly than they were in the previous three months of the survey - the last quarter of 1999 - claiming they ate up $1.15bn in the first three months of year, a fall of 24%.

There are 20 more companies included in the survey this time as more companies are making disclosures about their positions. Revenue - said by analysts to be the key to success for any dot.com company - is starting to rise, with the net companies taking in a combined $12.5bn in the first quarter, from $10.3bn.

This is said to give dot.com companies a combined life span of 13 years, a dramatic improvement on the eight years calculated during the last survey. Barron's found nine companies that actually reported positive cash flows - rather than a cash drain - during the three months.

Near burnout

Months to immolation:

Netzee* -0.6
Bluefly 0.1
Rowecom 0.6
CDNow 1.0
Drkoop.com 1.5
Claimsnet.com 2.4
Pilot Network 3.2
US search.com 3.3
Streamline.com 3.5
Netivation.com 3.8
Mortgage.com 4.5

* Received credit line from a shareholder
Useful links
Barrons
Amazon
Ask Jeeves

fields.headline: Life with my abusive boss
fields.trailText: 22 June: My boss is beginning to be a real problem. Not just for me either. If she were someone on the street I would have smacked her in the mouth by now.
fields.body:
The problem

My boss is beginning to be a real problem. Not just for me either. She is constantly looking for things we have done or got wrong. She is also quite personal in her remarks, once even mocking one of my colleagues sexuality.

If she were someone on the street I would have smacked her in the mouth by now. She also refuses us holiday at peak time and then gloats about it. She refused to allow a colleague to go to the lavatory yesterday claiming there was no-one to cover him. We are thinking of seeing the head of human resources - is this the right thing to do?

Janine

The solution

This is not on. Your boss is seriously out of order and you should be able to prepare a strong case against her. Before you go to her line manager with your complaints I suggest you team up with as many colleagues who feel aggrieved as possible. All of you should start keeping diaries in which you log every bullying, or offensive comment or action from this woman. In particular, note every time she:


 Makes comments that have no relevance to your work


 Makes personal remarks


 Makes sexist remarks or those pertaining to sexual orientation


 Any time she refuses to allow you to go to the loo

Make notes of any witnesses to her behaviour and when the file is reasonably fat, off you go to make your complaint. If you get no satisfaction after this, consider putting a formal grievance procedure in place against her. Your company should have a written policy on how to go about this.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Testament to Tavener
fields.trailText:
Total Eclipse
St Paul's Cathedral, London ***
fields.body:
Total Eclipse
St Paul's Cathedral, London ***

The language of spirituality, struggling as it does to find words for the inexpressible, sometimes approaches the language of sexuality. John Tavener's Total Eclipse - given its world premiere on the opening night of the City of London festival - curiously shares its title with Christopher Hampton's haunting study of the creative power of homoerotic love. Both works, essentially about inspiration, also share blinding as an image: Hampton's characters are metaphorically blinded by desire; for Tavener, the light of Christ robs the body of physical sight in order to illuminate the soul.

Writing for performance in St Paul's Cathedral, Tavener takes that saint's conversion on the road to Damascus as an archetypal model of mystical experience. This is music that aspires to convey a sudden flash of insight that resonates through eternity. Tavener, himself a convert to the Eastern Orthodox Church, ranges fearlessly over time, space and tradition. The scoring embraces antiquity and modernity: the main orchestra is a period band (the Academy of Ancient Music, conducted by Paul Goodwin) augmented by modern percussion and ancient Tibetan instruments. Saul/Paul is dually represented by a counter-tenor (Christopher Robinson) and a soprano saxophone (John Harle), the pair of them weaving their way round the building in the enactment of their spiritual journey. The Choir of New College Oxford, in full regalia, anchor the work in ritual. Massive batteries of timpani are placed in each transept.

Tavener exploits to the limit the cathedral's vast 10-second reverberation, and begins by bombarding us with a barrage of sound from all sides in an awesome depiction of the Crucifixion, against which Harle's sax can be heard screaming flutter-tongued imprecations. The tumult is gradually stilled as the voice of Christ (tenor James Gilchrist) drifts down from the dome. Harle's raving is gradually replaced by arpeggiated lyricism. Robson, hitherto silent, finds both voice and words as Paul's conversion is effected.

From this point on Tavener proceeds with the measured solemnity of Orthodox ritual, often impressively, though it strikes me that he comes unstuck in the section that forms the theological crux of the work. This depicts, as Tavener puts it, "the teaching moving through Christ into the mouth of Paul". What actually happens is a lengthy canon for Gilchrist, Robson and Harle, its entries shortening with each repetition as Christ effectively dictates to Paul part of Chapter 13 of the First Letter to the Corinthians. Musically the piece dips here and doesn't regain its momentum by the time it reaches its serene close. Even so, I suspect Tavener has another hit on his hands. The standing ovation that followed was testament to both the work's impact on the audience and his cult status.

webTitle: Selectors turn back to the old guard

fields.headline: Selectors turn back to the old guard
fields.trailText: The selectors have abandoned their policy of developing players for the next World Cup in favour of trying to create a winning environment to carry on through the rest of the summer, says Mike Selvey.
fields.body:
In recalling Alec Stewart, Graham Thorpe and Robert Croft to the England one-day scene the selectors have abandoned their policy of developing players for the next World Cup in favour of trying to create a winning environment to carry on through the rest of the summer.

None of the three has played a limited-overs international since the World Cup in England last year. Andy Flintoff, who missed the one-day series in South Africa and Zimbabwe last winter because of a broken bone in his foot, has also been recalled and the Nottinghamshire all-rounder Paul Franks is the only uncapped player in the squad announced at Lord's yesterday.

Franks, seen by the captain Nasser Hussain as "a competitive character and desperate to do well", has come through the England system having been on two A tours. The temptation to use Mike Atherton to blunt the extravagant movement of the white ball was resisted.

Only four players are under 30: Flintoff, Franks (who is 21), Vikram Solanki and Darren Gough, just. All 14 players will be given central contracts, effective not from yesterday's announcement - which was timed to sit alongside the launch of NatWest's £5m three-year deal to sponsor the triangular series - but from when the squad gather three days before their opening match against Zimbabwe on July 8.

The only difference then between this and the old system is that, rather than being paid match fees, each player will receive a salary based on whichever of the three bands they are graded under.

In order to avoid the situation that occurred with Dean Headley, whereby the fast bowler sustained a serious back injury shortly after being awarded a test contract, both Craig White, who suffered an unexplained black-out four weeks ago, and Alan Mullally, whose long-term rib injury has only just cleared up, will be monitored closely and tested stringently.

Stewart's return will be trumpeted by some as a huge about-turn by the selectors, who opted for Chris Read last winter. Certainly David Graveney and his fellow selectors would have shirked their duty had they not been trying to give England players the sort of experience in this form of international cricket gained by most of their opponents.

However, as Stewart's fragile hands needed specialist attention after a strenuous test tour, his omission last winter was on humane grounds as much as anything. Graveney believes the break was nothing but beneficial to the player. Now Stewart can expect to break Graham Gooch's record of 125 appearances (paltry actually, given that 70 players worldwide have exceeded it ) in their opening game at the Oval. He equalled it in England's final game in the World Cup.

Although he has never scored a century in 53 matches, Thorpe creditably averages more than 40. His reinstatement, after opting out of the test series last winter, provides nous to the engine room of the innings where the requirements are either consolidation or acceleration - à la Michael Bevan - depending on the circumstances.

Graveney sees Thorpe as Neil Fairbrother's natural successor in terms of his capacity to read situations and pace an innings accordingly.

With Graeme Hick in the side to fill in with his off-spin, it was felt that only one spinner would be needed. Although Ashley Giles might have got the chance, it was Croft who was chosen, not least because of the way he bowled his off-spin to the left-handed Bevan in Australia two winters ago.

webTitle: Reynard rockets women into unfamiliar territory

fields.headline: Reynard rockets women into unfamiliar territory
fields.standfirst:
England 159
South Africa 139-9
England win by 20 runs
fields.trailText:
England 159
South Africa 139-9
England win by 20 runs
fields.body:
Karen Smithies watched from beyond the boundary yesterday as England's women recorded their first one-day international win since last year.

The presence of the former captain, who resigned after England's 220-run defeat by Australia in February, was a reminder to the coach Paul Farbrace that she is still around. Smithies has been promised a return if she recaptures her form - possibly before the end of this five-match series - but on yesterday's evidence against South Africa she may not be required.

With the World Cup approaching in November, England began to find the talents that dramatically deserted them on their tour of Australia and New Zealand.

It was their batting that let them down then, so yesterday's decision by the captain Clare Connor to bat was particularly courageous. It looked like backfiring, however, when England were all out for 159.

The veteran Barbara Daniels, never at her best during the winter, compiled 49 from 89 balls before the Yorkshire dynamo Melissa Reynard bolstered the total with a rapid 46 from 54 deliveries.

But it was in the field that England's improvement shone through. They started the upward curve in New Zealand and here it went off the graph, as three run-outs and a brilliant stumping by Jane Cassar condemned South Africa to a frustrating afternoon.

fields.headline: Franks given chance to come of age
fields.standfirst: The 21-year-old bowler is fit and ready, writes  Paul Weaver
fields.trailText: The 21-year-old bowler Paul Franks is fit and ready, writes Paul Weaver.
fields.body:
It is perhaps apt that for someone with a degree in tourism Paul Franks made the most of his A trip to Bangla-desh and New Zealand in the winter and is the one new face in England's one-day squad for the NatWest series starting on July 6.

Many cricketers considered Franks unlucky not to have made the senior squad for the tour of South Africa and Zimbabwe, so the selectors have atoned for their sin of omission.

Franks is a strong, natural cricketer. An all-rounder, he is a resourceful fielder and an able late-order batsman. But it is his bowling that has propelled him to precocious achievement. He generates good pace and moves the ball both ways off the seam. There can be a little swing, too, if the conditions are favourable.

He has been selected, apart from his ability, for his character, determination and considerable promise. He also has a good fitness record. Because he has been around some years it is easy to forget that he is only 21.

Martyn Moxon, the manager of last winter's A tour, said yesterday: "He's an old-fashioned deck-hitting bowler and a real 100 per center. He's very talented, very committed and I'm delighted for him. He did very well in the winter and has had a decent summer, so he deserves his chance.

"Even on the stodgy pitches in Bangladesh he really ran in. And his second and third spells were no slower than his first. He turned round one one-day international when New Zealand were cruising it.

"It's difficult to criticise someone for being too exuberant but sometimes he does get carried away. Because he has this great desire to be successful he can be too eager and excited at times and, when that happens, he can lose control. But it's not a bad fault to have at this stage in his career."

Gus Fraser agrees. "He is an exciting, competitive young cricketer. He may need pulling up every now and then - he can be a bit over the top - but there is an energy to his cricket that I like. He is a Dominic Cork-type player with a bit of pace and movement."

Fraser, along with Durham's coach Norman Gifford and Kent's coach John Wright, selected Franks in a Wisden Cricket Monthly pre-season survey to discover the outstanding young player in the land.

Franks was only 17 when he first played for Nottinghamshire in 1996 and the following season he became the third youngest player to take a hat-trick. He was selected to play for England in the ulti mately cancelled World Super Max 8s in Perth in 1998. He made his first England Under-19 tour, to Pakistan, in 1996-97 and his first A tour, to South Africa and Zimbabwe, in 1998-99. He was awarded his county cap last season, when he took 63 wickets at 23.63.

Yesterday, fielding calls on his mobile while a Nottinghamshire team-mate drove him to London for today's NatWest Trophy fixture against Middlesex at Lord's, he said: "I had a call from David Graveney last night, telling me not to be too surprised if I found myself in the squad. It's a great feeling. I had a reasonable A tour but I think I attracted the selectors this season when I took seven wickets in a championship match at Lord's and six in a National League game against Durham. I know that Geoff Miller and David Graveney have watched me play.

"I was lucky to have Paul Johnson as my first captain at Notts. He told me just to go out and enjoy myself. I bowled as fast as I possibly could in those days.

"Since then I have done a lot of work with Dennis Lillee in Madras and more recently Clive Rice has helped polish up a few things. I've also been trying to watch Glenn McGrath, who for me is everything a bowler should be."

If Franks is everything the selectors want him to be, he will be a front-line, one-day fast bowler this summer and also someone capable of stiffening a tail that looked long and limp in the winter.

webTitle: England favourites? And Hick's the new Bradman

fields.headline: England favourites? And Hick's the new Bradman
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel The most extraordinary fact about last week's Edgbaston test is that England started the match as favourites with every bookmaker. Now we seem to be hallucinating.
fields.body:
The most extraordinary fact about last week's Edgbaston test is that England started the match as favourites with every bookmaker. Indeed, until the game started they were favourites to win the entire series, a position they had held unchallenged for several months. West Indies, despite their 30-year record of success against England, could be backed at 9-4.

In the current atmosphere of general Cronjery, this would normally mean something very odd. If you go to a racecourse and see a hot tip drifting in the betting market, you look carefully to see whether it is limping. These days in international cricket - once the most transparent of sports - it has become necessary to assume the worst.

But on this occasion nobody got nobbled: the form worked out to the nth degree. On Saturday afternoon anyone walking in from doing something more rewarding and being told the score was 20 for three could have guessed at once that Mike Atherton was still batting and that Graeme Hick must be out for nought.

I did not have a bet against England. It might have been smart but it is just too cruel. The fun has gone out of cricket betting, anyway. Even discussing the subject feels somehow like complicity with the flannelled criminals and flannelling administrators who ignored every warning sign about the game's corruption.

That, however, is the game's other crisis. And the odds do somehow seem like a symbol of the latest phase of the English crisis. We have gone beyond the disappointment, cynicism and utter despair that was evident last summer after the defeat by New Zealand. Now we seem to be hallucinating.

The chairman of selectors David Graveney says he is refusing to panic. If I were in his shoes I would panic like mad, possibly contemplating more rewarding employment - marketing manager of the Dome, perhaps. If he means that he is not planning to kick out most of this lot and replace them with another lot, that is fair enough (though if Hick ever plays a match-winning innings against West Indies, I will build a shrine to St Jude in my front garden). It is right not to focus too much on selection, because whom England pick is essentially irrelevant to the outcome of the series.

If Ambrose and Walsh maintain their authority in the remaining tests, and if Lara continues fit and focused - at the crease rather than on the analyst's sofa - then West Indies will win. There are no English cricketers of their calibre. Should any of these pillars start wobbling, then England have a chance of fighting back.

But to recapture public respect, that is no longer enough. They drew the last two home series against West Indies in 1991 and 1995. English cricket now needs the catharsis that can come only with winning the series. The odds against that are - amazingly enough - still around 7-2. Rush, if you insist.

At moments like these, officials at Lord's usually start issuing statements purporting to show that the entire under-18 population of England and Wales is now playing cricket 24 hours a day. Yet the anecdotal evidence seems more forceful and relevant.

I have just had a letter from a Redditch reader who works at a big West Midlands factory: "A few years ago, whenever a test match was being played, people would tune in to radios right across the factory and, if they knew you were a regular cricket follower, engage you in some conversation about the game. Now there is no sense that most people even know a test match is being played, let alone care."

Well, how would anyone know? Just as cricket-lovers might have been getting the hang of this test series, they have suddenly announced a squad for a one-day tournament. This is the year of first division cricket, which is supposed to create an elite. So the new name ("on form," says Graveney) is Paul Franks, who plays only second division cricket. And between now and the Lord's test, which apparently is happening next Thursday, there are no County Championship matches at all.

How can anyone be a regular cricket follower? All we get are irregularities - one way or another.

fields.headline: How Keegan's men rated
fields.trailText: Nigel Martyn 5
fields.body:
Nigel Martyn 5

Made a great save in the opening minute but has to take some blame for two Romanian goals. Out of position for the first and got in a mix-up with Keown for the second.

Gary Neville 6

Again demonstrated the understanding he has with David Beckham. Generally sound, though caught out by a ball that almost led to a goal for Chivu.

Martin Keown 6

Did not look as solid as against the Germans. Lack of understanding with Martyn put Romania in for their second goal.

Sol Campbell 7

Gave team-mates palpitations at times with his attempts to over elaborate when a swift clearance would have been a better option. But most times managed to get himself out of trouble.

Phil Neville 6

Started well but still looks vulnerable to opponents who run at him. His poor distribution allowed the Romanians to put pressure on England.

David Beckham 6

For once, the radar was not working on his crossing. Subdued for much of game.

Paul Ince 5

Got forward well for the penalty and began the move for the second goal. But lost possession far too often and was lucky that Romania did not profit from a suicidal back pass.

Paul Scholes 7

Tidy and solid as ever, completed more passes than any other England player. But, restricted to holding up the centre of midfield, never got into his usual dangerous positions.

Denis Wise 5

Lacks his club confidence at this level. Continually gave away possession and was too easily knocked off the ball in the first half. Improved a little in the second before being substituted.

Alan Shearer 6

Played too deeply but produced an absolute killer ball which led to the penalty. Then buried it with his usual panache. Stupidly booked for diving.

Michael Owen 6

Once again struggled to hang on to the ball but took his goal superbly. Looked livelier after that but again substituted.

Emile Heskey 6

Struggled to get into the game with England so on the defensive in the second half. Looked better when Barmby came on to provide balls on the deck rather than high balls from the back.

Nick Barmby 7

Looked sharper and more attacking than Wise as soon as he came on. Confident and accurate in his passing, he must be close to a starting position.

Gareth Southgate 6

Played only the last 10 minutes as Keegan tried to shut up shop.

fields.headline: Odds fellow
fields.standfirst: French to cash in on dress rehearsal for final
fields.trailText: At the start of the competition Coral were offering a top priced 12-1 on France and Holland meeting in the final on July 2. Betting has been suspended until after the group stages but tonight's Group D encounter in Amsterdam gives punters what could be an intriguing foretaste of that climactic showdown.
fields.body:
At the start of the competition Coral were offering a top priced 12-1 on France and Holland meeting in the final on July 2. Betting has been suspended until after the group stages but tonight's Group D encounter in Amsterdam gives punters what could be an intriguing foretaste of that climactic showdown.

The French are a best priced 15-8 with Surrey to win this evening. Holland are no bigger than 7-4 with Sunderlands while Coral are quoting 11-5 the draw.

The other Group D game between Denmark and the Czech Republic in Liège is of strictly academic interest with both teams already eliminated. Bets should be kept to a minimum but the Czechs should gain a consolation win at 10-11 with Stanley. The Danes can be backed at 7-2 with Heathorns and the same firm are quoting 5-2 about a draw.

It's a brave punter who would confidently predict the final outcome of Group C. Spain face a must-win situation against Yugoslavia in Bruges this afternoon. A Spanish victory is forecast but more in hope than confidence at even money with Chandler. The Yugoslavs are a top-priced 100-30 with Surrey and Stanley are betting 12-5 a draw. Norway ought to beat Slovenia in Arnhem at 8-11 with Stanley. A draw is available at 11-4 with Hills and a Slovenian victory at 4-1 with Surrey.

Today's games look hazard-ous from the point of view of buying and selling supremacy and total goals. Spread backers are advised to look instead at England's cricketers and sell Graeme Hick's total runs against the West Indies at 205 with Sporting.

fields.headline: Schmeichel vows to play on
fields.trailText: Denmark and the Czech Republic meet in Liège tonight, both eliminated clubs searching for their first points of Euro 2000. But Peter Schmeichel, Denmark's veteran goalkeeper, says the Group D game, his 123rd cap, will not be his swansong.
fields.body:
Denmark and the Czech Republic meet in Liège tonight, both eliminated clubs searching for their first points of Euro 2000. But Peter Schmeichel, Denmark's veteran goalkeeper, says the Group D game, his 123rd cap, will not be his swansong.

"I just want to carry on for as long as I can and for as long as I enjoy it," said the 36-year-old former Manchester United player, adding that his next goal was the 2002 World Cup.

Liverpool's midfielder Patrik Berger is set to play his first and last game of the tournament after a suspension that kept him out of their opening two matches.

The Czech coach Josef Chovanec said: "One certain change will be Patrik Berger's position in the starting line-up."

Czech Republic (probable, 3-5-2): Srnicek; Fukal, Rada, Gabriel; Poborsky, Bejbl, Nemec, Nedved, Berger; Koller Smicer.

Denmark (probable, 4-4-2): Schmeichel; Helveg, Schjonberg, Henriksen, Heintze; Jorgensen, A Nielsen, Gravesen, Gronkjaer; Tomasson, Sand.

fields.headline: French eschew Dutch deja vu
fields.standfirst:
Today's match between France and Holland may be a foretaste of the final, says Jon Brodkin
Teams that met again
fields.trailText: Today's match between France and Holland may be a foretaste of the final, says Jon Brodkin
fields.body:
The venue will be 40 miles down the road, the kick-off three-quarters of an hour earlier. But otherwise the bookmakers and millions of others see little difference between the action at the Amsterdam Arena tonight and what awaits on July 2 in Rotterdam.

For France v Holland to decide group D, read a likely final in 11 days' time. Which is one reason why a game between two guaranteed quarter-finalists is more than a kickabout to establish which team will do their sightseeing in Bruges and which in Amsterdam before the next round.

"It's important to win for psychological reasons because it is possible we will meet them again," said France's Youri Djorkaeff. That the dress rehearsal will be missing several rested members of the French cast - only two of the first team, Fabien Barthez and Marcel Desailly, seem likely to start - is seen by some as a reflection of its significance. "Maybe they don't want us to see all their qualities," suggested the Holland defender Bert Konterman.

Whatever the reasons for France not showing their hand, they arguably hold the psychological aces in the event of a second encounter. Win this evening and they will leave Holland wondering what on earth awaits once the stars abandon their deckchairs. Lose and Roger Lemerre's team can dismiss the defeat almost out of hand.

Victory tonight is important for Frank Rijkaard, the Dutch coach. Only then can his team stay on home soil, and he knows an expectant public will settle for nothing less. He is also a firm believer that success breads success.

The 37-year-old knows from personal experience, though, that failure need not prompt him to dive into an Amsterdam canal with weights around his ankles if the teams meet again in the final. The Holland side he was part of at Euro 88 lost to the Soviet Union in a group game and beat them less than a fortnight later to lift the trophy.

A 2-0 win in the final followed a 1-0 defeat in the opening match. "It was a big blow for us," Rijkaard recalled of the first match yesterday. "But we were very confident because we knew we had played a good game, better than them." And the early tie ultimately served an important purpose. The then Dutch coach Rinus Michels changed Marco van Basten's orders for the final and he scored the second goal.

Rijkaard acknowledged that it would be difficult to learn much from this game given the weakened state of his opponents. Only Lemerre will benefit in that regard, just as West Germany did in the World Cup 46 years ago on another occasion when teams who met in the early stages of a major international tournament met again at the end.

The Germans, already qualified for the next round, put out a shadow side against a much-feared Hungary, whose recent results included a 12-0 win over Albania and an 8-0 hammering of Finland. The idea was to watch and learn. And after losing that game 8-3 the Germans went on, with only six of the same players, to win the final 3-2.

In fact, if there is a loser tonight they might be glad to hear that only once have a victorious team gone on to beat the same opponents in the final. That was in Euro 96, when Germany defeated the Czech Republic 2-0 in a group game but needed Oliver Bierhoff's golden goal to win at Wembley. The fourth instance of such a second meeting saw Brazil held 0-0 by Czechoslovakia in the 1962 World Cup and progress to beat them 3-1 in the final.

Ultimately, then, it would be daft to read much into tonight's result if the teams are reunited in Rotterdam. It is peaking at the right time that counts. Bayern Munich's two resounding defeats of Real Madrid in the group stage of last season's Champions League counted for little when the sides met again in the semi-final, Real winning and going on to defeat Valencia in the final.

And it has escaped no one's attention that a defeat for France would suit both sides. Just as the Dutch would get to stay in Hoenderloo rather than having to move to Belgium, Lemerre's squad would be able to remain at their base in Genval, deep in Francophone Belgium, and play their next game in Bruges, where they have already won twice. If they win or draw, Amsterdam beckons.

The French irregulars are hardly pushovers, though, as they proved by beating Denmark 2-1 during a similar exercise in the third match of the last World Cup. Frank Leboeuf is among those expected to play as those with minor knocks and one yellow card step down. "We must be very careful," Lemerre said. "We will have to play a match every three days."

Holland will be without the suspended Giovanni van Bronckhorst and the injured goalkeeper Edwin van der Sar, giving Liverpool's Sander Westerveld a start. And although Michael Reiziger may step down to avoid the danger of a second yellow card, the signs are that Frank de Boer, who also has one booking, will feature as they try to end a run of 19 years without a victory over France. Rijkaard is counting on a good performance to maintain the momentum belatedly established in the last 35 minutes against Denmark.

But otherwise the bookmakers and millions of others see little difference between the action at the Amsterdam Arena tonight and what awaits on July 2 in Rotterdam. For France v Holland to decide group D, read a likely final in 11 days' time. Which is one reason why a game between two guaranteed quarter-finalists is more than a kickabout to establish which team will do their sightseeing in Bruges and which in Amsterdam before the next round. Win this evening and they will leave Holland wondering what on earth awaits once the stars abandon their deckchairs. Lose and Roger Lemerre's team can dismiss the defeat almost out of hand. He is also a firm believer that success breads success. fields.headline: Norway pass up premier position
fields.standfirst: Britain's other team have been a big disappointment, says  Roy Collins
fields.trailText: Britain's other team have been a big disappointment, says Roy Collins
fields.body:
The doom and gloom merchants continue to bang on about how all the foreign players in the Premiership are denying our brilliant young kids a future. But for English fans at Euro 2000 genuinely interested in the outbreaks of football between the boozing and rioting, the familiar foreigners have offered an alternative outlet for their support.

Arsenal fans, for instance, could, for a day at least, have replaced their flag of St George with a French tricolour and run through their repertoire for Thierry Henry, Patrick Vieira and Emmanuel Petit, with the bonus of being able to sing insults at their old boy Nicolas Anelka. Sheffield Wednesday fans watched Gilles de Bilde crash to two successive defeats in Belgian colours as his team went out of the tournament. No change for them there.

But were English fans able to shed their domestic tribalism, the obvious alternative team to support would be Norway, who have eight Premiership players in their squad, as well as Trond Andersen of Wimbledon and Celtic's Vidar Riseth. They are, if you like, the UK's second team at Euro 2000.

With Norway portrayed as the Wimbledon of the tournament, it really would make perfect sense. The ugliest fans at Euro 2000 supporting the ugliest team, though it is difficult to understand why a Wimbledon fan would want to travel across Europe to witness the same garbage he can see for less at home.

If France and Portugal offer a version of Pele's beautiful game, Norway are seen as the ugly sister. They could, critics believe, become the latest Scandinavian side to sour a major championship, after the sterile football that took Sweden to the World Cup semi-finals in 1994.

And who are these critics? Well, Tore Andre Flo, the Norwegian striker, for one. Although one might expect him to profit from, and ap prove of, the tactic of aiming lots of high balls at his head, he says: "Playing for Norway is another game altogether. I prefer the way we play at Chelsea, though our national style works well for us."

Despite defeat by Yugoslavia in their last game, Norway will reach the quarter-finals of this, their first European Championship, if they overcome Slovenia in Arnhem today. And Flo expects a change in fortunes, if not style, saying: "I still feel I have a lot more to show but so far it's been more fighting than football."

Norway's coach Nils Johan Semb complained that Yugoslavia were guilty of "sabotage" in their meeting on Sunday, wasting time and continually diving. But perhaps fearing an FA-style charge of bringing the game into disrepute from Uefa, he has since accepted that the Slavs deserved to win. Certainly no one could dispute that they played the better football. Some would say the only football.

Norway, though, produced the shock of France 98 by beating Brazil in a group match and announced their presence here by winning their opening game against Spain, many people's fancy for the tournament.

A draw might be enough to take Norway through to the last eight from what should be known as the group of life, because any two of the four teams can still go through. Semb's biggest worry is how many players will be fit for the knockout stages.

The Liverpool defender Vegard Heggem has already returned home after suffering a recurrence of a hamstring injury which will keep him out for at least six weeks. And Manchester United's Henning Berg will be lucky if his hamstring strain recovers for the quarter-final.

Norway's physical style also took its toll against the Yugoslavs. Steffen Iversen broke his nose in a collision with the goalkeeper Ivica Kralj and the centre-half Otto Bragstad had four stitches inserted in a cut above his left eye. Both hope the doctor will allow them to play tonight and Erik Mykland expects to have recovered from a heel injury.

Slovenia do not appear to have a worry in the world, their coach Srecko Katanec announcing that he feels tempted to resign because his team have reached such dizzy heights, which could be the ultimate piece of kidology or perhaps another example of some of the desperate translation at this tournament. His team have a single point and that from a match in which they led Yugoslavia 3-0. God knows how they quantify failure in Slovenia but you could not see Katanec lasting long with Doug Ellis.

Norway, unusually, find themselves in the role of hot favourites. The rest of the teams here might loudly cheer their exit but defeat tonight would bring humiliation for their players and put huge holes in the theory that the Premiership is the best league in the world. But then it is mainly England's fans who say that.

webTitle: Fear of another flop haunting Spain

fields.headline: Fear of another flop haunting Spain
fields.trailText: Spain may have been many people's dark horses for Euro 2000 but so far their sorties have been more in keeping with the pantomime variety. Tonight, if they are eliminated by Yugoslavia, it will be adios amigos again.
fields.body:
Spain may have been many people's dark horses for Euro 2000 but so far their sorties have been more in keeping with the pantomime variety. Tonight, if they are eliminated by Yugoslavia, it will be adios amigos again.

A thoroughly uninspiring 1-0 defeat by Norway, followed by a sketchy 2-1 win against Slovenia, have left the Spaniards suffering from a collective foreboding before tonight's double bill.

While Norway face Slovenia in Arnhem, Spain take on Yugoslavia here. Any two from four can reach the final eight and, Spain being Spain, the feeling of deja vu is never far away.

The Spanish, after all, have always been susceptible to stage fright in major tournaments. La Liga may be top of the pile when it comes to the Champions League but, time and time again, the national team have flattered to deceive.

Yesterday their coach Jose Camacho did his best to calm his increasingly tense players. But as Raul waited to board the team bus the Real Madrid striker was gnawing at his fingernails.

After seducing their critics during qualifying, the constant reminders of yesteryear's failures seem to have weighed heavily on Spain now that the competition has started in earnest. That Camacho nominated Denmark and the Czech Republic, two sides now vying for the wooden spoon, as his pre-tournament favourites hardly bodes well either.

"I would remind everyone that we are not a nation with a fine record in Europe," he said. "But for us to go out, yes, that would be unthinkable for the people of Spain."

Why Spain struggle to take their club form on to the international stage is the $64,000 question, and one that Camacho struggles to answer.

"You people," he tells the chain-smoking Spanish pressmen, "are consumed with pessimism. I am an optimist and I believe in Spanish players. They haven't done it up to now but there will be a time when that changes."

For Raul, that time is now. "That win against Slovenia was vital for us, regardless of how it came about," he says. "We can play better, be sure of that, but at the moment the result is everything. We must beat Yugoslavia, we must."

At least Spain will, by and large, know what they are up against. Seven of the Yugoslav squad are based in La Liga and their coach Vujadin Boskov was Camacho's manager during his formative days at Real.

"We are facing the toughest team in the group, even if they have not shown it yet," says the Yugoslavia captain Dragan Stojkovic. But for now at least his country are calling the shots. They lead the group with four points, Norway and Spain have three apiece and Slovenia one.

"Technically, the Spaniards have fallen. We can win this game and finish top of the group," says Boskov. "If any of my players wants to settle for a draw they will be out of the team. If we don't want to win the match then it would be better for us to stay in the hotel."

fields.headline: Euro 2000 shorts
fields.trailText: • Uefa is to take no action against Turkey for the violence that accompanied their passage into the quarter-finals in Brussels.
fields.body:
 Uefa is to take no action against Turkey for the violence that accompanied their passage into the quarter-finals in Brussels.

Some 2,000 Turkish supporters rampaged through the centre of Brussels on Monday night after their 2-0 victory over the co-hosts Belgium, with English supporters among those attacked.

But Uefa said yesterday: "There were just minor problems. We have been told [by police] there is no need for us to take the matter any further."

 Belgian police are investigating two incidents in which Dutch journalists are alleged to have incited fans to violence at the tournament.

Police said a Dutch photographer allegedly offered money to English fans in Charleroi on Friday to cause a disturbance. They are also examining reports that a Dutch television crew gave firecrackers to Belgian fanson Monday and asked them to act like violent fans in the game with Turkey.

 Turkey's coach Mustafa Denizli sent home the midfielder Tugay Kerimoglu yesterday after the player reacted angrily to being substituted in the 2-0 win over Belgium.

Tugay, who has had an unhappy spell with Rangers since joining the Glasgow club this year, threw his shinpads towards Denizli after being replaced after only 37 minutes on Monday night. He later asked for "forgiveness" but was still banished by Denizli.

 The Danish referee Kim Milton Nielsen has been forced to pull out of Euro 2000 after pulling his thigh muscle in Belgium's game with Turkey. "It's only the second time I've been injured during a match in my entire career," he said. "I'm extremely disappointed."

With Denmark eliminated from the tournament the experienced Nielsen, who sent off England's David Beckham in France 98, would have had a good chance of refereeing the final on July 2.

 Miran Pavlin of Slovenia has signed a four-year contract with the Portuguese club Porto. The midfielder, who is moving from the German second division club Karlsruhe, scored in Slovenia's 3-3 draw against Yugoslavia in Belgium last week.

 Belgium's veteran central defender Lorenzo Staelens has announced his international retirement after Belgium's early exit from the tournament following the defeat by Turkey on Monday. The 36-year-old earned 68 caps over 10 years and scored seven goals for Belgium.

"I'll carry on at Anderlecht but it's time to make way for a younger man in the national team," he said.

 Spain may have gone into this tournament as one of the favourites, but their supporters have been conspicuous by their absence.

Now the Spanish federation has announced plans to set up a supporters' club for the national team to try to whip up support for future competitions.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 diary
fields.trailText: The French love leather, the Dutch like cards, the Italians love nicknames
fields.body:
 The French newspaper France-Soir is printing a daily questionnaire from the France camp. It's tedious stuff in the main - or it was until Emmanuel Petit got his hands on it. Asked whether he preferred wearing jeans or a suit, the Arsenal midfielder said: "I like the comfort offered by jeans, and the elegance of a suit. But above all I love the sensuality and sexuality that emanates from leather. Leather is like silk, it multiplies one's sensations tenfold."

 Frank de Boer is, apparently, a great sportsman. "Away from the football, I try to keep our Barcelona card school going. I'm the big winner at the moment but that's no surprise: I'm always winning," he says. Jaap Stam has another slant: "The De Boers are the most competitive at cards. They play as a pair and, if Ronald isn't doing well, Frank will yell at him. He hates to lose at anything. If it happens he's in a cranky mood for the rest of the day." It is perhaps no surprise that the De Boers' mother is called Git.

 While on the subject of funny Dutch names, the Diary particularly enjoyed the tasty desert on the special Euro 2000 menu at Arnhem's Haarhuis Hotel. It's called Slagroom.

 The Diary was intrigued by Alessandro del Piero's unusual nickname, Pinturicchio. After all, only in Italy would a player be named after "a Renaissance painter famed for his delicate frescos". However, if the International Dictionary of Arts and Artists is to be believed, he should not be pleased. "In any discussion of painters of the High Renaissance," it says, "Pinturicchio, if mentioned at all, is invariably placed in the second rank."

 Not everyone was celebrating when Italy and Turkey qualified for the second round. In Switzerland a 75-year-old man, angered by fans driving around hooting their horns, took out a gun and started shooting. Luckily his aim was not as hot as his temper, and nobody was hurt.

 Not everyone loved England's historic win over Germany on Saturday. "I watched most of the match on TV," says Frank de Boer, "but I fell asleep with about 20 minutes left." Still, it'll be remembered as a classic over here and, impressively, the video, distributed by Visual Entertainment, hits the shops this Friday. It costs £12.99, but we've got 10 copies to give away to anyone who can tell us what percentage of all the players in Euro 2000 play in Britain. Is it a) 10%, b) 20%, or c) 15%. Answers by fax to 020 7713 4107 or email to euro2000@theguardian.com by 9am tomorrow.

fields.headline: Sunderland in the hunt for Czech midfielder Bejbl
fields.trailText: The Czech Republic midfielder Radek Bejbl may be on his way to Sunderland after impressing the manager Peter Reid in Euro 2000.
fields.body:
The Czech Republic midfielder Radek Bejbl may be on his way to Sunderland after impressing the manager Peter Reid in Euro 2000.

Reid said of the Atletico Madrid player: "We've got an interest in Radek but deals are always complex nowadays. He's a player I rate highly but I can't say too much more at the moment."

The Premiership newcomers Charlton will today unveil a record signing in Mark Fish, who has joined the promoted club from First Division Bolton in a £1.5m deal. The Australian defender has been at the Reebok Stadium for three seasons.

Bradford have given Sheffield Wednesday permission to speak to Paul Jewell about the vacant manager's job at Hillsborough. Bradford's chairman Geoffrey Richmond said compensation terms had been agreed should Jewell, who left Bradford over the weekend, take the job.

The FA of Wales will meet in Cardiff today to discuss a deal that could have serious implications for Welsh clubs' finances. It has to decide whether to accept a recommendation from its commercial committee to sell the TV rights for home internationals to a German agency rather than long-term partners BBC Wales. It fears the BBC might not win a new contract and therefore pull the plug on all its domestic soccer coverage and its £3m sponsorship of the FAW Premier Cup.

webTitle: We always play to win - whatever the match

fields.headline: We always play to win - whatever the match
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 special report
fields.trailText: I can really feel my confidence flowing. Watch out for me. There's plenty more to come.
fields.body:
Tonight's match with France is being widely billed as the dress rehearsal for the final of Euro 2000, and I would go along with that. I've heard that our opponents may not field their strongest side for this game but I certainly hope that we will field our best team.

I understand the temptation to protect players but, given that we can play a maximum of only six games during the tournament, do we really need to worry about resting players? Also, if we win tonight we get to continue playing in the Netherlands.

We haven't hit our full form and the only way to reach peak form is to play games, especially against teams such as the world champions. A win tonight would allow us to inflict a psychological blow on the French, which would come in handy should we meet them in the final.

My prediction that Thierry Henry would be the player to watch has proved accurate. After playing alongside Thierry last season I saw how dangerous he can be and got to know his character. My previous two strike partners at Highbury have been very contrasting personalities, Ian Wright the big extrovert and Nicolas Anelka extremely introverted. Thierry is essentially an extrovert, something everyone sees by the way he celebrates goals and shows his passion when he plays.

He is a scholar of football who is determined to improve himself. We chat a lot and share an obsession with goals and the art of goalscoring. If we've seen a goal we particularly admired we will discuss it. Goalscoring is our craft so it's natural we'll want to talk about it.

I have two more team-mates in the French camp in Emmanuel Petit and Patrick Vieira. They make a formidable midfield partnership at club level but I think they have yet to establish themselves as a partnership on the international stage. They may seem happier playing for France but that's because they have become marked men in England. Some opponents from smaller sides in England see Patrick and Manu as a scalp. They see kicking and winding them up as some sort of achievement.

In international football players luckily can't get away with that level of cynicism so Patrick and Manu are able to express themselves more. That's why they sometimes seem to play with more of a smile and less of a snarl on their faces when they appear for France.

So will the Dutch need motivating for tonight's match? Of course not. We've vowed to treat every match during the tournament as the final.

We don't shout as much as, say, English players do, but that shouldn't be mistaken for a lack for passion. There is probably more noise in the Dutch dressing room now than when I started playing for Holland but we are still a relatively quiet bunch of people, the Dutch.

In England there is music in the dressing room and everyone is shouting. The captain is very much the focal point and he will shout even more at everyone to get them motivated. Frank de Boer is respected as captain but he is still just one of the players. I think we are more democratic in the Netherlands.

Now people are looking to me for a "Dennis Bergkamp moment". All I can say is that I feel very comfortable, confident and I know I am in the right shape physically and mentally to show my skill to the world.

I am very much a confidence player. Once something happens to ignite my form, my confidence breeds more confidence and I go on a good run. The double-winning season at Arsenal is a good example of this. I played probably the best football of my career in the opening months of that campaign.

I carved open the Denmark defence for Patrick Kluivert's goal last week and now I can really feel my confidence flowing. Watch out for me. There's plenty more to come from Dennis Bergkamp.

For Dennis Bergkamp's Euro 2000 diary go to his official site at icons.com
