webTitle: No wacky hat? No thank you

fields.headline: No wacky hat? No thank you
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 special report
fields.trailText: Strange hats, synchronised swaying, a smattering of pretty girls - without these you will be letting down the viewing millions.
fields.body:
'In Holland it is oranje, oranje, oranje," an Israeli journalist was saying last week.

"After three days there even your urine is tangerine."

This is not actually the case (so if you were speaking literally, Mr Adar of Tel Aviv, go and see a kidney specialist this instant) but that is not through any lack of effort on the part of the Dutch. Every town is decked out with orange bunting, flags and balloons and the fountains throw up bilious spumes of carotene-tinged foam.

There are ludicrous orange objects for sale everywhere. A music store in Amsterdam offers a marmalade-coloured upright piano. The shop is in a square called Spui and I would defy anyone to look at that piano without feeling the urge to do just that.

On days when Holland are playing, oranjiness goes off the scale. There are men with orange windmills on their heads, there is an orange "Pope" complete with vestment, crook and mitre and a 70-year-old codger in a wig made from carrots.

All this is part of the new fan culture that started to emerge at major tournaments in the early 90s. Once supporters were simply expected to turn up on match days, shout and then go home again. Now a performance is as much demanded of them as it is from the players. Wacky hats, synchronised swaying, a smattering of pretty girls - without these you will be letting down the viewing millions around the globe.

Some groups have plainly not cottoned on to their responsibilities; the newcomers from Slovenia, for instance. They simply jump merrily about in T-shirts bearing the strange slogan, "Euro 2000. Taste Us!"

The fans of Turkey are much the same. For a country that is desperately putting itself forward as a future member of the EC, a place in Euro 2000 is a significant thing, an opportunity to promote the national image. A band of colourful fans would be a big boost.

In Eindhoven before last week's match with Sweden a Turkish band was playing and three girls were doing a dainty folk-dance. All were in Turkish national team shirts and several had Turkey's flag draped around their shoulders. A decade ago such a display would have been a magnet to media folk but in the modern world of flamboyant consumerist supporterdom it is just not enough to get you noticed. Film crews marched past oblivious, keen to get somebody dressed as a blue-and-yellow parrot.

The problem for the Turks is they do not have anything they can truly identify themselves by. Many countries' fans take their national stereotype and exaggerate it. The Dutch put foam clogs on their heads and in Rotterdam yesterday many Germans wore caps bedecked with rubber sausages.

The Turks, though, seem hesitant about getting involved in anything that involves kebab-shaped toppers or inflatable belly-dancers. In this they are a bit like the English, who do not exactly send up our national image, either - unless those fat, tattooed, belligerent drunks are actually engaging in a spot of ironic self-parody.

Belgium, of course, has no significant item of national dress to work with, unless you count spectacles. There are as many opticians in Belgium as in the whole of France but 40m fewer potential customers. As yet, Belgian fans don't seem to have twigged to the fact that their nation is big in glasses; instead they have picked a nickname, the Red Devils, which is a licence to paint their faces and stick pointy bits on their heads.

Spain have gone a different route. Rather than wearing grossly enlarged matador hats, they have Manolo, the irritating bloke who bangs the drum. He hits that thing so hard you can feel it thudding in the pit of your stomach; after 90 minutes you have an inkling what John Hurt must have been going through before that alien burst out through his ribcage. Yet nobody ignores the big man in the beret.

If the Turks and Slovenes are to take full advantage of the promotional opportunites of international football they need to learn from Euro 2000. It is either an outbreak of riotous self-mockery, a Ken Bailey of the Bosporus, or a sobriquet that will lend itself to colourful madness. Or they could be like the French and Italians and save a lot of both-er by simply winning things.

Harry Pearson is covering Euro 2000 for When Saturday Comes

fields.headline: Conceicao caps Germany's total humiliation
fields.trailText: Four years after winning the European Championship at Wembley, Germany slunk out of the first round of this competition last night, without spirit, without a win and apparently without hope.
fields.body:
How the once mighty have fallen and how remarkably fast. Four years after winning the European Championship at Wembley, Germany slunk out of the first round of this competition last night, without spirit, without a win and apparently without hope.

Their comprehensive defeat by a team of Portuguese reserves encapsulated their sorry plight. Long before Sergio Conceicao had completed his hat-trick by shooting into the far corner in the 71st minute, German heads had dropped. Where their opponents showed speed, invention and youth, Germany's ageing team looked leaden and lost, relics of another era.

Three of the Germany team that finished here had 100 or more caps, and the way Portugal teased and taunted them when they felt in the mood was a sign of the changing guard of European football. Erich Ribbeck's successor as coach has a huge rebuilding job on his hands.

When the match started Germany's fate was out of their hands but they knew they had to win to stand any chance of avoiding their first opening-round exit from a major championship since Euro 84.

Ribbeck made four changes from the side beaten by England. Among the absentees were Markus Babbel and Jens Jeremies, officially because of injury though there were rumours they had been dropped for disciplinary reasons.

The 23-year-old Michael Ballack was drafted in but at the other end of the scale Lothar Matthäus took his place as sweeper for his 150th cap.

Ribbeck must have been taken by surprise by the team Humberto Coelho sent out against his selection. The Portugal facing them bore little resemblance to the side that had beaten Romania on Saturday to secure a place in the last eight. Only two players - Jorge Costa and Fernando Couto - remained.

Even so Germany struggled to make much of an impression early on, strangely deploying Carsten Jancker as a lone striker despite the desperate need for three points. Their passing was neat at times as they monopolised possession, and the young Hertha Berlin midfielder Sebastian Deisler caused problems down the right flank, but there was little end product.

Sure enough the Portuguese second XI soon went close despite being mostly on the back foot. Twice they burst into life, Sa Pinto seeing a shot deflected over the bar and Pauleta flashing an effort just wide from Conceicao's cross.

Then came news that Romania had taken the lead over England and the German fans burst into life. Their team also started to fire as first Jancker turned sharply and shot wide and then Mehmet Scholl released Marco Bode, whose shot beat Pedro Espinha but came back off the post.

If Germany felt then that their luck was out it was confirmed in the next 15 minutes, when Conceicao gave Portugal the lead and in Belgium Alan Shearer equalised for England from the penalty spot.

On 35 minutes Pauleta's burst down the left ended with a cross-shot which looped off a defender and bounced agonisingly out of Oliver Kahn's reach and towards the far post, where Conceicao bundled it over with his head.

At half-time Germany's fate looked sealed. Ribbeck threw on a second forward, Paolo Rink, for Ballack but they still laboured to create chances.

Matthäus sweated to offer inspiration but his legs are not what they were. Likewise Germany's passing deteriorated as their spirits dropped. If an indication was needed of how far they have sunk and how minds had wandered, it came when Portugal's second goal arrived in the 54th minute.

Conceicao was again the scorer, cutting inside Hamann and hitting a low drive from the edge of the area which seemed a comfortable save for Kahn. But in bending down to collect it the Bayern Munich goalkeeper let the ball through his arms and legs and into the net.

And, as Conceicao made sure, that was not the last German embarrassment of the night.

fields.headline: France 2 - 3 Holland
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

France: Lama, Karembeu, Desailly, Leboeuf, Candela, Vieira, Micoud, Dugarry, Pires, Trezeguet, Wiltord. Subs: Anelka, Barthez, Blanc, Deschamps, Djorkaeff, Henry, Lizarazu, Petit, Rame, Zidane, Thuram.

Holland: Westerveld, Bosvelt, Stam, F. de Boer, Numan, Zenden, Davids, Cocu, Overmars, Bergkamp, Kluivert. Subs: Konterman, Makaay, Reiziger, Seedorf, Winter, R. de Boer, de Goey, van Bronckhorst, van Hooijdonk, van der Sar, van Vossen.

Referee: A Frisk (Sweden)

1 Holland kick-off and play the ball back before looking for Bergkamp. Bergkamp has a crack from distance and sends the ball into the stands.
2 Good work by Overmars on the right of the penalty area creates some space but his pass to Kluivert inside the area is blocked.
3 France yet to attack the Dutch goal as thay hoof the ball up into space.
4 Zenden races on to a long ball but Weterveld comes out to claim on the edge of the area.
5 Overmars gets away on the right, rides one challenge and then goes down under a second. Free-kick from the 40 yards out on the right. Bergkamp takes, Cocu rises at the far post and gets in a solid header that Lama is forced to block with his feet.
8 GOAL! France 1 - 0 Holland France corner on the right; it is floated in close to goal and Dugarry heads in from five yards for the opener.
10 France now coming awake and starting to look the part after scoring against the run of play. The game has settled into a flowing rhythm.
11 Bergkamp loops the ball over the top of the France defence to play in Kluivert on the left; his crisp shot is goal-bound but Lama meets it at the near post. Second good chance for Holland.
14 GOAL! France 1 - 1 Holland Kluivert away in space on the left after a great pass from Bergkamp in the centre circle, Kluivert races on unhindered, looks up and beats Lama with a right-foot shot to the far post.
17 Both teams have settled down with much of the play now taking place in midfield.
19 France push up and try to work the ball around in front of the Dutch back line but Holland hold firm and France lose possession. Holland break; they fail to win a free-kick when Overmars is checked by Dugarry bang on the edge of the France area.
22 Davids finds Zenden deep on the left with a long pass from midfield. Zenden crosses and Bergkamp, somewhat surprised, manages to hook a limp shot at goal only to see it loop up and come off the crossbar. Lucky escape for France.
26 The game appears to be settling into a pattern of a few minutes of exhibition knock-around in midfield followed by a couple of goal-scoring chances for Holland and tentative break from France.
28 France shuttle the ball through midfield, with Micoud the instigator. France win a free-kick 40 yards out but it misses everyone.
30 GOAL! France 2 - 1 Holland Micoud spots Westerveld off his line and tries a lob from the halfway line. It earns a corner. Micoud takes; the ball comes in from the right, skims off Stam's head and falls at the feet of Wiltord just over 20 yards out. His instant shot beats Westerveld at the far post.
35 Wiltord races upfield after the back-tracking Bosvelt but the Dutchman keeps the Franch striker at bay and clears.
37 Wiltord again as he strides away on the left, but he comes up against a wall of orange and loses possession.
39 Dugarry is stretchered off after a crunching challenge.
41 Overmars gets away on the right and wins a corner. Bergkamp takes and Cocu gets up to head the wrong way.
43 The game hits a lull as half-time nears.
44 France free-kick. Leboeuf takes but comes to nothing.
45 Zenden wastes his cross when Holland work the ball out swiftly to him deep on the left. Booking Dugarry. Half-time.

46 France kick off the second half. A very tentative start as both teams stroll around a little.
48 France win a free-kick 40 yards to the right. Micoud plays it short to Karembeu, but France lose possession after some neat passing.
49 Great chance for Dugarry just inside the area with only Westerveld to beat. He shoots but Westerveld blocks well.
50 Overmars gets away on the right after Kluivert plays him on with a sweeping one-two. His shot from the edge of the area is weak.
51 GOAL! France 2 - 2 Holland De Boer from a free-kick slightly to the right and just outside the area. He whacks it around the wall and into the top corner of the net.
53 Micoud with a corner for France. It is cleared and Holland break as Bergkamp feeds Overmars on the right again. The Dutch rush up and the ball is played in twice before France clear.
56 Bergkamp is unlucky not to get a free-kick when he is bundled off the ball by Micoud and Vieira just outside the penalty area.
59 GOAL! France 2 - 3 Holland Zenden gets on to the end of a deep centre, beats Karembeu on the edge of the area and places his right-foot shot to the left of the sprawling Lama.
60 Substitution Makaay on for Kluivert.
63 Great defending from Stam to deny France space to shoot on the right of the area...
64 ... France free-kick, Micoud wafts it in and Holland clear.
66 Stam, yes Stam, breaks on the right, but passes back to Overmars when he has to take someone on.
67 Davids down injured after a crashing into Vieira. Davids appears to have landed on his eyes and done some damage to his specs.
71 Holland corner from the left. Bergkamp takes but France clear with ease.
73 Zenden charges after the back-tracking Leboeuf. Lama is committed and Leboeuf shows great skill to hold off Zenden, drag him wide and then beat his man to clear.
75 Booking Desailly. Holland free-kick 30 yards out that is played back and to the right. Overmars cuts inside, but France clear and break...
76 ... but Trezeguet is run wide enough by Overmars to force the shot wide.
78 Substitution Winter on for Bergkamp.
79 The pace of the game has tapered off somewhat but the quality of overall play suggests there may well be another goal in this match.
80 Substitution Anelka on for Wiltord.
82 Overmars again races away on the right, but his touch past Desailly is too strong.
84 Stam again pushes up and rides two challenges in the centre circle before passing to the right.
85 Booking Cocu for ridiculously obvious shirt-pulling.
86 Davids does well deep on the left and wins a corner. Comes to nothing.
89 Substitution Van Vossen on for Overmars. Unsurprisingly, after such a frantic game, not much is happening as the game winds up. Either team could have won this game, and although France still look up for the challenge, they also look to be happy with the result, knowing that they are already through.
90 Three extra minutes to play.
Booking Vieira. Substitution Deschamps on for Vieira for his 98th cap. Free-kick to France. Djorkaeff takes, aiming towards Trezeguet; the ball comes out to Pires on the right but his shot is easy for Westerveld. Full-time. France 2 - 3 Holland. In the other match in Group D, the Czech Republic beat Denamrk 2-0.

webTitle: What Blair needs to do to woo back the women

fields.headline: What Blair needs to do to woo back the women
fields.standfirst: We thought we were getting a new feminised politics. It didn't happen
fields.trailText: We thought we were getting a new feminised politics. It didn't happen
fields.body:
Testosterone rampant on Charleroi streets made women feel smug. Women are better than men: feminist orthodoxy requires we think it. But sometimes believers' faith in the doctrine wavers. Harriet Harman and Patricia Hewitt's Fabian pamphlet this week lays out the growing gender gap between women and men's voting intentions. Yet again women are swinging against Labour. What's new? If women never had the vote, we'd never have had Conservative governments. Thank women's votes for Thatcher, Europhobia, the poll tax and the tripling of poverty. Think Molly in Animal Farm - airhead, fickle, silly moos.

A month before the last election the Fawcett Society and Mori reported that a quarter of women voters were still undecided. They put the best possible gloss on it: "These are the thoughtful voters," they said. Ho hum. Another Mori poll showed 63% of women proclaim themselves "not interested" in politics, compared with only 31% of men. Women are less well informed with 10% more men reading quality newspapers. The gender gap in voting habits has been pretty constant since the war, but in 1997 Labour cut it to just 2%. Now the Harman paper shows 13% more women than men expressing dissatisfaction with Labour. Women switch-voters threaten to switch back.

Ever since Margaret Thatcher there's been a feminist problem with women and politics. (Well, we used to explain unconvincingly, it's all because she was one woman alone, pushing her way into an all-male world, forced to cast herself in iron, tougher than the boys and so on.) Feminists are used to the standing-on-your-head posture to explain why women are always justified. But there are good demographic reasons to explain women's tendency to vote Tory. All over 55s are far more conservative than the young: there are many more old women, so women as a bloc are more conservative. The hope is for the future: women under 35 are the opposite. They are 10% more Labour than young men. But psephologists don't know whether women turn Tory as they get old or whether the current old women are a dying Tory generation. British Social Attitudes shows how higher education creates far more liberal attitudes and older women are the least educated. There's an old tradition of working-class women adopting conservative views along with higher social aspirations preferring to vote with the antimacassar not the cloth cap. But that's all dying out.

Politicians are not allowed to think voters are ever wrong, so this week Labour women have sought to explain women's bad voting habits. It's all the government's fault. Labour hasn't delivered. In the focus groups women who switched from Tory in 1997 complain that Labour hasn't come across on health, education, books in schools, A and E in hospitals, nursery places, class sizes and lots more. (The report does not say whether these logical, rational creatures think the Conservatives are likely to deliver more of those things.) Ignorant or not, they are unaware of what the government has done for women. The billions spent so far have not bought their votes, not the minimum wage (mainly for women), the working families tax credit, (mainly to women), biggest ever rise in child benefit (all to women), childcare tax credits, part-time workers rights or increased maternity. The news hasn't permeated the thick heads of the fair sex. What went wrong?

First of all, the poorest women who benefited most are the least likely to vote. Doing them good was for its own sake, not to buy votes. Some other policies haven't worked yet. Childcare credits have been taken up by few, not enough childcare is available, the money isn't enough to pay for it. What women want are high quality nurseries, but there's no plan for the gleaming universal nursery provision taken for granted across Europe. On the de Tocqueville principle of revolution, giving women a little more but not enough may only have inflamed them. Nice to have a bit more maternity pay and a few more rights, but it only reminds them how almost unbearably difficult it still is to have a baby and go back to work, juggle work and home and stay afloat.

Most mothers have to go back to work at 18 weeks and they feel it is too soon. There is no right to demand to work part-time or a four-day week, such as all men and women have in Holland and Belgium. And £70 a week doesn't buy enough childcare when it costs about £150. Too little, too timid, the policies for women haven't worked. As with the reluctant introduction of part-time workers rights, the government is so frightened of alarming business that they forgot to tell women altogether. They whispered and they mumbled.

What this pamphlet describes is an aura that died. Women in these focus groups thought they were getting a new, feminised politics. Blair looked nicely non-macho. Even if some gag at the sight, these women voters liked that picture of Blair surrounded by his 101 women MPs. But where did all those women MPs go? None in the key spending cabinet posts, none visible, even Mo shut out. The all-male image is rebarbative and image matters. But it's politics as usual, men's stuff, by men, for men. Old versus New Labour may fight it out - Kilfoyle v Mandelson - but both miss the spot for women. Gordon and his boys have done quite a bit for women - but it doesn't feel like women's policy because they don't own it. It has simply passed women voters by.

Tony Blair isn't even going to the Labour women's conference on Saturday. Maybe the WI have traumatised him, but he's going to have to learn how to talk to women - and not in the dreadful unctuous tones he used on the WI. The hand-claps drowned out reporting of his actual words. If you missed his misguided, tin-eared attempt to please those women, it was patronisingly awful - all about his mother's sense of duty in doing meals on wheels, "the moral guidance of churches", "the case for marriage", "the forces that hold communities together, the family, the church, respect for elders". Those Tory harpies didn't believe him and younger Labour-leaning women would hate all that too.

Today is the Commons modernisation committee's last chance to do what they should have done three years ago - abolish late-night sittings and programme bills for sensible debating times. It's a belated symbol of the power of women in parliament, growing restive at the anonymous misery of backbench life. Labour has so badly lost the plot on women that it risks having fewer women MPs next time - 11 men selected for vacant seats and only one woman. Harriet Harman, with the support of likely cabinet star Patricia Hewitt, has laid out the solution. Try putting women first in policies and pronouncements, women ministers delivering policies for women and they might find the best path back to where most voters are.

fields.headline: Fair and cheap
fields.standfirst: Ending university elitism is within reach
fields.trailText: After the fire and the fury, the true metal begins to emerge. Peter Lampl, the chairman of the Sutton Trust, which provided the devastating statistics on the extent to which Britain's top 13 universities were still unfairly skewed towards private school pupils, went before the Commons select committee on education yesterday.
fields.body:
After the fire and the fury, the true metal begins to emerge. Peter Lampl, the chairman of the Sutton Trust, which provided the devastating statistics on the extent to which Britain's top 13 universities were still unfairly skewed towards private school pupils, went before the Commons select committee on education yesterday. To the Sutton Trust's credit, the bias it has documented has been widely accepted, even by the university perpetrators. But the debate has moved on and is now looking forward, rather than back, addressing the crucial question: how can the bias be corrected?

On this front, there is room for optimism. Two of the top 13 universities - York and Warwick - have already demonstrated that inbuilt bias can be eliminated. Both these universities have already achieved their benchmarks. Good for them. The route which the other 11 should take is already clear. Indeed, most of them have already begun to take the next steps. First is the need for recruitment officers. Universities cannot sit back and expect exceptionally bright low-income students from state schools to apply. They must recognise the social and cultural barriers which deter them from applying. Like missionaries, universities need to go out to the field and proselytise. The most progressive colleges have already begun to do so. The Sutton Trust is promoting these experiments. Oxford's Mansfield College, for example, is targeting further education colleges with some success. Then there are other reforms which need to be put in place - summer schools to support students from overstretched state sixth forms; new links between colleges and state schools; more open days for pupils in inner-city schools. According to the trust, this entire package would only cost £20m for the top 13, a tiny amount for a higher education sector spending £12bn a year. Reform must not be restricted to the 13, but apply to all 100. They all need to be more open.

fields.headline: Shake-up time for Auntie
fields.standfirst:
Today's criticisms in the BBC governors' annual report don't bode well for BBC1 controller Peter Salmon, says media correspondent Matt Wells
The BBC's annual report
Special report
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 5.30pm: Today's criticisms in the BBC governors' annual report don't bode well for BBC1 controller Peter Salmon, says media correspondent Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Yet again, the BBC governors have laid into the corporation's flagship channel for failing to "hit the heights" with its mix of programmes.

More work needs to be done, they said in their annual report, to make BBC1 distinctive from its commercial rivals; standards were too variable, and the "average quality of programmes across the year on the channel is still not good enough."

Sitcoms have been poor, and BBC1 is too reliant on light, popular factual shows - an implication that the likes of Changing Rooms and Airport have had their day.

There was much praise for other parts of the corporation - notably radio - but the criticisms about BBC1 represent a serious blow for the channel controller, Peter Salmon, who is under increasing pressure. At a press conference today, BBC director-general Greg Dyke notably failed to endorse his position.

Salmon has been criticised for playing it safe, failing to show imagination in both scheduling and commissioning of programmes. BBC1's star is certainly on the wane: series flops such as the Peter Principle and Fish have not helped.

The governors acknowledged that last autumn was pretty successful, but said more money needed to be spent on better programmes. Dyke said more was on its way - but BBC1 and 2 will have to fight it out for the extra £15m bonus announced today.

The annual report is not the corporation's only headache today. The BBC's radical plans for its TV channels - creating a new raft of "genre-based" stations with entertainment on BBC1, serious programming on BBC2, youth and comedy shows on a new BBC3 and arts and culture channel output on BBC4 - were dealt a blow by the government.

A week after the BBC's director of television Mark Thompson outlined the plans in a speech in Canada, the department of culture media and sport announced it was tightening up the rules governing the launch of new services by the BBC.

It seems that Greg Dyke's honeymoon period is over.

webTitle: No more bunching: ban the bonus points

fields.headline: No more bunching: ban the bonus points
fields.trailText: It took 110 years to change to two divisions. The last county before Durham to be admitted to the fold was Glamorgan, in 1921. And Yorkshire said nay to Johnny Foreigner until 1992. But don't make the mistake of not seeing the trees for the dead wood. Because things really do change quickly in the Championship.
fields.body:
It took 110 years to change to two divisions. The last county before Durham to be admitted to the fold was Glamorgan, in 1921. And Yorkshire said nay to Johnny Foreigner until 1992. But don't make the mistake of not seeing the trees for the dead wood. Because things really do change quickly in the Championship.

Last week's column looked at the pitiful start made by Hampshire. It was obvious: they were the biggest certainties for relegation since Swindon Town made it to the Premiership in 1993. Hampshire's response? They skittled Durham for 83 and 93, and shot up from last place in division one to sixth. Durham, who began the season with a stunning 231-run victory over champions Surrey, are now bottom. Told you things change quickly.

The second division is even closer. Seven points (which is what a team would get for taking six wickets and scoring 200 in a rain-ruined draw) separate

the top five sides, while even Northants in sixth are just 20 points (a win with maximum bonus points) adrift of leaders Worcestershire.

With a possible 20 points at stake, positions are set not so much in concrete as quicksand. But does this really mean there's not an awful lot between the sides? The fact is that the counties are bunched more closely than they should be. And the problem is the old bonus-points system. Or rather the new one (see below for details), which is little better. It exists ostensibly to encourage teams to build big first-innings totals, which is no bad thing - though in practice the groundsmen produce greentops and 23 wickets fall by tea.

But it persists in awarding three bowling points if a side takes nine wickets in 130 first-innings overs (or a wicket every 87 balls). This is ridiculous. It means a side that draws a match with full bonus points (eight, plus four for the draw) has done as well as one that wins (12 points) without claiming any bonuses. An unlikely scenario, maybe, but you get the point.

So teams can muddle along with ten points here, and 12 there, safe in the knowledge that the odd victory will do wonders for their position. Notts have won just one game in seven, but are fifth in division two. How come? Twenty bowling bonus points, more than any side in the country except Hampshire (21). Last season Hampshire finished seventh and qualified for the top flight. Sussex, who won one more game than them (six to five) and lost as many (five), came 11th and looked forward to division two. This season Lancashire have won three and drawn three out of six. But they trail Leicestershire, who have two wins and a loss out of seven. In both cases, bonus points are the culprits.

Domestic competitions overseas award points for wins, draws and first-innings leads. This is more sensible. But it's still flawed: in India, a five-day Ranji Trophy semi-final can come down to a tedious battle for first-innings lead. Third innings are as common as Yorkshire running away with it at the end of the season.

The only alternative is to ban bonus points altogether, but still give 12 points for a win and four for a draw. This would encourage teams to play for a win rather than waste time batting on in rain-interrupted games for another point or two, and would widen the gap (proportionally) between the best teams and the worst.

At my old school, there was an archaic rule that allowed the head boy to keep a goat on one of the playing fields. Why it existed, no-one knew. The raison d'etre of the bonus-points system isn't quite as mystifying, but like the goat that probably never was, it should be put out to graze. Then we might get a more accurate reflection of every side's ability over two innings - not a mish-mash of sides surviving on the scraps of an outdated system.

Five points are available for batting (1 for 200, 2 for 250, up to 5 for 400), and three for bowling (1 for 3 wkts, 2 for 6, 3 for 9). Last season points were scored over the first 120 overs and the split was four and four (1 batting point for 200 runs, up to 4 for 350; 1 bowling point for 3-4 wkts, 2 for 5-6, 3 for 7-8, 4 for 9-10).

fields.headline: System for choosing QCs 'discriminatory'
fields.standfirst:
Merit not the key factor in legal promotions, argues report
Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The system for choosing judges and QCs is riddled with indirect race and sex discrimination, according to a report carried out for the Lord Chancellor's Department.
fields.body:
The system for choosing judges and QCs is riddled with indirect race and sex discrimination, according to a report carried out for the Lord Chancellor's Department.

The study is embarrassing for the lord chancellor, who insists that appointments are made purely on merit. His department commissioned and paid for the independent research by Kate Malleson of the London School of Economics and Fareda Banda of the School of Oriental and African Studies.

Dr Malleson, who has written widely on judicial appointments in Britain, the US and Canada, said the study showed that the system in England and Wales was indirectly discriminatory. "It shows that beyond the criterion of merit there are other factors which play a part which are not merit-based. Certain groups are disadvantaged even where the individuals have merit."

Questionnaires were sent to 320 barristers and solicitors with 15-22 years of experience in the profession - the group from which QCs and part time judges are appointed - and 52 were interviewed face to face. Lawyers who want to be full time judges must first serve several years part time.

Interviewees included many who had succeeded in their applications, as well as those turned down and others who had not applied. But there was widespread criticism of the system, which depends on "secret soundings" from judges and senior lawyers. Success was seen as being determined by "who you know" rather than on merit. A key factor was whether or not a candidate belonged to one of the elite sets of chambers which produce most of the QCs (the top rank of the bar, also called "silks") and senior judges.

Those most satisfied with the system were white male barristers, who were more likely to belong to those chambers.

One said: "I am the wrong person to ask about the difficulties in applying for silk. In these chambers usually everyone gets silk the first time of asking and everyone becomes a judge. It is a sort of golden road."

A woman barrister said: "You put yourself in the circle if you are in the right chambers. You have only to look at who gets in - if you are the child of a judge or one of the senior lawyers or a judge."

Solicitors and ethnic minority barristers felt most disadvantaged. Black barristers were less likely to be in top chambers or to have the type of practice which led to silk.

The Lord Chancellor's Department has broadened the consultation, introduced open competition, and encouraged more women and non-whites to apply.

Sarah Harman, a solicitor and part time judge, attacked the lord chancellor yesterday for his failure to appoint more women judges. Ms Harman, sister of the former Labour minister Harriet Harman, said: "There has been a complete lack of progress."

Women make up only 11% of the judiciary and are concentrated in the lower ranks. There are only seven women high court judges, two in the court of appeal, and no women law lords. There are no ethnic minority judges in the high court or above.

fields.headline: NHS pay awards 'riddled with racism'
fields.standfirst:
The future of the NHS: special report
Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Allocation of performance pay in the NHS is "riddled with racism", according to a survey published yesterday.
fields.body:
Allocation of performance pay in the NHS is "riddled with racism", according to a survey published yesterday.

It found black health visitors and community nurses were only a third as likely as white staff to get performance related pay awards worth up to £1,300 a year.

The finding, reported by the health union MSF and the Community Practitioners and Health Visitors Association, comes as ministers conducting the NHS review are considering extending performance pay by offering team bonuses to hospital staff improving quality and throughput.

The survey of 1,210 health visitors and community nurses found that 5% of black staff got performance pay rises under the discretionary scheme introduced in 1998. This compared with 14% of their white and Asian colleagues.

Roger Kline, MSF's head of health, said: "The discretionary points system is a crude form of competency based pay which has now been shown up as being riddled with racism."

The disparity in awards could not be explained by the age or grade of black staff or regional variations in the proportion of staff getting awards.

"At a time when there is widespread recognition of the discrimination facing black staff in the NHS, this appears to be a devastating finding," the report said.

The Department of Health said the survey was too small for clear conclusions on the operation of the scheme.

Under a national agreement with the unions, the scheme was meant to accord with best equal opportunities practice. The department said: "We expect all employers and local unions to act accordingly. There is no room for discrimination in the NHS."

In April the government issued an equalities framework for the NHS, setting targets for the advancement of women and people from ethnic minorities. It has also set up an action programme for tackling racial harassment in the NHS.

webTitle: Hague accuses government of 'rationing' health care

fields.headline: Hague accuses government of 'rationing' health care
fields.trailText: The government was today urged to set up a fund to reimburse GPs who spend above their budget on vital drugs and surgery.
fields.body:
The government was today urged to set up a fund to reimburse GPs who spend above their budget on vital drugs and surgery.

Tory leader William Hague said the fund was necessary because it was clear that the government was "rationing" health care in the wake of a report that said multiple sclerosis sufferers should be denied a drug that many claim gives them relief from the disease.

"This is, of course, a preliminary report. But it will have caused immediate and deep concern to thousands of families.

"Will you now acknowledge that after three years of a Labour government, there is more rationing in the health service than ever before?" Mr Hague asked prime minister Tony Blair.

Mr Blair told the Commons that no one currently receiving the drug beta interferon for MS would be affected by the national institute of clinical excellence's suggestion that it should no longer be available on prescription. Responding to Mr Hague's taunts, he accused the Tory leader of an "opportunistic pretence that somehow when you were in government people got all the drugs they wanted".

The prime minister claimed that the Tory fund would cost £1 billion, the same amount he said that Mr Hague would take out of the NHS to pay for private medical insurance tax relief. "How can you spend £1 billion more when you are dedicated to taking £1 billion out?" he asked.

"Nobody who gets it now is going to be denied it," Mr Blair told Mr Hague. "You say it is available to all MS sufferers elsewhere in Europe. In fact, in France, Germany and Italy only 12% of MS sufferers get it."

Liberal democrat leader Charles Kennedy asked the prime minister what he made of a world health organisation report that ranked Britain's health service 18th in the world. Mr Blair said it was "complimentary" and debunked the idea that Britain had a third world health service. He said the report ranked the NHS higher than its equivalents in Germany, Sweden, the US and Canada.

webTitle: Father and son injured in Belfast bomb blast

fields.headline: Father and son injured in Belfast bomb blast
fields.trailText: A father and son were injured today in a bomb blast in a nationalist area of west Belfast.
fields.body:
A father and son were injured today in a bomb blast in a nationalist area of west Belfast.

The blast happened at Glenalina Crescent, in the Ballymurphy district. Police were this afternoon trying to determine the cause of the explosion. But security sources confirmed that it was caused by an explosive device.

No one has claimed responsibility for the explosion, but it came a day after paramilitaries in the loyalist Ulster Freedom Fighters threatened to break their ceasefire if attacks on Protestant homes in north and west Belfast were not halted by midnight last night.

One of the victims, who was in his 30s, was found bleeding badly and slipping in and out of consciousness. He had leg and head injuries. The second, in his 50s, also suffered head injuries. Both were taken to the Royal Victoria Hospital. A Royal Ulster Constabulary spokesman said he did not believe their injuries to be life threatening.

The house is in a republican area of west Belfast where tensions are high in advance of a loyalist parade in the neighbouring Upper Springfield Road district on Saturday. Three RUC officers were hurt when police moved into to keep rival crowds apart late last night.

Police this afternoon sealed off the area around the terraced house in which the explosion occurred. Army bomb disposal experts entered the house to investigate the bomb blast.

Parish priest Father Denis McKinley said Lily O'Brien had told him her husband and son had been in the garden shed when there was an explosion.

He said after visiting the house: "She told me the men were in the back garden, they were clearing something from the shed or something like that, and the next thing she heard was the explosion. There was some rumour that one of them lifted a pipe but it is all a bit garbled at this stage and nobody really knows exactly what happened."

Father McKinley went to the Royal Victoria Hospital to see the men but was unable to do so. "I don't know the extent of their injuries," he said.

webTitle: Football games, Computer games and War games

fields.headline: Football games, Computer games and War games
fields.trailText: BUCKEROO!
fields.body:
BUCKEROO!

If it wasn't for a slightly fortuitous win against Germany, a foaming, flapping Kelvin Koogan would probably have offered his resignation by now. And Bryan Robson would have probably been rolled in to replace him. So is it any wonder that the hardened tabloid hacks decided to give Koog's 'honesty is the best policy' policy a strangely easy ride earlier today?

"I have not set the world on fire so far with my management skills but I still get the opportunity to do that in a World Cup," was Koogan's opening gambit. "I have learned things, it would be sad if I hadn't." Quite right, thought the Fiver. Sadly, the only thing he seems to have learned is how to pass the buck.

"The last thing I am going to do is say anything detrimental about the players in the hotel," he said. "I picked the best 22 players available to me. But we were not good enough." Kelv then accused the Premiership of not "fitting in with the style of international football", before insisting that it would be a waste of time to fill the team with fresh talent... and of course he prepared for the tournament properly!

Is it any wonder, then, that the Fiver's mailbox is bursting with readers pleading with us to be the vanguard of a 'Bring back Hod' campaign or a 'Bring back Venables' campaign? Luckily, there's been no call as of yet to launch 'Bring back Taylor', but with Koog in this form it's probably just a matter of time.

PAUL JEWELL'S FINAL DAY OF LEISURE

1015

Haul myself out of bed after enjoying a lovely long lie-in. Decide to dig out PlayStation and have game of Qxwgrgk The Wizard XIV. I've yet to get past Brraaap's Cave because I've never found the magic key, but thanks to all this time I've got on my hands after resigning and being put on paid leave by Bradford, I'll be able to work out how to get to the next level. Yay!

1016

Bah! I've got to go to Sheffield! Howard Culley, the Wednesday chairman, wants me to put the final touches to a deal which will see me become manager at Hillsborough.

1059

Put final touches to deal whilst thinking about magic key.

1100

"Promotion is what we're aiming for. I think I know what it takes to get back in the Premier League - a lot of hard work, a lot of passion, and also we've got some good players here," I announce as I am unveiled as Wednesday's new boss. I tell everyone that Peter Shreeves, who was caretaker manager at Wednesday after the sacking of Danny Wilson, will stay on as first-team coach, and Culley tells everyone that I am "first class". As he runs off to pay compensation to Bradford, I head home to continue my attempts to get out of the cave.

1101

Suddenly realise I am now in permanent employment again and subsequently far too busy to play computer games. Sell good-as-new console for peanuts to passing small child. Seethe.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We've never been able to get on easy street and the day we can we'll be a better side" - It's lucky that Kelvin Koogan's going home for a nice rest, isn't it?

COMMONS PEOPLE

The Fiver is sick of having to report about supporters of opposing teams picking fights with each other and causing bother whenever there's a football match on. But we suppose there was always going to be trouble last night. Labour MP Jackie Lawrence and Tory MP Andrew Robathan - you should both be ashamed of yourselves.

Lawrence was loafing about in the Commons dining room when she and the rest of her Red Firm decided they wanted to watch the England game. She asked Commons staff to switch one of the annunciators - tedious screens which are full of political bumph - over to the football coverage. Her wish was granted, but Robathan, backed by a dozen baying members of the notorious Blue Casuals, marched up to the screen and provocatively switched it off.

A full-scale riot was narrowly avoided by segregating the two warring factions with a curtain, but the measure brought no end to the verbal abuse. "I thought it showed a lack of patriotism / for them patriotism is rhetoric not action," chanted Lawrence. Robathan responded with a chorus of "I spent 15 years in Her Majesty's Armed Forces / serving in the Gulf and Northern Ireland / not everybody links patriotism with football / not everyone in this country thinks that the most important thing that was happening last night was a football match / I and my colleagues were having an interesting political discussion."

Ugly scenes indeed. The Fiver says: take their passports away!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Leeds have expressed an interest in Juventus defender Zoran Mirkovic.

Chelsea are set to renew their attempts to sign Parma's £6m-rated Croatian all-rounder Mario Stanic.

Arsenal and Chelsea have made enquires about Belgium's £5m-rated central defender Joos Valgaeren.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Erich Ribbeck is to stand down as coach of Germany following his side's dismal performance in the Euro 2000 finals.

Alan Shearer insists he will not change his mind about retiring from international football. "I've made my decision and I stick by it," he said earlier today.

Rangers hope to complete the transfer of Kenny Miller from Hibs within 48 hours. Miller has been granted permission to discuss a move to Ibrox after a reported initial £1.5m fee was agreed with a further £500,000 to be paid six months after the signing date.

William Hill have quoted Phil Neville at odds of 1000-1 to be the England skipper for the World Cup qualifying game against Germany in October.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1: Match of the Day Live (4.35pm)

Spain v Yugoslavia. Sadly, we get to miss out on the entertaining Norwegians, who are playing at the same time. Shame.

MOTD @ Euro 2000 (11.15pm)

With loads of quality football to fit in, let's hope the first 55 minutes of this hour-long programme is about Kelvin's bunch of losers, eh?

Euro 2000 Replay (12.45am)

Probably containing extra-long analysis of why England got knocked out. But isn't it obvious?

ITV: Euro 2000 Live (7.30pm)

France v Holland. How proper teams play football.

Euro 2000 The Big Match (1.45am)

Sideshow Bob Wilson is made to stay up late as punishment for being Sideshow Bob Wilson.

ITV2: Euro 2000 Live (7pm)

Denmark v Czech Republic. Does this mean we'll get two Barry Venisons at once?

British Eurosport: Euro 2000 Football Live (7pm)

This is a complete waste of time. Denmark v Czech Republic, we mean, not Eurosport.

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (7pm, 11.15pm)

Decided to show some football again, have we?

Radio 5 Live: Euro 2000 Live (4.55pm)

A series of grumbles and angry growls.

Midweek Football Phone-In (10pm)

Would do exactly what it says on the tin were it in a tin.

QUOTE OF THE DAY "We've never been able to get on easy street and the day we can we'll be a better side" - It's lucky that Kelvin Koogan's going home for a nice rest, isn't it? COMMONS PEOPLE The Fiver is sick of having to report about supporters of opposing teams picking fights with each other and causing bother whenever there's a football match on. But we suppose there was always going to be trouble last night. Labour MP Jackie Lawrence and Tory MP Andrew Robathan - you should both be ashamed of yourselves. Lawrence was loafing about in the Commons dining room when she and the rest of her Red Firm decided they wanted to watch the England game. She asked Commons staff to switch one of the annunciators - tedious screens which are full of political bumph - over to the football coverage. Her wish was granted, but Robathan, backed by a dozen baying members of the notorious Blue Casuals, marched up to the screen and provocatively switched it off. A full-scale riot was narrowly avoided by segregating the two warring factions with a curtain, but the measure brought no end to the verbal abuse. "I thought it showed a lack of patriotism / for them patriotism is rhetoric not action," chanted Lawrence. Robathan responded with a chorus of "I spent 15 years in Her Majesty's Armed Forces / serving in the Gulf and Northern Ireland / not everybody links patriotism with football / not everyone in this country thinks that the most important thing that was happening last night was a football match / I and my colleagues were having an interesting political discussion." Rangers hope to complete the transfer of Kenny Miller from Hibs within 48 hours. William Hill have quoted Phil Neville at odds of 1000-1 to be the England skipper for the World Cup qualifying game against Germany in October. webTitle: A lifetime of 'what ifs' and 'if onlys'

fields.headline: A lifetime of 'what ifs' and 'if onlys'
fields.standfirst: Anne Garvey  relives the day her nephew drowned. Can such accidents be prevented?
fields.trailText: Anne Garvey relives the day her nephew drowned. Can such accidents be prevented?
fields.body:
One glorious spring bank holiday my sister's 17-month-old son, John, drowned in the small pond in their garden. The day was fine and the family was gathered for about the first outdoor day after a rainy spring and dreary winter. John was only just walking; in fact, this was his first outdoor ambulant season after a winter spent cruising around furniture. The Sunday roast was in the oven; we were all relaxing.

It happened very fast. John's father was playing tennis on the court across from the garden. Everyone else was having coffee indoors. John was suddenly gone. No one could find him. But he wasn't missing long. His mother found him face down in the pond. He had died instantly, they said afterwards, on impact with the icy water. A dry drowning it's called.

That moment began a long agony for our family that we will never fully recover from. My sister was in a desperate world of grief. The priest came to be with us. Things seemed unreal. Hardly a religious family, we now prayed in despair, holding on to each other for help, clasping hands together for support - inchoate and appalled. But there is no help when a small child dies. There is only the endless regret, the quiet intense introspective reproaches, the silent searching for someone to blame.

Suffering like this should never happen to any family. It's un natural and, in a very true sense, unnecessary. Every second thought is punctured by the real rage of thinking "what if" - what if I had come in that door five minutes earlier, what if the tennis had been a more conclusive score and they had knocked off in time to see the child as he headed for his death, what if the pond had been filled in earlier (it was next on the list after the dead tree had been dragged off).

And when it wasn't "what if", it was "if only". If only I had said I thought the pond was rather deep, if only I had taken the children for a walk, asked them to my house, suggested a holiday. If only X had come in a moment sooner or Y left a second later. There is no end to the recriminations passed in whispers around the family.

Before the funeral, I watched my sister coming down the long staircase in her black dress. Suddenly the large outside door swung open and there was my husband Andy, who had just arrived. She hurled herself into his arms with a terrible cry, the first we had heard from her in two days. In my life I have never seen anyone suffer more, or heard anything more chilling as when the child's father one night wandered into the garden and simply howled.

No one should go through this. Families must check and check again on swimming pools and ponds because to rely on one's own vigilance is to court disaster. No one can be 100% alert and the enviroment around small children has to be literally fenced, safe and riskfree.

Toddlers are utterly reckless, ludicrously careless of their own lives. And the best parents in the world cannot be vigilant all the time. So accept that you might fail your children. Realise you are human and liable to relax your guard. Then check the enviroment and leave nothing to human chance. Be ruthless. If you can't properly fence off that pond, fill it in. Abolish that stylish water feature. Fork out and fence the swimming pool you are so convinced they would never go near. And do it gladly - knowing that even if it ruins your garden or costs you a packet, you are at least less likely to have the agony of a spring funeral and the lifetime of regret that follows.

Keep your child safe

Some 43,000 children aged 14 and under are taken to hospital A&E departments every week as a result of accidents. That is about 256 injuries an hour. Accidents will happen, of course, but parents can minimise the risks.

Research shows that children's accidents fall into a pattern relating to the child's age and stage of development. Falls at home are the most common cause of injury in children under five, for example, while choking accidents peak in babies under one; poisonings peak around age two; and seven to 11-year-olds are most likely to be injured on the roads.

Knowing the risks associated with each age and stage can help parents prevent injury as children grow up.

 The Child Accident Prevention Trust (CAPT) produces five child safety leaflets. To obtain a copy of the leaflet relating to your child's age group, send a stamped, addressed envelope to: CSW 2000 leaflets, Child Accident Prevention Trust, 18-20 Farringdon Lane, London EC1R 3HA. State your child's age so the right leaflet can be sent to you.

CAPT also produces a number of other leaflets, ranging from safety in the garden to sports safety. For further information, call: 020 7608 3828.

webTitle: What can meditation do for your child?

fields.headline: What can meditation do for your child?
fields.trailText: If you're one of those parents who insists on getting down on the floor to join in your offspring's games, take heed: according to the American Psychological Society, which met last week in Miami, gatecrashing on children's play stifles the very creativity you are probably trying to foster.
fields.body:
If you're one of those parents who insists on getting down on the floor to join in your offspring's games, take heed: according to the American Psychological Society, which met last week in Miami, gatecrashing on children's play stifles the very creativity you are probably trying to foster. Parental involvement turns play into something structured, the researchers found, and the child's primary concern then becomes pleasing the parent, rather than following their instincts. To foster creativity and imagination, leave the kids alone, the society was told, and give them opportunities to explore their inner feelings without fear.

This message didn't surprise Christian Kerr, a London teacher who has long believed that too much structure and interference puts a lid on children's natural creativity. Her answer: meditation for children.

Kerr's classes always start with a physical activity - a ball game, perhaps - after which the children sit or lie down for a 10-minute meditation. "I help them with ideas about what to focus on and how to do it, and it's amazing how still and quiet they can become. The other day a class came in full of beans and I thought they'd never settle. But they did a breathing exercise, and then I got them to visualise being in a rocket going into space. They were incredibly silent, and the stories they came back with were really colourful and original: one had seen aliens eating marshmallow sandwiches, another had seen a king and queen in a golden palace. These days there's so much emphasis on the spoken and the written word that it's easy to forget that we can use our creativity in other ways, too."

Given that most primary school children rarely seem to sit still these days, teaching them to meditate sounds a tall order. Or, looking at it another way, a jolly good idea. After all, we all need a bit of silence in our lives - and if children don't learn the value of peace and quiet when they're young, when will they learn it? What's more, meditation is a stressbuster - and with more than half of Britain's under-11s now suffering from school-related stress, and one in five suffering a stress-related health disorder, it clearly has its work cut out. "Constant activity is very much the norm for our kids," says Kerr. "They're always at this class or that class, and there's so much pressure on them. But almost everything they do is about the external world, and there's very little attention to finding out about yourself, on looking inward for a change.

"Meditation teaches children that it can be useful to be quiet and still sometimes. It can help them to learn to settle down at night and sleep better. It also makes them more self-aware, which helps confidence - and it helps boost their imagination, too."

Learning to use breathing to keep calm and relaxed helps children to deal with the unforeseen situations life throws at them, Kerr believes. According to mother-of-three Helen Kemmitt, whose son Alex, seven, and daughter Hannah, five, have both attended Kerr's classes, even when children are initially reluctant, they can be drawn in and can benefit.

"The other day my son was really upset by some dispute over Pokémon cards, and I said we'd try some meditation. He wasn't keen so I just went ahead with my daughter. We did one of those exercises where you tense up every part of your body and then relax it bit by bit. After a few minutes, Alex joined in and got really into it. His worries just floated away - it was something specific he could turn his attention to, it really took his mind off it."

So should we all be signing our children up for meditation classes? According to psychologist Professor David Fontana, co-author of Meditation for Children (Element), meditation appeals to some children and not others in the same way it appeals to some adults and not others - but he does think that many more young people could benefit from learning to listen to their inner voice.

"I think the time to introduce it is around the age they start school. There's no doubt it can increase a child's attention span and, as a result, improve memory. It allows the child to recognise the value of silence, and it teaches them to allow their body to relax and their mind to relax."

But just as important as helping children with the here and now, believes Fontana, is preparing them for the future. Many of the tensions that beset adults, he says, first make their appearance in childhood, so teaching youngsters to deal with stress today could mean creating calmer, more relaxed adults tomorrow.

Given his enthusiasm for the benefits of meditation, it's not surprising that Fontana would like to see trainee teachers tutored in its use, and schoolchildren taught its benefits; currently just a handful of schools have classroom meditation sessions.

But, he advises, meditation isn't something that has to be left to experts: anyone with any experience of it through yoga, or time to read about its benefits, could start to meditate and learn alongside their child or children. Here are his tips:

 Never force a child to meditate, or use it to punish a child for disruptive behaviour (or anything else).

&#149 Choose your moment: bedtime is often best for a child who finds it hard to settle at night. On the other hand, 75% of adults who meditate prefer to do so in the morning; some children are too irritable for it at night.

&#149 Begin by concentrating on simple breathing techniques, gradually progressing to visualisation.

 Christian Kerr's classes, Calm For Kids, are held at Chiswick Library in London. Call 020 8994 5093 or visit CalmForKids@aol.com

fields.headline: Down with girls!
fields.standfirst: Why do boys do badly at school? A new book blames feminists.
fields.trailText: Why do boys do badly at school? A new book blames feminists. By Angela Phillips
fields.body:
The Americans like to conduct their arguments at the top of their voices so that the shock waves reverberate across the pond. The latest book to cause a storm in the States - The War Against Boys, by Christina Hoff Sommers (Simon and Schuster) - hasn't even been published yet and already it is being serialised in the Sunday Times.

In the book, Hoff Sommers accuses the American education system in general, but feminist scholars in particular, of promoting gender reform that leaves boys out in the cold. Schools have spent so much time making sure girls feel comfortable, she says, that they have lost sight of what it is that boys need. While teachers fuss about sexual harassment, and otherwise try to impose "new versions of manhood" on their charges, boys are left lagging seriously behind their sisters. What is needed now, she insists, is a return to "discipline, respect and moral guidance".

Take a close look, however, and her analysis quickly runs into the sand: the fact is, male under-achievement at school predates modern feminism by centuries. Way back in 1693 John Locke was bewailing the fact that boys had such trouble learning Latin while girls took so easily to French (he saw it as a failure of method, not a failure of intellect). A schools inquiry in 1868 commented, "Girls come to you to learn; boys have to be driven." And as recently as the 60s the boys' 11 plus results were "skewed" to make sure that grammar schools weren't filled with diligent girls.

Feminism did have an impact, though - on the ambitions of girls. During the 80s girls' maths and science results really took off; and by the beginning of the 1990s, they were level pegging with boys. This might not have mattered had it not taken place within a rapidly changing industrial and social scene. Boys who prefer action to books can no longer be absorbed into the shrinking manufacturing sector and the army. The world of work wants soft skills not hard muscles.

It is against this background that Hoff Sommers wants to return to a golden age in which boys are boys and girls know their place. In an earlier article in Atlantic Monthly Hoff Sommers said: "To impugn his desire to become 'one of the boys' is to deny that a boy's biology determines much of what he prefers and is attracted to."

This view of masculinity as something pre-programmed, immutable, and yet at the same time capable of being fatally damaged by too much contact with femininity, lay at the heart of much of the initial reaction to "the gender gap" in this country in the mid 90s. Male education experts called for recruitment campaigns to get more men into teaching and for changes in the literature curriculum (not so many chick books like Wuthering Heights). They then jumped all over a single experiment in which Eastwood school at Leigh-on-Sea, Essex, divided its boys and girls for a number of key subjects. The results showed the same sort of improvements that might have been achieved by any reasonably focused managerial change (the fact that the improvement was much greater for girls was somehow glossed over) and gender separation was hailed as a way forward for boys. David Blunkett promised to "consider encouraging similar schemes".

Perhaps he then took a look at the rather larger-scale experiments in the inner cities in which some boys and girls have always been educated separately - single-sex schools. The evidence here is a lot less encouraging. Parents and children alike have voted with their feet. A macho all-male environment is not popular and doesn't improve results for boys. Indeed most of the worst results in the country are to be found in the boys' schools. In Hackney all but one of them have now closed; in Islington, one of the most famous - Highbury Grove - is now a co-ed and, in Tower Hamlets, where a large Asian population ensures a higher level of parental support for single sex schooling, all three boys schools are considered by Ofsted to be failing. One is already in "special measures" and the other two have "serious weakness".

In boys' schools, leaders emerge. They quickly establish an alternative authority, in opposition to the school, and they exact obedience to this anti- school ethos from the lower ranks. And it is the boys in the lower ranks who suffer. It is they who are bullied, teased, and forced to conform to the dominant masculine ideology of the group.

Parents whose sons have been recruited into the ranks of the anti-school army are rightly alarmed by this effect. The boys know what is happening but most feel powerless against the effect of peer group pressure. I asked a group of 14-year-olds at a school in Hackney what would happen if half the boys in the school thought that scoring goals in football would make them appear less hard, less manly. They all responded in the same way: the boys would avoid scoring. Not one boy suggested that winning would be more important than being laughed at. As one said: "They would do very badly. Most people are always out to look good. Most of their decisions depend on it."

So what is a parent to do? Those who are watching their daughters read Proust while signing up for classes in rocket science are hardly likely to buy the Hoff Sommers approach. Holding girls back is not going to push boys forward. Yet it is dispiriting to find that, at the age of 12, your son's language skills have gone into reverse and he seems to be interested only in mixing music or playing football. Hoff Sommers is right to recognise that this is now a problem both for boys themselves and for society at large, but it is the goal posts that have moved, not the players. In firing a broadside against feminist educationalists she is attacking the very people who are closest to finding a way through.

Madeleine Arnott, from the University of Cambridge school of education, has spent the last four years running a research project aimed at improving boys' attitudes to education. For Arnott, the issues lie in the different ways in which boys and girls regard school and themselves: "Girls want different things from education; they are seeking autonomy, autonomy is the pay off for literacy. What is the pay off for boys? How can we help boys to recognise that the world has changed, to adapt to it, and find a path through?"

It is this kind of thinking that is so desperately needed in schools. Martin Cribb is head of learning and school development in Tower Hamlets, London, and knows that providing a more "masculine" environment for boys is not the answer. Indeed it is a traditional, macho, masculine style that lies at the heart of the problem: "It is hard to recruit staff into a tough, inner city school. You don't want macho staff, you want people who are good teachers."

According to Arnott's research this is the right emphasis: "There is evidence that the major problem for boys is that they are holding on to very traditional masculine identities. Some are changing but very few compared to the girls. The world has changed. The question we have to ask is, are schools addressing this, are they helping the boys to change or are the traditional masculine values of the schools actually holding change back? Research indicates that it is not the sex of the teacher that matters but the approach. Male teachers with traditional views on masculinity may actually be confirming and colluding with laddish culture rather than challenging it."

Arnott is right, Hoff Sommers is wrong. As Adrienne Katz discovered in her research into teenage boys (Leading Lads, 1999) it is the boys who are less traditional in their masculinity, who are happier, more confident and more engaged with school. Perhaps it is time then, to start working with boys in schools on more useful ways of "looking good". Projects aimed at getting boys to talk about masculinity and what it means to them have now started in a handful of schools. It is too soon to tell whether they will close the gender gap but one thing we do know is that the boys like it. They don't want to be disciplined, they want to be listened to.

Boys who prefer action to books can no longer be absorbed into the shrinking manufacturing sector and the army. The world of work wants soft skills not hard muscles. It is against this background that Hoff Sommers wants to return to a golden age in which boys are boys and girls know their place. In an earlier article in Atlantic Monthly Hoff Sommers said: "To impugn his desire to become 'one of the boys' is to deny that a boy's biology determines much of what he prefers and is attracted to." This view of masculinity as something pre-programmed, immutable, and yet at the same time capable of being fatally damaged by too much contact with femininity, lay at the heart of much of the initial reaction to "the gender gap" in this country in the mid 90s. Male education experts called for recruitment campaigns to get more men into teaching and for changes in the literature curriculum (not so many chick books like Wuthering Heights). They then jumped all over a single experiment in which Eastwood school at Leigh-on-Sea, Essex, divided its boys and girls for a number of key subjects. The results showed the same sort of improvements that might have been achieved by any reasonably focused managerial change (the fact that the improvement was much greater for girls was somehow glossed over) and gender separation was hailed as a way forward for boys. David Blunkett promised to "consider encouraging similar schemes". Perhaps he then took a look at the rather larger-scale experiments in the inner cities in which some boys and girls have always been educated separately - single-sex schools. The evidence here is a lot less encouraging. Parents and children alike have voted with their feet. A macho all-male environment is not popular and doesn't improve results for boys. Indeed most of the worst results in the country are to be found in the boys' schools. In Hackney all but one of them have now closed; in Islington, one of the most famous - Highbury Grove - is now a co-ed and, in Tower Hamlets, where a large Asian population ensures a higher level of parental support for single sex schooling, all three boys schools are considered by Ofsted to be failing. One is already in "special measures" and the other two have "serious weakness". In boys' schools, leaders emerge. They quickly establish an alternative authority, in opposition to the school, and they exact obedience to this anti- school ethos from the lower ranks. And it is the boys in the lower ranks who suffer. It is they who are bullied, teased, and forced to conform to the dominant masculine ideology of the group. Parents whose sons have been recruited into the ranks of the anti-school army are rightly alarmed by this effect. The boys know what is happening but most feel powerless against the effect of peer group pressure. I asked a group of 14-year-olds at a school in Hackney what would happen if half the boys in the school thought that scoring goals in football would make them appear less hard, less manly. They all responded in the same way: the boys would avoid scoring. Not one boy suggested that winning would be more important than being laughed at. As one said: "They would do very badly. Most people are always out to look good. Most of their decisions depend on it." So what is a parent to do? Those who are watching their daughters read Proust while signing up for classes in rocket science are hardly likely to buy the Hoff Sommers approach. Holding girls back is not going to push boys forward. Yet it is dispiriting to find that, at the age of 12, your son's language skills have gone into reverse and he seems to be interested only in mixing music or playing football. Hoff Sommers is right to recognise that this is now a problem both for boys themselves and for society at large, but it is the goal posts that have moved, not the players. In firing a broadside against feminist educationalists she is attacking the very people who are closest to finding a way through. Madeleine Arnott, from the University of Cambridge school of education, has spent the last four years running a research project aimed at improving boys' attitudes to education. For Arnott, the issues lie in the different ways in which boys and girls regard school and themselves: "Girls want different things from education; they are seeking autonomy, autonomy is the pay off for literacy. What is the pay off for boys? How can we help boys to recognise that the world has changed, to adapt to it, and find a path through?" It is this kind of thinking that is so desperately needed in schools. Martin Cribb is head of learning and school development in Tower Hamlets, London, and knows that providing a more "masculine" environment for boys is not the answer. Indeed it is a traditional, macho, masculine style that lies at the heart of the problem: "It is hard to recruit staff into a tough, inner city school. You don't want macho staff, you want people who are good teachers." According to Arnott's research this is the right emphasis: "There is evidence that the major problem for boys is that they are holding on to very traditional masculine identities. Some are changing but very few compared to the girls. The world has changed. The question we have to ask is, are schools addressing this, are they helping the boys to change or are the traditional masculine values of the schools actually holding change back? Research indicates that it is not the sex of the teacher that matters but the approach. Male teachers with traditional views on masculinity may actually be confirming and colluding with laddish culture rather than challenging it." Arnott is right, Hoff Sommers is wrong. As Adrienne Katz discovered in her research into teenage boys (Leading Lads, 1999) it is the boys who are less traditional in their masculinity, who are happier, more confident and more engaged with school. Perhaps it is time then, to start working with boys in schools on more useful ways of "looking good". Projects aimed at getting boys to talk about masculinity and what it means to them have now started in a handful of schools. It is too soon to tell whether they will close the gender gap but one thing we do know is that the boys like it. They don't want to be disciplined, they want to be listened to.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: The average British kid now gets £3.10 pocket money a week. How much does your child get?
fields.trailText: The Question: The average British kid now gets £3.10 pocket money a week. How much does your child get?
fields.body:
Margaret Galea Mother of Michael, 8, Peter, 6, Thomas, 4, and baby Edward

None of my children get any pocket money yet, although we're shortly going to start with Michael. He'll get £1 a week, £1.50 if he keeps his room tidy. We haven't been tempted to give him pocket money until now because I think they tend to just spend it on rubbish if they're too young - they just rush out and go mad and it's nothing they really need. If we go somewhere like a funfair or a sale I'll give them a small amount each and tell them they can spend it on whatever they want, but when it's gone that's it. And they get money on their birthdays and when people visit, so they do have something to save up in their piggy banks.

Verdict: nothing

Michele Elliott mother of two sons, aged 18 and 21

I started mine on pocket money when they were around 10. I opened them bank accounts so they could learn to save, and we always gave them money as a monthly allowance so they learned to budget. When they were 10 they got around £20 a month, and as they got older and wanted to go out more they got more. You have to bear in mind that a night out with friends is easily going to cost £12 or £15 these days - my 18 year old currently gets £80 a month. When you live in London, even getting around costs a lot. But we've always helped out if there was something special they wanted to do that they couldn't afford from their allowance.

Verdict: £20 a week

Steve Smith Father of 8-year-old Amy

A couple of years ago we started giving Amy £1 a week, but she would just blow it on anything and we realised she was just too young. It almost became an obsession, she was always asking when she was getting her pocket money and then wanted to go straight out to spend it. So we stopped and only recently started it again. She gets £1 a week basic, more if she helps out with little jobs around the house. I want her to learn to save for things she wants, but I know it can seem difficult to a young child to save, say, £8 for a CD. So when she wants something, she saves up half the money she needs and we'll give her the rest.

Verdict: £1, more with jobs

Mark Moorhead Father of 6-year-old Christian and 4-year-old Joseph

My boys each get £1.50 a week from their grandad. That's the only money they get - they spend it on sweets or to buy a toy. Christian bought a Buzz Lightyear a few weeks ago. He saved £10 and borrowed £2.50 from us, and he paid us back over the next couple of weeks. Joseph is saving for a Woody. They are very good, and they love jangling their purses. They are always thrilled to be spending their own money, and over the last year they've become more aware of what to spend it on. At Christmas they drew £10 each out of their bank accounts and went Christmas shopping - they bought me a garlic sausage.

Verdict: £1.50
