fields.headline: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.standfirst: My infertility, your problem
fields.trailText: My infertility, your problem
fields.body:
Quick, call the tabloids. Perhaps it's a hazard of becoming a national newspaper columnist, but I've been taking drugs in public toilets. I can see the headlines now: "Barren columnist snorts drugs in BHS bog." Unfortunately, my secret drug habit doesn't give me any kind of buzz. Nor does it improve my social life. It just makes me feel sad. I shouldn't have to hide.

Of course, I indulge my infertility drug habit openly at home. But I've told my seven-year-old daughter I'm sniffing Suprefact (a sex hormone-reducing drug) for hayfever, which I've never suffered from. The subterfuge involved in concealing IVF treatment is considerable. Mysteriously, the most discreet method of medication - pill-popping - is the only one not included on my IVF action plan. I have to sniff, and will soon inject and insert things in places they aren't normally inserted. Of all the leaflets available in the Assisted Conception Unit it's a shame there isn't a list of excuses to give when I go in for my egg retrieval or embryo replacement, if I get that far.

Why do we hide our infertility? It's presumed to be because being barren is too big a stigma to bear openly. But the reason is not how I feel, but how the fertile world feels about me. The assumption is other people's happiness makes me unhappy.

Pregnant friends - uncharacteristically for people who are pregnant - don't prattle on to me about their morning sickness or sleepless nights. Women with small children don't tell me when they first walk, or talk. They don't want to upset me. I know this avoidance of toddler talk is meant kindly, but what these potent women don't understand is that it's the not talking to me that's so upsetting. I'm doubly excluded. First, for not having the joy of the first-hand experience myself. Then, because they're preventing me from enjoying their joy.

Perhaps I feel like this because I already have a daughter. I know childless women who cross the road rather than walk past Mothercare. But I can say, quite honestly, that I do not feel resentment, jealousy or whatever else it's imagined I might feel when I see swollen bellies or a child on a swing. But I can also say, quite honestly, that I know exactly what the fecund world feels for me. Pity. And it is being pitied that I do, very fiercely, resent.

That is one reason why I write this under a pseudonym. I have to protect my small but perfectly formed family from the crumbs of misplaced sympathy that would fall their way. They don't feel like sufferers. My infertility doesn't define or destroy them any more than it does me. Yet in the office corridor, as I pass those who "know", I notice the shake of a head and a whisper: "Such a nice girl, too . . ."

But my feelings towards other people's fecundity aren't the only feelings others read wrongly. My many miscarriages are also misread. Each loss is treated as bereavement. But I've never felt like I have lost a baby, even though I've had many a loss. It's rather the loss of plans I was barely aware I'd made. Even in early pregnancy, you stop buying snug-fitting clothes in case they won't fit in a few weeks. You rub out that pencilled-in holiday requiring jabs a pregnant woman shouldn't have. It was the loss of my future life, not another's, that I missed.

The hospital tried to recognise and respect my "blighted ovums". After each miscarriage, my boyfriend and I would be shown into a very small, softly decorated room, with just two comfortable chairs, a book and a mighty box of Kleenex. In the book, which looked like a wedding photo album, other couples had recorded their own miscarriages and stillbirths, raw outpourings written at the greatest moment of grief. My boyfriend dubbed it The Dead Baby Room. After a couple of visits, we asked not to be shown inside any more. It wasn't because it was too painful; it was too maudlin. We didn't want our feelings to be elevated beyond what they were, a brief spell of straightforward sadness.

I may keep my barrenness to myself. But I do not mope about it. So please save your pity for yourself. I've got a life to get on with.

fields.headline: American Mom
fields.trailText: Ten years ago if you told a native New Yorker that Times Square would become a dream destination for parents, they would have suggested you might like to visit any one of the city's 10,000 therapists. Today, those shrinks have no one to talk to.
fields.body:
Ten years ago if you told a native New Yorker that Times Square would become a dream destination for parents, they would have suggested you might like to visit any one of the city's 10,000 therapists. Today, those shrinks have no one to talk to.

The city has practised tough love with the sleazy strip joints, tacky bookstores and drug dealers who called Times Square home, and sent them packing. In their wake, a mecca of neon-lit theme shops and restaurants (plus the ubiquitous Disney store) have sprung up.

It's enough to make the locals pine for the bad old days, but Mayor Guiliani, who masterminded the transformation, is unrepentant. The new Times Square has made American parents with fat wallets happy, and that was the plan.

Well, they were happy.

This month the National Rifle Association, the largest pro gun lobby in the US, announced plans to open a theme restaurant and shopping complex in Times Square. The theme, naturally, would be guns. "What will their sign say, 'Over a Million Killed'?" snapped one outraged parent.

The NRA Sports Blast complex will offer virtual-reality trap and skeet shooting, hunting clothes for sale and a restaurant serving wild game. The idea that a theme restaurant will glamorise shooting and sell killing as "family fun" after so many devastating school shootings has parents outraged.

"Parents are furious," says Kim Mariniani of Handgun Control Inc, a Washington DC gun control lobby group. "How do you say to your children 'We don't want you to play with guns, we think they are dangerous' when there is a theme restaurant promoting the idea that guns are fun and harmless?"

But NRA Executive Vice President Wayne LaPierre thinks parents are over-reacting. "More Americans participate in shooting sports than in basketball, baseball and other sports," he said, suggesting the complex would be as innocent as one that had a soccer theme.

Mariniani says local parents, who have already picketed in New York, are now going to step up their efforts in association with Handgun Control Inc to drive the NRA out of town.

"We have 30,000 gun deaths a year in this country, and 12 a day are children. Parents here are not going to let the NRA make money glorifying guns by selling burgers. No way."

fields.headline: The BBC's annual report
fields.standfirst:
BBC governors have signalled radical changes for the corporation as we enter the digital age. Derek Brown explains why

Special report
fields.trailText: BBC governors have signalled radical changes for the corporation as we enter the digital age. We explain why
fields.body:
Is it good news for Auntie?
That is in the eye of the beholder. Greg Dyke, the irrepressible new director general, is as ever upbeat in his first annual review, which lays stress on the bigger share of resources being spent on programmes. Mr Dyke announced a £58m fillip for programme makers, funded from £70m of efficiency savings. But the BBC's own governors are caustically critical of the quality of programmes on BBC1 and BBC2, saying they were "simply too variable".

What kind of programmes do BBC governors like?
They give top marks to The Royle Family, dinnerladies and The Vicar of Dibley sitcoms, along with the history programme Walking with Dinosaurs. They are less impressed with early-evening offerings on BBC1. "The average quality of programmes across the year on the channel is still not good enough," they say. "BBC1 is not held in the same degree of affection by the public as it once was. Winning that affection back is vital to the future success of the whole BBC."

What of the BBC's new media offerings?
The governors are lavish in their praise of BBC Online. The number of regular users has risen to 3.8m a month. The service, which cost £32m in the past year, is to get £8m more, partly to fund the new BBC Sport Online network. The BBC chairman, Sir Christopher Bland, is also keen for the corporation to speed up its entry to the digital age. Speaking on Radio 4's Today programme he inserted the phrase "the digital home" into virtually every sentence. He will doubtless expand on the theme when he goes online tomorrow.

How much did Auntie spend last year?

The report shows total spending of £2,318m, of which more than half - £1,244m - went on the two terrestrial television channels. The financial statements are upbeat about the latest licence fee increase, which kicked in too late to affect the latest accounts. The report also notes with satisfaction that the number of licence fee evasions are at a record low.

What else is in the report?
Whatever else it is accused of, the BBC cannot be called secretive. The full report is presented on its website in exhaustive, glossily illustrated detail. (You can even compare it with last year's report). Alongside are pages and pages of Beebfacts. There is a lengthy page devoted to the 400 awards won last year, and another spelling out who runs what. You can also ferret around for a job. The contents page, incidentally, includes an item called "Ensuring the BBC behaves responsibly".

fields.headline: Susan Kramer
fields.standfirst: Liberal Democrat mayoral candidate Susan Kramer was live online on Thursday March 30, answering your questions on her election campaign and plans for London. She gave her views from transport to the yuppification of the city to cooperating with the government. This is an edited transcript; click here to read the full debate and have your say.
fields.trailText: Liberal  Democrat mayoral candidate Susan Kramer was live online on  Thursday March 30, answering your questions on her election campaign and plans for London. She gave her views from transport to the yuppification of the city to cooperating with the government. This is an edited transcript.
fields.body:
kris99: Susan - who's getting your second preference?

Susan Kramer: I am totally focused on winning on May 4. Anyway, you don't tell Liberal Democrats how to use their votes so I'll let the other candidates worry about second preferences.

A000457: What's your catchphrase going to be?

SK: Kramer can do it! (Do the job and win the race)

A000457: It's not exactly catchy, is it? Surely a shorter one would be "Kramer can do the job and come third in the race"?

markwhitehouse: Susan, how long do you think it will be before the mayor and the assemly will actually gain some substantive powers rather than the token 'face-of-London' which the next incumbent will assume? Also, would you go along with the previous LibDem policy and lobby to have the mayor sitting in the assembly and chosen by its members rather than Londoners generally?

SK: markwhitehouse, it's crucial that the mayor doesn't go off on an ego trip. Even though the powers of the assembly are weak, I would work with the assembly to get real scrutiny on problems in London, like inequality in the health service, and ask assembly members, for example, to join advisory boards to achieve our goals on the environment, like doubling recycling. This new government level will only make sense if it forgets prize fighting politics and works with Londoners, businesses, the voluntary sector, etc. to get problems solved.

Interestingly, Liberal Democrats will hold the balance of power in the assembly, which is the best guarantee that it will be effective.

bazac: How much cooperation do you expect to receive from the government if elected?

SK: Londoners want a voice and I have always said I will put responsibility to Londoners ahead of any party interests. I expect the government to take the same view which means we should find it relatively easy to work together in the interests of 7m Londoners. I prefer using quiet persuasion and rational argument. It is not my intention to make the government lose face, to score points. But my whole working experience has taught me to be very tough when necessary.

Just a note of encouragement, if you look in other countries mayors of one party tend to be very successful in working with governments of another party. It forces everyone to behave like a grown up.

nigellewis: Transport is the burning issue of the campaign, it seems, mainly because that is the only important issue the mayor will be able to influence. Am I right? What are your policies? I have taken to the motorbike rather than endure the torture that is public transport. How those millions of poor people who do it everyday is beyond me. Some policies please (rather than rhetoric!)

SK: nigellewis, it isn't just transport.

My priorities are: rescuing public transport, reducing crime, revitalising our deprived communities. Everything I do will also carry forward the principles of equality (tackling discrimination), environmental sustainability and engagement with Londoners.

Specific policies: Keeping the tube in public hands and raising the money to rescue transport through issuing bonds. Making the bus system fast and reliable - enforcing bus priority, expanding the priority network, revising the routes so buses go where needed. Integrating bus, tube and train but also power two-wheelers, cycling and walking. (I notice you use a motorbike and I am determined to get coordinated free and secure parking for motorbikes.) Integrated communication so that you can use your mobile phone or pager to find out when the bus or train is coming and where the traffic jams are. I've got lots more to say but maybe this is enough for starters.

stgon: But doesn't this transport congestion problem require a more radical solution, like proactively making it difficult and expensive for people to use private cars in the city centre? Other European cities (like Munich, although I know it's much smaller) have done this, to the benefit of the quality of life in the city. People are addicted to their cars and are not being tempted away by public transport on its own. Look what happened to John Prescott, its gonna take more that a photo-op with a cycle helmet to sort the traffic chaos issue out. What exactly is to be done?

SK: Congestion charging - I will introduce this in my first term as mayor to discourage the terrible congestion and pollution that blights central London. It will apply only to central London on working days during working hours. I will not introduce it for at least two and a half years so that Londoners can see improvements already beginning in public transport. Every penny will go to public transport. I want to use a travelcard approach so that when you pay to use the road you can then use bus, tube and train for free.

Please email me with other transport questions including expanding the system. Surely someone has questions on the Met, or jobs, or affordable housing or saving our communities.

sgcc2: Okay Susan, what can be done to stop the yuppification of certain areas? Once Islington had people of all classes living cheek by jowl, now few can afford to live there (and similar processes in Borough, Bethnal Green...) Are the poor going to have to move to Walthamstow?

SK: sgcc2, London is becoming a ghetto of the very rich and people on housing benefit with the middle squeezed out. I will use the money for regeneration which comes to the mayor to reinforce and re-establish genuinely mixed communities. New developments will need to include social and affordable housing right alongside homes for private ownership. At this moment I am joining residents in Tooley Street who have been threatened with the demolition of their community by Southwark council so that the land can be sold for private development. Ironically, the rise in the value of Tooley Street is largely due to its proximity to the new, grand building for the mayor.

We can increase the amount of affordable housing in London by changing planning rules. I also intend to set up community banks in London's more deprived areas to provide financing for schemes like shared ownership (where people on low incomes can buy half their house and get on the property ladder).

matbaz: What have you achieved and what will you strive to do for lesbian and gay Londoners?

SK: I would lead the fight against discrimination against lesbians and gays. The Met must treat queer bashing as harshly as other hate crimes. I want to expand the liason committees between local police and gays and lesbians. My gay and lesbian friends should feel as comfortable in any part of the city as they do on Old Compton Street and I would be glad to support Gay Pride and other celebrations of this key part of our community.

dreagplaip: Are you in favour of 24-hour licensing for London's pubs and bars?

SK: dreagpliap, London is increasingly a 24-hour city. I want to work with the boroughs to set up zones where bars, clubs, pubs, etc. can be open all hours. We will need 24-hour transport, which means many more buses and black cabs. Once we've cracked the maintenance backlog, I want the tube to be 24-hours, at least on weekends.

FruitCake: Susan, tell us about your cat. Are you sure you can you count on Whittington's support throughout the campaign?

SK: FruitCake, my cat Whittington says I can count on his support provided I feed him and you read his diary (reachable via my website). His key policy is dog wardens, dog wardens, dog wardens.

bobkenyon: Since semi-privatisation of London buses, I've noticed that the drivers drive faster, more recklessly and more jerkily. I've seen old people inside the bus knocked off their feet by the jerks. They won't stop exactly at the bus stop any more but about ten feet away and get impatient, even with old ladies of 84, if you don't run to get on. How about a more civilised driving style?

SK: Civilised bus driving - you've been on the same bus as I have, bobkenyon! I have already told the bus operators that drivers need more training and I will make sure London buses assist with the financing for it.

SK: Regretfully, I have to go to the next meeting. Please keep your questions coming through my email and website.

info@susankramer.org

www.susankramer.org

Thank you, Susan.

fields.headline: Stack of ability
fields.standfirst: Why are some employers still reluctant to hire people with learning disabilities? Kendra Inman on a new guide that dispels myths
fields.trailText: Why are some employers still reluctant to hire people with learning disabilities? Kendra Inman on a new guide that dispels myths.
fields.body:
If Richard Borowski has a quiet moment during his working day in the House of Commons library, he snatches a few minutes to improve his design for a car of the future. His employment support worker, Charlotte Meyer, disapproves.

Borowski, 25, has a learning disability and Meyer, of the Pathway employment service, thinks that frequent breaks in the day suggest his employer isn't working him hard enough. "They were unnecessarily worried about giving him anything he couldn't do so I told them they had to push him a bit harder."

The government sees getting people into work as a way of tackling social exclusion. But just one in 10 people with a severe learning disability is in work, according to the charity Mencap, which this week launches a guide, Taking Care of Business, to encourage employers to do more.

Borowski works in the Commons library's health and safety department as a clerical assistant, filing and photocopying. His employer was initially nervous about taking him on to the staff and he joined on work experience. However, he quickly proved himself and recently secured a three-year contract.

Borowski likes to dress smartly, typically in a suit and shades, and is proud of his job, says Meyer. He is also unequivocal about his need to work. "I really wanted to earn money and I was quite confident I could," he says. "They are really nice and understanding. I've never had any complaints."

At the beginning, Borowski needed intensive support from a "job coach" provided by Pathway - which is run by Mencap - and had to get to grips with tasks like learning the journey to work. Then the support gradually decreased and now he's seen by the agency on average only every six weeks.

Many more people like Borowski could work if they were given the chance, says Tom Berry, campaigns officer at Mencap. Instead, thousands while away the hours at home or in day centres which, although comforting and friendly, do little to make them feel included in mainstream society. Privately, employers admit to being reluctant to take on people with learning disabilities because of concerns about the cost in time and money.

Mencap is launching its guide as part of national learning disability week. The charity hopes to dispel the myths about people with learning disabilities and show anxious employers how much help is available for them if they take the plunge.

"They worry about health and safety issues or that they will have to make an enormous investment in training," says Berry. "But they're not fully aware of the benefits."

Previous campaigns of this type have emphasised an employer's duty to take on disabled people. This drive, by contrast, is adopting the language of marketing and is putting what Berry calls "the business case" for doing so.

According to Mencap, employees with learning disabilities take fewer days off sick, they are more reliable and likely to stay longer with one employer. Employing them also has a positive impact on a company's image.

For those who remain unconvinced, the new guide reminds companies that under the Disability Discrimination Act 1995, they are barred from discriminating against people with learning disabilities when it comes to recruitment, training, promotion or dismissal.

Businesses that overcome their qualms are "generally very pleased with what they get for their money", says Berry. "People with learning disabilities are happy to do repetitive jobs that other members of the workforce wouldn't do," he adds. "Once they've learned the job, they can be very productive."

Susan Anderson, director of human resources policy at the Confederation of British Industry, agrees with Mencap's approach. She says employers' perceptions, like those of the rest of society, need challenging. "They need to be made to see the benefits."

Businesses interested in taking more people with learning disabilities can seek help from a range of schemes. The supported employment programme subsidises employers so they can pay staff the going rate for the job, even if their output is lower than that of their colleagues.

The New Deal for disabled people can also provide help, but Mencap has yet to find out how many people with learning disabilities are benefiting. While the government's own figures suggest a shortfall of 40,000 supported employment places, the charity thinks the true figure could be three times that.

Right Guy for the job

Guy Morley has always dreamed of owning his own home. Since his first pay packet, he has stashed away every spare penny to help fund a deposit. Now, at 38, his thrift is about to pay off. He is in the process of buying his first house, 10 minutes' walk from the family home in Louth, Lincolnshire. And the purchase is being funded with the help of wages from his job as a grocery assistant at a Somerfield supermarket where he works 30 hours a week.

Morley is proof that, with a little help, people with learning disabilities can live full and active lives. "It's nice there," he says of his workplace. "Everyone knows me. They all say: 'Hi Guy. How are you doing?'" The work is not difficult, he explains. "When I got there they showed me what to do, where to put things. Once I'd got the hang of it, I did it automatically. It keeps me fit and I like helping customers."

Brenda Househam, personnel manager at the store, admits that Morley does get a little more attention than other staff. "But not much more. He's a good worker and an excellent timekeeper."

Although things have worked out for Morley, he has not always been so fortunate. It was only when his family moved to Louth, and came into contact with a pro-active job centre, that he was put in touch with Pathway. He joined Somerfield last August through a supported employment scheme run by Remploy, the biggest employer of disabled workers, under which Somerfield pays him the going rate for the job but receives a subsidy.

Previously, the family felt poorly served. Ann Morley, Guy's mother, recalls: "We weren't even claiming all the benefits we were entitled to."

 Taking Care of Business is available free from Mencap's public liaison unit (tel: 020-7454 0454).

fields.headline: Town mouse
fields.standfirst: Liz Whittaker finds rural poverty far harder than giving up her eccentric individuality
fields.trailText: Liz Whittaker finds rural poverty far harder than giving up her eccentric individuality
fields.body:
Despite numerous attempts over the past months on the part of formidable gatherings of rural dwellers intent on bringing home to city types the deprivations they suffer, no one believes them. Living in the country, it seems, is still seen by those who live in cities to be an advantage that far outweighs what small sacrifices are suffered.

Many city dwellers entertain the fantasy that because the country is wonderful for a weekend, one day they will make their homes there. White-painted cottage, pub around the corner, golf nearby, perhaps even sailing if one combines seaside with country. So when the country folk start shouting and saying that life is not all cream teas and happy hay rides, do they have a point? And who's listening?

Well, I am, for one. For more than 20 years I lived miles from the nearest town, in the under-populated back of beyond. When I left it, I wept. But I also rejoiced. I was finally going to get to be a townie, fashionable, social, comfortably off, have-it-all.

When you first hit town after a life in the sticks, the single biggest thing you miss is permission to be an individual. Fitting in becomes the yardstick, the collective is more important than the one. In the country, you can believe that life in the big world is made up of small groups of people like you relating to each other. From simple courtesies with acquaintances which create the backdrop of your own personal drama, to the live, loving and hating within relationships of family and friends - you matter. You matter because there are so few people about that everyone becomes known - name, work, quirks, your family, your life.

Even if you are a private person, in a rural community you are seen, commented on, more often than not left alone, if that's what you want - but you matter, because you are part of a very small world. My social life in the country was 100% better, and my idea of fashionable was regarded as eccentric perhaps, but not, like here, downright odd. Here in the city it is label and cost that matter with clothes, not style or uniqueness. Conformity in all things holds when you get here, despite what many believe.

Comfortably off? Not quite, but better than the living I could earn in the country. Have it all? You jest. Urban life stinks. Why don't people say so? The size of it and the numbers of people in it, and the need for all those people to try to be the same - all led by the same must-haves, from labels to lap-tops to this year's car, makes for competitive living which is destructive and dangerous.

Last week I went back for a visit. I returned to the empty wilderness where I had lived. Just as when I left, employment remains low, money is still desperately tight. Friends and family who are still there live as they always did, pretty much from hand to mouth. They still pick up any kind of temporary work they can - sometimes quite unsuitable for them, sometimes way below their abilities, and the pay is minimal. They live in breathtakingly lovely places with views that bring tears to your eyes, but they're broke. They were broke then and they're broke now.

Justifying to my country friends why I choose to live in an unquestionably less-than-beautiful urban environment, I am forced to admit that I hate it. But I also recognise that poverty is an even more despicable state than the obstacles one has to take on board in the city. They shake their heads - how can anyone value money higher than a healthy, natural environment?

Living in an area where employment is high and reasonably paid has advantages. You don't feel suicidal when the electricity bill arrives. You don't have to count pennies every time you buy a coffee or put petrol in the car. But the price is high. Because, whatever the advantages, they are ultimately subsumed by the anonymity of it all, the pointlessness of life, heightened by the incapacity to move freely, to speak to a stranger, to walk in spaces that aren't thronging with other people, where there is no room to breathe without breathing on someone else.

And that, in the end, is why no one listens to those who go on about the decline in rural employment and the end of the green belt and other equally relevant matters. It is because, although they may have less money, and their material prospects may be less than glittering, they do have something approaching a life they can call their own. And that is seen as most unfair by the city types who know they've sold theirs for a mess of pottage.

And that is seen as most unfair by the city types who know they've sold theirs for a mess of pottage.

fields.headline: Party politics
fields.standfirst: Glastonbury celebrates its 30th birthday this weekend. For George McKay, its links with the peace and environmental movements mean that it has always been more than just a music festival
fields.trailText: Glastonbury celebrates its 30th birthday this weekend. For George McKay, its links with the peace and environmental movements mean that it has always been more than just a music festival
fields.body:
In the Land of Youth

There are pleasant places,

Green joyful woods and fields...

These lyrics are from the libretto of the 1914 opera, The Immortal Hour, the best-known work of the bohemian composer, Communist party member and self-styled English Wagner, Rutland Boughton. He was the organiser of the original Glastonbury Festival, which ran from 1914 to 1926 (interrupted only by the first world war), offering Arthurian legend and a form of alternative Englishness to audiences which included George Bernard Shaw and Thomas Hardy.

When Boughton was in town, the area was invaded by long-haired alternative types, music lovers rumoured to run naked round Glastonbury Tor at sunrise, enthusiasts for free love, spiritualism and vegetarianism. Sound familiar? Shaw warned Boughton against "introducing Glastonbury to Moscow", while members of the Workers' Theatre Movement described him as "up to his neck in money and down to his ass in long hair".

The Avalonian spirit of festival returned half a century after Boughton, when a nearby farmer, Michael Eavis, put on a mini-rock festival in September 1970, inspired by the sixties' tribal gatherings such as Monterey, Woodstock and the Isle of Wight. Today, Glastonbury remains an eccentric English space, where the ley line meets the leylandii, where King Arthur's resting place, the Isle of Avalon, is disturbed this weekend only by, well, 100,000 pairs of feet, a similar number of mo bile phones, superloud rock music and even louder techno - the massed ranks of the me and E generations combined.

Yet there are other ways of looking at Glastonbury. The spiritualist writer Dion Fortune was an admirer of Boughton's project there. An early champion of female spirituality, Fortune recognised that "the veil is thin", that Glastonbury is a spiritual hotspot where we can glimpse the genius loci of our preference, whether pagan or Christian, Arthurian or new age. She wrote in her 1934 paean to the town, Avalon in the Heart, that "the past lives on at Glastonbury. All about us it stirs and breathes, quiet, but living and watching." For Andrew Blake, professor of cultural studies at King Alfred's College, Winchester, that past is political: the Glastonbury festivals of both Boughton and Eavis are "involved in a historic imaginary which stretches back through the long history of Arthurian literature and music . . . to propose an imagined rural, mystical and at least semi-pagan Britain".

It's no surprise then, in this atavistic rural space, to find peace and green campaign movements favoured. The Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament was founded in 1958 with what we can see now as a strong yearning for lost British global authority. CND's nostalgia was for a less technologically dangerous age, of course, but was also inflected with a British sense of moral superiority, the flipside of Empire. JB Priestley wrote at the time that nuclear war "is not war as it used to be" - presumably because the upstart US, with its showy hydrogen bomb, now ruled the waves. David Widgery described the first CND Aldermaston March of Easter 1958 as "a student movement before its time, a marching pop festival".

Contrary to its earnest image, perhaps, CND has always embraced festival culture, been open to what the 1960s called "play power", what the 1990s called "party and protest". The introduction of US-controlled Cruise missiles in the 1980s sparked the campaign's second great surge of popular support. Alternative lifestyles contributed significantly to CND, from Greenham Common to the Peace Convoy, from the anarchopunk movement to the Glastonbury Festival. Glastonbury then was "the CND festival"; the 1987 programme cover gave Elvis Costello and CND chairman Bruce Kent equal billing. The £1m raised by the festival for CND during the decade helped underwrite spectacular events such as the London CND carnivals, as well as the more mundane national structure of regional offices.

In some ways, CND made Glastonbury. Prior to the campaign's involvement in 1981, the festival had only happened three times, once as a free event and on the other two occasions losing money. Michael Eavis acknowledges that "1981 was our breakthrough: 24,000 people turned up, delivering a £20,000 profit". CND's international profile and relative organisational sophistication meant transatlantic headliners, efficient ticket sales, and a large pool of committed volunteers over festival weekends. By the end of the decade though, "CND was getting smaller as the festival was getting bigger," recalls Tony Myers, of CND. "Couple that with serious internal tensions within CND to do with the Gulf war and you see how things just moved apart."

Glastonbury changed its main beneficiaries in 1992 to Greenpeace and, because of its campaigning against the arms trade, Oxfam. Greenpeace had started in 1969, with a ship trying to obstruct US nuclear testing at Amchitka Island, so that thread remains. Festival finances are available on the official website ('glasnostbury', as someone said a few years ago).

For 1999, out of a total budget of around £7m, £2.5m was spent on entertainment and £600,000 donated to the big international campaigns and to less glamorous local groups. Wookey Hole Cricket Club got £2,880, Shepton Mallet Christmas Lights Fund got £2,000, for instance. Such embracing of global and local concerns is characteristic of the way the festival operates, is part of its ideology and of its eccentric charm. Interestingly, £1.5m was spent on policing and other security. "It's a police benefit gig," said some of the more hardline countercultural figures.

Yet Eavis hasn't shied away from some of the more difficult groups who make a claim on the festival either. In the mid-1980s, when the Stonehenge Free Festival was banned and new travellers were seriously demonised by police, Glastonbury festival was a temporary haven for them on more than one occasion. Until 1990, new travellers were given free access, though more recently they have been directed to fields a few miles from the main festival site.

Eavis told me: "I've worked with the [Peace] Convoy and with travellers over the years, negotiated with them one-to-one, accommodated them when I could or when I've had to. My approach is a bit different to [Stonehenge guardians] English Heritage's, isn't it?" While relations between the festival and new travellers are not easy, the fact that the festival makes the effort is a sign that it tries to practise what it preaches.

Glastonbury's environmental ambitions were expressed by co-organiser Andrew Kerr at the legendary 1971 free Glastonbury Fayre: "If the festival has a specific intention it is to create an increase in the power of the universe, a heightening of consciousness and a recognition of our place in the function of this, our tired and molested planet."

The eco-awareness returned in 1984, when the old Green Party Gatherings, which had sometimes been held at Worthy Farm, relocated to the festival itself. These transformed into the Green Fields, where today you encounter tepee circles, wood turning and new age inner-self workshops. These solar-powered spaces offer a mishmash of instant histories to cater for the most atavistic deep green tastes, best symbolised perhaps by the 1990s neo-megalithic stone circle that wouldn't be out of place in a faux past theme park. In fact, didn't Legoland in Windsor have a Stonehenge scene for a while, complete with new travellers and police?

The Glastonbury Festival's links with CND and with eco-groups such as Greenpeace, are evidence of a longer-lasting effort to present or explore different ideas and solutions, possibly counter-modern ones, by re-examining alternative traditions from real and mythic pasts alike. This merging of past and politics is one of the festival's lasting achievements.

Each year, it seems, rumours spread that this will be the last. Michael Eavis is in his sixties now, while his wife Jean sadly died last year. In spite of my research, I don't know what the future holds for Glastonbury Festival, though I'm pretty sure I'd rather it simply stopped than got taken over by one of the commercial festival organisations. After all, there are worse options for an atavistic culture and politics than to become part of the past.

 George McKay is professor of English and American studies at the University of Central Lancashire. His new book, Glastonbury: A Very English Fair, is published this week by Gollancz (price £14.99).

fields.headline: Streets ahead
fields.standfirst: Hilary Wainwright on lessons we should learn from the south
fields.trailText: Hilary Wainwright on lessons we should learn from the south
fields.body:
According to opinion polls, one of the biggest cities in the world - Brazil's sprawling industrial centre, São Paulo - is set to elect a mayor who will open budget decisions directly to the people. While we are used to responding to appeals for the street children of Rio, the idea that the south can teach us political and technical lessons is a novel one.

Last month, Manchester council and its neighbour, Salford, were host to Evanildo Da Silva, from a radical church network that assists the direct involvement of communities in their cities' budgets across Brazil. For 15 years, in about 80 cities, the radical Workers' Party (Partido Trabhalidores, or PT) has been working with smaller parties and community movements to create the process of participatory budgeting. One city, Porto Alegre, won the UN Habitat prize for the best-governed city. The process is now, under community pressure, implemented by conservative governments - as in Recife, where Da Silva is based.

The brokers for Da Silva's visit were Oxfam's UK poverty programme and Community Pride, an action research group created by Church Action Against Poverty and the main Manchester churches, specifically, according to organiser Ed Cox, "to discover how far participatory budgeting could be applied to British cities".

The town halls on either side of the River Irwell differ on how far local people should be involved in running their cities. Manchester's approach is explicitly about customer care - improving the quality of services run by the council. Kath Robinson, the council's deputy leader, says: "We do not devolve decision-making, but we do consult. We have introduced co-ordinators of ward plans who work with customers."

Salford, on the other hand, is devolving 2% of the council's budget - including its regeneration funds - to be decided by community committees. The council's deputy leader, John Merry, argues: "We want more direct participative involvement in budgeting than the formal electoral process allows." But he adds: "We're not about to dissolve ourselves into community committees; it's a question of the right level of decision-making for the appropriate problem."

Councillors and officials from both cities were impressed by Da Silva. Not surprisingly, perhaps, because what makes the Brazilian experiment so important is that it achieves the goals of customer care - an efficiently run city - through sharing power with the community.

The commitment to popular democracy stems from the history of the 600,000-strong PT, the main opposition to the "third way" party of President Fernando Enrique Cardoso. The PT's socialist ideology comes from liberation theology and the new left, rather than orthodox Marxism or conventional social democracy, and looks to popular movements for its vision of democracy.

The PT's prospective mayor of São Paulo, Martha Supplicy, explains: "As we got near to government we believed we had to share political power with [popular movements] and the community." They started with the budget, she says, because it was where corruption thrived in its secrecy.

In Porto Alegre, around 15% of the budget - "the investment plan" - is subject to the participatory process. In general it is a yearly cycle that begins with neighbourhood meetings that debate their needs and elect delegates to regional forums which negotiate priorities, applying criteria that have been agreed with the city government the previous year. These meetings elect representatives to the budgetary council, where government and community representatives meet weekly to thrash out a proposal, which then goes to the municipal council for a final round of open negotiations and agreement.

The importance of the "participatory budgets" in the PT-run municipalities is that, through trial and error, they have developed an effective institutional framework for sharing power. They have created a democratic public sphere which is not just an influence on government but an independent source of democratic power, making the state more accountable to society than the periodic vote could ever do.

Tarso Gennaro, one originator of the process, says it is not easy. "There are many conflicts of interest. Some officials feel that the participatory budget is a bit of a nuisance. They want things done quickly."

Quick fixes would not have achieved the first significant redistribution of public resources towards the urban poor, nor big improvements in housing and education, as well as municipal developments in transport, recycling and telecommunications. Global surveys confirm that participatory budgeting has meant efficient, democratic government.

The Brazilian experience confounds conventional wisdom that the management of industrial societies is incompatible with popular participation. On the contrary, the redistributive benefits and increased citizens' awareness suggests that participatory democracy is necessary to overcome a growing gulf between increasingly reluctant voters and the state. No wonder that Salford and Manchester, concerned about turnouts of below 25% in the May local elections, are keen to learn from the south.

 Hilary Wainwright is a senior research associate at Manchester University's International Centre for Labour Studies.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: • Half a lifetime ago, Satish Kumar walked from India to Britain with a twinkle in his eye. He's still here, undaunted, and for 25 years has been editing Resurgence, a gloriously idiosyncratic mag devoted to the environment, art and spirituality. Resurgence is produced on a shoestring but Satish has never failed to persuade the world's leading thinkers, activists, environmentalists and philosophers to write. This Saturday, Vandana Shiva, Jane Goodall, George Monbiot, Anita Roddick, Andrew Marr, Sir Crispin Tickell and Jonathon Porritt, among other regular contributors, will be taking part in a suitably diverse all-day jubilee "conference" at the Royal Geographical Society in London, to celebrate those 25 years. Tickets are available on the door and cost £25. For more information, or for a free copy of the magazine, call 07977-538424.

 Capitalism's got a bad press of late and anti-capitalists are scoring lots of points. But now we have anti-anti capitalists who like to write satirical nursery rhymes. Here's one, sent anonymously from Oxford:

The Grand Old Duke of York,

He had 10,000 men

They turned their guns on him

and set up an anti-militaristic,

anti-capitalist vegan community

on a hill in Wales

And when they were up they were,

like, really high man,

And when they were down it was

because it was seriously bad shit

And when it rained they went to live in

a van and sign on with 10,000 dogs

on strings

Here's another:

Christmas is coming

The geese are getting fat

Let's mask up

And go down the farm at night

And free them From their capitalist prison

 Ominous news. Ravi Kanbur, a highly respected US professor, was the leading author of the World Bank's upcoming World Development Report on poverty. Far from being dull, this was expected to be a massive statement which would set benchmarks and the tone for much of the frenzied debate about present-day capitalism and globalisation. For once, the World Bank critics were delighted and there was real hope that he would open up whole areas of previously taboo official debate. But last week he resigned, saying he was concerned about "unreasonable pressure" being put on him to tone down sections on globalisation. So who was twisting his arm? Step forward Larry Summers, the US treasury secretary. Summers, a former World Banker himself, famously wrote a memo some years ago suggesting that the rich should export their toxic waste to poor countries on the basis that the poor lived shorter lives and presumably would not mind so much. Alex Wilks, coordinator of the Bretton Woods Project, says: "It raises questions of who really calls the shots at the bank and what evidence or opinions about the impacts of globalisation they are trying to suppress."

 Better news from the global coalface. A year-long campaign by environmentalists, human rights groups, trades unions and other non-governmental organisations has persuaded the UN Development Programme to abandon plans to create a global sustainable development facility. But why should this arcane body pose a problem? Well, it was to be a partnership between the UNDP and some 15 global corporations, including Dow Chemical, mining giant Rio Tinto, energy conglomerate ABB and biotech leader Novartis. The UNDP had planned to sell them its international network of offices, high-level governmental contacts and its reputation at a bargain price.

 So what's it like being a poor community dependent on or living next to a giant multinational? Ask the very poor community that lives round the Monsanto subsidiary, Flexsys Rubber Chemicals Ltd, near Wrexham, north Wales. Many people there earn their money from the plant, but almost everyone accepts that they could be polluted. Last week, a High Court judge approved a £180,000 payout to 304 local people, including 55 children, following an October 1995 hydrogen sulphide gas leak, when people suffered vomiting, nausea, headaches, asthma attacks, sore throats and stinging eyes. For many, it was a case of déjà senti; the previous year, there had been another leak and Flexsys had had to pay significant compensation to 300 people. "The case highlights the importance of community civil actions in deterring similar, or more serious, incidents from arising in the future, a role unlikely to have been achieved by the criminal prosecution of the company", said a lawyer from the Leigh Day practice in London who worked with the community.

To add insult to injury, within days of the payout, Flexsys announced it would make 160 people redundant.

 For many people in Britain, last week's news that Germany is to phase out nuclear power was a good reason to celebrate green governance. But the deal threatens to actually destroy the whole movement, according to many German commentators. Here, from Friends of the Earth activist Daniel Miittler, are six reasons why it's not just lousy but "a disaster, and an "historic sham":

1. The agreement is reversible.

2. The nuclear industry can carry on for 32 years. By then, all reactors will have reached the end of their "natural" life - that is, no reactor will be forced to shut.

3. The government guarantees "smooth operations" and renounces its right to tighten security standards. So, if there were a future accident, the government could not respond with higher standards. For Greenpeace, therefore, "this agreement makes nuclear power less safe".

4. Reprocessing nuclear fuel will now go on until 2005, even though last year the Greens promised to end reprocessing by the end of 2000. So, more German nuclear waste will be sent to Sellafield.

5. The production of nuclear waste continues. Another 7,000 tons will be generated before the phase-out.

6. Two waste dumps will not be halted, despite doubts about their geological safety.

"This is not a shutdown programme, but an insurance policy for the nuclear industry", says veteran anti-nuclear campaigner Wolfgang Ehmke. If the Green party passes this policy at a congress next week, its end could be in sight, he says. Meanwhile, the Green party speaker, Antje Radcke, predicts that "one-third of our members could quit". Either way, the Greens in power are now a declared enemy of the anti-nuclear movement.

This Saturday, Vandana Shiva, Jane Goodall, George Monbiot, Anita Roddick, Andrew Marr, Sir Crispin Tickell and Jonathon Porritt, among other regular contributors, will be taking part in a suitably diverse all-day jubilee "conference" at the Royal Geographical Society in London, to celebrate those 25 years. Tickets are available on the door and cost £25. For more information, or for a free copy of the magazine, call 07977-538424.  Capitalism's got a bad press of late and anti-capitalists are scoring lots of points. But now we have anti-anti capitalists who like to write satirical nursery rhymes. Here's one, sent anonymously from Oxford: The Grand Old Duke of York, He had 10,000 men They turned their guns on him and set up an anti-militaristic, anti-capitalist vegan community on a hill in Wales And when they were up they were, like, really high man, And when they were down it was because it was seriously bad shit And when it rained they went to live in a van and sign on with 10,000 dogs on strings Here's another: Christmas is coming The geese are getting fat Let's mask up And go down the farm at night And free them From their capitalist prison  Ominous news. Ravi Kanbur, a highly respected US professor, was the leading author of the World Bank's upcoming World Development Report on poverty. Far from being dull, this was expected to be a massive statement which would set benchmarks and the tone for much of the frenzied debate about present-day capitalism and globalisation. For once, the World Bank critics were delighted and there was real hope that he would open up whole areas of previously taboo official debate. But last week he resigned, saying he was concerned about "unreasonable pressure" being put on him to tone down sections on globalisation. So who was twisting his arm? Step forward Larry Summers, the US treasury secretary. Summers, a former World Banker himself, famously wrote a memo some years ago suggesting that the rich should export their toxic waste to poor countries on the basis that the poor lived shorter lives and presumably would not mind so much. Alex Wilks, coordinator of the Bretton Woods Project, says: "It raises questions of who really calls the shots at the bank and what evidence or opinions about the impacts of globalisation they are trying to suppress."  Better news from the global coalface. A year-long campaign by environmentalists, human rights groups, trades unions and other non-governmental organisations has persuaded the UN Development Programme to abandon plans to create a global sustainable development facility. But why should this arcane body pose a problem? Well, it was to be a partnership between the UNDP and some 15 global corporations, including Dow Chemical, mining giant Rio Tinto, energy conglomerate ABB and biotech leader Novartis. The UNDP had planned to sell them its international network of offices, high-level governmental contacts and its reputation at a bargain price.  So what's it like being a poor community dependent on or living next to a giant multinational? Ask the very poor community that lives round the Monsanto subsidiary, Flexsys Rubber Chemicals Ltd, near Wrexham, north Wales. Many people there earn their money from the plant, but almost everyone accepts that they could be polluted. Last week, a High Court judge approved a £180,000 payout to 304 local people, including 55 children, following an October 1995 hydrogen sulphide gas leak, when people suffered vomiting, nausea, headaches, asthma attacks, sore throats and stinging eyes. For many, it was a case of déjà senti; the previous year, there had been another leak and Flexsys had had to pay significant compensation to 300 people. "The case highlights the importance of community civil actions in deterring similar, or more serious, incidents from arising in the future, a role unlikely to have been achieved by the criminal prosecution of the company", said a lawyer from the Leigh Day practice in London who worked with the community. To add insult to injury, within days of the payout, Flexsys announced it would make 160 people redundant.  For many people in Britain, last week's news that Germany is to phase out nuclear power was a good reason to celebrate green governance. But the deal threatens to actually destroy the whole movement, according to many German commentators. Here, from Friends of the Earth activist Daniel Miittler, are six reasons why it's not just lousy but "a disaster, and an "historic sham": 1. The agreement is reversible. 2. The nuclear industry can carry on for 32 years. By then, all reactors will have reached the end of their "natural" life - that is, no reactor will be forced to shut. 3. The government guarantees "smooth operations" and renounces its right to tighten security standards. So, if there were a future accident, the government could not respond with higher standards. For Greenpeace, therefore, "this agreement makes nuclear power less safe". 4. Reprocessing nuclear fuel will now go on until 2005, even though last year the Greens promised to end reprocessing by the end of 2000. So, more German nuclear waste will be sent to Sellafield. 5. The production of nuclear waste continues. Another 7,000 tons will be generated before the phase-out. 6. Two waste dumps will not be halted, despite doubts about their geological safety. "This is not a shutdown programme, but an insurance policy for the nuclear industry", says veteran anti-nuclear campaigner Wolfgang Ehmke. If the Green party passes this policy at a congress next week, its end could be in sight, he says. Meanwhile, the Green party speaker, Antje Radcke, predicts that "one-third of our members could quit". Either way, the Greens in power are now a declared enemy of the anti-nuclear movement.

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: Police in Cardiff received a 999 call from a man in a pub complaining that another customer had just dumped his false teeth in his pint.
fields.body:
Beer with bite: Police in Cardiff received a 999 call from a man in a pub complaining that another customer had just dumped his false teeth in his pint.

Right Charlie: Staff at a sports shop in Wakefield, West Yorkshire, stopped and searched a stiff-legged customer walking like Charlie Chaplin and discovered three golf clubs down his trousers.

Explosive temper: A pensioner in Kentish Town, London, threatened workmen with a hand grenade and a samurai sword because they had parked their van outside his house.

Over the top: The car driven by a stuntman during filming of a road safety video in Bolton, Greater Manchester, crashed over a cliff.

Stock answer: A farmer in Cockermouth, Cumbria, banned by the local council from putting up a sign offering B&B and refreshments, has painted his adverts on the sides of his six Scottish Blackface sheep.

Burning bra: Firefighters called to a suspected blaze at a block of flats in Birmingham found that alarms had been triggered by smoke from a pan in which the tenant was boiling her bra.

Radio scam: A burglar who broke into a house in Worthing, West Sussex, switched the owners' radio alarm clock from a local station to Radio 4 while ransacking the bedrooms.

Loitering within tent: Thieves stole a rucksack containing a policewoman's uniform and notebook from the police refreshment tent at the Royal Cornwall county show.

Reel wind-up: A woman who trashed her own home told Blackpool magistrates she had done it because her husband had promised to take her out for the first time in two years but went fishing instead.

Shocking loss: The electric fence erected around a builder's yard in Teignmouth, Devon, following a series of thefts has been stolen.

Dead-heading: A woman tending flower beds in the garden of her home in Doncaster, South Yorkshire, unearthed a wooden casket containing the ashes of the previous owner.

Emergency measures? Customers of a pub in Heathfield, East Sussex, who drink too much to drive home are being offered lifts in the landlord's former Red Cross ambulance.

Dignified exit: Council workers who fill in graves at Banbridge cemetery, County Down, may be given uniforms so that they look more dignified during funeral ceremonies.

Toilet humour: The names of 45 celebrities, ranging from Bernard Manning to Winston Churchill, who have visited Todmorden, West Yorkshire, are inscribed on a toilet roll of honour in a new museum at the local sewage treatment works.

fields.headline: Better late...
fields.standfirst: David Walker on how Oxford, 'the home of lost causes', has finally embraced sociology
fields.trailText: David Walker on how Oxford, 'the home of lost causes', has finally embraced sociology
fields.body:
Oxford has at last entered the 1960s. Decades after the archetypal sixties' discipline of sociology was first recognised by other British universities, Oxford University has accepted it as a legitimate field of study by launching a separate department for the subject. Even Cambridge, long resistant, began teaching sociology as a separate subject in 1970.

And at the very moment that Oxford colleges are under fire for excluding students from working-class backgrounds, the university has appointed as its head an expert in social mobility who is openly critical of the "third way", says that "the brute facts of class have not declined" and dismisses the government's efforts at improving access to higher education as "tinkering" which fails to address fundamental inequalities in British society.

In his inaugural lecture last week, Anthony Heath vowed to make the distribution of income, opportunity and life chances a focus of his new job. He promised more "longitudinal" studies of attitudes and behaviour over time. The department would also favour quantitative analysis of voting, elections and choices among political parties. Oxford - sometimes referred to as the home of lost causes - would never, he said, cease to pay attention to subjects which the government was not willing to pay to have researched, especially social class.

Heath, a fellow of the British Academy, criticised sociologists who were more interested in "theory" than going out and gathering evidence. He also castigated "gurus" who wrote books about society without asking people questions, or about "globalisation" without making any statements or propositions that could be subjected to proper scientific tests. Members of his audience were left in little doubt that he was referring to Antony Giddens, director of the London School of Economics, whose work has influenced Tony Blair.

Oxford undergraduates will not yet be able to take a degree in sociology. Instead, the new department will provide courses and lectures for other degrees, including PPE (philosophy, politics and economics), and teach postgraduates and Oxford's recently created degree in human sciences. The department will insist its researchers are versed in the latest mathematical and statistical techniques and emphasise skills necessary to undertake survey work.

Sociology has existed at Oxford since the 1950s, when Peter Collison wrote his famous study, The Cutteslowe Walls: A Study in Social Class. This told the story of a barrier put in place by a property developer to stop council house tenants walking through a private estate. But sociology's existence in the ancient university has been marginal. For some time, it was housed under the disguise of "social and administrative" or confined to Nuffield, the postgraduate college founded after the war with a bequest from the car magnate William Morris (Lord Nuffield) to specialise in social and economic studies.

The college provided a base for, among other sociologists, AH Halsey, who has written extensively on schools and higher edu cation and served as a special government adviser on education. The college's professorial fellow, John Goldthorpe, has led large-scale examinations of job mobility. Another leading light of Nuffield has been David Butler, who stimulated the serious study of parliamentary elections.

Heath, who also comes from a Nuffield background, is well known for his work on the relationship of class and party preferences in voting, the effect of schools on life chances and as co-director, with Roger Jowell, of the Centre for the Study of Elections and Social Trends, which collaborates in the indispensable annual British Social Attitudes survey.

In his lecture, Heath called upon sociologists to emancipate themselves from ways of thinking about society borrowed from the discipline of economics, especially the assumption that people act rationally after making a careful calculation of the balance of advantage to them personally of, say, voting or consuming a particular product. The antidote, he said, was to study the dynamics of how people related to one another inside communities.

fields.headline: Basic errors
fields.standfirst: Kathryn Frederick feels that some nurses now seem indifferent to the dignity and needs of patients
fields.trailText: Kathryn Frederick feels that some nurses now seem indifferent to the dignity and needs of patients
fields.body:
The Department of Health last week published what it called a "milestone report" on cancer nursing. Its first principle is that every patient should be attended by nurses who are "caring and competent". The ordeal of a close friend of mine suggests this is not always the case.

Amid all the talk of a crisis of care in the NHS, particularly in cancer treatment, it isn't fashionable to criticise nurses. I recognise how pressured they are and that some of the suffering endured by my friend - who has just completed six months of chemotherapy - is attributable to lack of resources and administrative failings.

But some of her suffering has undoubtedly been caused by nurses' basic incompetence or apparent indifference: failure to change dressings; not bothering with sterile conditions in key procedures; talking loudly about test results in the corridor instead of discussing them privately; even asking about meal preferences when the patient is vomiting. More worrying still has been a basic insensitivity, a lack of compassion and an absence of human warmth.

Of course, nurses cannot take away the physical and mental horrors that accompany diagnosis of cancer and its treatment. Nor can they, or the consultants for that matter, tell a cancer patient precisely how long they will live, what the quality of their life will be like, or whether they will still hold down the high-powered job they had before they got ill. And nor can they always offer the in-depth conversation and reassurance that many patients need when they feel scared and vulnerable.

Nevertheless, they could remember that each person feels acutely the loss of their precious independence, former good health and, in the case of my friend, their beauty. In the months my friend has been undergoing treatment, she has never been asked how she feels about her diagnosis or how she is coping with declining independence, relative isolation and a changed self-image.

Instead, as on lots of hospital wards, cancer wards seem charac terised by an incessant, joking banter that passes for cheering patients up. Some of it is genuinely and warmly meant, and counters what otherwise would be a sad and pessimistic atmosphere.

But some of my friend's experiences have been so crass that they beggar belief. Loud voices across the ward as nurses recount something strange a patient might have said ("Listen to her, she thinks she's going back to work after all this."). Or, as the screen goes round a patient, the whole ward hears: "We're sorry, we're going to have to take the other breast off this afternoon. Do you want to phone anyone?" Or a patronising reply to a question about treatment ("old worry boots"), accompanied by eyes rolled upwards in mock irritation.

An absence of compassion seems at the root of such insensitivity. Small demonstrations of tenderness, affection or concern are rare among nursing staff. Instead, in my friend's case, it has been junior doctors and consultants who have shown kindness and care.

By the end of six months, patients themselves have learned to be passive or even to adopt the banter if they are not to be seen as "difficult". They have learned not to ask irritating questions, or to push for proper answers. But at that point, when there is no indication whether the chemotherapy might prolong life, the last course of treatment is a momentous milestone and the start of a new phase of psychological and physical adjustment.

In my friend's case, the last treatment was marked by an unceremonious indifference. As she told me, she only wanted them to acknowledge the end, perhaps to say "well done" for surviving and to explain what would happen next. Instead, she left to a casual: "Oh, you're off then? See you when we see you."

My friend and those supporting her have learned at times to make light of the horrors of cancer, even to joke about them. But nurses seem to have become immune to what patients go through. Perhaps they become insensitive as a form of professional immunisation; perhaps the ravages of cancer and its treatments become too much to bear.

Whatever the reason, my friend began her treatment with the same cheerful stoicism, optimism and careful planning with which she runs her life and career. At my last visit, she seemed mentally and physically defeated. I know she will bounce back. But why, on top of coping with a cancer diagnosis and the most barbaric treatment, did she have to run the gauntlet of indifference and insensitivity?

 The health department's report, The Nursing Contribution to Cancer Care, can be found at www.doh.gov.uk/cancer

fields.headline: Against the flow
fields.standfirst: Roger Cowe reports on bold plans for remodelling Yorkshire Water that challenge the very basis of privatising public services
fields.trailText: Roger Cowe reports on bold plans for remodelling Yorkshire Water that challenge the very basis of privatising public services
fields.body:
Mutuality is supposedly on its death-bed, but new life has been injected into this apparently moribund business model with the decision by Kelda, the owner of Yorkshire Water, to create a new kind of co-op for its water assets. The move not only questions the widespread assumption that the trend away from mutuality in the building society and insurance sector is irreversible, it also challenges the basis of privatisation of public services beyond water, such as Railtrack, and throws a new idea into the fierce debate about financing London's tube network.

This is not about taking back the assets into government ownership, but it is a radical approach to private finance of public assets. Kelda announced last week that it was to create a registered community asset mutual (RCAM) to hold the monopoly water assets of the Yorkshire region - the reservoirs, pipes and treatment works.

The operations will be run by a conventional company, which will initially be Kelda, but subsequently will be the winner of a competitive tender. This split mimics the approach to energy and railways, where ownership of the infrastructure is separated from delivery of the service.

The RCAM is a novel structure based on the consumer co-operative model pioneered in Rochdale in the mid-19th century. It is designed to place ownership of the assets in the hands of the community which uses them, bypassing government structures and going directly to the customers. But while this will be a consumer-owned business, there are important differences from the Co-op. The differences are designed to satisfy the water regulator's demands to protect consumers against indolent or self-interested executives and against political interference in the business. It is also important to protect against the "carpet-baggers" who have forced many building societies and insurers to abandon mutuality so that the accumulated wealth of previous generations can be paid out to current members.

Peter Bryant, chairman of utility regulation experts United Capital, which is behind the idea, said: "We had to develop a brand new set of rules. When you are dealing with real public assets you need a brand new model."

Like the co-ops which run grocery shops and other businesses up and down the country, the RCAM will be governed by industrial and provident society law. And as with the co-ops, the members will be its customers.

Unlike the co-ops, however, the members' powers will be limited to some extent. First, the RCAM will not be allowed to pay out any profits in the form of dividends. Any surplus will be "repaid" in the form of lower prices - for the benefit of all customers. In practice, the customers and members are likely to be the same, but it is possible that some customers may turn down the chance to grab a share of their local water company, even though they will have to pay only a token price. After all, there is no money in it, unlike privatisations and demutualisations.

The second constraint will limit the extent to which members can elect the board. While all directors will have to be approved by the members, they can propose only two. The other directors will be chosen by headhunters, according to specifications designed to ensure a suitable mix of skills and experience - and to exclude takeover of the board by any factional interests.

Non-executives will be in the majority on the board, with the aim of mimicking share holder pressure for maximum efficiency and avoiding sleepy executives running the business in their own interests rather than those of the customers.

While there are some differences from conventional consumer co-ops, the model is essentially the same. It strikes a powerful blow against the apparently inexorable advance of shareholder power at a time when the co-op movement is in the middle of a navel-gazing exercise to try to understand its place in 21st century capitalist society.

It is no surprise to discover, however, that Kelda has not come up with this innovation out of altruism or some ideological antagonism to the stock market world. Money is behind it, plus a desire to bring competition to bear on what is a natural monopoly. The problem is that stock market investors expect steady growth in profits, and demand returns - in the form of dividends - to reflect the risk inherent in business. The water regulator, on the other hand, wants prices to stay down and investors expect steady growth in profits, and demand returns - in the form of dividends - to reflect the risk inherent in business

The water regulator, on the other hand, wants prices to stay down and investment to go up. He has demanded a 14% cut in prices and a £1.5bn spending programme over the next five years. That is not a recipe for profit growth. (Kelda also announced last week that it made £222m profit, just £1m more than the previous year.) The result is that the debt share capital is more expensive than borrowing, so long as the debt can be raised at relatively low interest rates. And since water is a steady business which more or less guarantees regular cash flows, if not always water flows, lenders are likely to provide the £2bn-plus to finance the RCAM at rates which will cut its borrowing costs by more than one percentage point.

Kelda's Richard Emmott says: "What we are really saying is that equity is not the right way to fund this kind of business."

Bryant is keen to stress that competition is an important motivation behind the Kelda split. "The idea is to maximise the amount of real competition," he says. "We came to realise that competition has little relevance where there is a real monopoly." His answer - possibly for other privatised services as well as water - is to put the core of the monopoly into an RCAM and open the remainder of the operation to competition.

It is a model which is being actively considered by other water companies, such as Anglian. And it could work for the railways as well as the tube, although the retiring water regulator, Ian Byatt, has already made clear his concern that politicians such as Ken Livingstone should not be allowed to get their hands on water assets and interfere with their operations.

Whether or not Londoners get a chance to own a stake in the underground, Kelda's bold move challenges the notion that conventional company structures should be applied to all manner of activities which are not merely about making money. The Yorkshire RCAM emphasises that private finance does not necessarily mean private shareholders.
