The differences are designed to satisfy the water regulator's demands to protect consumers against indolent or self-interested executives and against political interference in the business. It is also important to protect against the "carpet-baggers" who have forced many building societies and insurers to abandon mutuality so that the accumulated wealth of previous generations can be paid out to current members. Peter Bryant, chairman of utility regulation experts United Capital, which is behind the idea, said: "We had to develop a brand new set of rules. When you are dealing with real public assets you need a brand new model." Like the co-ops which run grocery shops and other businesses up and down the country, the RCAM will be governed by industrial and provident society law. And as with the co-ops, the members will be its customers. Unlike the co-ops, however, the members' powers will be limited to some extent. First, the RCAM will not be allowed to pay out any profits in the form of dividends. Any surplus will be "repaid" in the form of lower prices - for the benefit of all customers. In practice, the customers and members are likely to be the same, but it is possible that some customers may turn down the chance to grab a share of their local water company, even though they will have to pay only a token price. After all, there is no money in it, unlike privatisations and demutualisations. The second constraint will limit the extent to which members can elect the board. While all directors will have to be approved by the members, they can propose only two. The other directors will be chosen by headhunters, according to specifications designed to ensure a suitable mix of skills and experience - and to exclude takeover of the board by any factional interests. Non-executives will be in the majority on the board, with the aim of mimicking share holder pressure for maximum efficiency and avoiding sleepy executives running the business in their own interests rather than those of the customers. While there are some differences from conventional consumer co-ops, the model is essentially the same. It strikes a powerful blow against the apparently inexorable advance of shareholder power at a time when the co-op movement is in the middle of a navel-gazing exercise to try to understand its place in 21st century capitalist society. It is no surprise to discover, however, that Kelda has not come up with this innovation out of altruism or some ideological antagonism to the stock market world. Money is behind it, plus a desire to bring competition to bear on what is a natural monopoly. The problem is that stock market investors expect steady growth in profits, and demand returns - in the form of dividends - to reflect the risk inherent in business. The water regulator, on the other hand, wants prices to stay down and investors expect steady growth in profits, and demand returns - in the form of dividends - to reflect the risk inherent in business The water regulator, on the other hand, wants prices to stay down and investment to go up. He has demanded a 14% cut in prices and a £1.5bn spending programme over the next five years. That is not a recipe for profit growth. (Kelda also announced last week that it made £222m profit, just £1m more than the previous year.) The result is that the debt share capital is more expensive than borrowing, so long as the debt can be raised at relatively low interest rates. And since water is a steady business which more or less guarantees regular cash flows, if not always water flows, lenders are likely to provide the £2bn-plus to finance the RCAM at rates which will cut its borrowing costs by more than one percentage point. Kelda's Richard Emmott says: "What we are really saying is that equity is not the right way to fund this kind of business." Bryant is keen to stress that competition is an important motivation behind the Kelda split. "The idea is to maximise the amount of real competition," he says. "We came to realise that competition has little relevance where there is a real monopoly." His answer - possibly for other privatised services as well as water - is to put the core of the monopoly into an RCAM and open the remainder of the operation to competition. It is a model which is being actively considered by other water companies, such as Anglian. And it could work for the railways as well as the tube, although the retiring water regulator, Ian Byatt, has already made clear his concern that politicians such as Ken Livingstone should not be allowed to get their hands on water assets and interfere with their operations. Whether or not Londoners get a chance to own a stake in the underground, Kelda's bold move challenges the notion that conventional company structures should be applied to all manner of activities which are not merely about making money. The Yorkshire RCAM emphasises that private finance does not necessarily mean private shareholders.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
Anyone who has spent any time teaching introductory sociology will know that one of the first tasks is to persuade students of the need to abandon their obsession with purely psychological explanations of social phenomena. There is nothing particularly mysterious or blameworthy about such an obsession.

The world is stuffed with individualistic explanations of such matters as poverty, deviance, mental illness and personal unhappiness, and it requires a considerable imaginative effort to abandon these homely accounts for the less immediate and more abstract stories that sociologists have to tell about the influence of culture and social structure upon our everyday lives.

But, of course, our readiness to tell psychological stories about the world, stories that rely upon reference to personal emotions and the subjective self, is not a constant. At a time when even politicians bow down before "inexorable" market forces, it is hardly surprising that citizens increasingly succumb to the belief that the only real changes that can be made to their lives are at the personal or emotional level.

With the possible exception of Richard Sennett, few contemporary sociologists have addressed this predicament with such a sense of urgency as Zygmunt Bauman, professor emeritus of sociology at the University of Leeds. In his new book The Individualised Society (published later this year by Polity) Bauman provides this vivid portrait of the contemporary dilemma. "In our 'society of individuals' all mess into which one can get is assumed to be self-made and all hot water into which one can fall is proclaimed to have been boiled by the hapless failures who have fallen into it."

But, of course, the problem with these individualistic stories is that while promising to bring some sense of meaning to our lives, they simultaneously disguise the genuine sources of our anxieties and discomfort. We drive ourselves into "a blind obliviousness with social games, psychological tricks and personal preoccupations so far removed from the reality of our situation that they are forms of madness - agreed madness, shared madness, disguised and dignified madness, but madness all the same".

Sociology seeks to remedy this by reminding us that there "are more ways of telling a story than are dreamt of in our daily story-telling". Its task is to bring back into view the areas that have been banished into the background by our obsession with the private and personal.

 Laurie Taylor talks to Zygmunt Bauman about the individualised society on Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4pm today.

fields.headline: Home truths
fields.standfirst: Good services depend on where you live, reports David Brindle
fields.trailText: Good services depend on where you live, reports David Brindle.
fields.body:
The full scale of the challenge facing the government if it is to develop comprehensive rehabilitation services is revealed today. Reviewing the present state of services, the audit commission concludes: "Taken together, the picture is one of disorganised rather than organised care."

Much is riding on the potential of the health and social care sectors to raise their rehabilitation game. With two in three hospital beds occupied by patients over age 65, ministers are banking on a huge expansion of "intermediate" services for those no longer needing acute care but not yet ready to go home. Acute beds would be freed, cutting waiting times and forestalling winter crises.

Success is unlikely to be so straightforward, the commission suggests. True rehabilitation demands development of a range of services at three levels - in hospital itself, at an intermediate level and in the community - and a fourth requirement, the most important of all, is effective integration. Moreover, it is by no means assured that providing rehabilitation is cheaper than not.

Stuart Turnock, one of the authors of a report by the commission, says: "The whole question of working out what is cost effective in this context is extremely complex.

"If you are going to provide rehabilitation services, you have to invest upfront. What we have shown, though, is that where you have got these services operating effectively, you can have an impact further down the line in terms of avoiding hospital admissions and long-term placements in residential and nursing home care."

The report, The Way to Go Home, is the latest in a series of commission studies of care for older people. It focuses on services for those over 75 who have suffered a stroke - the third most common cause of death after cancer and heart disease, and the leading cause of disability. Sixteen locations were visited and some 160 patients were surveyed.

In line with the national picture, almost half the sites did not have a dedicated stroke unit. All claimed to provide in-patient rehabilitation beds, but some were on acute wards and others offered such low levels of therapy that patients might have been better off in general elderly care environments. One study site had almost five times as many rehabilitation beds as another, but was providing five times less therapy time.

Similar confusion was found in relation to intermediate services. Where there was clarity of definition and purpose, however, results were impressive. In two Devon schemes, in Exmouth and Plymouth, four in five people who had been considered on the threshold of entering residential care were enabled to avoid it; in Rotherham, a similar proportion were enabled to return to their own homes and 70% of them were still there six months later.

In the community, almost all sites were found to have a day hospital, whereas just over a third had a multi-disciplinary rehabilitation team. Yet the commission is more impressed with the latter, as established across Sheffield, in preventing avoidable admissions to hospital or residential care and reducing the duration of hospital stays.

Turnock says: "We struggled to find a really good, well functioning day hospital. The difficulties are well known - relatively short working days, problems of transport - and we think they need to be thought through fairly carefully."

Part of that thinking must involve the patients themselves, the commission says, because too often, they are not included. Of those surveyed for the report, no fewer than 42% had not even been told, when in hospital, what a stroke was.

 The Way to Go Home: Rehabilitation and Remedial Services for Older People is available (price £20) from Audit Commission Publications (tel: 0800 502030).

fields.headline: Prince William's 18th birthday
fields.standfirst:
Everything you need to know about the future king on the web
Special report
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the future king on the web
fields.body:
1. William is 18 today. Jolly good luck to him, but he will surely forgive us if we don't sing "Happy Birthday, dear Prince William Arthur Philip Louis Schlesweig-Holstein-Sonderburg- Glucksburg-Saxe-Coburg-Gotha..."

2. A Yahoo! search for "Prince William" produces 108,120 results. A great many are generated in and by the estimable Prince William County of Virginia, but even more relate to the lad who is next but one in line for the throne.

3. Wills will celebrate his birthday with 40 pals, several of them blonde and dishy, at the Hot Rocks bistro in Eton Wick. Channel 4 will celebrate his birthday with an irreverent cartoon film.

4. The web is awash with fanzines about young Wills. Some are rather sweet, and most are a great deal more entertaining than the wretched official royal family site, with its dreadful Royal Insight magazine and dire FAQs. "Swan upping", indeed.

5. You will find dreary posed pictures of Wills on the royal-approved site. He's the one looking as if he's just had to listen to a speech by his dad.

6. You won't find one of him in his gawd-help-us waistcoat.

7. Apparently, the young Wills was a bit of a brat, given to throwing his four-year-old weight around. And his food.

8. If he makes it to the top job, he will be the fifth King William. (Or the first King Louis, if he chooses that one). His predecessors, William I, William II, William III and William IV were all rather interesting men of action.

9. The first one, known to schoolboys as Willie the Conk, had probably the most disgusting funeral in history. But back to birthday boy:

10. Among the treats available on the Wills Wide Web, is a video of him cooking. He's fond of his tucker, is our Wills. If he gets pictured swigging a glass of birthday wine, we could call him Willie the Plonk.

fields.headline: Stonehenge celebrations pass off peacefully
fields.standfirst: Low-key policing at solstice makes a "useful contribution to the social atmosphere"
fields.trailText: Thousands of people took part in peaceful summer solstice celebrations this morning after Stonehenge was opened to the general public for the event for the first time since 1984.
fields.body:
Thousands of people took part in peaceful summer solstice celebrations this morning after Stonehenge was opened to the general public for the event for the first time since 1984.

Druids, revellers and the police mingled freely as about 6,000 people gathered under murky skies at the historic Wiltshire site.

English Heritage said the success of this year's event paved the way for greater access in the future. "We are very happy that a lot of people came along and it was a happy and peaceful atmosphere," a spokeswoman said. "The fact that it's gone so well means that we will be looking at more arrangements in the future."

Some people climbed on the lower stones, but there were no arrests as the crowd waited for the sun to rise at 4.44am. A spokeswoman for Wiltshire police said: "The atmosphere has been carnival-like. People have come and enjoyed themselves and the only thing to let them down is the weather. People were coming up to police officers and shaking their hands. We're very pleased with the way it's gone."

Computer programmer Emile Joubert from Salisbury said: "The people I was most surprised to see mingling in so well were the police. They made a very useful contribution to the social atmosphere. I'm very glad there hasn't been any violence."

Before daylight, the night sky had been lit up by fire eaters and drums could be heard some distance away. The centre of the stone circle was packed with cheering people and, while students from the University of East London entertained crowds with their colourful costumes and samba drums, druids in their traditional attire performed a ritual ceremony a short distance away. The ban on amplified music at the site was respected.

One member of the Order of Bards, Ovates and Druids, who gave his name as Shaun, travelled from Southampton for the ceremony. He said: "Opening Stonehenge to everyone is the best solution. If people get to know the stones they will learn to respect them."

Veronica Hammond, arch druid of the Cotswold order from Cheltenham, said: "I think opening it up is a very good decision. I was crowned on Saturday and it's good to be here. The majority of people have behaved."

The move to open Stonehenge for the summer solstice comes one year after an organised visit for 150 people, including religious groups, was disrupted after gatecrashers pushed down fences and clambered on the stones.

Stonehenge was first closed to the general public during the summer solstice in 1984 and a four-mile exclusion order was put in place after disorder problems.

fields.headline: No 9: Zlatko Zahovic
fields.trailText: Favourite Food Fish
fields.body:
Favourite Food Fish

Favourite Drink Juice

Favourite Movie The Godfather

Favourite Car Mercedes

And I suppose his favourite female singer is Whitney Houston? You're close, but Zlatko prefers the rockier, raunchier sound of Tina Turner. And who can blame him?

Anyway, let's talk football. I've been well impressed with Zahovic throughout Euro 2000. But he's 29. So why I haven't I heard about him before? We're not sure. It certainly isn't an overnight thing, because Zahovic was regarded as of the best players in Europe while he was at FC Porto, where he won three successive league titles.

But how come I never saw him in the Champions League? Maybe you weren't watching closly enough. Because in 1998-99 Zahovic scored seven goals in just six group games.

And then he went Olympiakos for £10m and it all went wrong Not according to the official Uefa website. They claim that despite a two-month self-imposed exile, "Zahovic has been such a hit in Greece that Olympiakos have won every game in which he has played."

Even friendlies? Are you daring to doubt Uefa?

And what about his record for Slovenia? How does 25 goals in 48 games sound? No wonder the Sports Journalists Association of Slovenia declared last year that: "Zlatko Zahovic was in this dream season the soul of Slovenian team. He convinced his team-mates that even the impossible can be possible."

But surely the impossible is impossible? Not when you're Slovenia. Last December, for example, the team won two awards on the same day: the Fifa award for 'Best Mover of the Year' (for Miran Pavlin's version of the moonwalk we presume) while the Sport Journalists Association of Slovenia (yes, them again) gave them the 'Best Team of the Year for Slovenia' award.

But what about their chances against Norway tonight? They're certainly much better than the 7/2 the bookies are offering.

Do say "The impossible can be possible"

Don't say "Where exactly is Slovakia?"

fields.headline: Calypso cricket? No - organisational planning
fields.trailText: By beating England in three days at Edgbaston, West Indies made fools of all of us who said last winter that England would be favourites to win this series. The match had less in common with West Indies' recent whitewashes at the hands of New Zealand than the blackwashes they used to inflict on England in the Eighties.
fields.body:
By beating England in three days at Edgbaston, West Indies made fools of all of us who said last winter that England would be favourites to win this series. The match had less in common with West Indies' recent whitewashes at the hands of New Zealand than the blackwashes they used to inflict on England in the Eighties.

The most remarkable thing about West Indies' recovery is their astute team management. Since the triumvirate of Jimmy Adams as captain, Roger Harper as coach and the low-key Ricky Skerritt as manager was installed, the team's Test record is played 6, won 4, drawn 2. There's a quiet efficiency about the dressing-room these days. That's not to denigrate the Brian Lara/Clive Lloyd (and a bit of Viv Richards) regime. But the new leaders are doing things a little differently.

Captain Adams has been a revelation. He deserved the hundred which was denied him by a questionable but still brilliant catch by Flintoff. It was the best example of his new refuse-to-lose policy. A few months ago Zimbabwe needed 99 to win their first Test in the Caribbean. Adams demanded a response from his bowlers, and the result was 63 all out. A super-gritty 48 not out, much of it spent in the company of Courtney Walsh, won a close series against a good Pakistan side. At the start of the year he was a player in decline, but the leadership has made him rediscover his form. Michael Holding picked the wrong Jamaican - Walsh - as man of the match. On a bowlers' pitch, it was surely Adams.

Roger Harper is emerging as a quietly effective coach. He and Ricky Skerritt punctuate much of their conversation with the words "the team", and it seems to have been transmitted to the players. No one made a hundred at Edgbaston, but Sherwin Campbell, Brian Lara, Shiv Chanderpaul and Adams all made half-centuries, Franklyn Rose got 48, and Curtly Ambrose, too often too careless with his batting, made a valuable 22. England were never allowed to seize the initiative when they took a wicket. The Windies were 136 for 4 following Gough's brilliant dismissal of Lara. Six short months ago they would have struggled to make 200. Here they got nearly 400. They've clearly toughened up mentally.

Ricky Skerritt remains largely unknown and few people would recognise him. Tall and bespectacled with a neatly trimmed beard, he would not be out of place in a barrister's chambers or a bank in the City. He even uses finance-speak to describe how he has tried to turn things around. "We see this squad as an organisation," he told me shortly before play on the first day. "It requires a sense of organisational management and planning."

Man-management has been subtle, starting with the reintegration of Brian Lara. I suggested it might be difficult with a settled, successful and harmonious side, but Skerritt disagreed. "Brian is very special, and as long as he wants to play we'll pick him." The great man was clearly comfortable among colleagues he was formerly in charge of, laughing and exchanging hugs and high-fives.

Skerritt's approach to the other players is that they're told they alone deserve the credit for however well they do, and for the hard work they put into preparation. "What the management has been able to do is to encourage them to be more confident and relaxed, and give them whatever technical assistance they need," says Skerritt. As Adams has explained, they're left to their own devices, as long as they stick to a team plan. At Edgbaston it was about building a lead of 150-plus. This team is big on preparation and planning. TV viewers on Sunday were even treated to the sight of the players having a "warm down" - a kickaround with a football. Does all this explain their success? Hard to say, but it seems likely that the future is Ricky Skerritt rather than David Lloyd, "Search for the Hero", a boom box and patriotic exhortations.

It's still too early to tell whether Birmingham has set the tone for the rest of the series. A lot can change over a summer. England have drawn their last two home series against West Indies. webTitle: Why we should learn to love football

fields.headline: Why we should learn to love football
fields.standfirst: Patrick Barkham explains why English fans should take their football more seriously
fields.trailText: Wednesday, 2pm: Patrick Barkham explains why English fans should take their football more seriously
fields.body:
Even the limp flags of St George that remained hanging outside pubs across the country seemed a bit despondent in the morning gloom today. Millions of people had traipsed quietly away from pubs and bars, or gone and put the kettle on after Phil Neville's ill-timed tackle handed Romania a penalty, victory and a place in the quarter-finals of Euro 2000 last night.

England has always done defeat rather well, taking it in good - or at least indifferent - spirit. "It's a shame it is over so soon," I heard one fan remark as she left the pub. It seemed to sum up the prevailing mood: now England are out, Euro 2000 is over. This indifference towards the tournament does football a grave disservice.

Ignoring the drab England v Germany match, Euro 2000 has been one of the best football tournaments in the last two decades. It has featured a feast of sublime passing football and a lot of (good) goals. The French team, revolving around the visionary Zinédine Zidane behind the frighteningly quick Thierry Henry and Nicolas Anelka, are thrilling to watch and arrogant to boot.

When the Dutch got going against Denmark, they looked almost as slick. Italy, Slovenia and Yugoslavia have also played flowing football and, with the exception of the latter, there has been a refreshing absence of the cheating and cynicism which has despoiled many a recent tournament.

The quality of entertainment is right up there with the best of recent years, including the 1982 and the 1994 World Cups. Unfortunately, many English fans will struggle to remember the latter as England, under the dark years of Graham Taylor, failed to even qualify. (In 1994, the American hosts also demonstrated how to enjoy appreciate good football without knowing a thing about it.)

The tournaments English fans tend to most easily recall are ugly competitions where England have done well, such as the 1990 World Cup, which was marred by horrendous on-field disciplinary problems and a dubious Argentinian team led by a known drug addict, and the 1996 European Championships, which were just plain dull.

English fans' indifference to the best football in the world is down to two very different traditions. The first is the ingrained tribalism of football in this country. As football writer Simon Kuper has remarked, in Holland the first football question anyone asks you is, "What team do you play for?" when in England it is, "Who do you support?"

The fierce rivalry between fans is the source of much of the passion - and the strength - of the Premiership and other leagues; it is often good humoured and amusing as well. But when translated to the international arena, it seems only to lead to racism and hooliganism while England are in the tournament, followed by indifference once they are out.

The second cause of indifference in England is the rise of the part-time supporter. The (often overstated) transformation of football from working man's game to middle-class pursuit enjoyed by both sexes during the 90s has created a legion of casual football fans. Many don't support a club, only joining the football frenzy at tournament time. These supporters enjoy dipping into the passion of supporting England, but lose interest in football again when it becomes something contested - much better - by other international teams.

It is a shame for all sorts of reasons. A love of good football, rather than England, would erase most of English football's hooligan problem, if only because England's manifestly bad football would lead to a rush of interest in other, better international teams. And what hope is there of learning how to win a tournament when we never stay to the end to see how it is won?

webTitle: New law needed to combat drug rape, says study

fields.headline: New law needed to combat drug rape, says study
fields.standfirst: Home Office
fields.trailText: New legislation is needed to deal with the increase of drug  rapes, a study funded by the Home Office urged today.
fields.body:
New legislation is needed to deal with the increase of drug rapes, a study funded by the Home Office urged today.

The report into drug-assisted sexual offences calls for "a new look at sexual assaults through 21st century eyes".

Scotland Yard Detective Chief Inspector Peter Sturman, who compiled the report, says the legislation used to prosecute offenders - the Sexual Offences Act 1956 - is 44-years-old and it is time for a "complainant driven" approach. In the course of the study, over 20 months, 123 female and male drug rape victims were interviewed:

 70% said they had been attacked by someone they knew;
 47% of attacks took place in a club or pub;
 More than half the drugs were administered with alcohol;
 In some cases drugs were hidden in milk or drinking chocolate.

Of the victims, 14 were male. Of the women, 42% were in their thirties, and many had just survived a divorce or partnership break-up and were looking for a new relationship. The other largest represented group were students - 20% of victims were at university at the time of the attack.

Mr Sturman's report calls for a national database of drug rape statistics and training of police officers in what is a relatively new crime.

While the problem is not of epidemic proportions, it is on the increase in the UK, he says.

Among 71 recommendations are calls for consecutive sentences for multiple offenders and life sentences commensurate with the human life span.

Calls for a lesser offence for acquaintance rape are rejected and banning drugs traced in drug rape incidents, like GHB, are also dismissed.

But Mr Sturman does call for more stringent controls and further research into the effects of drugs like GHB.

Evidence that a drug has been used in an assault is often extremely difficult to prove. Drugs stay only a few days in the system and many victims take weeks to report the attack.

New techniques, like hair sampling, should be used to screen for the presence of drugs days after an attack.

A network of 24-hour sexual assault treatment centres should be set up across the country, where victims can receive medical attention, counselling and make a statement to police under one roof.

The report urges police officers to take any complaint seriously, no matter how bizarre or incredible the allegations seem.

"The allegation that appears to be quite bizarre may be evidence of an attack by a very experienced, serial offender," the report warns.

Even if a victim feels he or she has consented under the influence of the drug, it should be treated as rape, the report adds.

Of those interviewed for the study, more than half felt their treatment at the hands of the police was poor, or very poor. Among male victims, 71% rated their treatment as very poor.

The rise of drug rape has led to creation of the Drug Rape Trust by journalist Sharon Doughty, who became involved in Mr Sturman's report during the course of making a documentary on drug rapes.

She warns: "We know offenders are using the Internet to find information on how to commit these crimes."

The Trust is setting up its own web site to supply information and support to victims.

An advice list being issued to students and through the Drug Rape Trust warns those at risk never to leave drinks unattended and to appoint a "nominated drinks watcher" when out in pubs and clubs.

webTitle: Kosovan refugees' fond farewell to Britain

fields.headline: Kosovan refugees' fond farewell to Britain
fields.standfirst: Northern editor Martin Wainwright meets a family preparing to return to the country they fled in terror a year ago
fields.trailText: Northern editor Martin Wainwright meets a family preparing to return to the country they fled in terror a year ago.
fields.body:
Asylum debates tend to bring out emotion and passion on both sides ­ too many refugees flooding in, says one group; too cruel, a shambles of hostels and limited permits, counters another.

Under a cedar of Lebanon planted by a Leeds iron-smelter 200 years ago, the debate found a welcome calm this week as one, small Kosovan family, the Berishas, sweltered in a very un-English heatwave.

Their experiences over the last 15 months are unimaginable to a comfortable Briton. Almost all of us are as George Orwell described in Homage to Catalonia: placid, well set-up and never expecting to be woken by the roar of bombs.

Rape, murder, torture. You cringe to hear such things described by a 15-year-old girl or her brother on the brink of his 17th birthday. Scarcely surprising, then, that Faton Berisha ­ his name quickly anglicised to Tony by his schoolfriends in Leeds ­ doesn't want to catch the 7.30am Refugee Council flight from Leeds-Bradford airport.

His immediate priority, for instance, is getting a second season in Farsley football club's youth team. "We partied ­ we partied a lot," he grins, harking back to the club "do" on the night of England's Euro 2000 victory over Germany. "I am always hoping, as well, that Yugoslavia will lose."

His teachers Sue Matthews and Sue Buckle, picnicking on the refugee hostel lawn in a last goodbye to their 25 temporary pupils, mourn his lost opportunities. "You almost don't have to teach the Kosovans," says Sue B. "They are desperate to learn." But Tony ­ soon to be Faton again ­ is only one part of the Berisha family worldview. His father, Bislim, and mother, Shuknije, can't wait to be back in Kosovo, finding hammers, nails, loan of a sewing machine, to rebuild their home, which was gutted by Serbs. The heatwave reminds them of the need to get on with it. All too soon the Balkan winter will close in, says Bislim, a company accountant before the horrors of last year. They would not want to go back then, to queue for planks or breeze blocks at Nato-protected stores, or to shiver on their uncle's sofas (their temporary home from next week).

The uncle has been weighing on the mind of Marita, the youngest Berisha, who last Friday pleaded at Hillary Benn MP's Leeds surgery for an extension of the family's one-year permission to stay. Like Tony, she has made plenty of friends at Primrose high school and she bubbles with the fun of Leeds life, especially after the nightmare of the deportation trains from Pristina.

But after talking it over, she has changed her mind. Home is Kosovo, she accepts, where the uncle is and other Berishas scattered about the villages south of the provincial capital. She is still torn. But her family hopes that their British friends will stay in touch and come out to Pristina.

Above all, they hope that reconciliation will lead to prosperity; that prosperity will lead to links with the European Community; and that those links will lead to a happier return to Yorkshire.

"Maybe to work, maybe to study at Leeds University," says Marita, heading off to pack. "Maybe to play for Leeds United," says Tony. Bislim and Shuknije just want to shake my hand, for a long time, and ask that their "thank you" can be passed on to the people of Britain.

webTitle: Labour and Tory MPs in big match TV row

fields.headline: Labour and Tory MPs in big match TV row
fields.standfirst:
Follow Euro 2000 on Football Unlimited
Special report: football violence
fields.trailText: A Labour MP today accused Tory colleagues of  lacking patriotism after a row about watching last night's England-Romania Euro 2000 match in the Commons dining room.
fields.body:
A Labour MP today accused Tory colleagues of lacking patriotism after a row about watching last night's England-Romania Euro 2000 match in the Commons dining room.

Preseli Pembrokeshire MP Jackie Lawrence was among a group of Labour members who wanted to watch the match - which England lost, ending their championship challenge - over dinner.

They asked staff to switch one of the annunciators - TV screens that give details of Commons business - over to the football coverage. "The staff said yes, though they added that if there were any complaints, they would have to reconsider. The TV was put on, and it was hardly audible," she explained.

"Then one of a group of about a dozen Tories, the Blaby MP Andrew Robathan, stormed up the dining room, went straight to the TV, reached over Labour members and turned it off. He didn't even say anything. We couldn't believe it."

The Labour group then asked the staff if the TV could be put on with the volume switched off altogether. But that failed to pacify the Tories, one of whom went towards staff to complain, she said.

"The Tory member insisted this was the dining room, not a TV lounge.

"I saw what was happening and went over and asked whether we couldn't reach a compromise.

"There are curtains in the centre of the room, so the curtains were pulled across between the Labour and Tory ends. The whole thing was just bizarre."

Ms Lawrence criticised the Tories for their attitude. "I thought it showed a lack of patriotism. For them patriotism is rhetoric, not action.

"And on a night when 98% of the population were watching this match, I don't see why MPs should have been deprived. It just shows how out of touch they are."

Ms Lawrence said that although she represents a Welsh constituency, she was backing England to win last night. "I'm prepared to support any UK team - you support your friends," she said.

Mr Robathan rejected the accusation that he lacked patriotism.

"I spent 15 years in Her Majesty's Armed Forces, serving in the Gulf and Northern Ireland," he said.

"Not everybody links patriotism with football, and not everyone in this country thinks that the most important thing that was happening last night was a football match.

"I and my colleagues were having an interesting political discussion."

He added: "The House of Commons is well supplied with TV rooms. There are TVs in the offices, and there are bars.

"I think it's really a question of whether really we should be reduced to having TV dinners in the members' dining room in the House of Commons.

"If Jackie Lawrence wants to have TV dinners, why not go home, and not force the rest of us to have to listen to the TV."

Now for the selections for today's Turkey v Sweden game.

Sean Ingle

Double: Czech Republic to beat Denmark 5/6 and Raul to score the first goal against Yugoslavia 9/2 (£10)

"Never bet on a dead match. Freaky things happen." So states rule number 2 of the gambler's handbook. So why am I staking cash on the Czech Republic to beat Denmark? Well, look at the teams. Surely Nedved, Koller, Berger and co will have too much for Allen Nielsen and the rest of the Danes' first-division midfield - or I have missed something?

Holland surely can't start three matches in a row in such poor fashion, and I expect them to raise their game against the world champions. Either that or these teams will deliver the 0-0 draw I nearly plumped for, which will make me feel a tad queasy.

Norway v Slovenia: Discipline more than 40pts - yellow 10pts, red 25pts, maximum 35pts per player - 5/6 (£20)

Betting at really short odds doesn't exactly smack of fearlessness - but a minimum of five yellows in this potentially bruising and desperate fixture carries tons of appeal. Our own Graham Poll is the tournament's toughest ref to date and both sides have picked up eight bookings between them so far. Let's hope it gets out of hand.

I turn my back for a minute and suddenly I've been left behind, £40 off the pace. I feel I am setting a bad example to all youngsters who might get into gambling, so with my last few quid I will do my best to land a big win.

fields.headline: Arnie: 'I'll be back' in T3
fields.trailText: Now Arnold Schwarzenegger has made the heart of a thousand fan boys leap - he's announced that, yes, he will make another Terminator movie
fields.body:
"If I go to Russia, when I was in China or when I go anywhere in Europe or in Africa, it's the most asked question, 'Will you do another Terminator'?" Now Arnold Schwarzenegger has made the heart of a thousand fan boys leap - he's announced that, yes, he will make another Terminator movie.

Arnie last starred as cinema's favourite cyborg in T2 (1991), having introduced the character in Terminator in 1984. After insisting in recent years that he'd never make T3, the Austrian man-mountain now says, "I like the idea, but it's not only me. I always go by what the people out there in the world would like to see."

Schwarzenegger's one reservation concerns T1 and 2's director James Cameron. Arnie insists that the Oscar-winning helmer do T3 - but Cameron has said he is not interested in the movie. In an interview with Access Hollywood, Arnie says he hopes Cameron will change his mind: "A script is being written as we speak and it's a film that Jim will definitely produce. If he will direct it or not, I don't know yet because he never makes up his mind until the script is all done and perfect." Terminator co-stars Linda Hamilton (Cameron's ex-wife) and Edward Furlong are both said to be interested in reprising their roles.

There remain, however, inconsistencies in Arnie's statements. Independent producers Andrew Vajna and Mario Kassar have bought the rights to the franchise, and are set to make instalments 3 and 4 on their own. At the present time, Kassar is apparently keen for Arnie to come on board, but Cameron is definitely out of the picture.

Describing the direction the films would take, Vajna and Kassar's colleague at the production company C-2, James Middleton, said: "T3 will be present-day, 2000, about the first engagement between Skynet and humans, and about the beginning of the war." The fourth movie will be set in the future, "after the nuclear conflagration has ended. There will be a protector Terminator, and an antagonist machine."

webTitle: Exorcist trailer 'too extreme' for modern audiences

fields.headline: Exorcist trailer 'too extreme' for modern audiences
fields.trailText: The Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) has vetoed a trailer for the upcoming re-release of The Exorcist, deeming it "too extreme" for modern audiences. Director William Friedkin, who supervised the restoration of the film, including 12 minutes of footage that was cut from the original version, is not best pleased.
fields.body:
The Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) has vetoed a trailer for the upcoming re-release of The Exorcist, deeming it "too extreme" for modern audiences. Director William Friedkin, who supervised the restoration of the film, including 12 minutes of footage that was cut from the original version, is not best pleased.

"Rejecting it on the grounds that it was too intense is like rejecting it on the grounds that it's too funny," Friedkin told The Hollywood Reporter last week. "It makes no sense at all and seems to be contrary to the purpose of the ratings board, which is not to judge content but simply to issue a rating based on certain material in the shots - nudity, excessive violence or language - and this trailer has none of that."

Friedkin described the axed trailer as "very abstract and impressionistic. You won't get the story-line out of it." The MPAA has yet to give an account of their reasons for banning the ad. The film was released in 1973, and was re-released in Britain in 1999. According to the movie's (official website), its restored version includes the notorious 'spider walk' scene, wherein Regan (Linda Blair) turns upside down and walks down a flight of stairs in a crab-like posture. We hope the MPAA don't mind us letting you read about that.

fields.headline: Pearce, puns and puffed-out chests
fields.standfirst: Jamie Rainbow looked on aghast at his TV screen last night. And that was before Phil Neville made his fatal lunge
fields.trailText: Jamie Rainbow looked on aghast at his TV screen last night. And that was before Phil Neville made his fatal lunge.
fields.body:
Looking on the bright side, at least England weren't thrown out of the tournament because of the conduct of a load of idiots pretending to be England fans. No, they were dumped out of the tournament because of the conduct of 11 idiots pretending to be international footballers. Oh yeah, and because the FA gambled on employing a clown rather than a qualified coach to manage the team.

Even by their own dreadful standards, England were abysmal last night. Their passing, their movement, their all-round play was, at times, staggeringly bad. In fact, the only thing comparable to the players' uneasy relationship with a football was Stuart Pearce's tenuous relationship with the English language.

"England need a bit more sort of attacking play" was Pearce's shrewd observation at half-time. Earlier, his finite potential as a pundit was exposed when he suggested "it was a Wise decision to play Wise" before proceeding to analyse England's performance "backwards-wise and midfield-wise". "No pun intended," he added. No pun taken, Stuart.

Perhaps the saddest episode in a miserable evening for England supporters occurred just after Romania had scored their third goal. With the clock running down, the camera focused on Keegan who chose that moment to unveil his highly-convincing impersonation of a chimpanzee. "Be big, keep believing," he shouted whilst puffing out his chest and drawing his hands up to his armpits. It was, I suspect, the closest the team had come to receiving a tactical team talk during their time in Belgium.

Keegan was honest enough afterwards to accept that England simply hadn't been good enough. Looking as bewildered as a Neville brother confronted by a Romanian attacker, Keegan went into metaphor overdrive, discussing "wounds to lick" and "mountains to climb." Nice bloke, way out of his depth.

Pressed by Garth Crooks to list England's shortcomings, Keegan avoided the obvious reply - "How long have you got?" - opting instead for: "If it was just about endeavour and honesty we'd win Euro 2000."

An incomprehensible answer. But in the light of the last ten shambolic days, that's only to be expected.

webTitle: 21 June: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: 21 June: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Kate Winslet stalked, Psycho man's grave marker stolen, Johnny Depp jokes, and on the casting couch Giovanni Ribisi and George Clooney
fields.body:
 Kate Winslet has received a string of email death threats from a woman stalker. The sinister fan, who calls herself Dina, says she wants to "rape her, kill her and just hit her". The threats have been left on Kate's fan club website, and originated from the literature department at the Aristotle University of Thessalonica, in Greece. No one at the university was available for comment.

 The grave marker for the man who inspired the Alfred Hitchcock film Psycho has been stolen. Waushara County sheriff Patrick Fox said he expects to see Ed Gein's grave marker turn up for sale on the web. "There are people who would pay big bucks for that," the sheriff said. Gein was arrested in 1957 when investigators found a body gutted and hanging in his home. The story of the reclusive man, who kept his late mother's room exactly as it had been when she had died a decade earlier, made international headlines. Horror writer Robert Bloch's character based on Gein was the inspiration for Hitchcock's Norman Bates.

 Johnny Depp is something of a prankster, says his co-star in the drug-smuggling movie Blow, Penelope Cruz: "Johnny is the funniest man. I don't think people know this, but he is always the joker." So what's so funny, Penny? Well, Depp got most amused by letting off his whoopee cushion in the middle of dramatic scenes. "You know, I am screaming, pulling at my hair. All of a sudden I hear 'pfgggggggg' and I think, 'Incredible, just ignore it'. But it comes again and I start smiling. Then everybody laughs."

 Video giant Blockbuster will give $100,000 and a distribution deal - including a marketing campaign to be seen at 4,000 Blockbuster stores - to the winner of its new Independent Film-maker Award. The award is described as "an exciting chance to discover new talent and films that are not in the mainstream production lines of a studio," said a spokesperson. "It also presents an excellent opportunity for a film-maker to reach a large and diverse audience."

 DreamWorks is in discussions with Aardman Animations for the British animation house to follow its 2002 picture The Tortoise and the Hare with a feature-length version of Wallace & Gromit. If the movie, based on the characters in the Oscar-winning shorts The Wrong Trousers and A Close Shave, goes ahead, it probably won't hit screens until 2004.

Casting couch

 Giovanni Ribisi (Gone in 60 Seconds, Boiler Room) is to star opposite Cate Blanchett in Miramax Films' Heaven, to be directed by Tom Tykwer (Run Lola Run). Based on the final screenplay from the late Polish director Krzysztof Kieslowski, Heaven revolves around a woman who takes the law into her own hands after police ignore her pleas to arrest the man responsible for her husband's death.

 George Clooney has optioned the novel Bad Connection, and may star in the film. The not-yet-released tome, by telephone worker Mike Ledwidge, features a telephone cable splicer who has a moral conflict after inadvertently receiving insider information about a corporate merger.

webTitle: Peace in balance as Barak government splits

fields.headline: Peace in balance as Barak government splits
fields.trailText: Ehud Barak, Israel's prime minister, was today struggling to assemble a coalition that would allow him to press ahead with a peace deal with the Palestinians.
fields.body:
Ehud Barak, Israel's prime minister, was today struggling to assemble a coalition that would allow him to press ahead with a peace deal with the Palestinians.

His government was on the point of collapse after four members of the ultra-Orthodox Jewish Shas party submitted their resignations from the cabinet yesterday in a dispute over funding and control of Shas's school system. The ministers quit despite winning promises of extra funds for their scandal-ridden school system and the legalisation of the Channels of Holiness radio network.

Without Shas's 17 seats, Mr Barak stands to lose his 68-52 majority in parliament. Under Israeli law, the resignations take effect in 48 hours, leaving the sides until tomorrow afternoon to engage in brinkmanship. If his parliamentary majority disappears, Mr Barak would find it nearly impossible to stay in power for long while pursuing peace.

Shas and its rightwing supporters view the West Bank, captured in war 33 years ago, as part of biblical Israel. But the party's spiritual leader, Rabbi Ovadia Yosef, would back Mr Barak's ceding land to Palestinians in order to preserve Jewish lives.

Mr Barak said yesterday that the sides had agreed on "90% of the problems". Elected last year to accelerate negotiations, Mr Barak affirmed Israel's commitment to forging a permanent peace with the Palestinians. Shas carried out its threat to leave the government weeks after Mr Barak was hailed as a hero at home for ending Israel's 22-year occupation of south Lebanon and at a critical juncture in Israeli-Palestinian peacemaking.

Without Shas, Mr Barak would probably enlist the six-seat, secular Shinui party with an avowed policy of fighting ultra-Orthodox influence into a shrunken coalition. He would have to rely on the outside support of Arab parties in pursuing peace. He might try to form a so-called "national unity government" with the rightwing Likud party, the second largest in parliament.

But the Likud leader, Ariel Sharon, demands a full partnership in decision-making, making any land-for-peace deal Mr Barak might envisage extremely difficult. With polls showing Mr Barak ahead of Mr Sharon, he could call early elections. But there is no guarantee that he would forge a more cohesive coalition now than he did after defeating the Likud prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu in May 1999.

Israel and the Palestinians aim to sign by September a treaty solving the most difficult issues at the heart of their conflict - Jerusalem, Palestinian refugees, borders and Jewish settlements. Mr Arafat has said he will declare a Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza Strip later this year with or without a peace agreement with Israel, which occupied the two areas in the 1967 Middle East war.

webTitle: Keegan vows to 'bounce back' after Euro 2000 disappointment

fields.headline: Keegan vows to 'bounce back' after Euro 2000 disappointment
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan today admitted that he "had not set the world on fire" as England coach, but vowed he would bounce back from the disappointment of Euro 2000.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan today admitted that he "had not set the world on fire" as England coach, but vowed he would bounce back from the disappointment of Euro 2000.

The England boss, still trying to come to terms with last night's 3-2 defeat by Romania in Charleroi, said: "I have learned things in this job. I have not set the world on fire so far with my management skills but I still get the opportunity to do that in a World Cup.

"I have learned things, it would be sad if I hadn't. Bill Shankly, when I met him, would say you never stop learning at this game and I am looking forward to the future. I will bounce back. I have done that before and I will do it again.

"We had a lot of things going for us, fantastic support in the stadium, we led 2-1 at half-time. We made a fight of it, but we were not good enough to go through. We've just fallen short of the standards required of an England side. Whatever the nation feels, our disappointment is greater."

But Keegan said he had no plans to make wholesale changes to the side for the World qualifiers.I am not talking about rebuilding," he claimed. "I think changes are inevitable in football. But if anyone thinks I'm the sort of coach who will drop players because their birth certificates say they are over 30, no. I'll pick the best players."

Keegan also criticised the Premier League for not producing players conducive to international football. "We've got to be honest and say our Premiership is a fantastic league but it doesn't fit in with the style of international football," he said. "You haven't got the same players and you don't quite play the same system. You have to adjust and adapt and maybe that's let us down on this trip."

Meanwhile Alan Shearer has spoken of his "numb feeling" at England's Euro 2000 exit following last night's 3-2 defeat by Romania in Charleroi.

The England captain, who has retired from international football said: "It is difficult to describe how numb I feel following last night's defeat and I am sure that the whole country shares my emptiness.

"I accept that Romania played well and knocked the ball around skilfully but until those last awful couple of minutes I still felt that we would qualify.

"However we can look forward to the future with confidence, with an exceptional motivator like Kevin Keegan at the top and players like David Beckham, Michael Owen, Steven Gerrard, Paul Scholes and Emile Heskey around it is only a matter of time before England achieve the success that everyone hungers for.

"I have enjoyed every moment of my international career - the pride I have felt just pulling on the white shirt will stay with me forever."

webTitle: Last gasp penalty knocks out England

fields.headline: Last gasp penalty knocks out England
fields.standfirst: They're coming home:  3-2 defeat ends European adventure
fields.trailText: England were knocked out of Euro 2000 in the most dramatic fashion last night when a penalty two minutes from the end gave Romania a 3-2 victory.
fields.body:
England were knocked out of Euro 2000 in the most dramatic fashion last night when a penalty two minutes from the end gave Romania a 3-2 victory.

Ioan Viorel Ganea scored the goal that ended Kevin Keegan's dream of a quarter-final date with Italy on Saturday after a clumsy challenge by the England defender Phil Neville gave away the penalty.

There were no reports of any violence from England fans in Charleroi before or during the match, which was played in a festive atmosphere amid nail-biting tension.

England, who needed just a point to qualify for the quarter-finals, fell behind to a goal from Christian Chivu in the 21st minute and looked to be going out of the tournament in a first half dominated by the Romanians.

But in the 39th minute Alan Shearer gave Keegan a lifeline with his 30th goal for his country, joining Tom Finney and Nat Lofthouse as the fourth highest goalscorers for their country.

The England captain started the move that led to the goal when he fed the ball into the path of Paul Ince, who was brought down by Chivu. The referee instantly pointed to the penalty spot. Up stepped Shearer to send the goalkeeper, Stelea, the wrong way.

In first-half injury time England completed a remarkable turnaround in fortunes when Michael Owen put them ahead. Paul Scholes played the ball over the defence into the path of Owen who kept his head as he clipped the ball wide of the advancing Stelea before turning it into an empty net from an acute angle.

Three minutes into the second half, however, the Romanians drew level when Munteanu volleyed home after a weak punch by the goalkeeper, Nigel Martyn - who was only playing because David Seaman injured himself in the pre-match warm up.

In sweltering temperatures of over 30c before the kick-off, England fans partied instead of causing trouble.

In Charleroi's main square, the scene of most of the violence before the game with Germany on Saturday afternoon, there was a carnival atmosphere as bands played and fans enjoyed the sunshine dancing in fountains.

Around 2,000 police officers were on duty and all tables and chairs had been removed from the main square.

Uefa, European football's governing body, and the Belgian authorities became embroiled in controversy in the run-up to last night's match over the serious trouble caused by Turkish fans in Brussels on Monday night.

Several bars were smashed and there were a number of skirmishes between fans and police, but Gerhard Aigner, Uefa chief executive, described the events as a giant party that went wrong.

Francois-Eavier de Donnea, the mayor of Brussels, said after the violence that the initial trouble caused by English fans over the weekend was to blame.

He added: "There were people still looking for British hooligans for revenge. They still feel they were psychologically attacked by British hooligans. It was not a good idea to provoke them. It started a chain reaction that was hard to stop."

The comments were attacked as a "disgrace" by Kevin Miles of the Football Supporters Association.

Police admitted yesterday that many of the 921 fans arrested over the weekend might have been innocent. Col Herman Biki, coordinator of the security operation, said: "We regret that. That's a problem but it's rather difficult to spot the difference between those who have committed a crime and those who have done nothing."

fields.headline: Jewell appointed Wednesday manager
fields.trailText: Paul Jewell has been appointed the new manager of Sheffield Wednesday. He has signed a three-year deal at Hillsborough.
fields.body:
Paul Jewell has been appointed the new manager of Sheffield Wednesday. He has signed a three-year deal at Hillsborough.

Bradford yesterday gave their Yorkshire rivals permission to speak to the Liverpudlian, and Wednesday chairman Howard Culley sealed the deal this morning.

Jewell quit Bradford over the weekend claiming he had lost his enthusiasm for the job. He kept the Bantams in the top flight with a last game win over Liverpool, while Wednesday lost their Premiership status.

Richmond gave Wednesday permission to approach Jewell after he realised that he could not persuade him to stay at Valley Parade, despite two successful years in charge - including promotion to the Premiership 12 months ago.

The Bantams chairman initially refused to accept Jewell's resignation and placed him on paid leave. Richmond was determined Bradford would not miss out on compensation for their boss, who had two years left on his contract.

His stance paid off, with Wednesday now due to pay Bradford compensation having given Jewell the job.

fields.headline: Hague bids for religious vote
fields.standfirst: William Hague's letter in The Times link
fields.trailText: Conservative leader William Hague today made a bid for the religious vote with a promise to address what he calls the government's "disregard for the faith dimension in national life and the failure to promote the family".
fields.body:
Conservative leader William Hague today made a bid for the religious vote with a promise to address what he calls the government's "disregard for the faith dimension in national life and the failure to promote the family".

Mr Hague accused public policies of "riding roughshod"' over the common sense values of families in Britain and calls for "a more generous acknowledgement of the role of faith communities" in an article in the Times.

Modern families' concerns, he said, include broadcasting standards, drugs, relationships and education. The Tory leader cited the government's recent abolition of the married couple's allowance as an example of the "wrong message" being given about the importance of family life.

"The consequences of government policy's subversion of the public's values are most serious for those people who can least afford it," Mr Hague said.

Britain's poorest communities, where the support structures are often very weak, have to rely on churches and other faith communities to pioneer "innovative projects to help people overcome multiple disadvantages."

But the Conservative leader argued that successful faith-based programmes are often denied government funds because of their "spiritual foundations", while the European Union's proposed employment directive could imperil their independence.

"I will fight to protect the independence of faith-based projects as well as the right of potential users of such programmes to choose a secular alternative," Mr Hague promised.

His comments were timed to coincide with the Tory leader meeting some of the principal advisers behind the "compassionate conservatism" doctrine of US Republican presidential candidate George W Bush.

Mr Bush has promised greater freedom for religious charities working with the poor and proposed that Christian organisations would be paid by the government to run drug treatment, health care, child care or homelessness hostels.

Presbyterian church elder Marvin Olasky, Mr Bush's adviser on welfare and social policy, will brief Mr Hague on his work in getting Christian religious groups involved in tackling inner city problems such as housing, family breakdown and drugs.

Professor Olasky, a Texas University lecturer who is being accompanied on his trip to London by Don Willett, Mr Bush's special projects director, are also expected to meet other shadow cabinet members.

Mr Olasky told the Today programme that he had discussed his ideas with Mr Hague's aides and believed that they were applicable to the UK.

He said: "The state should make greater use of folks who are willing to volunteer to help their neighbours.

"Our experience in America is that people in churches and mosques are very willing to come forward and that has been the most effective form of poverty-fighting, using one-to-one help rather than going to a bureaucracy.

"In recent years in America, we have been able to reduce the number of people on welfare by half, with families being helped and children seeing that there is an alternative to welfare dependency.

"The emphasis is on people doing all they can to work and to be citizens. It has been very helpful in the US and from what I hear it would help in the UK too."

fields.headline: Thin end of the wedge
fields.standfirst: Today, the government's 'super-waif summit' will debate the causes of eating disorders in girls.  Hadley Freeman, who was hospitalised for four years with anorexia as a teenager, reveals that while images of skinny celebrities did not cause her illness, they did delay her recovery
fields.trailText: Today, the government's 'super-waif summit' will debate the causes of eating disorders in girls. Hadley Freeman, who was hospitalised for four years with anorexia as a teenager, reveals that while images of skinny celebrities did not cause her illness, they did delay her recovery
fields.body:
In a way, Alexandra Shulman is absolutely right: you do not catch anorexia from Vogue magazine. At today's summit meeting, she and the other editors of fashion magazines can sit down, safe in the knowledge that the pages of their publications do not carry some kind of bacteria that will make their readers anorexic.

Anorexia and bulimia are not trendy, zeitgeist illnesses. There are records of anorexics from as far back as the 16th century, so there is no point in trying to relate the cause of the illness to current pop-cultural issues.

No one would argue that alcoholism is caused by beer advertisements, and the concern that Trainspotting would lead to kids shooting up on the streets is now, at last, widely scorned. Nevertheless, lazy commentators still make the simplified assumption that too much Kate Moss is bad for your health. The truth is far more complicated. I know from painful experience - I suffered from severe anorexia through most of my teenage years, spending almost four of them in hospital. All because I, quite simply, stopped eating.

As studies routinely prove, the underlying causes of anorexia (as much as any psychologist can ascertain) are depression and childhood trauma. It can even be genetic. Far more complex, in other words, than the simple desire to fit into a size eight.

Like alcoholism and drug addiction, eating disorders tear families apart. Parents, husbands, children, wives (an increasing number of men suffer from eating disorders) watch with a desperate helplessness as their loved ones slowly, seemingly wilfully, kill themselves. To suggest that all this misery is caused by a jealousy of Kate Moss or out of petulant vanity is insulting.

So yes, the fashion industry can pat itself on the back: it is not from reading too many copies of a magazine that people decide to starve themselves to death.

And yet. When models are becoming increasingly bony, when the ideal clothing size is diminishing every year, with actresses proudly showing off their hip bones and clavicles at this year's Academy Awards, when actresses and models who still need to wear a bra are called "curvy", there is something very unhealthy going on. To watch the current series of Ally McBeal on television is a particularly fascinating experience, with actress Calista Flockhart's tendons becoming more prominent each passing week. Yet she is being celebrated as an icon of feminine beauty and independence in at least two magazines this month. People in the fashion and entertainment industries are deliberately and belligerently missing the point when they storm that they don't "cause" anorexia.

An eating disorder is a mental illness. It is characterised by the sufferer's belief that they are too fat, that to survive on 500 calories a day is the norm, that doctors are trying to make them fat, that weighing more than seven stone is obese and unacceptable. So far, so paranoid.

Yet the current culture of skinniness legitimises the anorexic's beliefs. That is where the danger lies. Once a person becomes severely anorexic, they are usually too locked into their own little world to care if Jennifer Aniston is now a size six, or to read about Jodie Kidd's protruding hip bones. But when they try to recover, it is very difficult to shake off these old beliefs when every other magazine cover seems to validate them.

Unquestionably, models and actresses are now expected to be thinner than ever before, and we are becoming inured to the situation. When these women become dangerously, bone-jutting skinny, they garner more publicity, more adulation, more success. This then becomes a vicious circle, with such images of skinniness being seen as the image of a Successful Woman. Calista Flockhart, Portia de Rossi, Lara Flynn Boyle, Sarah Michelle Gellar, Elizabeth Hurley, Courtney Cox and Jennifer Aniston were all, at most, moderately well-known actresses before their ribcages began to show. Now, particularly in the case of Flockhart and Aniston, they are to be seen marching down red carpets, clad in Versace dresses, beaming out from magazine covers, feted in high-fashion magazines which had previously ignored them. One US fashion magazine is said to have splashed out on a Marc Jacobs cashmere jumper to disguise what even it recognised as excessive skinniness during a cover shoot with Flockhart. Thousands of models walk down the catwalks every year, yet it was Jodie Kidd who grabbed the press's attention when she strutted down, vertebrae visible to all.

These women then become caught: the media focuses on them, with a mixture of fascination, adulation and voyeurism, so they are unable to put on any weight without making headlines. They are not to be attacked for being so thin; nor should they be blamed for making teenage girls push away uneaten plates of food, as Kate Moss was five years ago. They are simply manipulating (consciously or not) today's culture to their advantage, and the blame for this culture lies firmly on the heads of the media. Instead of pitying actresses and models who look pale, wan, ill, they are feted as symbols of wealthy, successful women. Incredibly, some fashion magazines have even made this a moral issue, claiming that they are defending a woman's right to be thin. Of course, no one should be criticised for their natural body shape. However, to look at some of the women in today's fashion and media industries is a painful experience. Everything about them, from their sunken eyes, thinning hair, bony arms and pigeon chests is a visual emblem of their self-denial and the misogyny propagated by this culture of thin. Women are not meant to look like women, they should resemble pre-pubescent boys.

My own anorexia kept me in hospital almost continuously for four years and I never imagined it was possible to be so unhappy. I weighed five stone and yet still exercised compulsively up to six hours a day. My day was built around how to avoid eating ("If I say I'm meeting someone for coffee, my mum won't make me eat breakfast"), how to exercise as much as possible (always take the stairs, never the lift) and just how to make it through the day. I was always cold - a cold that ripped through my increasingly visible bones, rather than one I could block out with my beloved baggy clothes.

While my school friends, with whom I quickly lost touch, were going to parties and having their first snogs, I wasted these years crying on a hospital bed. I was always the youngest patient on the ward, and my closest friends were women and men 20 years older than me who had been ill for decades. At least three of them have died since my last admission. I took my GCSEs sitting cross-legged in a consulting room while a teacher from my school stood outside, asking the nurses to "keep the patients a bit quieter, please". This is not a part of my life of which I am particularly proud. However, I find it easier to talk about anorexia than to sit back quietly when people claim that it is entirely to do with models, or, conversely, that the current veneration of thinness is blameless. Both positions are simplistic.

When I was in hospital, the other patients and I hardly ever talked about models. The doctors and my parents would try to assure me that all of my fears about fatness and food and my beliefs about the importance of thinness were the illness talking. Yet when I was finally discharged, I was amazed to find myself in a culture which seemed to disprove all of the doctor's assurances. These images had been irrelevant to me when I became ill, but, now that I was trying to recover, they fed into all of my thoughts.

I read articles in women's magazines that could have been written by me when I was locked on the ward at the Maudsley Hospital. There were models in magazines who looked like my former fellow patients. There was Elizabeth Hurley saying she would commit suicide were she as fat as Marilyn Monroe. I felt like the paranoid in a horror movie who realises that his worst fears are, in fact, real. There is something very wrong when society condones an attitude reminiscent of the beliefs I held when I was ill.

For a while, I used this as an excuse not to get better. If models, actresses and other women didn't eat and obsessed about weight, then why should I have to change? Why were doctors picking on me?

When I was finally discharged from hospital I weighed about six-and-a-half stone. Although most people commented on how thin I was, dozens of women used to do so with a tone of envy. I remember a group of women coming up to me in the street to congratulate me on my "sticky legs", counselling me not to put on any weight because "you can wear anything and look good when you're so thin". I went into a shop and cried.

I finally began to recover when I realised that I could no longer bear being so unhappy, and accepted that this meant eating on a regular basis. I had to stop myself reading women's magazines, at least while I was putting on the weight, and stop desperately scanning magazine diet (or "health") articles and gazing at the models.

When I look at these women now, I no longer feel the instinctive pang of envy, but rather one of pity. I remember, all too clearly, what it felt like to have that constant roar of hunger in my head and that feeling of being totally trapped and helpless. In their eyes, beneath the carefully applied eyeshadow and concealer, there is a familiar misery reflected back at the camera. The memory of that feeling girds me against ever letting myself slip back into the illness again.

Ironically, I now work in fashion journalism, which is why I feel even more strongly about this issue. Fashion does not need to present dangerously ill images of women. Fashion is about beautiful clothes, and fashion editors risk alienating their audiences and losing touch with any concept of reality with their needless promotion of the bony look.

Models don't cause anorexia, but that does not mean that the fashion industry is off the hook and that we should maintain the status quo. We have to ask, why are women who weigh seven stone venerated as icons of beauty? The common reply from fashion magazines is that the sample sizes of clothing they receive are getting smaller, so they need to use models who can fit into a size eight or six. If this is the case, then they need to insist on sample sizes being bigger - this is not a difficult situation to resolve, and it needs to be resolved soon.

Should we hang, draw and quarter magazine editors? Of course not. But we have to ask, do we really want to live in a culture in which the icons of beauty resemble patients in a hospital?
