There is something very wrong when society condones an attitude reminiscent of the beliefs I held when I was ill. For a while, I used this as an excuse not to get better. If models, actresses and other women didn't eat and obsessed about weight, then why should I have to change? Why were doctors picking on me? When I was finally discharged from hospital I weighed about six-and-a-half stone. Although most people commented on how thin I was, dozens of women used to do so with a tone of envy. I remember a group of women coming up to me in the street to congratulate me on my "sticky legs", counselling me not to put on any weight because "you can wear anything and look good when you're so thin". I went into a shop and cried. I finally began to recover when I realised that I could no longer bear being so unhappy, and accepted that this meant eating on a regular basis. I had to stop myself reading women's magazines, at least while I was putting on the weight, and stop desperately scanning magazine diet (or "health") articles and gazing at the models. When I look at these women now, I no longer feel the instinctive pang of envy, but rather one of pity. I remember, all too clearly, what it felt like to have that constant roar of hunger in my head and that feeling of being totally trapped and helpless. In their eyes, beneath the carefully applied eyeshadow and concealer, there is a familiar misery reflected back at the camera. The memory of that feeling girds me against ever letting myself slip back into the illness again. Ironically, I now work in fashion journalism, which is why I feel even more strongly about this issue. Fashion does not need to present dangerously ill images of women. Fashion is about beautiful clothes, and fashion editors risk alienating their audiences and losing touch with any concept of reality with their needless promotion of the bony look. Models don't cause anorexia, but that does not mean that the fashion industry is off the hook and that we should maintain the status quo. We have to ask, why are women who weigh seven stone venerated as icons of beauty? The common reply from fashion magazines is that the sample sizes of clothing they receive are getting smaller, so they need to use models who can fit into a size eight or six. If this is the case, then they need to insist on sample sizes being bigger - this is not a difficult situation to resolve, and it needs to be resolved soon. Should we hang, draw and quarter magazine editors? Of course not. But we have to ask, do we really want to live in a culture in which the icons of beauty resemble patients in a hospital?

webTitle: How the Germans got our joke

fields.headline: How the Germans got our joke
fields.standfirst: For centuries our Teutonic cousins have remained unmoved by our sense of humour. So why are they remaking Fawlty Towers? James Hopkin reports
fields.trailText: For centuries our Teutonic cousins have remained unmoved by our sense of humour. So why are they remaking Fawlty Towers? James Hopkin reports
fields.body:
The news that a German television network is to remake Fawlty Towers will have sounded to many this side of the Maginot Line like the set-up line for a bad joke. To observers of Teutonic culture, though, the return of Basil Fawlty to German screens - he has already goose-stepped across them once in a dubbed version of the British comedy classic - is the latest sign of a subtle but significant change. At last, the Germans seem to be getting our jokes.

For years, the stereotypical view of Germans has been of a race utterly devoid of a sense of humour - the sort of character typified by Harry Enfield's contrite yet overbearing Jürgen the German. Yet over the past few years, a new brand of German comedy has been developing. The humour of the younger generation, especially those who have grown up since reunification, is much more western, more ironic, less considered - even frivolous.

No one knows what makes the Germans laugh better than Professor Hans-Dieter Gelfert, fellow of English literature at the Freie University in Berlin. Gelfert's book, From Max to Monty, offers a historical analysis of the difference between the British and German senses of humour. Spanning four centuries, this scrupulous study traces the evolution of humour in the two countries through literature, philosophy, and popular culture.

"Traditional German humour is often marked by Gemütlichkeit - a cosiness. It's an unencumbered, warm-hearted humour, and it has dominated practically everything," he says. "This humour still survives today, but chiefly among the elderly and the more conservative middle classes. For this reason, 'cosy' humour is still the predominant form of humour in our TV programmes."

Another aspect of traditional German humour, says Gelfert, is its tendency to moralise. He cites political cabaret as an example. "It's very different from English political satire, which is often cruel and amoral. The English laugh at themselves and at their most sacred values, and are always keen to challenge authority - that's what foreigners love about the English. And that's the exact opposite of German humour. Our political cabaret, however cruel it may be, is totally in favour of the authority of the moral system."

Germans, meanwhile, are puzzled by the British fondness for eccentricity - the mad granny, the alcoholic aunt. "The Germans want to keep these characters backstage, because eccentricity means tension, deviation from the norm."

Then there is our predilection for punning and wordplay. This is more common in English, says Gelfert, because of the greater number of homophones and monosyllabic words in the Anglo-Saxon language.

Perhaps most important of all is the difference in irony. "English irony is the subtle irony of understatement; they go below what they mean. The Germans, on the other hand, go above what they mean; they practise irony by overstatement."

Increasingly, though, many of these characteristics are being superseded by a new brand of German humour, says Gelfert. "Urban, rebellious, anarchic" - all systems and authorities are viewed with disdain. The growing band of self-mythologising young pop writers in Germany are a case in point. In witty novels such as Generation Golf and Relax, they display a studied disregard for all that has gone before. Their humour is fast and superficial. There is no longer the same degree of respect for the profound, ordering principles of society. The straight-faced German could soon be a thing of the past.

Another example is the singer-comedian, Stefan Raab, who graced our screens in his glittery suit and oversized specs in this year's Eurovision Song Contest. The song, philosophically entitled Wadde Hadde Dudde Da? (loosely: What Have You Got There?), exemplified another new aspect of comedy which the Germans call Blÿdelei (meaning foolishness). It's a comedy that incorpo rates funny sounds and gestures and is roughly akin to English slapstick. Raab's song even contained one stanza in English by way of comedic homage.

Raab is something of a star in Germany. He has his own comedy show during which he lampoons his guests, and he used to be a presenter on Viva (the German MTV), where he mocked the pop star guests. His jokes are simple, disposable and mildly offensive. Needless to say, the Eurovision audiences were slightly baffled.

A few people in Germany aren't so sure either. The Bild-Zeitung (the German equivalent of the Sun) ran the headline "Germany divided over Stefan Raab". He has caused a rift beween the followers of traditional German humour, who despise him, and the acolytes of the new style of comedy that is colourful, loud, and nonsensical. Younger Germans in particular adore him.

Gelfert believes the new brand of German humour could help chip away at the outmoded, caricaturish stereotypes that the British and Germans foist on each other. "The German idea of Englishness is old-fashioned, obsolete: a gentleman in a suit with a copy of the Times." Yet the younger generation looks to England for inspiration in fashion and music. For them, an Englishman is a Britpop fan carrying a copy of the NME.

"There has never been a time when so many people have been working for a mutual understanding between the two countries," says Gelfert. He should know. In 1996 he received an award for helping to improve Anglo-German relations with his thoughtful, comparative studies. Who knows, perhaps John Cleese will be up for next year's prize.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the transfer talk bottled at source and efficiently shipped to thirsty people
fields.trailText: Liverpool are interested in Portugal striker Joao Pinto. But the odds on the Merseyside club winning the battle for the Benfica striker's signature are slim: Barcelona, Fiorentina, Paris Saint Germain, Monaco, Sporting Lisbon and Porto are all in the race as well.
fields.body:
Liverpool are interested in Portugal striker Joao Pinto. But the odds on the Merseyside club winning the battle for the Benfica striker's signature are slim: Barcelona, Fiorentina, Paris Saint Germain, Monaco, Sporting Lisbon and Porto are all in the race as well.

Manchester United are interested in £6.7m Portuguese defender Beto, according to Planet Football. But they face competition from Roma for the Sporting Lisbon centre half.

Leeds are preparing a bid for Slovenian defender Aleksander Knavs, who also interests Bayern Munich and Benfica. However, there's bad news for David O'Leary: the 24-year-old centre half, who plays for Tirol Innsbruck, is said to favour Bayern.

Tottenham want Belgian midfielder Marc Wilmots, but will not meet his club Schalke 04's £6.5m valuation.

Chelsea and Arsenal are chasing Belgium defender Joos Valgaeren. The left-footed defender is rated at £7m by his club Roda.

Alessandro Pistone is interested in moving to Everton. The 24-year-old is expected to hold talks with the Toffees next week.

fields.headline: Crown of discomfort
fields.standfirst:
Today the heir to the throne turns 18. So here is a special birthday message for Prince William
The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Today the heir to the throne turns 18. So here is a special birthday message for Prince William
fields.body:
Happy Birthday dear William, happy birthday to you! I know, I know - today is going to be a frightful bore, what with all that revision for the history of art exam tomorrow - but I just thought I'd sneak in a quick "many happy returns" for your big day.

No, don't worry. I'm not going to wade through all that tedious "Wills comes of age" stuff the papers have been dumping on us for the past three weeks. Talk about Yawnsville! I couldn't care less about your Groovy Baby, union jack waistcoat; I'm not bothered whether you are a dab hand with a chicken paella or have been groping a triple-barrelled deb on John Latsis's yacht. I don't care.

That's not because you're not important. You are. Whether we like it or not, you are predestined to be the head of state of the country I and 60 million others live in. While you're at it, you'll be the titular head of Canada, New Zealand and Australia - as well as a string of other, smaller nations dotted all over the globe. You matter a lot.

Some people will say (though not to your face), that your powers will be purely "ceremonial". Don't believe a word of it. Talk to your granny instead: she'll set you right. She's understood for nearly half a century that she occupies a central place in the British constitution. In a deadlocked situation, she gets to choose which party leader should be given first shot at forming a government - or even to call fresh elections. She signs the bills which become our laws. Don't be fooled, William. We still live in a land ruled by crown prerogative, with vast authority concentrated at the very top.

There's another word to watch out for, besides ceremonial. Defenders of your birthright will use it often. The monarchy no longer matters, they'll say: it's only symbolic. They're half right. Right that it's symbolic - wrong that it's "only". As I suspect you already know, symbols matter, especially to a nation. They tell the rest of the world - and ourselves - who we think we are. Just look at the fuss we made last night of the England football team. The head of state is like that writ large: a person who serves as the living embodiment of our values, our traditions and our ideals. It's a big job. No "only" about it.

So how come I don't care whether you're exchanging raunchy emails with Britney Spears or adolescent phero-mones with Isabella Anstruther-Gough-Calthorpe, the gel from a family so good they named it thrice? I don't care because it's not fair - to us or to you.

Take us first. I think it diminishes us a nation that we can make a national event out of a few snaps of an 18-year-old boy, even one as photogenic as you. I think it makes us smaller as a people to read 30 bland questions and 30 blander answers from a young man who has done precisely nothing. To publish these across 12 Daily Mail pages, including long analyses decoding the hidden meaning of responses such as "I don't know" or "I haven't really thought about it" is a kind of national humiliation.

It's not you, I promise. It's equally belittling that TV newsreaders wear solemn faces and give fat minutes of airtime to announce that the Queen met Camilla, as they did at the start of the month. What would that look like to a visitor from abroad? What kind of tinpot, chocolate-soldier Ruritania is it that makes room on an evening news bulletin for a tale which belongs in the Eurotrash pages of Hola! magazine? It makes Britain little better than a wet-weather Monaco.

So I don't like what it does to us. But I don't think it does much good to you either. "I don't like the attention," you said in one of the few full answers supplied to that questionnaire at the weekend. "I feel uncomfortable with it." I bet you do. For we, through the media we all keep in business, have already made your adolescence pretty freakish and are well on the way to making your adult life a high-octane, plushly lined observation tank.

Most kids are allowed to grow up and make their mistakes with the teasing of family and friends the only sanction. You have no such freedom. You can't be snapped with a glass in hand, lest you look like a lush. You can't dye your hair or pierce an ear without setting off a national debate. Even before you turned 18, the broadsheet newspapers speculated over whether you had lost your virginity. And when. And where.

You are the one school leaver in Britain who can never take advantage of New Labour's rhetoric of "opportunity for all". When Gordon Brown goes on about creating a society where young people can be whatever they want to be, you should plug your ears - because it doesn't apply to you. Just as a century ago the son of a miner had no choice - he had to become a miner - so you, too have no choice. Never mind your talents or dreams, they will all come to nought. Your course has been set. You will be our head of state; you have no say.

I admit it, this is a new line for us republicans. For centuries the very word has evoked images of Jacobin execution squads, hooded men plotting to place you and your kin at the mercy of the guillotine. Even in your own, brief lifetime republicans have seemed, if not thirsty for blue blood, then at least unbothered by the plight of your family. Throughout the 90s, anti-monarchists too often came across as resentful green-eyes who wished ill fortune on an already blighted dynasty.

It doesn't have to be that way. There is no contradiction between a desire to fill Britain's ultimate job by democratic means and an empathy for the family who've been saddled with it for the best part of a millennium - your family. On the contrary, there is a connection between the two. For democrats can reach out to the doubters and defenders of monarchy by making a new case: call it pro-Windsor republicanism.

We could say that your grandmother is a good woman who's done an impossible job - and that we have no business asking her family to do it any longer. We could wish her a long and healthy life and promise that, when the time comes, we will give her a full state funeral, with all the honours. But we could also promise, at that same moment, to bury this fairytale institution with her. Not just for our sake, but for all of you. You know first-hand, from the tragic fate of your parents, what cost this constant, inherited demand exacts. The prying, invasive interest in you is already growing. It destroyed your mother: you must fear what it will do to you.

I should let you go; you have an exam to prepare for. But today you turn 18; you join an age group which is more republican than any other. If you meet the untitled among your peers, as well as the Davinas and the Zaras, you'll hear more of this kind of talk. Think on it. To wish the end of the monarchy is not to wish the end of your family - but rather a new beginning. Good luck, William - and happy birthday.

fields.headline: Fiji coup nears end
fields.trailText: Fiji's temporary military regime and the rebels who have been holding 31 people, including the prime minister, hostage, claim to be nearing an agreement to end the month-long crisis.
fields.body:
Fiji's temporary military regime and the rebels who have been holding 31 people, including the prime minister, hostage, claim to be nearing an agreement to end the month-long crisis.

Indigenous rebel leader George Speight said today that he expected to sign a deal with the Fijian military by the end of this week. An agreement is believed likely to give him and his leaders protection from arrest, as well as some role in an interim government.

Both Mr Speight and the military, led by Commodore Frank Bainimarama, have told local Fijian media that the latest round of negotiations are the closest they have reached to bringing the crisis to an end, which began when armed rebels took control of parliament on 19 May.

Mr Speight's spokesman Jo Nata confirmed that "a preliminary accord has been drafted and has been gone through by lawyers and all the parties, and could be signed by this afternoon."

Mr Nata refused to reveal a timetable for the release of the hostages, including the ethnic Indian prime minister Mahendra Chaudhry, saying, "The release of the hostages is not of importance to us."

The hostages have been held inside Fiji's parliament for 34 days and are showing signs of trauma caused by isolation and fear for their safety, reported the director of Fiji's Red Cross branch John Scott.

"Some people have become withdrawn, to say the least," said Mr Scott, the only person apart from the captors who has been allowed regular visits with the hostages.

Despite progress in the negotiations, the decision to dismiss Mr Chaudhry and abandon Fiji's 1997 constitution, which guaranteed equal rights for indigenous Fijians and ethnic Indians, is seen as a blow to race relations in the country.

"The power of the gun must not be allowed to dictate policy," said an editorial Tuesday by The Fiji Times newspaper.

The military and Mr Speight's armed rebels are haggling over how to implement the demands of Mr Speight, who led the May 19 armed takeover of parliament amid widespread looting and street violence. The military took control of Fiji and imposed martial law 10 days after the coup.

On Monday, Mr Speight suggested that he could be willing to allow a few Indians in the interim government, although reinstating Mr Chaudhry is not on the negotiating table.

Today Mr Speight backed away from that statement. "Our very strong view, which is the reason why this whole coup happened, is that no non-Fijian should be included in lawmaking or the promulgation of a new constitution," he said.

Commodore Bainimarama has announced a plan to restore civilian rule by appointing an interim administration to oversee a recasting of the constitution and hold elections within two years.

The United States, Australia and New Zealand have said they will impose sanctions on Fiji if it does not return to full democracy.

webTitle: Stars to make Method work at Actors' Studio

fields.headline: Stars to make Method work at Actors' Studio
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Acting, said Marlon Brando in a moment of self-denial, is an empty and useless profession. Fortunately for movie- and theatre-goers, Al Pacino, Harvey Keitel and Ellen Burstyn would beg to differ. The three actors have taken over the leadership of the world's best-known theatre workshop, the Actors Studio, home of the Method, once derided as "armpit acting".
fields.body:
Acting, said Marlon Brando in a moment of self-denial, is an empty and useless profession. Fortunately for movie- and theatre-goers, Al Pacino, Harvey Keitel and Ellen Burstyn would beg to differ.

The three actors have taken over the leadership of the world's best-known theatre workshop, the Actors Studio, home of the Method, once derided as "armpit acting".

The 53-year-old New York school, founded by the late Lee Strasberg, was based on the principles of Constantin Stanislavsky, who preached assimilation of character through mental exercises rather than the conventions of the 19th century.

Brando was its best-known student but others associated with the school and its attachment to realism include Paul Newman, James Dean, Montgomery Clift, Anthony Quinn, Marilyn Monroe, Robert Duvall, Robert De Niro, Lee Grant and Dustin Hoffman.

Strasberg's big idea was to train actors to draw on sense memory to recreate emotions on stage or screen.

But Newman, a former president of the studio, is equivocal about its influence and said of Strasberg: "I found everything that he was teaching fascinating, but I could never really make it work for me."

Pacino, Keitel and Burstyn have been named as co-presidents to replace the director Arthur Penn, who is leaving to produce a television series.

Mr Penn said: "There was a period there that the torn undershirt and Brando's mumbling became sort of fair game for making fun of the studio."

Mr Penn was instrumental in opening up the once-inscrutable institution, which now has a spin-off cable television series of interviews with actors and a master's degree course.

It was conceived in 1947 by Elia Kazan, Cheryl Crawford and Robert Lewis as a place where actors could experiment and develop their work and now the studio wants to return to their aesthetic code, liberated from the demands of commerce.

"We want to work toward making it that kind of place again, a place of refuge from the commercial world," said Estelle Parsons, the artistic director.

webTitle: After 50 years, we still don't quite get him

fields.headline: After 50 years, we still don't quite get him
fields.standfirst: Michael Billington  on Britain's love-hate relationship with Tennessee Williams
fields.trailText: Michael Billington on Britain's love-hate relationship with Tennessee Williams
fields.body:
You could say that Tennessee Williams is back. Birmingham Rep's production of Baby Doll moves into London's Albery Theatre tonight and Orpheus Descending opens next week at the Donmar Warehouse. But then, I never really felt that Williams had been away: his sympathetic surveys of desperation, loneliness and beleaguered idealism have been part of our theatrical landscape ever since The Glass Menagerie and A Streetcar Named Desire opened in Britain in the late 40s. Yet although Williams has been with us for half a century, one still wonders whether we get him precisely right.

Initially, he was seen in Britain as a lurid sensationalist. When Streetcar was first produced here in 1949, one critic wrote that he felt as if he had "crawled through a garbage heap". The play was denounced in parliament as "low and repugnant" and dubbed "salacious and pornographic" by the public morality council.

Nine years later, when Peter Hall directed the British premiere of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, the Comedy Theatre had to be turned into a private club in order to circumvent the prying attentions of the theatrical censor, the Lord Chamberlain; a Pulitzer prize-winning play acquired the reputation of a banned shocker. But Williams also made Americans go hot under the collar: when Elia Kazan's film of Baby Doll was released in 1956 Time magazine called it "just about the dirtiest American-made motion picture that has ever been legally exhibited" and Cardinal Spellman denounced it as "immoral and corrupting".

With enemies like that, Williams scarcely needed friends: the hysteria his plays and films generated helped to turn them into box-office hits. But just because Williams was mistakenly seen as a salacious sensationalist, his apologists were forced to treat him rather gushingly, as if he were a theatrical Mother Teresa overflowing with Christian love. In fact he did have a religious instinct: in his later, drug-fuelled years, Tallulah Bankhead once wittily remarked, "Tennessee, you and I are the only constantly high Episcopalians I know." It is also true that Williams shows great charity to life's walking wounded. But, to me, he was both a more comically caustic and a more instinctively political writer than our theatre generally acknowledges.

Williams certainly viewed his own life through a comic prism. We tend to see The Glass Menagerie as fragile poetry, but there are stories of managements being asked to remove Williams from public performances because of his disruptive chuckles. I also once had the unnerving experience of trying to summarise the plot of Williams's Vieux Carre on a radio programme while he sat opposite me. As I described the autobiographical hero's sad early struggles in New Orleans, I was confronted by dismaying explosions of laughter. Williams clearly looked back on his own life not with anger but with a buoyant hilarity.

Undeniably, Williams was deeply sensitive to life's pain and cruelty. But he also has the eldritch humour that is part of the southern gothic tradition. In Small Craft Warnings, which shows a group of human flotsam convening in a seedy Pacific beach-bar, an ageing beautician dumps herself down beside a broody gay couple and barks, "Well, boys, what went wrong?" More famously, Cat on a Hot Tin Roof deals with people who refuse to face the truth of life; but it also mocks a grotesque Mississippi delta family whose teeming children are characterised as no-neck monsters. "It's too bad because you can't wring their necks if they've got no necks to wring," cries the frustrated Maggie. Williams's famous compassion was always accompanied by a sly awareness of the human comedy that has often gone unrecognised by British directors - with signal exceptions such as Peter Hall and Richard Eyre.

Alongside the comedy goes a keen awareness of the deep injustice of American life. It is fascinating how many of Williams's plays revolve around the corrupt power structures of the Deep South. And A Streetcar Named Desire, far from being a sensationalist story of an ex-prostitute raped by her brother-in-law, is actually about a confrontation of values. Blanche Dubois may have her pretensions, but she represents poetic sensibility and feeling; Stanley Kowalski, on the other hand, embodies destructive animal force.

Harold Clurman, writing about the original Broadway production with Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy, is the only critic I've come across who grasped the play's social and political resonances. "Stanley," he wrote, "is the unwitting Antichrist of our time, the little man who will break the back of every attempt to create a more comprehensive world in which thought and conscience are expected to evolve from the old Adam. His mentality provides the soil for fascism, viewed not as a political movement but as a state of being."

My gut feeling that underneath Williams's lyricism and comedy lay a writer with a social conscience who hated the stench of injustice was confirmed by the National's excellent revival of the almost unknown Not About Nightingales. Written in 1938 and set in a Philadelphia County jail where a group of inmates go on hunger strike, the play had the bold outline of a Warner Brothers melodrama. But what hit me was Williams's acute understanding of power. The prison was run by an unhinged autocrat backed by state troopers. The inmates were equally dominated by a charismatic ringleader named Butch. Williams shows the prison warden and Butch as class-opposites; he also demonstrates the natural complicity of power - both men are compared to Mussolini - which he clearly detests.

I suspect we have often misunderstood Williams in Britain. First we treated him as if he were a quasi-pornographer. Then we turned him into a woozy mystic. For me Williams is something rather different: both a sardonic observer of life's absurdities - in particular of the grotesqueness of southern reality - and an instinctive radical who was always on the side of the oppressed. He frequently succumbed to rhetoric, but he also had a tough, clear-eyed understanding of the victimisation of the weak by the strong. And it is by his comprehension of the flaws in the American social and political system, as well as by his complex compassion, that all future productions should be judged.

 Baby Doll opens at the Albery Theatre, London WC2 (020-7369 1740), tonight. Orpheus Descending premieres at the Donmar Warehouse, London WC2 (020-7369 1732), on June 27.

fields.headline: Who needs England?
fields.trailText: Who was England's worst player? Who remembers Mick Mills? Who haven't we spoken to for a while?
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

EUROTALK

"In a negative sense the icing on the cake for me was that England went out as well" - Erich Ribbeck not in any way bitter after Germany were stuffed 3-0 by Portugal reserves. That's 3-0. By some reserves.

THE EURO-TORIAL

At 9.36pm last night, England crashed out of Euro 2000. And sadly - no correct that, shamefully - a vast number of the Great British public will have crashed out with them. "With our boys gone, what's the point?" sums up the national mood of indifference this morning.

But why the performance of the England team should make a difference we don't know. Because so far we've enjoyed a great tournament. It's better than Euro 96, which was permeated by safe and soulless 0-0 draws. And it's certainly better than Italia 90, which produced some of the most negative and tedious football ever seen on the big stage. Yet we remember those fondly because England bumbled through, avoiding humiliation.

Of course, it's still too early to tell, but we might be witnessing the best international tournament since Espana 82. For the Brazilian side of Zico and Socrates, there's the French side of Zidane and Henry. And for the Northern Ireland of Gerry Armstrong read Slovenia, supposedly everyone's whipping boys until they rushed into a 3-0 lead against Yugoslavia. In short, there's been very little of the cynical football which has polluted the game for the past couple of decades.

So far we've been entertained by an exciting, attacking and wonderfully invigorating carnival of football. All we need now is a game which compares to 82's France v West Germany semi-final, and we'll have had a tournament to remember. England certainly don't need to be there to provide it. After all, who remembers Mick Mills?

Paul Ince 7.2 - "His legs maybe getting older, but he was still inspired" (The Sun) Paul Scholes 6.8 - "Snappy in the tackle and gave England added aerial options" (The Mirror) David Beckham 6.6 - "Far less threatening than against Portugal and Germany" (Daily Mail) Dennis Wise 6 - "Outclassed by Chelsea team mate Petrescu" (The Express)

Alan Shearer 7 - "Led the line with gusto, if not masses of skill" (Daily Star) Michael Owen 6.6 - "Lively performance, highlighted by an excellent goal" (The Express)

WHAT THE PAPERS SAID

"Nevastated" - The Sun

"Frankly, the warm-up was England's best spell of possession" - John Sadler, The Sun

"The strange thing is that none of us is really surprised if we're honest. Because we know in our hearts that we aren't good enough at football any more" - Editorial, The Mirror

"Those who have campaigned long and hard for Shearer's retention reaped the rewards last night. In an ineffective team, he was ineffectuality itself, the personification of a washed-up hero well past his England sell-by date" - Oliver Holt, The Times

"To be brutally honest, and brutality is the language in which the English have been most articulate during this tournament, Italy would have exposed the bankrupt state of our national game for the whole world to see" - Jeff Powell, Daily Mail

A MESSAGE FROM BREATHE.COM

Football and beer. They go together like... well, top sporting action and a tasty liquid beverage. Win a crate of beer from Lastorders.com for Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com and click on the link on the left hand side.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

No trouble has been reported in Charleroi following England's exit from Euro 2000. There's something at least.

Although Kevin Keegan is adamant he won't resign, Bryan Robson (God save us) has been quoted as 9/2 favourite to replace him as England manager. John Gregory (heaven help us) is second favourite at 6/1, while Peter Reid is an 8/1 shot. Alan Shearer is 33/1 to take over the team. And apparently England's odds on winning the 2002 World Cup have gone out from 12s to 20s. But what do the bookmakers know?

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Hi folks, Karel Poborsky here! Due to one thing and another I haven't had much time to chat to you over the past week. Sorry. And now I'm back, you've all got faces longer than the M1. Talk about timing, eh?

But don't feel too sorry for yourselves. You may feel bad now, but it'll pass. Believe me, I know what I'm talking about, having suffered last-gasp heartbreak myself at the end of the Czech Republic's Euro 96 campaign. OK, so we also enjoyed a series of memorable victories which we'll fondly remember all our lives, but you know what I mean.

Anyway, although us Czechs go home later today, I promise not to leave you until I find some transfer activity involving a big continental club and an England player. So let's look!

Leeds are preparing a bid for Slovenian defender Aleksander Knavs, who also interests Bayern Munich and Benfica. However, there's bad news for David O'Leary: the 24-year-old centre half, who plays for Tirol Innsbruck, is said to favour Bayern.

Liverpool are interested in Portugal striker Joao Pinto. But the odds on the Merseyside club winning the battle for the Benfica striker's signature are slim: Barcelona, Fiorentina, Paris Saint Germain, Monaco, Sporting Lisbon and Porto are all in the race as well.

Tottenham want Belgian midfielder Marc Wilmots, but will not meet his club Schalke 04's £6.5m valuation.

Chelsea and Arsenal are chasing Belgium defender Joos Valgaeren. The left-footed defender is rated at £7m by his club Roda.

Dear me! I do want to go home eventually, you know. Does anybody want to buy a Neville? Buy one, get one free...

By some reserves. THE EURO-TORIAL At 9.36pm last night, England crashed out of Euro 2000. And sadly - no correct that, shamefully - a vast number of the Great British public will have crashed out with them. "With our boys gone, what's the point?" sums up the national mood of indifference this morning. But why the performance of the England team should make a difference we don't know. Because so far we've enjoyed a great tournament. It's better than Euro 96, which was permeated by safe and soulless 0-0 draws. And it's certainly better than Italia 90, which produced some of the most negative and tedious football ever seen on the big stage. Yet we remember those fondly because England bumbled through, avoiding humiliation. Of course, it's still too early to tell, but we might be witnessing the best international tournament since Espana 82. For the Brazilian side of Zico and Socrates, there's the French side of Zidane and Henry. And for the Northern Ireland of Gerry Armstrong read Slovenia, supposedly everyone's whipping boys until they rushed into a 3-0 lead against Yugoslavia. In short, there's been very little of the cynical football which has polluted the game for the past couple of decades. So far we've been entertained by an exciting, attacking and wonderfully invigorating carnival of football. All we need now is a game which compares to 82's France v West Germany semi-final, and we'll have had a tournament to remember. England certainly don't need to be there to provide it. fields.headline: Greek politicians hail euro feat
fields.standfirst:
Single currency: Athens faces more belt tightening after admission to EMU club

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Europe's oldest currency, the drachma, was formally consigned to the bin of history yesterday as Greece, in the name of modernity, was anointed the 12th member of the eurozone.
fields.body:
Europe's oldest currency, the drachma, was formally consigned to the bin of history yesterday as Greece, in the name of modernity, was anointed the 12th member of the eurozone.

Approximately 3,000 years after the ancients first began dabbling in the money, Hellenes were told to begin thinking in terms of euros: after Herculean efforts Greece, the EU's poorest partner, had finally met the stringent economic criteria to join the single currency.

The European Commission president, Romano Prodi, said the feat should serve as an example, not only to EU candidate countries, but those like Britain which still preferred to snub Euroland. Two years ago Athens was left out of the euro club for failing to meet any of the convergence criteria. For those who had watched Greece's profligate ways during the eighties, there were few who believed it would ever make the grade.

"With this one single move Greece has emerged a much stronger country, with more possibilities and much greater self-confidence," the Greek prime minister, Costas Simitis, enthused at the close of the summit yesterday.

While politicians greeted the move with euphoria, ordinary Greeks have met the prospect of the euro with thinly veiled bewilderment.

"Most Greeks, like most Europeans, just don't have a clue what it means," says Constantine Papadopoulos, an adviser for European affairs at Greece's Eurobank. In recent days the Greeks have been bombarded by bulletins informing them on how the new currency will change their lives. The publicity blitz will be officially accelerated in Athens today when merchants attend a conference on what the euro "means for our shops".

"There's not a moment to lose," says Panayis Karellas, president of the 40,000-strong Athens Traders' Association. "We've only got eight months before the start of the transition period. Businessmen are only just beginning to twig that they're going to have to change their tills, the software in their computers, the way they do their accounting ... we're even thinking of asking the government to introduce fake euro notes to acclimatise consumers. " No other country has benefited more from EU funds than Greece. Over the next seven years Athens will receive 50.3bn euros in structural aid, in addition to the £16.2bn pounds already ploughed into infrastructure projects. At over £500 per head of population that is more than any other EU member.

But while meeting EMU goals has ironically done more for the Greek economy than any other (growth rates have jumped in the past three years), entering euroland will not be without its hardship.

Yesterday, Mr Simitis was the first to say that while Greece had achieved nominal economic convergence with its partners the real challenge would now be in meeting "real" economic convergence if the country is to be compet itive in a united Europe. As Europe's most state-dominated economy, with few privatisations and little industry to its name, the government will now have to derugulate the labour market, speed up denationalisations, specialise Greeks in technological skills and modernise an unruly civil service.

Mr Simitis says with the extra money generated by increased growth the Greek state will be able to improve its health, education and social welfare services - areas that have suffered as a result of belt tightening. But after 13 years of economic austerity programmes, the prospect of yet more painful reforms has already met with protests. Sell-offs will lead to higher unemployment, at 11.7 % already the highest in the EU.

fields.headline: Blair's 'psycho-political' problem over the euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday brushed aside renewed pressure from the European Central Bank to accept that there is a window of opportunity for Britain to join the single currency zone - and that the major remaining obstacle is "psycho-political" rather than economic.
fields.byline: Michael White in Santa Maria da Feira
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday brushed aside renewed pressure from the European Central Bank to accept that there is a window of opportunity for Britain to join the single currency zone - and that the major remaining obstacle is "psycho-political" rather than economic.

British diplomats privately flinched at the blunt language deployed by Wim Duisenberg, Dutch president of the ECB, when he addressed MEPs in Strasbourg on the closing day of the EU's summer summit in Portugal, days after Mr Blair's senior cabinet colleagues were sniping at each other over their tactics for handling the promised euro-referendum.

A day after Greece was signed up to become the 12th member of the currency from 2001, Mr Duisenberg reinforced this month's unwelcome message from the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, that Britain is more ready for its own decision than it suits ministers to admit.

Mr Blair said Europe's senior banker had been misunderstood, while side-stepping the main thrust of Mr Duisenberg's charge: that the real problem is public hostility to the euro in Britain and the cabinet's fear of that hostility.

"In principle, membership of a successful single currency is the right course for Britain, but in practice economic conditions have got to be right because it's an economic union. I do not think you will find in the ECB or anywhere else in Europe a misunderstanding of the fact that the economic conditions are important," Mr Blair insisted at the close-of-summit press conference.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, and Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, were at the prime minister's side. The trio were together in public for the first time since last week's quarrel over Mr Brown's well-documented reluctance to countenance a more positive tone on the euro before the general election.

"I have said - and I know Robin will repeat - there are no differences," Mr Brown interjected when asked about the row. Mr Cook, whose Commons speech was trimmed by Downing Street last week, later said: "Gordon, Tony and I have all spoken on this and given interviews in the last week. We have all said exactly the same thing."

Mr Blair blamed the media - "you can write what you like" - and repeatedly emphasised that "the economic conditions have got to be right". He added: "Whenever I ask people to explain what these differences are supposed to be, they can't tell me. There are no divisions."

Mr Duisenberg had earlier told MEPs: "A window of opportunity is becoming increasingly open. Certain obstacles are to be overcome, mainly of a pyscho-political nature.The exchange rate conditions are, to my mind, not yet optimal for the UK to become a full participant at this rate."

fields.headline: Calling the shots
fields.standfirst: From reducing burglaries to placing street lights, residents are getting involved in making decisions that affect their lives. But a balance between councils genuinely listening and total control by residents is vital. Barry Wade reports
fields.trailText: From reducing burglaries to placing street lights, residents are getting involved in making decisions that affect their lives. But a balance between councils genuinely listening and total control by residents is vital. Barry Wade reports
fields.body:
Power to the people it isn't, but there is an undoubted vogue for drawing communities into local government decision-making. And as responsibility and even financial control seep out of the town hall, the role of councils and councillors in the future of regeneration planning seems increasingly uncertain.

Go back almost a decade to events such as the Meadow Well estate riot on Tyneside. Local authorities stood accused of leaving communities feeling isolated, making them tinder boxes for discontent. There has since been a growing effort to involve local people in regeneration work. But with no definite template and New Labour modernisers breathing down their necks, many council leaders feel these are anxious days.

"Local government is in a process of redefining with the public what the role of councils should be," says Ken Hay, head of community development at Cambridge city council. "It's difficult to predict what is going to happen to local councils."

Hay, for one, has seen a marked change in the role of his authority in recent times. "In the last decade," he says, "there has been a shift in how we interact with the public - about quality of services and the opening up of decision-making processes." Five years ago, Cambridge introduced a community planning project targeting four of its poorest wards - Kingshedges, Arbury, Abbey and Coleridge - and some of the tasks of the community development department have since been taken over by residents.

"Initially, it is a city-sponsored project," says Hay, "but councillors, local people and agencies help develop a bid to the city council for resources to meet the outcomes of consultation. The communities direct how council officers develop the consultation process. Once the resources have been allocated they manage the implementation programme. We have tried to devolve as much of the budget as they want and they advise us on capital expenditure."

Residents give more than advice, though. They control refurbishment and redevelopment, construction of play areas and facilities, better lighting and landscaping, and in the Abbey ward there is even a community cafe run by an independent community organisation, which did all the negotiating over the creation of the facility.

Hay hopes that the community-led model will be adopted by other areas of the council, including police and education.

Andy Boys, community forums officer of the Villages Initiative, has seen community involvement widen in Stoke-on-Trent and, as a result, a huge culture shift in the council.

"A change in view by politicians and officers over what knowledge local people can handle is opening the way for us to let the communities control events," Boys says. "Our community safety group was police dominated. Through resident forums, it's gone from police led to joint responsibility. The police are now going to give the community a lot of influence in how burglary reduction funding is to be used and how projects are managed. This is a quantum leap."

The Villages Initiative project insists that partners who carry out council work engage with the community. When engineers were called to fix new street lighting they thought they would call the shots. Instead, residents pulled the purse strings and chose the positioning.

Boys believes that bringing residents into the regeneration process is helping to reshape local government, and that the local government bill could take this process further. "Most councils have adopted a cabinet structure of government and have a lot of councillors who have a residual role in terms of deciding strategic policy," he says. "The modernising agenda could help councillors look back to their constituencies and get involved."

Alison West, chief executive of the Community Development Foundation, also believes that the move to a cabinet style of local government will help draw councillors back to their wards, where their role could include keeping resident-controlled regeneration in check.

She says: "I think there will be a dynamic relationship where democratically elected ward councillors will be crucial to keeping the process of regeneration democratic. "We have central and local government to stop the tyranny of the clique. Resident control can be nasty, and getting a correct balance between making people feel genuinely involved with a safety net of democracy is the challenge."

As it is going to be compulsory under the local government bill for local authorities to organise integrated service delivery for residents, West also sees the role of councillors not elected to the cabinet as one of organisers of service provision, similar to Hay's Cambridge model.

"I think we will see a tripartite system," West says. "Local area plans will be constructed by residents using paid professionals. Then these plans will have to be gathered together by ward councillors. Their job will be to make sure that the plans are compatible with a top-down activity of pulling the major service bureaucracies together."

Whether this means councillors will be spending more time with residents remains to be seen. And we are a long way from total resident management - although, as West points out, that may not be a good thing. But the town hall is changing and, as residents gain more control, Andy Boys is confident they will help redefine the role of the local councillor. He says: "Residents are helping to put councillors back with the people they are supposed to represent, with a mechanism for constant dialogue - instead of just a cross in a box for a councillor they don't see for three years at a time."

webTitle: How volunteering can help tackle depression

fields.headline: First aid
fields.standfirst: It sounds simple but it works. Linda Steele visits a small community organisation helping women break the vicious cycle of depression and isolation through volunteering
fields.trailText: It sounds simple but it works. Linda Steele visits a small community organisation helping women break the vicious cycle of depression and isolation through volunteering
fields.body:
Past the bookies' and the kids hanging around the bus stop, through the shop door, and into three small, lavender-walled rooms. Squashed in between boxes and leaflets, cycle helmets and child car seats are a tired-looking woman trying to decipher a benefits agency decision and a colleague cheerfully answering the phone. In short, Health First is your typical small community development organisation - except, to hear people talk, you'd think it a place of miracles.

"If it hadn't been there, if people hadn't got involved, I really don't think I'd be here," says Lynda Smith. She describes struggling to bring up three children, with a disabled husband, on benefits, and spending "nearly a year indoors on anti-depressants". Now she is involved in the local credit union and a neighbourhood management committee. She has done some training and "might even get a job". And in that shift from despair to optimism lies something of arresting simplicity.

Smith comes from a part of Norwich comprising three pre-war council estates - West Earlham, Marlpit and Larkham. A short hop from the charming city centre, the area known derisively as Monkey Island could be light years away for all it shares in terms of opportunity and wealth. Low pay, unemployment and poverty make a breeding ground for health and social problems, such as drug addiction and mental illness. Psychological disorders, such as agoraphobia, anxiety, bulimia and depression, are rife.

Twelve years ago, a local GP's wife decided to do something about the ill health her husband and his colleagues saw daily. Eilay Laurie felt that the doctors were only scratching the surface. She says: "GPs see symptoms, but I'm interested in causes."

She talked to people in the waiting room and found that "top of their list was not clinical services but worry, stress, poverty, a lack of control and a sense of being second-class citizens". She wheedled some health promotion funding out of the practice and set about organising activities with a handful of local women. Their expertise was crucial. "Local people knew what the problems were and largely what the solutions would be," she says. "They just needed facilitating."

Kim Brown was there at the start and knew the issues at first hand. "I've crawled across the floor with the kids to avoid being seen by the rent man," she says. "I've been beaten by men and thrown downstairs when pregnant."

Brown and fellow Health First employee, Freda Sheehy, can reel off stories of others hauling themselves out of isolation and desperation through volunteering - others such as the battered and depressed young woman who initially described herself as "just a slug in the mud", but now runs children's activities.

Taking part when feeling that low takes a huge effort. Sheehy, Smith's sister, says she virtually "dragged her, kicking and screaming". But Smith did get involved in the activities springing up under the Health First umbrella.

One of the first was Coffee Break. Conceived as a breathing space - with free coffee and crèche - for isolated young mothers, the group invited speakers to talk about topics that concerned them, such as domestic violence, eating disorders and child abuse. Health First has since run art classes, a fitness group, a healthy lunch club, first aid training, advice sessions and a helpline, child safety lessons and a credit union.

For many, isolated by low self-esteem, poverty and sometimes violence, community involvement has fostered a sense of worth and greater control. Some have developed skills that have led to paid employment. And there does seem a sense of stronger community ties.

It's this nurturing of individual and community wellbeing that interests the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health, which today publishes On Your Doorstep, its research into the role non-mental health organisations can play in drawing people with mental illnesses back into the community and even ameliorating their symptoms.

Louise Villeneau, the report's author, says: "Health First is not commissioned to do mental health work. But they promote emotional resilience in families and communities and encourage those with common mental health problems, such as depression, to involve themselves in community development."

Unfortunately, says Villeneau, promoting social integration through community engagement is rarely seen as appropriate for mainstream mental health services. It is understandable but short-sighted, she argues. People with serious, chronic, mental disorders are among the most socially and economically alienated, with a heavy psychological toll. And, put simply, having friends and doing interesting things can reduce stress and protect against ill-health.

While the spotlight has been on tragic but rare cases of mentally ill killers, new national standards not only highlight safety and targeted mental health services, but also health promotion, early intervention and social inclusion. These, and the government's commitment to "joined-up" working, especially through local health improvement programmes, dovetail with community development, the report says.

Paul Henderson, practice development director of the Community Development Foundation, sees advantages in a generic approach for vulnerable people who fear being identified as mentally ill. "Community development offers a non-stigmatising context. One of its basic principles is 'de-labelling' people and neighbourhoods," he says.

Villeneau says that, with "creative" funding and voluntary and statutory partnerships, community development and mental health care are potentially complementary. Schools and leisure centres are prime sites for activities, she argues.

That "creativity" must cut both ways. Welfare to work aside, most major social inclusion programmes, such as action zones and the New Deal for communities, lack a mental health dimension. The Sainsbury report argues that specialist mental health staff are best placed to help generic organisations work with mental illness.

There are obstacles. Not least is community mistrust, which requires a light touch that doesn't come naturally to statutory agencies. But, for now, in Norwich, they're positive. The government's New Deal promises some £35m locally over 10 years for community-led regeneration projects. For Health First, that means another decade of building stronger, happier and healthier communities from within.

fields.headline: Veto threat to EU force
fields.standfirst: Defence: Turks' warning hits plans
fields.trailText: Ambitious plans for European defence suffered a heavy blow last night when Turkey warned it would not allow Nato to lend weapons or equipment to EU military forces.
fields.body:
Ambitious plans for European defence suffered a heavy blow last night when Turkey warned it would not allow Nato to lend weapons or equipment to EU military forces, just hours after EU leaders approved a new agreement on how their fledgling military structures would work in close collaboration with the western alliance.

"It is out of the question for us to accept Nato capabilities and assets being presented for the automatic use of the European Union," the Anatolian news agency quoted the Turkish foreign ministry as saying.

Turkey, a member of Nato since 1950, insists it deserves a decisionmaking role in new European security initiatives after defending Europe's south-eastern borders from the Soviet Union during the cold war. But it is at the very back of the queue for EU membership and resents being lectured about its treatment of the Kurdish minority and human rights abuses.

EU members, pushed by Britain and France, are drawing up plans to act independently of the US and Nato. But EU military efforts will need to "borrow" Nato assets such as heavy transport aircraft, satellite intelligence and in-flight refuelling facilities for years to come. Turkey could block that and render the exercise futile.

The Turkish defence minister, Sabahhattin Cakmakoglu, called on EU leaders to reconsider their decision and reminded them that Turkey could use its veto as a Nato member if needed. "For us the decision taken in Feira is not a final one." Turkish opposition will also fuel fears in the US that the EU eforts could serve to undermine Nato without contributing substantially to European defence.

webTitle: MS drug to be put beyond reach of NHS patients

fields.headline: MS drug to be put beyond reach of NHS patients
fields.standfirst:
Anger as sufferers face 'the most shocking injustice'
The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Beta interferon, the only drug that multiple sclerosis sufferers say gives them any relief from the debilitating progression of their disease, will not be sanctioned for prescription on the NHS by the government's advisory body, it is understood.
fields.body:
Beta interferon, the only drug that multiple sclerosis sufferers say gives them any relief from the debilitating progression of their disease, will not be sanctioned for prescription on the NHS by the government's advisory body, it is understood.

The preliminary decision by the National Institute for Clinical Excellence is likely to anger people with MS.

Peter Cardy, chief executive of the MS Society, said last night: "I think it would be the most shocking injustice - a wicked and dreadful indictment of what kind of society we have come to. There is no alternative for people with MS. There is nothing else that is going to prevent relapses. It would be a ghastly state of affairs if it were not permitted."

There were suggestions last night that patients already taking beta interferon - a very expensive medicine for which only certain health authorities agree to pay - will be allowed to continue with it on the NHS, while new patients are turned away. "How would that serve the notion of ending the postcode lottery?" asked Mr Cardy.

Stamping out "postcode prescribing" - the availability of expensive new drugs in areas where health authorities are willing to pay but not others - was one of the stated aims of ministers in setting up NICE over a year ago. Recent favourable decisions on drugs for ovarian and breast cancer have been universally applauded, but the beta interferon verdict will go down badly.

The MS Society, which put in evidence to NICE concerning the benefits to patients, intends to appeal, if the preliminary decision - leaked last night - becomes the final verdict.

Mr Cardy says the body has not stood by its undertaking to listen to the voice of the patient. "On the grounds of the process alone, NICE have disregarded their own rhetoric about inclusion of patient opinion," he said. At no point in the process of appraisal, which has been going on for months, were people with MS given an opportunity to air their views.

He believes a public outcry is inevitable if beta interferon is to be denied to people with MS. A recent lobby of Parliament for greater access to the drug attracted 1,200 people. "What I think is difficult to forecast is what the reaction of people with MS will be," he said. If there were 1,200 people wanting to lobby Parliament, we will have a great many more wanting to make their feelings clear to Mr Blair and Mr Milburn (the health secretary)." Scientific opinion on the benefits of the drug is mixed, however. While patients feel better, the evidence of the trials is not conclusive.

The news of the preliminary determination of NICE's appraisal committee, which has to assess the effectiveness of medicines by comparison with other treatments and - crucially - their cost effectiveness within the NHS, leaked out on the BBC news last night.

NICE is already spending taxpayers' money on a comprehensive leak inquiry into an earlier decision. It is likely that this latest leak will be added to the brief of the management consultants called in to carry it out. It is anticipated that the inquiry will conclude that keeping preliminary decisions secret is impossible because of the wide range of people who have to be told.

NICE has a policy of informing all those - including government, patient groups and drug manufacturers of its early decision, so that they can give their views. Yesterday's leak will reinforce the opinion of many that this system is unworkable, and that the preliminary decision must be made public, regardless of any potential damage to a drug's share price.

webTitle: It's semi-official: Charles and Camilla attend gala

fields.headline: It's semi-official: Charles and Camilla attend gala
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Prince Charles and Camilla Parker-Bowles last night appeared in public for the first time together at a semi-official engagement in the latest attempt to win public acceptance for their relationship.
fields.body:
Prince Charles and Camilla Parker-Bowles last night appeared in public for the first time together at a semi-official engagement in the latest attempt to win public acceptance for their relationship.

The Prince of Wales and Mrs Parker-Bowles, 52, hosted a gala dinner in Shoreditch, east London, in honour of the Prince's Foundation, one of Charles's charities.

The couple have appeared together in public before, but this was believed to be their first attendance at a semi-official function.

They arrived at the headquarters of the Prince's Foundation, which is in a newly-restored warehouse in Shoreditch, by car, where around 100 photographers were waiting. Mrs Parker-Bowles, who smiled broadly, was wearing a pale pink embroidered full-length gown - believed to be designed by Versace.

A group of anti-monarchy demonstrators shouted and waved placards as the couple walked into the building.

The couple had been expected to pose for photographers when they arrived at the dinner but were apparently startled by the noise of the Movement Against the Monarchy protesters on the other side of the road and disappeared quickly inside the building.

Guests at the gala included the fashion designer Donatella Versace, the model Elle Macpherson, the racing driver David Coulthard and his fi ancee Heidi Wichlinski, the screen legend Lauren Bacall, Sir Richard and Lady Branson and the comedian Joan Rivers.

Last night's event came two weeks after the queen met Mrs Parker-Bowles for the first time in years at a lunch for the ex-Greek King Constantine.

The Queen Mother will make a live television address to the nation during the pageant marking her 100th birthday, the Sun newspaper reported last night.

Her 60-second speech will be broadcast by ITV which stepped in to televise the pageant on July 19 after it was turned down by the BBC.

fields.headline: Tragedy befalls Macbeth
fields.trailText: Macbeth is living up to its reputation for bringing bad luck, with Kelsey Grammer's portrayal of the character the latest Shakespearean tragedy.
fields.body:
Macbeth is living up to its reputation for bringing bad luck, with Kelsey Grammer's portrayal of the character the latest Shakespearean tragedy.

Grammer, television's Frasier, is giving up after a series of hostile reviews. His Broadway version will close on Sunday, 10 days into a projected 10-week run with losses of $1.5m (£1m), much of it to be picked up by its star.

The New York Post said in its review: "Macbeth is impersonated by tall and plump Kelsey Grammer, who has the physique for a man in over his head in the game of bloody murder." The play had a run in Boston where the producers tried to close it before it reached New York. But Grammer put up the money to keep it alive.

The television star, a classically trained actor who was an understudy for Macbeth 20 years ago, said: "We just decided to fold her up. I had a wonderful time. Unfortunately the press community in town weren't very receptive. But I'm not going to moan about it. A lot of people warned me there would be no open arms for me here but we've been getting standing ovations from our audiences.

"I'll cram something else down their throats in another couple of years."

fields.headline: Kennedy nephew 'admitted' murder
fields.trailText: A member of the Kennedy clan admitted to a fellow alcoholic that he was involved in the murder 25 years ago of a teenage girl neighbour, a court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A member of the Kennedy clan admitted to a fellow alcoholic that he was involved in the murder 25 years ago of a teenage girl neighbour, a court was told yesterday.

The case has been the source of speculation for years because of the family connection and has inspired several books, including Dominick Dunne's best-seller, A Year in Purgatory. It has been suggested that the police in Greenwich, Connecticut, failed to press their investigation of the killing of 15-year-old Martha Moxley because of the influence of the parents of Michael Skakel, the prime suspect.

Mr Skakel wept as he confessed his involvement in the 1975 murder of Martha, a fellow inmate at an alcohol treatment centre told the court in Stamford, Connecticut. Mr Skakel, now 39, is the nephew of the late Senator Robert Kennedy.

John Higgins was testifying at a hearing to determine whether Mr Skakel is to be tried as an adult or as a juvenile. If the court rules that he should face trial as an adult, he could be liable to life in prison.

Mr Higgins and Mr Skakel attended the alcohol treatment centre for youths in the late 1970s. Mr Higgins told the court how Mr Skakel admitted his involvement in the murder.

"He related to me that he had been involved in a murder... or thought that he had been involved," said Mr Higgins, adding that Mr Skakel told him he remembered going through golf clubs stored in the family's garage, then running through the woods. Martha was beaten to death with a six iron and the club was traced to a set owned by the Skakels.

"He said that he didn't know whether he did it and he couldn't remember," said Mr Higgins. "He eventually said that he, in fact, did it."

Earlier, the former Greenwich chief of police, Thomas Keegan, said that only someone who knew that the Skakel family name was on the murder weapon would have wanted to hide the club's missing handle. The club used broke into several pieces, and the handle was never recovered despite an extensive search of the area.

"My conclusion is that the person who killed Martha was aware that that name was on the club," Mr Keegan said.

Martha's body was found on her family's estate. She had been at the Skakel house the night before with friends, including Michael Skakel and his brother, Thomas, then 17.

Police suspected Thomas for years, but switched to Michael after he changed his story about his movements on the night of the murder.

fields.headline: Yugoslavia 3 - 4 Spain
fields.trailText:
Yugoslavia: Kralj, Djorovic, Jokanovic, Djukic, Jugovic, Mijatovic, Milosevic, Stojkovic, Mihajlovic, Komljenovic, Drulovic.
Substitutes: Bunjevcevic, Cicovic, Dudic, Govedarica, Korac, Kovacevic, Nadj, Saveljic, J. Stankovic, D. Stankovic.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia: Kralj, Djorovic, Jokanovic, Djukic, Jugovic, Mijatovic, Milosevic, Stojkovic, Mihajlovic, Komljenovic, Drulovic.
Substitutes: Bunjevcevic, Cicovic, Dudic, Govedarica, Korac, Kovacevic, Nadj, Saveljic, J. Stankovic, D. Stankovic.

Spain: Canizares, Salgado, Abelardo, Helguera, Sergi, Mendieta, Paco, Fran, Guardiola, Perez Munoz, Raul.
Substitutes: Aranzabal, Casillas, Engonga, Etxeberria, Gerard, Hierro, Molina, Munitis, Urzaiz Aranda, Velasco, Valeron.

Referee: Gilles Veissiere (France)

1 min Spain kick off. It's do-or-die time for the perennial under-achievers - they have to win this match. Fran in space through the middle at a modest pace and Jugovic makes up 10 yards to close him down. Early encouragement for Spain.
3 Free kick to Yugoslavia on the left. Mihajlovic, delivering with pace, almost picks out Milosevic at the far post. Spain concede a corner. The centre is cleared but only as far as Mihajlovic, who drives a rising shot over the bar.
6 Milosevic, pulling his unfortunate marker this way and that, almost gets on the end of a Mijatovic cross from the left. A half-chance. Goal kick.
8 A corner to Spain from the left. Fran takes, but scuffs the centre and the Yugoslavs clear with ease. The Spanish pick it up again in their own half and the ball is fed through to Helguera, centre-left, who manages to turn whilst surrounded by three defenders and he gets the shot off, just wide of Kralj's right-hand upright.
10 Mihajlovic, caught back-pedalling, fouls Guardiola 25 yards out centre-right. Fran chips the ball in and the Spanish go bezerk appealing for a handball. No dice from the French referee, and the Spaniards feel hard done by.
13 An early substitution for Yugoslavia, as a limping Djorovic leaves the field, replaced by Stankovic (J).
15 Pretty cynical tackling by the Yugoslavs as Mendieta, in full flight down the left, is scythed down. The free kick, taken by Guardiola, is flicked on by Mendieta for Alfonso, who can only deflect the ball wide. Another good half-chance gone begging.
19 Alfonso misses the best chance of the game so far - a low, raking cross from Mendieta on the left is slightly behind the Spanish forward, 5 yards out. Stretch as he might, he could not make any meaningful contact.
23 Fran, cut from an earlier clash, can take no further part in the match. He is subsituted and Etxeberria comes on in his place.
28 A harsh free kick against Komljenovic, on the left. Guardiola takes and his drifting cross eludes Paco and Abelardo, both with seemingly free headers 10 yards from goal.
29 Down the other end now, as Yugoslavia attack in the shape of Mijatovic, who sends a long ball through for Milosevic. Canzaries is nowhere to be seen and Paco clears off his own goal-line. The Spanish defence is looking shambolic.
31 GOAL! 37 Stojkovic and Mendieta are having a personal tussle all over the pitch, off the ball.

43 Raul, homing in on an early ball from the left by Mendieta, tries the haymaker from 10 yards and fails to make any sort of contact. Spain attacking in waves now, with everything going through Valencia maestro Mendieta.

webTitle: England's rich kids fall right into poverty trap

fields.headline: England's rich kids fall right into poverty trap
fields.standfirst:
England's ramshackle bandwagon halted by verve of confident Romanians. Richard Williams reports

Euro 2000 special report
fields.trailText: Confident Chivu typifies spirit that halted England's ramshackle bandwagon.
fields.body:
Whatever luck England took into Euro 2000, they used it all up last night. And still it was not enough.

Fortunate to be in the lead at the interval, they rode their luck throughout the second half of a match in which Romania showed themselves to be clearly the superior side. So England go home from a tournament in which their presence was felt for all the wrong reasons, asking themselves why they could not do justice to their own expectations. The truth is that those expectations were wholly unrealistic, and that although English football may be providing entertainment while enjoying a period of unparalleled commercial success, in terms of technique and tactics it is still stuck in a deadly time-warp.

No, justice was certainly done in Charleroi last night. A team representing the most affluent league in football were beaten by a team that took the pitch without a single player drawn from a Romanian club, such is the poverty of their domestic league. But such is its abundance in terms of producing talented players, not to mention the richness of their spirit when they put on the buttercup-yellow shirts, that England were not only outclassed as comprehensively as they had been by Portugal at the beginning of the tournament, but even outfought.

If Group A proved anything, it is that what we think of as the Anglo-German way of playing the game has had its day. Like the Portuguese, the Romanians were on speaking terms with the ball, while the English - like the Germans -just tried to kick it from A to B. And, sadly, Kevin Keegan found himself eliminated from the tournament while trying to act against his essential nature. Hired on the basis of his gift for sending out teams dedicated to attacking football, last night he withdrew forwards and sent on defenders in an attempt to play safe, and lost to a team that never wavered from its commitment to the sort of flat-out aggression with which he became identified as a coach, but which seems to have been set aside under the pressure of managing a team at international level. Some good may come from this failure if he recognises the validity of the old, old motto: to thine own self be true.

Some will say that the last-minute inclusion of Nigel Martyn, after David Seaman injured himself in the warm-up, landed Keegan with a slice of bad luck reminiscent of the misfortune that befell Alf Ramsey in Leon 30 years ago, when he was forced to insert the unprepared Peter Bonetti for the unfit Gordon Banks. But so many had suggested that Seaman's best days were behind him that, had the Arsenal goalkeeper's accident happened a fortnight ago, it would have been widely accounted England's good luck. Martyn certainly bore no personal responsibility for the defeat, which could easily have been heavier.

After the sort of start which suggested that playing for a draw would no more be their forte than protecting an early two-goal lead, England showed character to reverse Romania's early lead before half-time. But luck certainly had a significant part to play in that - when the referee decided that Cristian Chivu had fouled Paul Ince inside the penalty area 40 minutes into the first half, and when his linesman kept his flag down five minutes later as Michael Owen raced on to Paul Scholes's pass, with another England player coming back from an offside position.

Those goals arrived shortly after England had enjoyed their biggest slice of luck of all, the departure on the half-hour of Gheorghe Popescu, Romania's seasoned and inspirational captain, carried off on a stretcher with a torn calf muscle.

After that, England had no more luck coming because, in truth, they did not deserve it. In terms of attacking football, they were played off the park by an intelligent Romanian side who knew that England had not beaten them for 30 years and were resolute in their belief that they could maintain the record.

England's sloppiness was thrown into particularly sharp relief by the performance of Chivu, a 19-year-old left-wing- back who, detailed to mark David Beckham, became the pivotal figure of the first half, and was by some distance the classiest player on the pitch.

So confident in only his fifth international match that he was prepared to press forward whenever an opportunity presented itself, Chivu was booked for bringing Beckham down after 17 minutes but refused to let it cramp his style. Four minutes later, the coolness with which he picked up a half-clearance and dribbled elegantly round the left flank of the England defence before chipping over Martyn's head and in off the far post made him the outstanding discovery of the tournament so far. England had no one in any position capable of rivalling his poise and touch.

Any thoughts that Romania would be disheartened by England's two goals in the five minutes before half-time were banished when they came out after the interval with their spirit rekindled, tearing once more into the vulnerable heart of England's defence. The instant long-range volley with which Dorinel Munteanu capitalised on Martyn's punch came from one of a flood of chances.

And so, after Ioan Ganea's penalty, England took their leave, with the sight - curiously appropriate - of Ince berating the referee for failing to give him a free-kick on the edge of the Romanian penalty area. Finally, Kevin Keegan's luck had run out.
