fields.headline: Spice island raid claims 114 lives
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Hundreds of militant Muslims fighting a holy war on the Indonesian spice islands killed more than 100 people and destroyed most of a Christian village on Monday morning, it was reported yesterday.
fields.body:
Hundreds of militant Muslims fighting a holy war on the Indonesian spice islands killed more than 100 people and destroyed most of a Christian village on Monday morning, it was reported yesterday.

An army spokesman in the Molucca islands said 114 people were killed and 70 injured in the dawn raid on Duma, on Halmahera. About 300 buildings were burned down or otherwise destroyed.

He said it was one of the worst incidents in the 18 months of sectarian fighting in the region. Church groups said "very many" Christian women and children had been put on trucks and taken away. At least 500 were involved in the attack, they added.

The Rev Jerda Djawa of the Halmahera Gospel Church in Tobelo said that on two-way radio "we heard bombs going off and shooting for two hours non-stop".

A church sheltering at least 200 people was bombed and burned down, he said. "They were attacked with petrol bombs, guns, bows and arrows and machetes.

"Many were killed. Very many women and children who were not killed were forced to get on to trucks and were taken away. Others managed to flee into the forest."

No local Muslim leader was willing to comment on the attack, and the army spokesman, Major Puguh, could not say where the captives had been taken or whether they were still alive.

Soldiers arrived after about an hour and were attacked while trying to restore order. Muslim fighters were killed by Christians defending themselves and soldiers driving them away.

The attackers were mostly members of Liskar Jihad, a group from western Indonesia who have declared a holy war against the Christians in the Moluccas, one of the few places in predominantly Muslim Indonesia where Christians are in the majority.

Laskar Jihad began its offensive in Halmahera about six weeks ago. Its six big attacks have followed the same pattern: dawn assaults from several directions at once.

The regional governor, Saleh Latuconsina, says the group appears to be "connected to some political elite" in Jakarta, because the authorities have not prevented its members travelling to the Moluccas.

Mr Djawa accused the army of siding with the Muslims on Monday. "The army had been patrolling the boundary between the Christian area and the Muslim base following attacks in the last few weeks," he said. "If they were really neutral then the Muslims would not have been able to reach the Christian area."

Similar accusations have been made by both sides throughout the conflict, which has claimed several thousand lives. Hundreds of thousands of people have fled the Moluccas and tens of thousands are sheltering in camps in the region.

Vice-President Megawati Sukarnoputri is in charge of resolving the conflict, which was initially between locals and migrants but quickly shifted to a purely religious war. One of her officials said yesterday that peace talks between the two factions were "slowly but surely making progress" but admitted: "It is going to take time to reach a permanent solution."

Aid workers believe it will be years before Muslims and Christians resume living in mixed communities.

fields.headline: Families of dead fear expulsion
fields.standfirst:
Families of 58 dead fear expulsion
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Lawyers for the relatives of the 58 Chinese people who died in the back of a container lorry trying to enter Britain were last night seeking reassurances that they would not face action by the immigration authorities if they came forward to identify the bodies.
fields.byline: Paul Kelso, Alan Travis  and  Andrew Osborn
fields.body:
Lawyers for the relatives of the 58 Chinese people who died in the back of a container lorry trying to enter Britain were last night seeking reassurances that they would not face action by the immigration authorities if they came forward to identify the bodies.

The Kent police superintendent leading the criminal inquiry into their deaths yesterday confirmed that the 54 men and four women, nearly all in their early 20s and from Fujian province of China, had died from "respiratory failure". The two survivors were "comfortable" in Kent and Canterbury hospital.

The Dutch owner of the lorry, Arjan Van der Spek, 24, was last night arrested in Rotterdam. Police sources regard him as a petty criminal rather than the brains behind this particular human trafficking network. He is unlikely to face charges in the Netherlands and will probably be extradited to Britain for trial.

Relatives of the dead last night said they had spent four months trying to reach Britain overland through Russia and Europe, including trekking miles through the mountains to get across the border from the Czech Republic.

Yang Chen, 20, who fears his 19-year-old cousin Chen Lin was among those who died in the lorry, said last night: "All the way through their trip they were allowed to make calls back home to say where they were. The last call was from Holland on Sunday and they said they were travelling to the UK that night."

Mr Chen said his cousin had left the city of Jiangle, in Fujian province, in February and had travelled through Beijing, Moscow, the Czech Republic and then on to Holland. He added that his cousin's mother had asked him to go to Dover to identify the body.

Other Chinese families in Britain were today preparing to do the same.

But while Supt Dennis McGookin appealed to Britain's Chinese community for help in discovering further details of how the group came to be in the lorry, lawyers for some of the relatives said they were anxious not to jeopardise their own immigration status by coming forward.

Bobby Chan, a case worker at the Central London Law Centre, near Chinatown in Soho, London, said he had been contacted on Monday by one of the relatives.

"She called me when the news broke, very distressed and asking if there was a way of checking the identities of the dead. She said she was expecting a relative to arrive in the next two days and was very worried about him," he said.

"She was very concerned about talk of a major police investigation and was even worried about talking on the phone. She has just been granted exceptional leave to remain but she is worried that coming forward might endanger her status.

"Many of these people are unclear about their rights, uncertain about their future and feel unsafe talking to the authorities."

Beng Lan Chew, a practice manager at Tanburghs Solici tors in Shepherd's Bush, west London, said some of the relatives had themselves come to the UK in a similar way.

"One said he had been in a house in Holland where he met other people before they were all put in a lorry full of potatoes and onions.

"They have a saying: 'You die in China or you die on the road'. There's always hope with the second option."

Mr Chan said he wanted to see the Home Office grant some kind of immunity to people who came forward.

"There must be many worried families both here and in China," he said. "I would welcome an amnesty but people here are very reluctant to discuss these things. They do not trust the British government when they say there are no strings attached."

Last night the Home Office said: "We will examine carefully any specific re quest made by Kent police to assist them in this major criminal investigation and we will take all factors into account but it is not our policy to grant general 'amnesties'."

The Home Office released figures yesterday to demonstrate that the £2,000 per illegal entrant fines on lorry drivers who are found with clandestine travellers in their vehicles have already begun to bite.

Some 1,020 illegal entrants have been discovered by customs officers in 189 vehicles, nearly all heavy lorries, since the fines came into effect on April 3. In 56 of the incidents the driver involved was British.

Ministers claim that since the new asylum laws came into effect, the number of illegal entrants found had gone down by 26%, indicating that the new laws were working as a deterrent.

Most of the "finds" have involved groups of six or seven people hiding in the back of a lorry, but in one case in April a group of 50 Chinese was discovered in one container vehicle.

The driver and his company were fined £100,000.

fields.headline: Loyalists warned over ceasefire threat
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson warned loyalist paramilitaries last night that they will be flung back into jail if the Ulster Freedom Fighters carry out a threat to break their six-year-old ceasefire in Belfast.
fields.byline: Nicholas Watt  and  Maggie O'Kane in Belfast
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson warned loyalist paramilitaries last night that they will be flung back into jail if the Ulster Freedom Fighters carry out a threat to break their six-year-old ceasefire in Belfast.

The Northern Ireland secretary intervened within hours of a UFF threat to shoot Catholics from midnight last night if nationalists fail to stop a series of alleged attacks on Protestant homes along the "peace line" in north and west Belfast.

The statement, issued by a masked member of the second battalion of the UFF's West Belfast brigade, represents the most serious threat to the loyalist ceasefire.

Dissident republicans also provided a reminder of the continuing threat of violence when a bomb was found in the grounds of Hillsborough Castle, Co Down, the Queen's official residence in Northern Ireland where Mr Mandelson lives. Police said that the device, which had partially exploded, was left in a holdall outside a security fence protecting the castle's grounds.

Mr Mandelson, who was visiting Cork yesterday, said he would suspend the early release of UFF prisoners if the paramilitaries abandon their ceasfire.

In a direct message to the organisation's leadership, he said: "Before you start issuing statements of this kind or throwing around threats of this kind, think of the consequences not just for Northern Ireland as a whole but for also for you and the members of your own organisations."

In addition to ending the early release of prisoners, Mr Mandelson he can also order the return to jail of former paramilitary inmates released on licence. The UFF warned that it would resort to terrorist violence unless nationalists ended a "systematic or orchestrated campaign of intimidation from nationalists" in Belfast. A masked UFF leader, flanked by three masked paramilitaries armed with automatic weapons, said in a statement: "From 12 o'clock tonight 20th June 2000 the UFF reserves the right to shoot any person seen to be attacking protestant homes. This will be in direct contradiction to our ceasefire, which we have steadfastly adhered to despite intense provocation, but enough is enough.

"We cannot stand idly by and watch while protestants are intimidated out of their homes." The statement, read out to selected journalists at a secret location in the loyalist Shankill Road area of Belfast, caused bewilderment in Northern Ireland because there have been no reports of Catholic intimidation of Protestants in north and west Belfast.

The province's housing executive said that there have been 21 cases of intimidation, but these have been against Catholics.

John White, the chairman of the Ulster Democratic Party, the UFF's political wing, said that the statement had "very serious implications". Alex Atwood, an SDLP West Belfast Assembly member, accused the UFF of engaging in a cynical attempt to raise tensions in the marching season.

Sinn Fein said the threat from the UFF was a matter of "grave concern". Mitchel McLaughlin, the party's chairman, described the statement as an attempt to heighten tensions in the run-up to the marching season.

fields.headline: Shattered Eidos in takeover talks
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Eidos, the creator of the Tomb Raider computer games series that has seen its share price shattered by successive profit warnings, is in takeover talks with a mystery party.
fields.body:
Eidos, the creator of the Tomb Raider computer games series that has seen its share price shattered by successive profit warnings, is in takeover talks with a mystery party.

Analysts last night speculated that Vivendi's publishing subsidiary Havas Interactive is the most likely suitor. Early favourite Infogrames is understood to have looked at buying Eidos and possibly driving a three way merger with Activision of the US but decided against it.

Microsoft, which is said to be looking for content ahead of the launch of its own X-box games console, denied an interest. Gameplay, the games portal, is also believed to have contemplated a bid but is no longer interested.

Eidos was forced to admit that it was "in the early stages of discussions which may or may not lead to an offer" after a sharp rise in its share price. Chief operating officer Mike McGarvey said only last week that the company did not favour a merger at this time and it is unclear if any offer will materialise.

Nevertheless Eidos shares closed up 27% at 544p on the news, valuing the company at £534m. Analysts believe any offer would have to be pitched at about 750p per share with a large proportion of cash.

Eidos was one of the star performers on the stock market last year, largely thanks to the success of Tomb Raider and its heroine Lara Croft, and became Europe's first £1bn computer games company.

The shares have slumped following a series of profit warnings amid a general downturn in the computer games market as consumers postpone buying games until new consoles have been introduced. The allure of Lara is also said to be waning. At the end of last month the shares traded as low as 250p, compared to a high of £13.20 in December.

Analysts cited Infogrames as the likeliest bidder. It recently issued 350m euros (£222m) worth of convertible bonds, has a record of expanding aggressively through acquisition and is keen to expand its presence in Britain. Sources close to Infogrames indicated that talks had taken place but the French company was no longer in dialogue with Eidos.

Microsoft, which is said to have been targeting one of the largest Japanese publishers, ruled itself out of the running. Analysts said Havas was the most likely remaining bidder.

"Eidos would make a complementary fit for Havas," said Nick Gibson, analyst at Durlacher. "Havas is very PC driven and lacks a console focus. It also needs a greater presence in the European games development market. Eidos with its exposure to a variety of delivery platforms fulfils those criteria."

Last week, Eidos warned for the third time this year of tough trading conditions. It posted an operating loss for the year to March 31 of £26.8m compared to an operating profit of £39.2m in the previous year.

However, analysts say the company has a solid list of upcoming releases, including worldwide publishing rights to Sony's PlayStation and PC versions of the animated feature film Chicken Run. They add that the computer games industry is at the bottom of a regular cycle and Eidos's fortunes should improve once faster consoles and Microsoft's new machine start to go on sale from the end of this year.

fields.headline: Letsbuyit revives flotation plan
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Letsbuyit.com, the London-based online retailer, is to make a second attempt at listing on the Neuer Markt in Frankfurt.
fields.body:
Letsbuyit.com, the London-based online retailer, is to make a second attempt at listing on the Neuer Markt in Frankfurt.

Stock market volatility forced the company to pull its planned flotation a fortnight ago but yesterday executives said that the mini-recovery in the value of technology stocks had persuaded it to try again. The shares are due to start trading on July 12, following a seven-day subscription period starting on July 3.

"We have had incredibly strong support from our institutional investor base and as retail rebounds we are convinced that our listing on the stock exchange will be a huge success done now," said chief executive Martin Coles.

Letsbuyit refused to say how much money it was looking to raise or what its market value is likely to be. However, analysts believe advisers Robertson Stephens may have to revise a previously mooted valuation of around 750m-1bn euros (£473m-£631m) and come up with a more conservative figure in a market still sensitive to online retail new issues.

The new funds will be spent on European marketing and continuing a high-profile marketing campaign. When it first postponed its float Letsbuyit signalled it would have to cut back on its expensive television advertising campaign which runs regularly during peak viewing hours.

Letsbuyit.com's business model is based around consumers pooling their buying power to bring down the price of goods like TVs, personal stereos and electronic gizmos. The more people who agree to buy, the lower prices become.

It has around 700,000 registered members, following a 30% increase in May. During the month it took 30,000 orders totalling 4.3m euros. Average order valued increased from 120 euros in April to 148 euros.

"Our performance clearly demonstrates that we've earned our position among the select group of quality companies which will form the platform for e-commerce activities over the next several years," Mr Coles said.

Letsbuyit now operates in 13 countries and employs 350 staff. It was founded in Sweden in January and went live in April.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText:  Flat fee Internet service provider AOL Europe is to introduce a flat rate for internet users in Germany and Britain - its two most important European markets, AOL confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
 Flat fee: Internet service provider AOL Europe is to introduce a flat rate for internet users in Germany and Britain - its two most important European markets, AOL confirmed yesterday. In Germany, a new flat rate of DM78 (£25) per month is to be introduced, though a price for Britain has yet to be decided.

 Acquisition: Internet commercial exchange builder Commerce One said yesterday it signed a deal to acquire Internet consulting firm AppNet in a stock deal worth about $1.28bn (£843m). Commerce One said that it would issue 0.8 shares of its stock for each outstanding share of Maryland-based AppNet.

 Small change: Computer maker IBM said it has tripled the capacity of the world's smallest hard disk drive to one gigabyte. The company said that the move paves the way for a new generation of go anywhere pervasive-computing devices and applications, packing one gigabyte of data storage capacity on to a disk the size of a 10 pence coin.

webTitle: ICL Nordic offshoot to be valued at 1bn euros

fields.headline: ICL Nordic offshoot to be valued at 1bn euros
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: ICL, the Fujitsu-owned IT services company, expects its subsidiary, ICL Invia, to be valued at around 1bn euros (£633m), when it floats on the Helsinki stock exchange in the first week of July.
fields.body:
ICL, the Fujitsu-owned IT services company, expects its subsidiary, ICL Invia, to be valued at around 1bn euros (£633m), when it floats on the Helsinki stock exchange in the first week of July with shares offered at between 8.5 euros and 10.5 euros.

Cash raised from the offering will be used to fund the expansion and restructuring of ICL's Nordic operations following the Finland-based ICL Invia's integration of the Swedish, Danish and Norwegian divisions of the group earlier this month.

The public offering precedes a planned listing of ICL on the London stock exchange later this year which is intended to raise investment funds for a shift from IT services to e-business services.

ICL's wholly owned subsidiary, ICL Holding, which currently has an 83% stake in ICL Invia will retain a controlling interest after flotation.

Operating profits for ICL Invia for the financial year to March 31 2000 were 3.4m euros.

ICL group's change of direction toward e-business was bolstered when global e-business revenues doubled from £80m in 1998 to £160m in 1999.

E-business customers include Thomas Cook, First Direct and BBC Worldwide. Total group revenues for the year were £2.7bn - £480m of which came from the Nordic divisions.

Enskilda Securities, the Swedish investment bank which alongside other investors, bought a 16.8% share in ICL Invia earlier this year, is coordinating the offering, and has an option to purchase one and a half million shares.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Round Britain Quiz | Evening Concert
fields.body:
After 43 years of mindnumbingly convoluted questions Round Britain Quiz (1.30pm, Radio 4) opens another season. The Welsh team of Peter Stead and Patrick Hannan hopes to beat the field again, as it has managed to do in the past two contests. They and their rivals are under the occasionally impatient jurisdiction of Nick Clarke.

Midsummer Day is celebrated with appropriate musical jollity in the Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM). That prolific composer Anon is Nicholas Tresilian's first choice, with the Deller Consort's version of his (her?) Sumer Is Icumen In. After that the selection ranges from the inevitable chunk of Vivaldi's Four Seasons to Kiri Te Kanawa (pictured) singing Gershwin's Summertime. The main work is Mendelssohn's incidental music to A Midsummer Night's Dream, with Noel Levy conducting the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra.

webTitle: Parallel lives may be on collision course

fields.headline: Parallel lives may be on collision course
fields.trailText: The careers of Edgar Bronfman Jr and the boyish-looking Jean-Marie Messier have run almost parallel in the past six years .
fields.body:
The careers of Edgar Bronfman Jr and the boyish-looking Jean-Marie Messier have run almost parallel in the past six years .

Both have taken control of low growth hulking businesses - Seagram and Vivendi - and given them the direction they needed to become entertainment and media enterprises.

Yesterday, those like minds finally came together to form the world's second biggest media company. However, the success of Bronfman, who heads the Canadian Seagram liquor, music and Hollywood empire, has not been as polished as that of his French counterpart.

He is the third generation Bronfman to run Seagram and under his reign it branched out from its boozy roots as a liquor vendor of Absolut Vodka and Chivas Regal.

Bronfman added Universal film and music, which boasts stars like U2 and box office hits such as Gladiator and Jurassic Park, and PolyGram.

Yet the erratic movement of Seagram's share price over the years has earned him a drubbing from investors and a question mark over whether the diversification added value. Supporters point out that Bronfman had the foresight to take Seagram into one of the fastest growing markets that delivered a springboard to the internet.

The merger raises the issue of personalities. Bronfman may well be putting aside his ego to sell his family's business to Vivendi and deliver shareholders some value. But can he be happy being number two to Messier? Analysts say management is the crucial point where this deal could fall apart.

It is an issue that is likely to have been addressed carefully by Messier. As a former investment banker he would be shrewdly aware of the importance of management in deals of this size.

In fact in 1998, when Vivendi took a 51% stake in French pay television group Canal Plus, many thought its conservative boss, Pierre Lescure, would be ousted by the more modern and Anglo-Saxon inclined Messier.

fields.headline: Murdoch's $40bn satellite gambit
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch indicated yesterday that he is pressing ahead with what promises to be the biggest ever flotation of a media company when his News Corp empire spins off its satellite television businesses, including its 40% stake in BSkyB.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch indicated yesterday that he is pressing ahead with what promises to be the biggest ever flotation of a media company when his News Corp empire spins off its satellite television businesses, including its 40% stake in BSkyB.

An initial public offering on the New York stock exchange later this year could raise up to $5bn (£3.3bn) for the company, according to Wall Street analysts.

The chairman of News Corp is expected to become chairman of the separately listed Sky Global Networks.

In yesterday's submissions to the US securities and exchange commission the company said it would seek to raise at least $100m.

The share sale, being handed by Goldman Sachs and Merrill Lynch, is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

The flotation will bring together the stakes News Corp owns in British Sky Broadcasting, Star TV in Asia, Stream in Italy, Sky Brazil, Sky Mexico, Sky Multi-country partners and Sky PerfecTV of Japan from the rump of the media business.

The flotation will also include its equity stakes in NDS, a set-top box business, and its TV Guide operation in the US. News Corp described the much-anticipated move - previously known as Platco within the Murdoch empire - as a restructuring of its "worldwide satellite platforms and certain related assets in to one umbrella entity".

The spin-off is the group's answer to the mega-mergers of the likes engineered by Vivendi and by Time Warner and AOL.

It is expected to pave the way for the group to form strategic relationships with long-standing rivals such as Vivendi, fresh from its three-way merger with Canal Plus and Seagram of Canada, as well as Nokia, the Finnish mobile phone operation and Microsoft, the computer software company.

Jean-Marie Messier, chief executive of the newly enlarged Vivendi, made it clear yesterday that he wanted to talk with Mr Murdoch.

The overall valuation of Sky Global Networks could rise to $40bn, putting it on a par with the current total worth of News Corp, which will continue to own the rump of Mr Murdoch's media businesses.

The flotation is the core of the group's strategy to prove its internet credentials despite recent nervousness among investors in so-called "new economy" ventures.

News Corp has played down concerns about the impact the recent stock market fall-out might have on the valuation of the satellite operations, which will reach 100m homes in more than 60 countries.

In a recent interview, Chase Carey, co-chief operating officer of News Corp, who is to become chief executive of the stand-alone entity, said: "We are moving from a television world to a multi-media world in which we can create an array of content services and applications for satellite, wireless and other platforms."

This is why the group is expected to enter into discussions with partners to provide more than TV programmes from its set-top boxes, which analysts predict could effectively become computers and telephones.

Speculation is already mounting that Sky Global Networks will also use some of the money it raises to make an acquisition of a US satellite business such as EchoStar Communications Corporation or DirecTV, part of the General Electric empire.

fields.headline: Publicis snaps up Saatchi & Saatchi
fields.standfirst: Cross-channel advertising coup likely to start new round of bids
fields.trailText: French advertising group Publicis yesterday snapped up Saatchi & Saatchi after it agreed to pay £1.3bn in shares to create the world's fifth largest group in the sector.
fields.body:
French advertising group Publicis yesterday snapped up Saatchi & Saatchi after it agreed to pay £1.3bn in shares to create the world's fifth largest group in the sector.

The deal is expected to set off further consolidation in a market where margins are already squeezed by enlarged and powerful media companies such as AOL-Time Warner and News Corp.

Kevin Roberts, Saatchi & Saatchi's chief executive, signalled the new group's clout. "Rupert Murdoch and all the media owners had better watch out because we're going to be knocking on the door for better deals," he said yesterday.

Cordiant, which demerged from Saatchi & Saatchi in 1997, is being tipped as the next medium-sized firm in need of a partner - with Aegis a possible match, according to analysts. It was only last month that Publicis failed to buy US group Young & Rubicam, losing out to WPP, which bought it for $4.7bn (£3.1bn).

Publicis will pay 1.64 new shares for every 100 shares in Saatchis - equivalent to 500p a share. Publicis has also offered guaranteed stock certificates protecting Saatchi shareholders from more than a 10% drop in the French group's shares in the next 18 months.

The deal is expected to be completed by September once shareholder and court approvals have been achieved.

Both companies will be run independently to avoid conflicts of interest. Mr Roberts will stay as chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi, and both he and chairman Bob Seelert join the Publicis management and supervisory boards.

Saatchi investors will own 31% of the new firm, to be known as Publicis Groupe, and the remainder will be held by Publicis shareholders.

Saatchi & Saatchi will be delisted in London, with the new firm quoted in Paris and New York.

The family of Publicis founder Marcel Blaustein-Blanchet have agreed to use their 60% shareholding to vote in favour of the deal. After the acquisition is complete the family will own 17% of the merged group.

The new company will have a market value of £4bn, revenues of £1.1bn and £174m of earnings - before interest costs, tax, depreciation and amortisation.

Maurice Levy, the president of Publicis, is looking for the merged company's earnings to grow by 18% compared with Saatchi & Saatchi's present level of 12%. He also wants it to consider further acquisitions.

However, Publicis shares dived in Paris as investors said the company had overpaid for the UK advertising group.

Shares in Saatchi & Saatchi fell 1.5p to 419.5p.

Neil Carter, an analyst at ABN Amro, said: "It's expensive, there's no doubt about that. But it serves one of the purposes for Publicis in getting a decent presence in the US." The new group's revenue split will be 49% in Europe, 38% in the US and 13% in the rest of the world.

Mr Carter expects annualised savings of about £20m in the first two years.

webTitle: BT wakes up to chance of making hyper-profit

fields.headline: BT wakes up to chance of making hyper-profit
fields.standfirst:
Outrage in US as web technology is found to have been patented

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: British Telecom confirmed yesterday that it is pressing ahead with plans to exploit a patent it holds for one of the main building blocks of the world wide web, and land potentially huge bills at the doors of US internet companies.
fields.body:
British Telecom confirmed yesterday that it is pressing ahead with plans to exploit a patent it holds for one of the main building blocks of the world wide web, and land potentially huge bills at the doors of US internet companies.

The company has sent letters to US internet service providers telling them of its claim to "hyperlinks" - the technology which allows web users to move from one page to another by clicking on text or pictures.

BT is inviting those ISPs to open discussions on licensing the technology, which is covered by patent number 4,873,662, issued to BT in the US in 1989. The patent runs until 2006.

One British-based intellectual property expert warned yesterday that the move could lead to "the most almighty bust-up" which could paralyse the US portion of the internet.

BT's claim on the technology goes back to research conducted in the 1970s. BT applied for patents relating to hypertext linking in 1976 but these were not granted in the US until 1989. The patents were granted for 17 years. Patents taken out at the same time elsewhere in the world have now expired.

A spokesman for BT said yesterday that the company had told major US-based ISPs about the intellectual property claim, and asked them to discuss the possibility of taking out licences.

ISPs have responded, but the spokesman refused to discuss the nature of the responses, other than to say negotiations were continuing.

"There are many very significant players in the US hi-tech economy making billion dollar-plus revenues a year out of intellectual property - IBM and companies of that scope," he said.

"BT is a major world player in terms of its intellectual property - we have over 15,000 patents - and we do things to exploit those commercially.

"This is something we think could create reasonable royalties for BT. As to how much, that will be something we will discuss with ISPs."

As the US internet woke up to the news yesterday, there was an immediate explosion of indignation online.

At the tech-savvy Slashdot bulletin board, some users initially thought the news that the web's key technology was patented was a late April Fool's joke. Disbelief, however, quickly gave way to anger - at BT for attempting to exploit its patent, and at the US patent office which delayed processing BT's application by nine years.

British legal experts said that they could see few legal hurdles to prevent BT from cashing in on its patent.

Robin Whaite, intellectual property partner at law firm Linklaters, said BT's new-found desire to protect its patent, years after it was issued, is not unusual. It was, he says, an example of a "submarine patent" which "pops up when you least expect it".

He added that, because of the relatively recent birth of the commercial worldwide web, BT should not have difficulty in extracting "reasonable royalties" stretching back six years. "This could be a huge case," he said.

Ben Goodger, an intellectual property expert at British law firm Willoughby and Partners, said he knew of no reason why BT should not be able to enforce its patent.

"What seems to be emerging is that if I went and put a website up and made a hypertext link I would not have to go to BT cap in hand and pay money," he said. "But it's AOL and other massive players on the internet that BT would be targeting with a commensurately huge licence fee.

"Once you are aware that you are infringing, the damages position becomes much worse. BT are obviously getting good advice; under US law, if you carry out what is called 'wilful infringement' you are liable for treble damages.

"What I would ask is: is it really in their commercial interest, given the culture of the internet? Over-assertion of intellectual property is very unpopular, and people will find a way to work around it."

fields.headline: FBI investigates new virus
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The FBI has opened an investigation into a new computer virus, spreading globally by email, which some technology experts say could pose serious risks to computer systems.
fields.body:
The FBI has opened an investigation into a new computer virus, spreading globally by email, which some technology experts say could pose serious risks to computer systems.

The IRC-Stages "worm," or virus, which replicates itself and sends out multiple emails does not damage computer files but could clog email systems, the United States government's National Infrastructure Protection Center (NIPC) insisted yesterday.

Although the virus has been circulating for nearly a month, the NIPC and anti-virus software companies upgraded their assessment of the virus to to high-risk, based on the number of samples received. The NIPC said it and the FBI were launching inquiries into the new virus.

The government-sponsored agency, Computer Emergency Response, said thousands of computers or systems were likely to have been affected.

Another company, Trend Micro, said the new virus could "easily fool the user into believing it is an innocent text file because the extension is not shown and the file assumes the icon of a text file".

The email generally has the title "life Stages" "funny" or "jokes", and might add either "Fw:" to the beginning or "text" to the end of the subject.

Resembling a harmless text file, the so-called Stages virus has infected systems at corporations from Asia to Australia to the US, including the cable network, CNN.

The virus does not harm computer files.

Instead it replicates itself, sending a copy to every user listed in the infected computer's address book, behaving similarly to the so-called Love Bug virus which clogged many email systems in May.

Stages uses Microsoft Outlook or Outlook Express email programs to spread.

It can also infect systems via chat rooms or AOL's instant messaging software.

The email message contains "funny", "life stages" or "jokes" in the subject line. The text of the message reads "the male and female stages of life," with an attachment, "life-stages.txt" or "life-stages.txt.shs."

The attachment contains a joke about advancing age.

The Hong Kong government has warned domestic computer users not to open emails containing such messages.

fields.headline: Jupiter Asset Management
fields.trailText: Investment trusts are a relic of the old school tie in the City. All the more remarkable, then, that two investment trusts worth nearly £400m yesterday served notice on Jupiter Asset Management that they may fire it from managing their funds.
fields.body:
Investment trusts are a relic of the old school tie in the City, with boards of directors drawn from the great and the good. Rock the boat they don't. All the more remarkable, then, that two investment trusts worth nearly £400m yesterday served notice on Jupiter Asset Management that they may fire it from managing their funds.

The bad news for Jupiter, in turmoil since founder and chairman John Duffield quit at the end of May, is expected to continue this week. All its trusts, bar those about to be wound up, are set to issue "protective notices" allowing them to sack Jupiter as manager without incurring hefty penalties for terminating contracts. At risk is £1.4bn in funds.

Even more damaging would be the loss of pension funds which form the bedrock of the £14bn Jupiter manages. Yesterday two major pension fund advisers, William Mercer and Watson Wyatt, confirmed that they had written to pension trustees about Jupiter.

Whether the trusts or pension funds jump ship will depend on whether Jupiter, owned by Commerzbank, is successful in preventing its star managers defecting to other asset management companies, particularly the new start-up promised by Mr Duffield.

Yesterday Jupiter's advisers were spinning hard. A spokesman said: "These are not notices to quit. It does not mean they are firing Jupiter. Not a single fund manager has left since Mr Duffield's departure, and most are locked in to the company. The trusts are clearly concerned about speculation and rumours, but would only want to move if our performance turns down, which it hasn't. It's rock solid."

It now rests on new managing director, Edward Bonham Carter, to rebuild confidence in Jupiter. Without it, the trusts' discounts will widen and they may have no option but to move. However, one trust is surely a lost cause. Jupiter Investment Trust, a £100m fund, has one major shareholder who owns 40% of the shares. The shareholder is none other than Mr Duffield.

webTitle: Ryanair sneers at BA flights of fancy

fields.headline: Ryanair sneers at BA flights of fancy
fields.trailText: Michael O'Leary, the ever-ebullient chief executive of Ryanair, Europe's largest budget airline, was at it again yesterday, bad-mouthing his bigger and dearer rivals such as British Airways and Virgin Atlantic, the unlikely new bed-partners, and comparing their sorry profits decline with his own tenth year of earnings growth.
fields.body:
Michael O'Leary, the ever-ebullient chief executive of Ryanair, Europe's largest budget airline, was at it again yesterday, bad-mouthing his bigger and dearer rivals such as British Airways and Virgin Atlantic, the unlikely new bed-partners, and comparing their sorry profits decline with his own tenth year of earnings growth.

"Everyone else is falling out of bed," he said as he set out ambitious plans to double Ryanair's passenger numbers within four years by offering even cheaper fares to customers using the internet to book flights.

It already offers return flights from London to Glasgow for £9, plus taxes. Mr O'Leary, never one to mince his words, revels in the woes of his competitors. "Where BA is cutting back capacity and increasing fares we see the profile for growth as being very good for us and that's via new services at cheaper prices."

The airline is buying 15 new Boeing 737-800s, opening eight new European routes from the UK and "they're all gangbusters".

Announcing record pre-tax profits of 90.1m euros (£57m) last year, up 19%, Mr O'Leary said his aim was to reduce the number of seats sold through travel agents to 20% this year compared with 60% in 1999 and halve costs through web-based booking.

Ryanair, which claims to operate Europe's largest travel website, with 50,000 bookings a week, already accounting for 70% of sales, is increasingly shifting away from its Irish base in Dublin and milking the strength of sterling to push for growth via Stansted near London and other British airports to the continent.

"The only dark cloud on our growth horizon remains Ireland, where the government continues to prioritise the interests of its high cost airport monopoly over the needs of the Irish consumer and potential European visitors," Mr O'Leary said.

webTitle: Lords veto terror bill exemption for journalists

fields.headline: Lords veto terror bill exemption for journalists
fields.trailText: Peers last night refused to exempt journalists from new nationwide anti-terrorism laws that will require anyone with information about a terrorist act to notify the police.
fields.body:
Peers last night refused to exempt journalists from new nationwide anti-terrorism laws that will require anyone with information about a terrorist act to notify the police.

The Lords voted to reject a Liberal Democrat amendment proposing to exempt journalists from the bill's requirement to notify the police of any information they receive about potential terrorist acts.

Lib Dem frontbencher Lord Goodhart QC told peers the provision would inhibit journalistic investigations into the source of terrorist funds and would be an attack on the right of journalists to protect their sources.

He said: "We regard this bill, insofar as it applies to journalists, as being a serious infringement of freedom of speech and a serious infringement of the freedom of the press."

But Cabinet Office minister Lord Falconer countered that journalists had a "degree of responsibility to society", and that the Lib Dem amendment would create a "potential loophole" in the bill. The amendment was rejected by 145 votes to 65.

Peers did, however, agree various government amendments aimed at extending the anti-terrorism legislation, including action to counter cyber-terrorism.

The Lords voted to extend the definition of terrorism to include the use or threat of action "designed seriously to interfere with or seriously to disrupt an electronic system".

Such action would be covered under the bill if it was done for political, religious or ideological purposes and if it aimed to influence government or intimidate the public.

The bill was also amended to allow such offences in Northern Ireland, under the Computer Misuse Act 1990, to be heard in non-jury Diplock courts.

Lord Cope, a former Tory Northern Ireland minister, said: "Financial rackets involved in computers and so on can be just as damaging and just as much of a weapon in the hands of the terrorists in Northern Ireland as bombs and guns are."

Lord Goodhart, for the Lib Dems, welcomed the changes as an improvement but warned that his party would seek further changes at the bill's third reading.

Pressed by Tory peer Lady Blatch on whether the new definition of terrorism could include threats by animal rights protesters to staff and shareholders of the Huntingdon Life Sciences Company, Lord Bach indicated that it could.

The minister said: "Whether it's covered by this legislation depends on the nature of the attack, obviously. Certainly, if serious violence were used and the public was put in fear and the motivation was religious, political or ideological, it could be caught by the bill."

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: It was a big day for tech investors. With Nasdaq in the US moving sharply higher, Britain's new economy sectors followed suit. In fact, in the US the broad Nasdaq composite index managed to wipe out all of this year's losses, breaking through 4,000 once more and helping our own Techmark 100 jump 3% - up 101 points at 3459.22.
fields.body:
It was a big day for tech investors. With Nasdaq in the US moving sharply higher, Britain's new economy sectors followed suit. In fact, in the US the broad Nasdaq composite index managed to wipe out all of this year's losses, breaking through 4,000 once more and helping our own Techmark 100 jump 3% - up 101 points at 3459.22.

Despite the shakeout in the premier index earlier this month, the FTSE 100 still has enough big technology and media companies to allow some of the fun to rub off yesterday. It closed 36.7 points higher at 6,526.9, although trading activity was a little restricted as Royal Ascot left one or two dealing rooms light on senior staff.

Vodafone, of course, helped the main index adding 9p to 320.5p. But the eye-catchers amongst the leaders included telecoms equipment specialist Marconi, up 39p at 954p, and mobile computer chip designer ARM Holdings , which came to rest 40.5p higher at 739.5p. That compares with February's high of £10.01 and May's low of 496p.

Reuters, meanwhile, surged from £11.70 to £12.42 - a move of more than 6% - as its US-listed associate, high-performance network specialist Tibco raced higher.

Against this, more fretting about the price of crude ahead of the Opec meeting saw Footsie heavyweights BP Amoco slip 7.5p to 624.5p and and Shell fall 14p to 550p.

Psion, the hand-held computing group, had a strong day, up 70p at 639p after Monday's technical price moves, where rogue trades from last Friday put the stock at an artificially low level.

A flurry of research notes on the biotech sector from several big investment banks sparked a sector-wide rally. Celltech jumped 110p to £12.45, while lower down the bio-corporate ladder Cambridge Antibody added 125p to £26.50 and Oxford Glycosciences put on 187.5p to £16.75 after winning fast track status from US drug regulators for its OGT 918 treatment for a hereditary complaint called Gaucher disease.

There was a two-way tug in the market for Shire Pharmaceuticals as Merrill Lynch repeated its "buy" recommendation on the stock and raised its price target from £10.35 to £12.50. But Dresdner Kleinwort Benson slapped a "reduce" rating on the company. With the market price up 48p at £11.13, Merrill seemed to have won the argument on the day.

Elsewhere, the was a sudden flurry in freight group Christian Salvesen, which left the shares 9.5p higher at 160.5p. Market shrewdies suggested some sort of corporate action is afoot, possibly after pressure from one of the groups bigger shareholders.

fields.headline: Where history repeats itself
fields.standfirst:
Ulster ceasefire threat As tensions mount amid talk of ethnic cleansing, weary residents say: 'They will have to burn us out'
Northern Ireland: special report
Ulster Democratic party
Sinn Fein
Northern Ireland Office
fields.trailText: In the corner of the Tigers Bay estate on the Protestant Limestone Road in Belfast, one house has three flags flying from it, the union flag and two Red Hands of Ulster. The man who owns the house does not want to talk and does not want to be named. He is up a ladder on the gable wall stringing another banner that reads "Ulster Volunteer Force" across the gable end.
fields.body:
In the corner of the Tigers Bay estate on the Protestant Limestone Road in Belfast, one house has three flags flying from it, the union flag and two Red Hands of Ulster. The man who owns the house does not want to talk and does not want to be named. He is up a ladder on the gable wall stringing another banner that reads "Ulster Volunteer Force" across the gable end.

Suddenly a car screeches to a halt along the Limestone Road. "You're fucking mad. Fuck you and your bloody ceasefire."

Then, its occupant, presumably a Catholic and republican, barrels off down the Limestone Road, which for 30 years has marked the line that divides Catholic and Protestant housing estates in this part of Belfast.

There are roads and estates like this all over the city and since John Hume and Bernadette Devlin led the first marches of the troubles through the street of Londonderry 31 years ago, the vocabulary, the missiles and the abuse that have been hurled across them has not improved. In Tigers Bay yesterday they seemed surprised that sectarianism, intimidation and abuse had suddenly become an issue.

30 years on

Further down the Tigers Bay in Syringe Street, John McBride, who is 74, regards the headline in the Belfast Telegraph, UFF in New Threat to Call Off Ceasefire, with nothing more than mild interest.

"This has been going on for 30 years. I've seen as much trouble from our side as the other side but I expect to be leaving this house in the long box. Nobody will put me out." His daughter Martha, 45, who has just bought two new hanging plants of plastic fuschias for the front window, agrees. "They will have to burn me out," she says in the weary Belfast tradition that both Catholics and Protestants seem to endure.

Many of Mr McBride's neighbours did not feel the same. Through the gleaming windows of his recently bought council house he points to the row of houses along Syringe Street. "See that first one. An RUC man was shot dead there 15 years ago. A fella from the other side came across and asked him for a light, and when he went into the back kitchen to get one off the cooker for him, he blew his head away."

His eye and his finger move along the street. "That girl in number 20 moved out three years ago. The other side backed on to her yard and they kept breaking her windows, so she had to go. She had kids. And number 22 - they left for Antrim a few years ago."

In the past four weeks the Northern Ireland housing executive has had 21 reports of intimidation. Ironically, all of them were from Catholics, given yesterday's statement that the "ethnic cleansing of Protestants" has to stop. But there is not doubt that the Protestants of Belfast feel under siege. However, none of them can quite work out what's new.

Mr McBride knows about "ethnic cleansing", as the Ulster Freedom Fighters have described the intimidation against his communities. He was four years old when his family were burned out of Ballast Street in 1930.

Over the years Mr McBride has had his windows broken seven times. His biggest worry yesterday was who would pay for the replacements. "We bought out this house, and the housing authority used to pay for them.

"A couple of years ago we had no front windows from the beginning of July until the end of August. The housing authority said they wouldn't replace them until after the marching season." The flurry and panic that the UFF announcement has caused hardly seemed to provoke a stir on Syringe Street yesterday. A freshly painted tiger, signalling the heart of loyalist Tigers Bay, looks down on streets that do indeed signal an exodus of Protestants from their traditional heartland.

"The young lads are out stoning the houses at the end of the row and when the people move out they start on the next one," said a tough balding Protestant. "This is a warning from the UFF and I think it will frighten them off."

Oxygen of publicity

An old woman who has spent her life on these streets is not so sure. "The UFF - mmmh - they make a statement like that and get great publicity from it. All the young lads will be out shouting UFF and thinking they're great. That's all they want, publicity - the papers are just as bad for printing it."

At present, two Protestant hardline groups, the Ulster Volunteer Force and the Ulster Freedom Fighters, have been battling for the mantle of protector.

The loyalists of north Belfast issue loud statements and speak in whispers. The statement screamed the ceasefire could break down at midnight and the whispers say there will be no Catholic bodies on the streets - it is just a warning.

The battle for the turf of Protestant Belfast has taken many twists and turns in the past few weeks. As the assembly gears into operation, the loyalist hardliners are being left behind. In the latest twist the Ulster Freedom Fighters have put in an order for 5,000 blue flags from Taiwan.

The Ulster Volunteer Force, whose flags are mauve and tangerine, has hit back, commissioning 16 new war murals, and for weeks now there have been running battles with paint brushes. The activities of both side have generated hundreds of calls to the lunchtime talk show on BBC Northern Ireland with almost all callers complaining that the last thing Ulster needs is new flags.

But Mr McBride says things have been worse: "Before the first ceasefire I had grids on my windows. I used to live like a canary."

fields.headline: UK-Jakarta arms deal confirmed
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Britain exported 10 Hawk aircraft to Indonesia last year, the government confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain exported 10 Hawk aircraft to Indonesia last year, the government confirmed yesterday.

Figures of the country's main weapons exports - including the heavily criticised arms trade with Indonesia - are contained in the government's annual return to the United Nations conventional arms register. The register also reveals the extent to which Britain is dependent on the Gulf for weapons sales.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, cleared the sale of Hawks to Jakarta despite widespread human rights abuse by Indonesian forces. He argued that the sales - agreed by the previous Conservative administration - could not be blocked for legal reasons. This was contested by lawyers acting for human rights groups.

The register says that last year Britain supplied 50 air-to-ground missiles to Saudi Arabia, recently singled out by Amnesty International for human rights abuses.

Britain also exported 10 armoured combat vehicles to Qatar and six to Oman. It exported 14 Challenger I battle tanks to Jordan, another traditional market for British arms.

In other UN-registered arms exports, Britain supplied six large-calibre artillery systems to Brazil, two frigates to Malaysia, five attack helicopters to South Korea, and four armoured combat vehicles to Finland for use in Bosnia.

The register reveals that Britain imported 26 cruise missiles from the United States. The Royal Navy used US submarine-launched cruise missiles for the first time during the Kosovo conflict.

It is now buying an unidentified number of missiles to replenish its stock and to be fitted in more of the navy's submarines.

The UN register does not cover small arms which cause many more deaths, especially in civil wars, than larger weapons such as tanks or missiles. A number of governments, including Britain, are pressing for strict controls on supplies of small arms to conflict areas, notably in Africa.

Recent British supplies of arms to the Sierra Leone government is just one indication of how difficult this will be to achieve.

webTitle: Beijing irked by Taiwan's call for a 'Korea solution'

fields.headline: Beijing irked by Taiwan's call for a 'Korea solution'
fields.standfirst: Korea: special report
fields.trailText: Taiwan's new president Chen Shui-bian tweaked Beijing's toe yesterday by suggesting that if the two Koreas could hold a successful summit, there was no reason why the mainland should not also agree to a "summit for peace".
fields.body:
Taiwan's new president Chen Shui-bian tweaked Beijing's toe yesterday by suggesting that if the two Koreas could hold a successful summit, there was no reason why the mainland should not also agree to a "summit for peace".

Mr Chen said that a Taiwan-China summit with Beijing's president, Jiang Zemin, should be held "in any form or place and not restricted by any preconditions".

He told a press conference that he had pinned a photograph of last week's famous handshake between the two Korean leaders on his office wall. "If North and South Korea can," he exclaimed, "why can't the two sides of the Taiwan straits?". Mr Chen invited Mr Jiang to "join hands and work to create a moment like the [Korean] handshake".

The proposal was promptly slapped down by a Chinese foreign ministry spokesman, Zhu Bangzao. Mr Zhu said that the Taiwan issue was entirely a Chinese affair.

Talks with Mr Chen could only take place if he accepted that "there is only one China and Taiwan is part of it".

Mr Chen's is regarded with deep suspicion by Beijing because he represents the pro-independence Democratic Progressive party, though he carefully avoided calling for independence both in his campaign and after being elected in March.

During his inauguration speech he gave a pledge not to declare the island independent during his term of office as long as China does not take military action.

Mr Chen repeated yesterday that he was prepared to agree on a loose definition of Beijing's "one China" principle as long as it was "acceptable to both sides". Calling for "wisdom and creativity", he effectively proposed that they should fudge the issue. He also claimed that the two sides had agreed in 1992 that they could each interpret the principle in their own way.

"If there was a consensus," he said, "it was a consensus to disagree." Mr Chen urged Beijing to accept that Taiwanese public opinion will not be dictated to. He also offered to support China's bid to host the 2008 Olympics and said that Taiwan could co-host some events.

While hailing the success of the Korean summit, and attempting to claim some of the credit for diplomatic moves to encourage it, Beijing insists that there is no parallel between a divided Korea and a divided China.

Mr Jiang is said to have given advice to the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il, during his visit to Beijing shortly before the summit, on how to combine an open-door policy towards the outside world with maintaining tight political control at home.

To Beijing, which likes to think that the "Chinese model" is relevant to Korea, the idea that the "Korean model" might be relevant to China is offensive. Many ordinary Chinese would like some of the spirit with which the two Korean leaders embraced to be transferred to the edgy relationship across the Taiwan straits.

But objective Asian opinion concedes that the two situations are very different. "The two Koreas do not have a problem of whether there is one Korea or whether they are Korean," says Chang King-yuh, a former China policy-maker in Taiwan. "I would say that the likelihood of a summit across the straits is very slim."

Observers in Seoul last week were struck by the strength of nationalist sentiment across the 39th parallel.

Mr Chen urged Beijing to accept that Taiwanese public opinion will not be dictated to. He also offered to support China's bid to host the 2008 Olympics and said that Taiwan could co-host some events. While hailing the success of the Korean summit, and attempting to claim some of the credit for diplomatic moves to encourage it, Beijing insists that there is no parallel between a divided Korea and a divided China. Mr Jiang is said to have given advice to the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il, during his visit to Beijing shortly before the summit, on how to combine an open-door policy towards the outside world with maintaining tight political control at home. To Beijing, which likes to think that the "Chinese model" is relevant to Korea, the idea that the "Korean model" might be relevant to China is offensive. Many ordinary Chinese would like some of the spirit with which the two Korean leaders embraced to be transferred to the edgy relationship across the Taiwan straits. But objective Asian opinion concedes that the two situations are very different. "The two Koreas do not have a problem of whether there is one Korea or whether they are Korean," says Chang King-yuh, a former China policy-maker in Taiwan. "I would say that the likelihood of a summit across the straits is very slim." Observers in Seoul last week were struck by the strength of nationalist sentiment across the 39th parallel. webTitle: Power failure takes BBC news off air

fields.headline: Power failure takes BBC news off air
fields.trailText: The BBC was paralysed by a massive power cut last night - hours before it was due to screen exclusive coverage of England's crunch Euro 2000 match.
fields.body:
The BBC was paralysed by a massive power cut last night - hours before it was due to screen exclusive coverage of England's crunch Euro 2000 match.

The power cut at Television Centre also affected other parts of Shepherd's Bush and Acton in west London.

The Six O'Clock News on BBC1 went off air, and BBC News 24 was also struck as well as Radio 4. Emergency generators were switched on but they also failed. The gap left by normal BBC transmission was filled by UK Today regional programmes until 7pm.

Thousands of staff were evacuated from the building because the fire alarms were disabled by the power failure.

Transmission of the football was switched to Birmingham and live coverage continued as normal. The news teams remained after the main power failed at 5.30pm. Emergency generators kicked in but lights and computers were not on full power and finally gave up at 6.20pm.

A spokeswoman said news journalists had been dispersed to Millbank studios in south London and to Birmingham.

Last night a BBC worker said: "All of a sudden the lights, computers and air conditioning failed. All the top news people were standing around looking ashen faced."

The power failure also blacked out around 20,000 homes as well as paralysing traffic lights. Hammersmith hospital switched to emergency generators. A London Electricity spokesman said the fault was traced to a substation in Acton.

fields.headline: Noisy tranquillity
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
Wenlock Edge

Night begins earlier in the woods. As the track worms deeper into the trees, so the shadows thicken. Puddles of light from above and below the hanging woods splash into clearings in the canopy but they become fainter. A breeze soughs through the upper branches and the sound changes depending on which trees "resound", to use the old English meaning of sough (swogan). In the ash and oaks the breeze forms a thick low sound which changes in the beeches to a crisper tone and then it lightens to a finer tone in the high lime trees.

These shifting wind sounds create a changing mood which echoes with the way the body experiences the wood, and not just human bodies. Narrow tracks converge at different levels, criss-crossing the steep slope, rising and falling. There are few flat-ways of human passage and these have been unused for many years. We stumble on four-legged ways to meet this wood on its own terms, terms which lead us from day into night. But this is not an easy transition. It is not merely the dimming of light; like everything else here it is contested. The daytime birds have their songs for the light. Blackbirds swap riffs with each other through the trees and other songbirds sharpen calls and phrases learned in far places, other continents, in the dying light.

As darkness gains a firmer grip, the songbirds fade and the owls start. Suddenly there is a wild screaming from the treetops further up the ridge. Jays are mobbing an owl. The jays, resentful of the haunting presence of the tawny owls, still have enough light left to maintain their ritual defiance. They jabber and shriek at an owl until it takes off, floating noiselessly down through the wood, sweeping past us by only a couple of feet, with a jay yelling threats and obscenities a second behind it - day pursuing night. The two birds vanish into the darkening trees and everything falls still - a stillness which builds towards something as yet mysterious and secret.

webTitle: Lies, dreams, and washing up in Chinatown

fields.headline: Lies, dreams, and washing up in Chinatown
fields.standfirst:
Arrival Gang help stops at the channel. Then they are on their own
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The yellow roofed pagoda in Newport Place, central London, is the hub of the capital's Chinese community. Every day, young Chinese Britons congregate on its steps to chat, read the papers and talk into their mobile phones.
fields.body:
The yellow roofed pagoda in Newport Place, central London, is the hub of the capital's Chinese community. Every day, young Chinese Britons congregate on its steps to chat, read the papers and talk into their mobile phones.

From there radiate the streets of Chinatown, lined with the restaurants, supermarkets, shops and businesses that provide employment and opportunity for many in the community - and a chance for new arrivals.

The dispersal of Chinese migrants after they arrive in Britain is a haphazard process and London, with its 60,000-strong community, acts as a magnet for many of the 400 to 500 who enter the country illegally every month.

Beng Lan Chew, a lawyer who represents Chinese asylum seekers, said: "I had a client, a young asylum seeker, who knew no one and could not speak English. He just went to the pagoda until he met someone who spoke his dialect. They took him in, gave him work and let him sleep in their restaurant."

According to other lawyers and community activists in the Chinese community, the sophisticated snakehead gang organisation that transports the migrants, stops at the English channel, leaving the migrants to fend for themselves.

Most of those who arrive are young men looking to establish themselves before calling their families to join them. Many are heavily indebted to the gangs, having paid only a small amount of the cost which can be as much £20,000.

"Some of these people borrow the cost of their freedom, and the gangs do not consider it their job to help these people settle and find work; they just want the money they are owed," said Bobby Chan, a case worker at the Central London law centre in Soho.

"The asylum seekers are left to find their own work and accommodation. Fortunately Chinatown can be like a private job centre for them."

The informal economy functions smoothly in Chinatown, with jobs advertised by word of mouth and many of them filled by fresh arrivals.

Often the first week's wages - around £100 for a washing-up job - is paid to the person who introduced the employer to the new arrival, and after that most of the money is sent home to settle debts and help family. The job includes food and accommodation.

"Every day in the post office just off Trafalgar Square you can see Chinese sending bundles of cash home," said Mr Chan, who has around 400 asylum cases at any one time.

He maintains that while there is criminality in Chinatown, most businesses are lawful, and the influence of gangs is minimal. The gangs' real influence, he said, lies in China where rural villages are increasingly the target for the human traffickers.

"China is so big that even central government cannot control it, which gives local officials the power of warlords," he said. "They implement policies so harshly it can cause people to flee."

The gangs tempt people to migrate and spread rumours about asylum, he added. "Last week someone asked me if it was true that as the Queen Mother is 100 this year there was an asylum amnesty in Britain. It seems unbelievable but people travel believing these stories are true."

fields.headline: We'll find racketeers, vow police
fields.standfirst:
Driver still held as victims' families urged to speak up
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Driver still held as victims' families urged to speak up
fields.body:
Police in Dover yesterday vowed to bring to justice the immigration racketeers responsible for the deaths of 58 young Chinese who were sealed into the back of a lorry.

Detectives conducting a manslaughter investigation were last night continuing to question the driver of the Dutch-registered vehicle in which the bodies of 54 men and four women, all in their 20s, were discovered at midnight on Sunday.

Two young men who survived the ordeal are still being treated in hospital for the effects of the intense heat in the lorry's refrigeration unit, which was switched off as temperatures soared outside.

They have indicated to officers that the doomed human cargo was from the south China coastal province of Fujian, and were yesterday being questioned further through an interpreter.

None of the victims' relatives have yet approached police, who have appealed for help identifying them.

Detective Superintendent Dennis McGookin, the senior investigating officer, said at a dockside press conference yesterday: "The main lines of inquiry are to identify these people and try to establish exactly what happened, to try to contact the families and loved ones of these people.

"Despite the fact that they come from the other side of the world we are determined to carry out a thorough and efficient investigation and those responsible for the deaths of these young people will be brought to justice.

"It may be that there could be relatives living in this country and I would make an appeal to the Chinese community that if anyone is concerned that one of the victims may be one of their loved ones, I would ask them to contact the casualty bureau where they can speak to people in Chinese dialect."

"We have got to remember that these young people died a horrifying death and we need to find their families."

He continued: "Two young men survived this horrific ordeal and both of them are still in hospital. Both are recovering under medical attention.

"These two young men are vital to our investigation and we will have to look after all of their needs."

Three Dutch police officers are in Britain assisting as English officers interview the driver, a Dutch national, who is being held at a police station in Kent.

Police have authority to hold him until 6pm today.

Mr McGookin refused to confirm the identity of the driver and would not say whether he had been cooperating.

He said police in Beijing had been "very supportive".

A Chinese embassy spokeswoman said yesterday that police had confirmed to them that the two survivors are from China and that consular officials had travelled to Dover to assist the detectives. It was not known if the officials would be speaking to the survivors.

The spokeswoman said: "The Chinese government is shocked at this tragedy. This incident showed that in the face of the rampant illegal immigration throughout the world, all countries have a responsibility to jointly crack down on such activity."

Police confirmed yesterday that preliminary results of the postmortems showed that the immigrants had died from asphyxiation. The examinations of the bodies are expected to continue into today.

More than 60 police officers and forensic experts are working on the inquiry and DNA samples and fingerprints have been taken from the bodies to help confirm their identities.

A vigil was due to be held last night at the bay on Dover's Eastern Docks where the white Mercedes lorry was searched.

The Rev Norman Setchell, one of Dover's port chaplains, said many in the town wanted to focus attention on the human tragedy.

The United Reformed Church minister said he had spoken to ambulance workers called to the docks who described having to prise dead bodies apart.

Worshippers from Dover's Christian churches who have volunteered to help refugees and asylum seekers in the town are expected to attend, along with port workers.

Mr Setchell, who is chairman of the Asylum Seekers Support Group, said: "We are reflecting really on the fact that this is suffering humanity and not just people labelled as refugees or asylum seekers.

"People have been phoning me and feeling that with all the conversation to do with either political things, or financial things or illegal trafficking, we shouldn't forget this is one of many painful things that are going on.

"It is a brutal shocking event in the midst of lots of other horrendous stories that we hear from people travelling here from other parts of the world seeking asylum or seeking justice or seeking a better life."

Anyone who fears one of their relatives may be among the dead are asked to contact the Kent police casualty bureaux on 0645 441551.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Mistake of the day
fields.body:
Mistake of the day

Lib Dem MP Jenny Tonge has paid the price for her sartorial style. Wandering the streets of Westminster she was accosted by a man and "ordered off the streets" while being accused of being a "bloody trollop". The MP for Richmond Park remarks: "I was wearing flat shoes and a long mac - so was he, now I come to think of it."

Flag day

The Saltire, the national flag of Scotland, is appearing in different shades of blue - a fact that has sparked debate in the Scottish parliament. George Reid from Edinburgh claims the flag should have a sky blue only background as decreed by Angus mac Fergus following his defeat of Angles and Saxons in East Lothian in 832. "No other country's flag is made with varying backgrounds," says a troubled Mr Reid.

Today

Commons: Norther Ireland questions. PM's questions. Children (leaving care) bill, second reading. Lords: Utilities bill, committee.

webTitle: Vindaloo, vindaloo, tally ho, tally ho, vindaloo

fields.headline: Vindaloo, vindaloo, tally ho, tally ho, vindaloo
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: A reader has emailed a brilliant suggestion that would end two of the government's big political problems overnight. Instead of chasing foxes, we could offer hooligan hunting.
fields.body:
A reader has emailed a brilliant suggestion that would end two of the government's big political problems overnight. Instead of chasing foxes, we could offer hooligan hunting.

What a colourful sight it would be! The hunt in their scarlet jackets, the sinewy, sweating horses panting for the start, the baying of the hounds, the brazen shout of the horns! A few fields away the hooligan is released from his cage, the hounds pick up the scent of Carlsberg and vindaloo, a tattoo flashes in the sunlight - and tally-ho!

People would call it cruel, but all the evidence is that hooligans love the hunt, and would take great pride in outwitting their pursuers, if only for a few minutes. And of course the rest of us would enjoy every moment.

As would Jack Straw. Yesterday the Tories returned to the attack over the scenes in Belgium, and managed to land a few bricks on his head.

I was also delighted to see what I had predicted to myself at the weekend: soon this row would become a battle of the decades.

Labour's Dale Campbell-Savours began. He pondered whether it was all to do with the collapse in values during the 1980s, which was the decade of Thatcherism. Why don't you talk about that? he asked Ann Widdecombe.

She snorted like a mare at a high fence. It was, she said to loud Tory cheers, not the fault of the 1980s, but of the 1960s and the 1970s.

But then, we wondered, why should the 1950s - decade of teddy boys and ripped-up cinema seats - get off so lightly? Or the 1940s, when all Europe was riven by professional hooliganism? Or even the Belle Epoque, that period of sexual licence which lowered the moral tone of an entire continent?

It was, in fact, one of those depressing moments when the Commons stops looking for solutions and descends to dreary abuse. Anyone who had anything useful to say was more or less ignored, the lot of the thoughtful legislator throughout the ages.

For instance, Paul Flynn pointed out that the Belgian police had prepared for a riot, whereas the Dutch police had prepared for a party, "with half-strength beer and the use of a drug which has a calming effect".

A good point, I thought, but the rules are rigid: anything which implies that the use of any drug in any way might be acceptable has to be ignored at best and reviled at worst. Miss Widdecombe ignored him and ploughed on to read the charge sheet.

At one point Joe Ashton made the mistake of smiling at something she said. This allowed her to make a classically fake debating point:

"The hon member considers it funny. I don't think our team considers it funny. I don't think our fans consider it funny. I don't think other governments ..." You get the idea. No, Miss W, he wasn't laughing at the problem: he was laughing at you.

The home secretary's point has been that the Tories' big solution - banning people who are not convicted but who are thought potential hooligans - would be useless, since the great majority of the people arrested in Belgium have no record. It now emerges that many of them have.

A-ha, said Mr Straw. But one third of all British men under the age of 30 have a criminal conviction. "So in any random group of 1,000 young men, one third would have convictions."

I keep hearing this amazing figure, which implies that there are considerably more criminals among the male population than there are men with brown eyes. The Home Office was unable to back this claim yesterday. I am prepared to believe it's true when I see the figures.

In the meantime I'm trying to sell the rights for hooligan hunting to ITV. Gary Lineker will be at a loose end soon.
