webTitle: Motor city's escape route from decline

fields.headline: Motor city's escape route from decline
fields.standfirst: Mayor's message: 'If you want to make money come to Detroit'
fields.trailText: Traditionally Woodward Avenue divides Detroit into the city's east and west sides. Drive along it these days, from the new baseball stadium downtown to the old General Motors headquarters up on Grand Boulevard, and it provides an instant snap shot of the challenging diversity of America's motor city.
fields.body:
Traditionally Woodward Avenue divides Detroit into the city's east and west sides. Drive along it these days, from the new baseball stadium downtown to the old General Motors headquarters up on Grand Boulevard, and it provides an instant snap shot of the challenging diversity of America's motor city.

The stadium is brand new - the centre piece of mayor Dennis Archer's ambitious plans for inner-city renewal. It has everything the baseball fan could want - except a decent team. Even the church next door exhorts the passing faithful to pray for the Tigers.

Mr Archer could use a prayer or two, as well. A Democrat now into his second stint at city hall, he turned down a place in the Clinton cabinet in his determination to add Detroit to the list of smokestack US cities which have shrugged off years of decline and turned themselves round. Detroit may not be as far along as the likes of Cleveland or Philadelphia but Mr Archer is determined to get it there.

With the fervour of a conviction politician he shrugs off suggestions that in the era of the new economy the US's premier industrial city - his description - may struggle to cope. He says there is still a lot to do but Detroit is on the way. Detroit's partnership between public and private sector will be a winner.

Since 1994 he calculates some $12bn (£8bn) has been invested in the city. Others, he says, put the figure much higher. The debt-rating agencies used to have Detroit's bonds on the "non-investment grade" list. Now the city's paper has the first A rating since 1962. "We have brought a positive fundamental change in a situation that had been in decline."

So what if the next census - just completed but not yet published - shows Detroit's population has dropped below 1m. The city won't slide into the river as a result, he says. The big three car makers, General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler on which Detroit's economy still depends are able to take on any challengers. They are investing heavily both on their own plants and with new, local, suppliers. That means good, well paid jobs. Not too long ago unemployment was 16%, now it is down to 5.3% - though that is still above the surrounding areas as well as the national average.

Like many another politician faced with a contracting industrial base, the mayor talks hopefully of "smart Detroit". For now that means a handful of internet companies moving into the city's downtown office blocks but the mayor hopes for more. A couple of casinos have added to the city's night life - as well as providing several hundred jobs.

But the mayor is thinking of the future. Education is a top priority. Mr Archer sees Detroit's future centred on the education of its children. "Our public schools are going to be able to deliver to business the educated youngsters business needs. They are no longer going to have to spend ungodly amounts of money on training."

Though the mayor is committed to Detroit he cannot pass up the chance of a party political broadcast on behalf of his friends in Washington. The national economy is in great shape, thanks to the "excellent domestic policies of president Clinton and vice-president Gore". But he is quickly back on the Motown theme.

"I'm very pleased with where we are and, more importantly, where we are going," he says. "There's an excitement about the city."

Parts of Woodward Avenue back up the mayor's contention. Around the baseball stadium cluster a selection of the city's theatres - Detroit boasts more theatre seats than any US city except New York - alongside libraries in neo-classical stone finery as well as galleries offering anything from Van Gogh to African modern. For those for whom art comes on a plate there are swanky restaurants where you can dine in style for $200 a head.

Further along parts of Wayne County University stand alongside a colour-coded veterans facility which would make even the avant garde designers of Paris's La Defense blink. In neat counterpoint is a stand of 1930s skyscrapers built as a lasting testimony to Detroit's economic power.

But in between the architectural signposts of the city's pomp and circumstance are other, unhappier, reminders that Detroit's is a mixed heritage and that the mayor still has a huge task. Small low-rise factories stand apparently abandoned, their landmark water towers looming over them like giant rusting spiders. It was a city that was once home to almost 2m people. Now it is half that. In poorer neighbourhoods the signs of blight are everywhere. Houses built in a hurry when Detroit was a boom town at the beginning of the century are showing their age. Others, abandoned, are fire marked and tottering. The city's infrastructure is hardly in an encouraging condition. Motor city's roads don't bear thinking about. More than 60% of the city's housing was built before 1950. There is little public transport.

Yet Mayor Archer is a persuasive force. The message to business is simple. "If you want to make money you should come to Detroit." But so far he had been operating against the background of a growing US economy and friends in the White House. Both could soon change. Given his legal background - he was a lawyer and judge before he took to politics - Mr Archer must know that as far as Detroit's future is concerned, the jury is still out.

webTitle: Morsel of hope in a mountain of waste

fields.headline: Morsel of hope in a mountain of waste
fields.standfirst: Young scavengers in Nicaragua are among those to benefit from efforts to end inhuman child labour
fields.trailText: Young scavengers in Nicaragua are among those to benefit from efforts to end inhuman child labour
fields.body:
Some children work by lamplight, others rise before dawn to sift through Nicaragua's putrefying rubbish. From the age of five upwards, they live by selling on the black market the scraps of copper, aluminum, glass, plastic and rubber they pull from Managua's municipal rubbish dump.

The 90-acre La Chureca dump is the permanent, vile-smelling home of more than 100 families and 480 children. Their shelters, among the mountains of waste, are made out of scrap metal or cardboard.

The adults are illiterate, the children get no education, suffer from malaria, dengue fever and respiratory diseases. The girls suffer regular sexual abuse and the boys often turn to drugs. All of "Los Churecos" are ostracised by the nearby community of 16,000 people.

But tonight in London, Dos Generaciones, a small non-governmental group that has been working with the families for 10 years, providing schooling and skills training, will share the world's largest human rights award, which focuses this year on harmful child labour. Other winners of the $300,000 Bodyshop award include grassroots groups from Brazil, Togo and India.

"It's inhuman, work that no one should do - least of all a child," said Mario Chamorro Ruiz, of Dos Generaciones. "They have spent all their life in the dump. It is the only thing that they or their parents have known. They see rubbish as their past, present and future. Their parents don't want to move because they fear they will not survive. We began thinking that we were going to take the children from there, but we soon learned that it wasn't to be."

Now they are trying to improve conditions, self-esteem and family relations. In the past five years Dos Genera ciones has overcome the families' suspician to provide education for almost all the children. But poverty in Nicaragua is increasing and new people arrive at the dump all the time.

The UN believes that some 250m children between five and 14 work, almost half of them full-time. Not all the work is harmful or exploitative but the global movement to stop children working in hazardous conditions or in work that interferes with their development is growing steadily.

In Bahia in northeast Brazil, up to a million children work in quarries, charcoal works, sugar cane fields and brick factories. O Movimento de Organizacao Communitaria (MOC), another award winner, has been working since 1970 to get children out of some of the worst work.

"They start sometimes at four," said Naidison de Quintrella Baptista, of the group. "Many works have processes that are designed for children. They only accept children who must work 12 hours a day or more for sometimes $1 a week.

"We have managed to get thousands of children out of virtual slavery," said Professor De Morais of MOC. "Of course the children help the families to survive, but we and many other groups have helped persuade the government to provide scholarships which are paid to the parents so they can go to school."

More than 30,000 children have benefited from MOC's work and in the past eight years, said Soleny Hamu of the national forum for the eradication of child labour, more than a million children have left dangerous work and received an education. "Everyone wants to get on the programmes now. But in the long-term, we must provide land.

"We are working with land reform groups and others. Education is the only way to break the cycle of poverty. We are going to start a new world, where children who never went to school get their chance to eat properly, to play."

He said the responsability of the rich countries was to help break the pattern of exploitation which condemns children to illiteracy. "The rich depend on the exploitation of the poor. We must all invest in trying to change the relationship."

The other two awards of $75,000 (£46,000) went to WAO Afrique which is fighting against child domestic workers being sexually abused and harshly treated in Togo, and Peace Trust which works with children in the spinning mills, bleach works, tanneries and quarries of Tamil Nadu in India.

fields.headline: GM trials suffer new setback
fields.standfirst: GM debate: special report
fields.trailText: Government backed trials of genetically modified crops suffered another public relations blow last night as ministers revealed that supposedly GM-free crops at the only Scottish site in the programme are contaminated with GM material.
fields.body:
Government backed trials of genetically modified crops suffered another public relations blow last night as ministers revealed that supposedly GM-free crops at the only Scottish site in the programme are contaminated with GM material.

But the Scottish executive insisted that the trial at Daviot, Aberdeenshire, would continue - despite ministers' advice that commercial farmers should plough up similar conventional rape crops grown from seeds provided by the Advanta company, which blames accidental cross-pollination in Canada.

The latest mistake in an embarrassing catalogue follows last week's revelation that another trial is taking place on a farm in Essex which has suffered a serious crop disease.

There are only 48 trials instead of up to 80 originally forecast this year, and the government cannot afford to lose many more in the programme, which is designed to compare the effects of herbicide treatments for GM and non-GM plants on the environment and wildlife.

Tests revealed that there was 0.9% GM contamination of the control crop at Daviot, nearly twice the 0.5% level the European commission thinks should be allowed in conventional seeds until more permanent decisions are made on purity. The Scottish executive was already furious that officials in England did not alert them to the Advanta contamination until weeks after the company first told the government of the problem. Neither the government nor its independent scientific advisers had tested any of the conventional seeds used in the trials for GM presence before learning of the Advanta mistake on April 17. It only asked Aventis, another seed company whose GM rape crops are being tested on 12 sites around the country, whether any of the control crops were affected at the beginning of June.

Aventis notified the government of the Daviot problem on June 9.The oil seed rape there is due to be harvested in late July or early August.

Ross Finnie, the Liberal Democrat rural affairs minister on the executive, said that he was satisfied the validity of the trial had not been compromised. He told the Scottish assembly: "It is important to recognise that there is a very pertinent difference between a crop which is grown for commercial purposes and one which is being grown as part of this trial."

Government officials said the site was a kilometre away from commercial farms and there was little risk of cross-pollination.

But Richard Dixon, of Friends of the Earth Scotland, said: "There is a clear contradiction here. The advice to any other farmer is 'If you have this crop in the ground, plough it up'. It is crazy."

Greenpeace said: "If the government wants to maintain any credibility, it should declare this trial void and destroy the crop immediately."

fields.headline: Devout family goes to ground
fields.standfirst:
Neighbours of suspect describe man unable to hold down jobs
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The home of Arjan van der Spek, the Dutchman held in connection with the deaths of the 58 young Chinese, hardly looks like the headquarters for a human trafficker.
fields.body:
The home of Arjan van der Spek, the Dutchman held in connection with the deaths of the 58 young Chinese, hardly looks like the headquarters for a human trafficker.

It's a nondescript two storey red brick flat above a bicycle repair shop, and pot plants crowd homely window sills which look down on to a busy road in this rather swanky suburb of the city.

A Sunday school sits directly opposite while a small town Dutch church nestles nearby.

A local cafe owner, shocked by the affair, tells a story of a god fearing family which attends a church in a nearby suburb at least twice every Sunday.

Arjan van der Spek's father is a quiet and gentle man called Wout, who works in the sprawling bike shop to make ends meet.

But his son, according to locals, has never been able to hold down a job for long because boredom always becomes too much for him.

Known as Arie, the 24-year-old worked on a local farm as boy.

Little is known about his older brother or his younger sister, Erika, who is thought to be 17.

His mother has already told the local press that she does not believe her son is guilty.

Her son, she maintains, is the victim of an elaborate criminal organisation which has appropriated his address and his passport for the sake of one illegal smuggling operation.

The family had yesterday gone to ground.

fields.headline: Record rise in borrowing
fields.standfirst: Credit card offers take the blame but figures prompt interest rate concerns
fields.trailText: Credit card borrowing surged by a record amount last month - partly fuelled by consumers flocking to take advantage of low rate deals - raising fears that the economy may not be slowing down as quickly as had been thought.
fields.body:
Credit card borrowing surged by a record amount last month - partly fuelled by consumers flocking to take advantage of low rate deals - raising fears that the economy may not be slowing down as quickly as had been thought.

Borrowing on credit cards rose by £490m in May, almost three times the rise seen in April and the biggest since the British Bankers' Association's records began in 1986.

While the BBA said the new figures had been "inflated" by card issuers offering low rate debt consolidation deals, they could send a signal to the Bank of England that further interest rate rises may be needed to keep consumer spending in check. They will also add weight to concerns expressed by the financial services authority about soaring consumer lending.

Total lending by the major British banks to the private sector, including individuals, rose by £5.09bn in May, compared with a £2.87bn rise the previous month, said the BBA.

The credit card figures partly reflect the cutthroat competition in the credit card market which has resulted in the lowest introductory interest rates ever seen in the UK.

There have been four interest rate rises since September 1 last year, but many credit card rates have actually fallen over the same period.

Nationwide building society last month reduced its introductory annual percentage rate for purchases to 3.5%, and Capital One Bank has slashed its rate to 3.9%.

Meanwhile the Tesco Visa card has cut its interest rate three times since May 1999; in one month alone it received 250,000 applications.

The last few months have also seen a plethora of low cost deals for those looking to transfer their outstanding credit card balances to another provider. Even Barclaycard, the UK's most popular card, was recently forced to cut its rate for balance transfers in a bid to keep new entrants to the market at bay.

"There is a lot more competition out there, there are a lot more cards, and a lot more ways of using your card," said Kathy Lewis, assistant director of the Credit Card Research Group. One of the areas seeing the strongest spending growth is the service sector. There were also new figures yesterday showing that mortgage lending bounced back in May following a temporary lull the previous month - with remortgaging making up a growing chunk of the total.

Gross mortgage lending rose to £10.3bn - up significantly on April's figure of £9.2bn but lower than the £10.7bn achieved in March, said the Council of Mortgage Lenders.

Remortgaging rose from £2.5bn in April to £3bn in May, while the proportion of loans for first-time buyers fell sharply, from 45% to 37%.

webTitle: Street theatre  students demand Suharto's trial

fields.headline: Street theatre  students demand Suharto's trial
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Indonesian students staged a protest in Jakarta yesterday to demand former president Suharto's trial for corruption. The demonstration followed the revelation on Monday that General Suharto, 79, had   protested to the UN that house arrest violated his human rights.
fields.body:
Indonesian students staged a protest in Jakarta yesterday to demand former president Suharto's trial for corruption. The demonstration followed the revelation on Monday that General Suharto, 79, had protested to the UN that house arrest violated his human rights.

He has been detained at his Jakarta home since May 27 when state prosecutors accused him of not cooperating with their investigation into the allegation that he enriched his family and friends during his 32-year authoritarian rule. He has denied the allegation.

President Abdurrahman Wahid has said that Gen Suharto's relatives are willing to negotiate the surrender of illegally acquired assets in return for the former leader's freedom. But he said that a court would have to decide how much Gen Suharto must return to secure a pardon, the Jakarta Post reported on Sunday.

"At least $25bn [£16.5bn], but how much further is the limit I don't know," the president was quoted as saying, without disclosing how he had calculated the extent of Gen Suharto's wealth.

A member of Gen Suharto's legal team flatly rejected the estimate and said it was up to the state to prove that the fortune existed.

webTitle: Watchdog rolls out new railway map

fields.headline: Watchdog rolls out new railway map
fields.standfirst: Guiding principle is to make services passenger friendly, says chairman
fields.trailText: A new railway map providing more passenger-friendly franchise areas was proposed by industry chiefs yesterday. The plans envisage Wales and its border regions being run by a single company and the establishment of a huge franchise covering the entire of the north of England.
fields.body:
A new railway map providing more passenger-friendly franchise areas was proposed by industry chiefs yesterday. The plans envisage Wales and its border regions being run by a single company and the establishment of a huge franchise covering the entire of the north of England.

The 25 existing passenger train franchises will be cut to 22, with some being changed and others being absorbed into new franchise areas. The plans - which are still subject to change - were drawn up by the shadow Strategic Rail Authority which said its intention was to "revitalise the network" at a time when passenger levels were rising sharply.

The map redrawing was welcomed by the government, the train companies and the main passenger group, the Rail Passengers Council. But the council said the franchise changes would only work if they were accompanied by heavy investment in the network.

Under the SSRA plan, services will fall into three new groups - long distance high speed, expanded from the former InterCity, London com muter and regional. The changes include:

 Trans-Penine express - a new franchise covering some north of England services;

 Northern - a new franchise which will combine local and passenger transport executive services at present run by the First North Western and Northern Spirit companies;

 Wales and the borders - another new franchise replacing four existing franchises "which have no clear focus";

 Thameslink 2000 - a new franchise based on the expansion of cross-London services;

 West Anglia Great Eastern - another franchise covering services in and out of London's Liverpool Street station;

 Wessex - serving the area between Worcestershire, Bristol and the south coast, and possibly the London-Exeter line and local Bristol services.

SSRA chairman Sir Alastair Morton said: "Our guiding principle is to improve service, not to introduce change for change's sake.

"What we are proposing is a map that will revitalise the network, with franchise areas designed to relate better to each other and to provide improved accessibility for passengers." The changes are announced as the SSRA copes with the replacement of the 18 short-term franchises existing under the current rail map.

 Fiat's restructuring took another step yesterday when it sold control of its rolling stock business to French industrial combine Alstom, writes Mark Milner . The sale of the 51% stake is likely to be followed by acquisitions in other areas. Under the deal Fiat receives euro360m (£228m), including debt, for the 51% stake. Last year the rail business had earnings of euro375m, less than 10% of the group total.

webTitle: City's oscar awards descend into farce

fields.headline: City's oscar awards descend into farce
fields.trailText: The Primark Extel awards, known as the City's "oscars", descended into farce yesterday when the organisers announced they had discovered "anomalies" in this year's results after a flood of complaints from disgruntled institutions.
fields.body:
The Primark Extel awards, known as the City's "oscars", descended into farce yesterday when the organisers announced they had discovered "anomalies" in this year's results after a flood of complaints from disgruntled institutions.

The awards were given out at a gala lunch at Guildhall last week, attended by Lastminute.com's co-founder, Martha Lane Fox, and Vodafone AirTouch's chief executive, Chris Gent.

They are watched closely by analysts and fund managers, whose multi-million pound bonuses are often affected by their position in Primark's rankings.

However, Primark posted a statement on its website yesterday admitting that there had been "an unexpected level of queries" regarding the ranking of analyst teams by industry sector.

It said an unforeseen bias had been created by the size of some teams. Because votes were cast for individual analysts and then added together to make team rankings, teams with more members automatically ended up with more votes.

Primark was forced to call in the accountancy firm Arthur Andersen to carry out a second audit of the results, which has taken the last four days. A Primark spokesman said: "This has been wholly unsatisfactory and it's unfortunate."

Analysts reacted with fury. One said: "The whole survey has become a complete joke."

Some believe their pay packets could be significantly lighter because of the results, though Primark would not reveal the extent of any changes.

The problem was caused by Primark's decision to make the survey pan-European, rather than focusing on Britain. This meant some of the analyst teams involved were much bigger.

A senior analyst, who declined to be named, said: "The one thing they had going, as against rival surveys, is that it concentrated on the UK market.

"The fact that they've messed up all the calculations suggests they don't know what they're doing."

webTitle: It's posher up north, now Harvey Nichols to open in Manchester

fields.headline: It's posher up north, now Harvey Nichols to open in Manchester
fields.trailText: The buying power of the M62 corridor across northern England was confirmed yesterday by Harvey Nichols' decision to site the fourth and last of its stores in Manchester, less than 40 miles from its profitable branch in Leeds.
fields.body:
The buying power of the M62 corridor across northern England was confirmed yesterday by Harvey Nichols' decision to site the fourth and last of its stores in Manchester, less than 40 miles from its profitable branch in Leeds.

The choice of the city was based on customer analysis which showed the "London effect", which has ruled out a branch in Birmingham, did not apply in the North.

"For whatever reason people don't seem to want to cross the Pennines to go shopping," said Joseph Wan, the chief executive of Harvey Nichols. The group's Manchester branch will be the flagship of a £50m development in the central Shambles area. The store will replace the last relic of the havoc caused by the 1996 IRA bomb with 88 lofts and flats on a neighbouring site.

Manchester is hoping for a repetition of the "Harvey Nicks trick" which is said to have revolutionised the image of Leeds. The Yorkshire store has consistently matched performance at the Knightsbridge flagship shop, and saw a further 7% rise in takings in the first 10 weeks of this year.

Mr Wan said that the Manchester branch completed the group's plan for big stores in the UK, although smaller outlets selling Harvey Nichols' branded goods will follow in up to 10 cities.

The third branch to open has just received planning permission for a site in St Andrew's Square, Edinburgh, with the opening due in autumn 2002.

"There are only a few cities outside London with the combination we need of a large catchment area, sufficient affluence and fashion-conscious customers," said Mr Wan.

webTitle: Clear victory for Gordon Brown's City mission

fields.headline: Clear victory for Gordon Brown's City mission
fields.standfirst: Withholding tax row resolved
fields.trailText: The European Union's wrangle over the withholding tax always looked as if it would be one of those rows that go on forever. To be sure the deal yesterday, scuppering an EU-wide savings tax and introducing an information sharing agreement to crack down on tax dodging instead, was soured by Austria's dubious determination to hang on to its right to hide money for foreigners.
fields.body:
The European Union's wrangle over the withholding tax always looked as if it would be one of those rows that go on forever. To be sure the deal yesterday, scuppering an EU-wide savings tax and introducing an information sharing agreement to crack down on tax dodging instead, was soured by Austria's dubious determination to hang on to its right to hide money for foreigners.

But getting 14 of the 15 nations at yesterday's meeting of EU leaders in Santa Maria Da Feira, Portugal, to buy into the principle that tax dodgers should not be free to hide within each nation's banking systems - and getting Austria to agree to let the rest of the EU get on and start building a system for swapping information - appears to be a clear victory for Gordon Brown's brand of stubborn diplomacy.

It is all the more impressive since this Labour chancellor has been willing to spend two full years fighting the corner of the City of London's eurobond market. This was about protecting a vibrant section of Britain's economy; it was not about middle England votes.

Six months ago, at the Helsinki summit towards the end of the Finnish EU presidency, Mr Brown had his back against the wall. He was roundly condemned in the capitals of Europe for seemingly protecting the privileged few to the detriment of ordinary taxpayers.

Now, instead of the withholding tax, we have the outline framework of something that will sit much more comfortably with wider international efforts to tackle tax evasion, focused on persuading or even coercing off-shore tax havens into adopting more open and transparent financial systems.

In a global economy some sort of truly international approach to the problem - not just an EU deal - is the only one that will prevent suspect money hopping borders. There are hurdles aplenty ahead - tricky things like getting the Swiss authorities to disclose data to EU governments on their citizens' savings. But for the moment we might treat Mr Brown's performance in Feira as proof that positive engagement in Europe can and does actually work.

Now France

It used to be such fun sniggering at French capitalism. Even its practitioners would admit - between fulminating against US cultural imperialism and/or economic hegemony - that their particular brand was "capitalism without capital". Critics were rather sharper. France, they would say, was in a state of enarchie, a pun based on the French Ecole Nationale d'Administration which produced a well-connected elite moving seamlessly between civil service, industry and government. In France, connections were everything. Even when privatisation set in, it had a particularly Gallic flavour, with the state unwilling to let private investors loose on anything until a bid-proof core of shareholders had been assembled.

But now it appears France's corporate heads are learning the rules of global capitalism and applying them with gusto. There have always been those such as arch-rivals Bernard Arnault at LVMH and Pinault-Printemps-Redoute's François Pinault who have taken a more Anglo-Saxon approach to corporate ownership. Yet they were the exceptions, and treated as mavericks.

That is changing. Three French companies yesterday made significant corporate moves, with Vivendi acquiring Seagram, Publicis bidding successfully for Saatchi & Saatchi and - rather more modestly - Alstom buying control of Fiat's rail business.

The timing is a coincidence. The trend is not. Nor can it dismissed simply as a reflection of the business confidence generated by France's resurgent economy.

French attitudes towards making money are changing. Those who have been seeking to persuade Paris to adopt a more Anglo-Saxon approach may yet have cause to regret it.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Asda to recruit first greeters
fields.body:
Asda to recruit first greeters

An Asda store is hosting a talent spotting evening to recruit American-style greeters for the first Asda Wal-Mart Supercentre to be opened in Britain.

The supermarket, in the Patchway area of Bristol, has 20 vacancies for greeters to be filled by the end of July. Applicants will be asked to sing songs and tell stories and jokes to amuse customers while they shop.

Store manager Pat Gamble said: "This is our way of giving local people a chance to come into the store and meet us face to face. We want people to come in and enjoy themselves and find a new job at the same time."

Halifax to cut up to 300 jobs

Halifax yesterday announced plans to axe up to 300 jobs at sites in Yorkshire. Around 160 jobs will be lost over six months at the bank's Halifax headquarters, with the rest of the cuts at its corporate sections offices in Leeds.

There would also be some redeployment between the two sites, personnel director John Lee said. "Around 250 to 300 people will need to leave the Halifax group in either Halifax or Leeds over the next six months," he said. The move follows a three-month review of the group's businesses in west Yorkshire looking at streamlining its central offices.

LVMH ready to sell Gucci stake

LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton said it is ready to sell its 20.6% stake in Gucci to Pinault-Printemps-Redoute if Gucci promises "there will not be a change of control without a full [takeover] offer at a fair price".

Such a solution "would be in the interests of all Gucci shareholders," LVMH said in a statement.

LVMH and retailer PPR abandoned talks yesterday aimed at resolving their differences Gucci's ownership with each blaming the other for the breakdown. LVMH has been looking to sell its Gucci stake as it is considered non-strategic, the Wall Street Journal Europe reported on June 5.

Diamond sales rise by 44%

Roaring US demand pushed diamond sales up 44% in the first half of this year to hit $3.5bn (£2.3bn) - more than was sold in the whole of 1998, the De Beers group said yesterday. The figures were higher than analysts' expectations and show little or no consumer resistance to diamonds resulting from worries about their role in fuelling civil wars in the Congo, Sierra Leone and Angola.

Glycosciences on fast track

Oxford Glycosciences, the biotech firm, is to be given fast-track treatment when US regulators scrutinise its drug for Gaucher's disease - a genetic deficiency affecting the metabolism. The news means the drug could be on the market by the end of next year, and the company's shares rose 187.5p to £16.75 after yesterday's announcement.

fields.headline: A monarch in waiting
fields.standfirst:
Advice to Prince William: get a life
The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The polo-playing heir to the throne keeps himself pretty fit and sticks, wherever possible, to a wholesome diet of organic food. Both his parents are alive and healthy and his grandmother is in remarkably good shape as she nudges 100. An actuary would give Charles favourable odds of making it to 85 at least. Thus, in all likelihood, it will be another 35 years or more before Prince William will become King - always assuming that the monarchical system still finds favour in this country in 2035, which is another interesting actuarial challenge.
fields.body:
The polo-playing heir to the throne keeps himself pretty fit and sticks, wherever possible, to a wholesome diet of organic food. Both his parents are alive and healthy and his grandmother is in remarkably good shape as she nudges 100. An actuary would give Charles favourable odds of making it to 85 at least. Thus, in all likelihood, it will be another 35 years or more before Prince William will become King - always assuming that the monarchical system still finds favour in this country in 2035, which is another interesting actuarial challenge.

The young prince is 18 today. It is a moment for celebration - Happy birthday, Your Royal Highness - but also for serious consideration of what on earth he is to do with his life while awaiting the possibility that sometime in middle age he might be called upon to perform the constitutional role to which he finds himself born. He could be forgiven if he viewed the decades ahead with a leaden heart. Whatever deal Lord Wakeham can arrange with tabloid editors in this country, William will find soon enough that he has no private life in any meaningful sense of the words. At the moment we know virtually nothing about our possible future King beyond the fact that he is good at water polo, bad at chicken paella and has a dog called Widgeon. All that will change. We will know every girl he goes to bed with and several that he does not. We will pick over his exam results, his choice of friends, his dress sense and his taste in motorbikes. We will learn if and when he smokes dope or gets drunk. We will know it all.

All this would be bad enough. How much worse if he were, like his father, trapped in some constitutional no-man's land dutifully awaiting his destiny. Who could possibly wish that William should spend the next three decades cutting ribbon in heavy suits ever smelling of fresh paint. Thirty years of making speeches which never quite strike a satisfactory balance between the controversial and the banal. Half a working life being groomed by jostling courtiers to be the next figurehead but one.

No one could possibly want that. And yet, if he is to be king one day, it does actually matter how William prepares for it. The best argument for a royal family is that advanced by Professor Vernon Bogdanor in his book on the subject: "A constitutional monarchy settles beyond argument the crucial question of who is to be head of state and it places the position of head of state beyond political competition. In doing so ... it alone is in a position to interpret the nation to itself." If such a proposition has any validity, then it matters that William prepares himself for that interpretative role. So far he has - for all sorts of understandable reasons - led an extraordinarily sheltered and privileged life. The privilege may be a life-time sentence, but the shelter need not be. He must determinedly get out into the world beyond Eton and Pop. To say that he must move among a class of people who do not wear starched wing collars and colourful waistcoats is not deadening class war. It is a statement of the obvious, though what is obvious to the rest of us is not always obvious to the courtiers who advise on such things.

William should, in other words, forget about being king for as long as possible and lead as normal a life as we allow him. Get a job, get a life. Learn about this country as a citizen and forget anything you may have been taught within palace walls about subjects. That way the monarchy may, for better or worse, survive. But at least it would not have blighted yet another life.

fields.headline: Chief Justice Ismail Mahomed
fields.standfirst: South Africa's most senior black judge, he overcame the humiliations of apartheid only to find uncertainties in high office
fields.trailText: South Africa's apartheid era has thrown up many extraordinary stories, but few have been more poignant than the life and times of the chief justice, Ismail Mahomed, who has died of cancer aged 68.
fields.body:
South Africa's apartheid era has thrown up many extraordinary stories, but few have been more poignant than the life and times of the chief justice, Ismail Mahomed, who has died of cancer aged 68.

He was, essentially, a conservative who, in the normal course of events, would have identified with the legal establishment and would, no doubt, have found a comfortable and distinguished place within it. "In another world, he would have been a patrician," as one of his brethren put it. But the course of events in postwar South Africa was anything but normal, and the frustration of such goals contributed instead to Mahomed's development into one of the finest civil rights lawyers the country has known.

Born the son of a tradesman, the oldest of six children in a devout Muslim family, he studied law at Witwatersrand University and was admitted to the bar in 1957. Unable to practice in his home city of Pretoria, where there was a ban on "non-white" barristers, he moved to Johannesburg. But even in that cosmopolitan city, where the bar boasted a number of outspoken critics of apartheid, the racial handicaps were excruciating for a proud and sensitive man.

The area in which the Johannesburg bar was situated was classified "white" under the Group Areas Act, so Mahomed was unable to rent chambers. Instead, he had to borrow the offices of sympathetic colleagues when they were out, or resort to a desk in the library to interview clients. Technically excluded from the common room, he lunched on occasion in the toilets.

The most ludicrous obstacles to Mahomed's practice arose when he appeared before the appellate division of the supreme court in Bloemfontein. Tradition required that barristers appearing at South Africa's highest court should arrive in the judicial capital the day before their hearing. But the law stipulated that Asians were not allowed to stay overnight in the Orange Free State. The logic led to Mahomed flying to Bloemfontein on the eve of his appearance, then flying on to Durban in the neighbouring province of Natal - only to return to Bloemfontein next morning.

Despite such handicaps, Mahomed proved to be an outstanding lawyer. In 1974, he became the first black in South African history to take silk. And, although his arrival in judicial office was to be long-delayed in South Africa itself, his qualifications were quickly confirmed by his appointment as a judge of appeal in neighbouring Swaziland and Lesotho, followed by Namibia's appointment of him as its chief justice. He was finally elevated to the South African supreme court in 1991, in the face of imminent black liberation.

A victim of apartheid, he gravitated naturally towards administrative law, winning some landmark decisions against the apartheid government. As an advocate deserving the description of "silver- tongued", he enjoyed triumphs in the well of the court - his brilliant defence of the United Democratic Front (UDF) leadership in the Maritzburg treason trial being among the most famous - as well as handing down historic decisions from the bench, including a passionately-argued judgment against capital punishment.

In 1994, Mahomed was made deputy president of the newly-created constitutional court, and, in 1996, he was appointed chief justice by Nelson Mandela. This last progression had several ironies about it, not the least of which was that a man once refused the hospitality of a bed in the judicial capital was now enthroned in it.

Mahomed's elevation - over the heads of judges senior to him in length of service - was bitterly contested by the all-white bench in the appellate division. Comically reduced to trying to engineer his withdrawal from the contest by appealing to his sense of collegiate "principle", the brethren short-sightedly failed to recognise his potential as a champion of their elitist cause.

Mahomed was seemingly driven by a determination to demonstrate his fitness - as a "non-white" - to hold the highest office in the land. But he reached it only to be tortured by the doubt as to whether he was, in fact, standing on the peak. For much of his tenure as chief justice, there was speculation that he would force the issue as to where the mantle of supreme judicial authority lay - whether on his own shoulders, as head of the appellate division, or on those of the president of the constitutional court in Johannesburg.

But the challenge was never forthcoming from Bloemfontein, whether because of his long-standing ill-health, or in acknowledgement that the current of South African law ran against him, or in appreciation that it could prove divisive of a judicial system struggling for stability amid sometimes chaotic, if overdue, political reform.

Instead, the constitutional court quietly slipped on the mantle in a recent decision, recorded in the last law report Mahomed could have seen, Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association and another: in re ex parte President of Republic of SA and others. In the end, the issue was peacefully, if sadly, settled by Mahomed's death, there being nobody left in the appellate division - now, once again, reduced to an all-white male domain - capable of taking up the Johannesburg challenge.

It used to be said of another eminent South African jurist, Mr Justice Schreiner, that he was the greatest chief justice the country never had. The life of Chief Justice Mahomed offers a contrary lesson, that the frustration of ambition can lie in the very achievement of it.

fields.headline: Nancy Marchand
fields.standfirst: Classical actress renowned for TV roles in mob and media series
fields.trailText: For most people, Nancy Marchand, who has died of lung cancer the day before her 72nd birthday, will be remembered as Mrs Margaret Pynchon, the imperious, but essentially fair-minded and liberal owner of the fictional Los Angeles Tribune, in the 1970s television series, Lou Grant.
fields.body:
For most people, Nancy Marchand, who has died of lung cancer the day before her 72nd birthday, will be remembered as Mrs Margaret Pynchon, the imperious, but essentially fair-minded and liberal owner of the fictional Los Angeles Tribune, in the 1970s television series, Lou Grant. City editor Grant (Ed Asner) complained about her superior and sardonic air, but most journalists would love to work for someone like Mrs Pynchon.

Hers was also one of the few TV roles showing an intelligent woman in a powerful position, who managed to suggest that strength and warmth need not be mutually exclusive. Marchand once described Mrs Pynchon as "a strange combination of being very imposing and down-to-earth". She won four Emmy awards for the role, each of which acted as a leg of a coffee table in her home.

More recently, however, Marchand managed to obliterate this perception of herself as a patrician woman by brilliantly playing Livia Soprano, the monstrous, whin ing, half-senile, domineering mother of mob boss Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini) in the Home Box Office series, The Sopranos. She never forgives her son for putting her into a nursing home, and becomes the cause of much of his guilt. "I think Livia is the first role I've ever had where the makeup crew tries to make me look bad," March-and commented. "I may be getting older, but I don't look quite that decrepit."

In fact, Marchand started off a long way from the well-groomed, tasteful ladies with which she became associated on the small screen. She was in at the exciting beginnings of TV drama in America, her most famous role being Clara, the lonely, plain young school- mistress in the original 1953 live broadcast of Paddy Chay- evsky's Marty, opposite Rod Steiger in the title role.

"I got the role of Clara because I wasn't cutesy," Marchant explained. "I never have been - and I had a bony face." The actress was a close friend of Chayevsky's, appearing in several of his television plays, including The Catered Affair and The Bachelor Party, making her feature debut in the film version of the latter.

But, despite the wider recognition of television, Marchand had a long, varied and distinguished stage career. After studying at the Actor's Studio - with the likes of Paul Newman, Joanne Woodward and John Cassavetes - she made her New York debut as the Tavern Hostess in The Taming Of The Shrew in 1951, going on to play many larger Shakespearean roles, including Nerissa, in The Merchant Of Venice, the Nurse, in Romeo And Juliet, and the Princess of France, in Love's Labours Lost. It was while acting in Shakespeare and Shaw at the Brattle theatre, in Cambridge, Massachusetts, that she met and married Paul Sparer, with whom she acted, on and off, until his death last November.

In 1960, she won an Obie award for the role of the Madame of the kinky brothel in Jean Genet's The Balcony. It was then back to the classics at the American Shakespeare festival at Stratford, Connecticut, and the Lincoln Centre repertory theatre, where she was splendidly regal as Queen Elizabeth in Schiller's Mary Stuart.

In 1980, commuting between Lou Grant in California and New York, Marchand triumphed on Broadway in a revival of Paul Osborn's back-porch family comedy, Mornings At Seven, as the youngest, and most homely, of four sisters. Among her best film roles were Mrs Burrage, in James Ivory's The Bostonians (1984), the Los Angeles mayor, in The Naked Gun (1988), and as a crusty, snobbish dowager waking up audiences in the soporific Sabrina (1995) - somehow managing to combine elements of Mrs Pynchon and Livia Soprano.

In real life, Marchand, who is survived by two daughters and a son, was very different from the strong-willed characters she played.

"I'm always very uncomfortable with people," she once admitted. "It's something that I get upset with myself for, but that's the way I am. But I love people. And when I'm on the stage, I can embrace people and still feel safe. There are a lot of different facets to my personality that I don't use all the time in my house, or in everyday life, that I can experience and share when I'm on a stage."

 Nancy Marchand, actress, born June 19 1928; died June 18 2000

fields.headline: Nikolaos Oikonomides
fields.trailText: Nikolaos Oikonomides, who has died aged 66, was professor of Byzantine history at Athens University, director of the Institute for Byzantine Research, and a scholar who epitomised studies of Byzantium, that empire built around the city of Constantinople (now Istanbul), which lasted for more than a millennium.
fields.body:
Nikolaos Oikonomides, who has died aged 66, was professor of Byzantine history at Athens University, director of the Institute for Byzantine Research, and a scholar who epitomised studies of Byzantium, that empire built around the city of Constantinople (now Istanbul), which lasted for more than a millennium.

Articles on the donation of castles, or the workings of the imperial chancellery in Trebizond, may sound dry. But in Oikonomides's hands, that medieval world - especially the activity of tax collectors, administrators and pen-pushers - was brought to life. His edition of the complex lists used to seat guests at Byzantine imperial banquets - according to a hierarchy of rank which we still call "placement" - sheds a completely new light on the administrative structures of a top-heavy bureaucracy.

Oikonomides extended his great skill in the study of manuscripts to the deciphering of the lead seals given to imperial officials. These were often worn, and had been coarsely struck in the first place, but through his work they revealed the functions of the kommerkiarioi (customs and excise officers). Appointed by Harvard University to organise their collection of seals at Dumbarton Oaks, Washington, he also established the periodical Studies In Byzantine Sigillography, devoted to these unlovely objects.

Oikonomides took his first degree at the University of Athens from 1951 to 1956, under Dionysios Zakythinos. In 1958, he went to Paris, joining Paul Lemerle's team of researchers, who were editing the vast archives of the Mount Athos monasteries. His doctorate analysed the four surviving versions of banquet seating, and was published as Les Listes De Préséance Byzantines (1972).

His opposition to the dictatorship of the Greek colonels, who seized power in 1967, forced him into exile in Canada, where, in 1969, he took up the chair of Byzantine history at Montreal University. There he remained until 1989, a Greek in the major Francophone city of the Anglo-Saxon world. He also held visiting posts in Paris, Harvard and Toronto. In 1987, he returned to Athens, and the chair of Byzantine history

The seven volumes of Mount Athos records he edited from 1968 to 1995 demonstrate the debt medievalists owe to Oikonomides. Sorting through thousands of sales, donations and quarrels over property, he began to judge the level of literacy of individual witnesses, as well as calculating the most complex numbers, all recorded in alphabetic figures.

Most recently, he constructed a new theory of Byzantine fiscality from the few surviving tax documents. In this way, he played a key role in making available for the world, through elegant French translations, the immensely rich archives of the Holy Mountain, home to Orthodoxy for more than a millennium.

Oikonomides had a marvellous sense of humour, and was at home in this polyglot world. He enlivened conferences with his witty lectures, whether in the Soviet Union, the Balkans or further east. He rose to become secretary of the International Association of Byzantine Studies. From May 1997, he was vice-president of the Hellenic Foundation of Culture. On his last visit to London, in February, Nikos gave the ninth Runciman lecture, at King's College London, on new discoveries in the mon- astic library at Patmos.

He is survived by his wife, the outstanding Ottomanist, Professor Elizabeth Zachariadou, and two daughters.

 Nikolaos Oikonomides, Byzantine scholar, born 1934; died May 31 2000

fields.headline: Harold Johnson
fields.trailText: In 1961, Harold "Johnnie" Johnson, who has died aged 86, became a director of research at the Central Electricity Generating Board. During the next 16 years, the centre developed an international reputation for power industry research and development.
fields.body:
I n 1961, Harold "Johnnie" Johnson, who has died aged 86, became a director of research at the Central Electricity Generating Board. At a brownfield site, next to the Marchwood power station on Southampton Water, he brought together major projects in the Marchwood Engineering Laboratories. During the next 16 years, the centre developed an international reputation for power industry research and development.

Many projects he initiated are still bearing fruit, others are today's standard engineering installations. Many of the techniques, design codes, instrumentation and machines developed at Marchwood - for welding, nuclear reactor inspection, turbines and other plant - have prolonged the life of Britain's conventional and nuclear power stations, while the large, low-speed wind tunnel, built to study power station emissions, has found customers as far afield as Hong Kong.

Born in Enfield, Middlesex, Johnnie took a science degree at London's Northern Polytechnic, while working for the BBC. In 1934, he moved to EMI at Brimsdown, Enfield, to work on the development of the television tube. In 1936, the EMI system was chosen by the BBC for its - and the world's - first public television broadcasts.

Meanwhile, electronic engineering efforts were switching towards the first radar early warning systems, with secret "chain home" stations being built along Britain's east coast. By 1938, the radar pioneer Robert Watson-Watt had recruited Johnnie into the research station at Bawdsey Manor, near Felixstowe, to work on the new system.

Johnnie had to advance his wedding from September 9 to September 2 1939, when the research station was air-lifted to Dundee. He and his wife, Kathleen, spent their honeymoon at Stenigot, on the Lincolnshire wold; he had a radar station to run there too. Eight months later, the headquarters became the Telecommunications Research Establishment, initially based near Swanage, and later in Malvern.

In the 1950s, Johnnie joined Vickers-Armstrong, becoming commercial manager of its guided missile division. That experience led to a senior appointment in 1957 with the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority, whose Risley group, under Sir Christopher (later Lord) Hinton, designed the Magnox series of reactors. As deputy director (overseas), Johnnie was responsible for the Magnox nuclear power stations at Tokai Murai, in Japan, and Latina, in Italy, the only British nuclear power plants that were ever exported.

In 1958, Hinton became chairman of the new CEGB, and boosted power industry research 10-fold, for which he brought across Johnnie, initially as a deputy director of research, then, in 1961, as a director.

In retirement, Johnnie worked as a consultant for, among others, the British National Oil Corporation. But most of his attention was focused on the Swanage Sailing Club, of which he was commodore from 1973 to 1977. He was known throughout the power industry for his work for the Electrical and Electronics Industries Benevolent Association.

Kind, humorous and astute, Johnnie had the capacity to think about people, as well as things. He leaves his wife and two daughters, Jenny and Billie.

fields.headline: Livingstone proposes £80 bus lane fines
fields.standfirst: Livingstone's London: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone yesterday kicked off his first London mayoral cabinet meeting with a proposal to introduce a flat-rate £80 fine for all motorists using bus lanes.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone yesterday kicked off his first London mayoral cabinet meeting with a proposal to introduce a flat-rate £80 fine for all motorists using bus lanes - a 300% increase in some areas - and close at least one major road to mark European car-free day in September.

The bus lane fine increase, which will have to be agreed with government and the London boroughs, won support from Labour, Liberal Democrat and Green advisory cabinet members, including former Labour minister and former mayoral rival Glenda Jackson, now Mr Livingstone's new adviser on homelessness. The mayor said: "You cannot improve the quality of transport in London without improving the bus lanes - that needs to be done by helping the majority of people instead of pandering to the few who clog up the lanes to go into a shop to buy cigarettes."

The road closure proposal was put forward by Darren Johnson, the environment adviser and former Green candidate, who said it would give a "sense of what the future could be like without car congestion". The mayor, who will not take over his formal responsibilities until next month, made clear he wanted to "steal" the idea of his defeated Conservative rival Steven Norris to run the Underground through the night, at least on Fridays and Saturdays.

He reported that he was close to agreement with the government on priorities for new investment in transport.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: With only a day to go before polls open for the Tottenham byelection, the parties involved are competing to claim the legacy of Bernie Grant, the crusading MP whose death last month set off the contest. Labour's candidate, David Lammy, is expected to win the seat, but members of Grant's family are unhappy about the way it has been drawn into the campaign.
fields.body:
With only a day to go before polls open for the Tottenham byelection, the parties involved are competing to claim the legacy of Bernie Grant, the crusading MP whose death last month set off the contest. Labour's candidate, David Lammy, is expected to win the seat, but members of Grant's family are unhappy about the way it has been drawn into the campaign. "Voters should not be told that all the Grant family are backing Lammy. It's not true," says Rosamund Grant, Bernie's sister. "No one should believe that the whole of the Grant family is supporting the Lammy campaign, that's not a fact." Instead, Rosamund advises voters to make up their own minds based on the parties' policies. "The sort of things that Bernie started in Tottenham that should be carried on locally," said Rosamund. "People should be voting on the policies and principles that Bernie stood for, as opposed to the family. We are not important in this." The election also comes as a poignant reminder for the family. "It's a painful time for the family - having the election brings it home to you," she said. "If Bernie was alive we'd be campaigning for him now."

On the other hand, tact does not appear to be the Labour party's strongest point at the moment, as a glance through the latest issue of the party's Women's News newsletter to activists makes clear. Under "Checklists to win women's votes", it advises: "When discussing the economy, women talk about the money they need to support their families, while men are more likely to talk about inflation rates." "Avoid terms like GDP and PSBR," it goes on. "Stick to terms like money and prices." Why not just stick to talking about knitting patterns? And people wonder why Tony Blair went down like a lead turkey at the Women's Institute.

There's a bit of panic in Oxbridge over elitism charges in the wake of the Laura Spence case. Dr Mark Hennings, senior tutor at Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge, sent this memo to his colleagues: "I have been asked to compile, as quickly as possible, a list of all Fellows' links with state schools, in case we need it." And if the list is expanded to include college porters and servants, they might even get a half-decent showing.

And now a message from Angela Wilkins, parliamentary campaigns officer for the Labour party. "Help," writes Angela in a memo sent to MPs yesterday. "The giant mock-up of a TV that was used for the photo-shoot on 'free TV licences for pensioners' has gone missing." Oh no. "Does anyone know where it is, and if so can we have it back please?" More importantly, how do you lose a giant TV in the first place?

Yesterday's interview between John Kampfner and Robin Cook on the Today programme harked back to a gentler age of political discourse (sample question: "Foreign secretary, is there anything you'd like to tell the nation?"). But two questions spring to mind. Is anyone in the BBC news hierarchy actually aware that Kampervan wrote a fawning biography of Cook with the subject's cooperation? And was a medical officer on hand in case John got his tongue lodged in the obvious place?

The phone rings and, cor blimey, it's Leo McKinstry of the Daily Mail, one of the form runners in the Diary's "non sequitur of the year" award after blaming the Guardian's Society section for causing child abuse and domestic violence. "Hello, Leo McKooky here!" he trills, trying to plug his new biography of Geoffrey Boycott. Leo, there's no place in this column for that sort of tawdry log-rolling (Boycs, 350pp, £16.99, "A fascinating book" - the Daily Mail).

We all know that the United States' economy dominates the rest of the world - but would you believe that the head of research at the World Bank is Mr Dollar?

webTitle: Austria defiant in battle over savings tax

fields.headline: Austria defiant in battle over savings tax
fields.standfirst:
Sanctions: Vienna shows its potential for disruption

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night claimed victory for Britain as EU leaders reached agreement in their long-running battle over a witholding tax on savings. But they left final implementation years distant and still hostage to an Austrian government pressing hard for sanctions to be lifted.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Santa Maria da Feira
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night claimed victory for Britain as EU leaders reached agreement in their long-running battle over a witholding tax on savings. But they left final implementation years distant and still hostage to an Austrian government pressing hard for sanctions to be lifted.

In a cliff-hanging meeting that overran the scheduled end of the Portuguese summit, 14 of the 15 member states pledged to exchange information on the savings of non-residents, and accepted that Vienna would not sign up now.

The aim is to end tax evasion by investors who lodge their savings in other EU member states on the assumption that the tax liability will not be spotted. Under the complex deal, which has taken two years to negotiate, governments may levy a 20% withholding tax on the interest Europeans earn on savings abroad until the information exchange can be formalised with other nations such as the US and Switzerland - itself no easy task.

Britain, long isolated over the issue because of its insistence that a tax would damage the City of London, successfully turned it into one of banking secrecy. "This is a personal triumph for Gordon Brown," declared Mr Blair. "British interests have been protected," said a delighted Mr Brown. "We said we would not compromise and we have not compromised."

Mr Blair said he hoped the achievement had "finally broken the mindset that every European summit is about Britain versus the rest".

EU leaders sought to present the agreement as a victory for all. "It is not possible to have a credible Europe with a single market and a single currency but to do absolutely nothing on taxation," said the Portuguese prime minister and summit host, Antonio Guterres. Several very serious hurdles still have to be overcome: an EU directive has to be unanimously agreed by finance ministers by the end of 2002, which is highly unlikely if Vienna is not back in the fold by then. Austria's 14 partners imposed an unprecedented diplomatic quarantine last February after the far right Freedom party, then led by the controversial Jorg Haider, joined the coalition government. Chancellor Wolfgang Schussel won recognition of a constitutional bar to surrendering banking secrecy, but it seems clear that that barrier would be removed when sanctions are lifted. On sanctions, he said: "I hope for a solution but my hope is not unlimited."

Mr Guterres denied that there was an explicit link between the last-minute compromise and the sanctions question, but he made clear that action was imminent. "There will be an intiative from the Portuguese government and as soon as I have consensus from the 14 member countries it will be made made public," he said.

Austria's stance showed its potential to disrupt EU business if the sanctions stay in effect, with serious worries about a crowded timetable for badly needed institutional reform and enlargement to the east.

fields.headline: The swing's the thing
fields.standfirst: Predicting the result of the next general election is a hazardous business. It's not enough to extrapolate from the national opinion polls
fields.trailText: Predicting the result of the next general election is a hazardous business. It's not enough to extrapolate from the national opinion polls
fields.body:
The three-point Labour lead reported by Mori in its recent poll sent shock waves through the political community. All of a sudden, the next election looks like a contest rather than a walkover. But has there not been an over-reaction? Our old friend the "swingometer" suggests a three-point lead should deliver an overall Labour majority of 60 - easily enough to give the party its coveted second full term in office. Tony Blair might have lost his large poll lead, but apparently he only needs a small one anyway.

The swingometer relies, though, on one assumption - that the whole country moves in the same direction and by the same amount. However, the results of last month's local elections suggest the Tory recovery and Labour's decline are not happening at the same rate across the whole country. And the bad news for Labour is that the variation is working to its disadvantage. Indeed in the general election a three-point lead is unlikely to be enough for a second full Labour term.

The first past the post electoral system was uncommonly harsh on the Tories in the last election. Bad though it seems, their performance was not as bad as Labour's in 1983. John Major still managed 31%; Michael Foot emerged with just 28%. But when it came to seats, Major was far worse off - just 165 to Foot's 209.

There are two reasons for this. First, Tory support fell more where the party was strongest (the opposite of what happened to Labour in 1983). Second, Labour and Liberal Democrat voters were willing to switch tactically to whichever opposition party was best capable of defeating the local Tory. As a result, the Tories lost 43 more seats than the swingometer would have predicted.

If Labour is to win the next election on a small lead, these two patterns need to remain in place. And the result in the Romsey byelection last month has led many to speculate that this is precisely what will happen.

But in truth Romsey seems to be atypical. In the council elections across England, anti-Tory tactical voting was on the decline. The rise in the Lib Dem vote (and the fall in Labour's) was above average in wards Labour was defending against the Tories. Labour's vote fell by less than the average - and the Lib Dems also lost ground - only where the Tories and the Lib Dems shared the top two places.

At the same time, the Tories gained ground most where they could profit - that is to say, where they started off first or second. William Hague's recent tactics have been criticised because they appear designed simply to appeal to his party's traditional heartlands. But reconnecting with the Tory party's heartlands was one of the major tasks Major bequeathed him. The impact of these two patterns on Labour's local election performance was dramatic. Labour lost up to twice as many seats as it would have done if the swingometer had been working. And the effect could be equally dramatic in a general election.

Bearing in mind that Labour never does very well in local elections, last month's results suggested Labour might have a two- to three-point lead if a general election were called now - very similar to the figure recently produced by Mori. As the chart shows, if this happened and the swingometer worked, Labour would still have an overall majority of 55. But if the variation found in the local elections were repeated, such a lead would leave Labour nine short of a majority - and dependent on the support of the Lib Dems to remain in office in some sort of coalition. In short, a small lead would not be enough to give a secure second term.

But why should we take any notice of the local elections? After all, there was yet another record low turnout, whereas in the parliamentary by-election in Romsey more than half the electorate voted. There is one simple reason. The two patterns that led to the Tory disaster of 1997 were apparent in every round of local elections between 1993 and 1996. Little noticed by commentators at the time, those local elections were the writing on the wall for the Tories. It would be unwise to ignore the message this time too.

Not that a repeat of the local election pattern is inevitable. How much tactical switching there is between Labour and the Lib Dems will depend in part at least on how much difference voters think there is between the two parties. And their perceptions on that score will in turn depend on the signals Labour and the Lib Dems send them.

At the moment relations between Labour and the Lib Dems seem to have been put on hold, while Labour decides what to do about its pledge to hold a referendum on proportional representation for the House of Commons. If Tony Blair were to reaffirm the pledge, relations might warm up once again. If he decided to scrap the referendum, cooperation would probably die.

So Labour faces a paradox. First past the post would still deliver a second term even if the party only has a narrow victory. But that will only happen if Labour continues to benefit from tactical switching. Yet for that to occur the party is probably going to have to keep its referendum pledge. But then, after all, the alternative may simply be to find itself after the election forced to keep its pledge as a minority Labour government sought Charles Kennedy's help to stay in office.

John Curtice is professor of politics at Strathclyde University. "Lessons from the local elections: how first past the post could fail to deliver a second Labour term" is available from Make Votes Count, 0207 928 2076

J.Curtice@strath.ac.uk

webTitle: Honest drivers spare sterling crisis biker's blushes

fields.headline: Honest drivers spare sterling crisis biker's blushes
fields.trailText: Doubts about the modern English character were eased yesterday by the honest folk of Lancashire, who turned down a chance to pocket thousands of lost pounds.
fields.body:
Doubts about the modern English character were eased yesterday by the honest folk of Lancashire, who turned down a chance to pocket thousands of lost pounds.

Notes from a £10,000 wad in a motorbike courier's unzipped haversack led to dozens of cars pulling on to the hard shoulder of the M65 near Accrington to harvest the money from the embankment.

Police were called during the evening rush hour after mobile phone calls from drivers about "people wandering about" between two junctions on the motorway north of Manchester.

Lancashire police said money had started to pour from the bag, unknown to the dispatch rider, between Accrington and Blackburn.

"There was a serious side because people were actually retrieving money from the third, outside lane, and no pedestrian should ever go on to a motorway, come what may," a spokeswoman said.

"But the marvellous - and to be honest, astonishing - thing was that every single note was handed back."

The courier is not being named, but police said he had been checked out and the delivery was "legitimate if an odd way to carry money around".

The bike was flashed to a halt by another motorist and drove back to the note-littered stretch, where drivers were waiting to refill his bag.

The police spokeswoman said: "It's very reassuring to have proof that people are basically honest" - a notion that was borne out by a Reader's Digest survey four years ago in which 80 wallets containing £30 each were deliberately left in British town centres. More than two-thirds of the wallets were returned unplundered, with Scotland managing 80%.

fields.headline: Armed robber stabbed to death
fields.standfirst: Shotgun gang flee after village postmaster fights off raider
fields.trailText: A postmaster fought off a robber armed with a sawn-off shotgun yesterday, stabbing him to death and forcing the gang of three robbers to flee empty handed.
fields.body:
A postmaster fought off a robber armed with a sawn-off shotgun yesterday, stabbing him to death and forcing the gang of three robbers to flee empty handed.

The man who died was one of three men with sawn-off shotguns who tried to steal thousands of pounds in cash from the post office in the village of Wolverley, near Kidderminster, Worcestershire.

He was later found dying 10 miles away in the parked getaway car with several stab wounds to his upper body.

The gang arrived at the post office in a blue Ford Sierra at about 10am yesterday. One of the men walked into the shop and threatened Richard Watkins, 50, with a single-barrelled shotgun.

Mr Watkins was alone behind the counter in the family-run store when the man burst in and demanded cash. The robber, who has not been named, struggled with Mr Watkins, during which he hit the postmaster on the head with the butt of his gun.

Mr Watkins, who is 6ft 4in tall and of stocky build, was able to snatch the shotgun from the robber in the struggle and grab a knife used for cutting open newspaper bundles.

Police said the robber was stabbed several times on the upper part of his body.

When their accomplice failed to appear, one of the two remaining gang members went into the post office and helped the injured man escape, lifting him into the back of the car and driving away empty handed, leaving the shotgun in the post office. Mr Watkins, who suffered a gash to his head that needed three stitches, immediately called the police.

An hour later, West Mercia police received an anonymous 999 call from a telephone box telling them where to find the getaway car.

Officers found the seriously injured robber in the vehicle in Forge Lane, in Wallheath, where attempts were made to resuscitate him but he was dead on arrival at Russell's Hall hospital, Stonebridge.

Assistant chief constable Peter Neyroud would not say if the gun had been fired but confirmed that the robbers left the scene empty handed.

Police appealed for witnesses who might have seen the gang, their blue getaway car or anyone with any information about a black BMW 520i, registration J537 WDA - seen leaving the scene where the blue car was abandoned - to get in contact.

West Mercia and West Midlands officers are considering a possible link with a robbery in Halesowen on Monday night in which three masked raiders, armed with a shotgun and a chisel, terrorised store staff and stole £342.

Mr Watkins, who is unmarried and has lived with his sister and elderly mother in the village for many years, was described by police as "an extremely well respected and well known member of the community".

Last night he was recovering at his brother's home while a police forensic team examined the scene.

His sister Sue, who helps run the post office, said: "Fortunately there weren't any customers in the post office at the time.

"They thought Richard was just going to hand over the money but they picked the wrong man."
