fields.headline: £5m inquiry into 'Robocop' ends in fiasco
fields.standfirst: Police chief delighted but remains suspended
fields.trailText: A huge and costly corruption inquiry into "Robocop" Superintendent Ray Mallon, the pioneer of zero tolerance policing in Britain, ended in fiasco last night with the announcement that the man feted by Labour and Conservative leaders will not face criminal charges.
fields.body:
A huge and costly corruption inquiry into "Robocop" Superintendent Ray Mallon, the pioneer of zero tolerance policing in Britain, ended in fiasco last night with the announcement that the man feted by Labour and Conservative leaders will not face criminal charges.

There were immediate calls for a public inquiry into the alleged waste of up to £5m on an investigation said by critics to be motivated by petty jealousies, which has seen the former scourge of burglars and violent criminals suspended for 2 years.

Labour MP Ashok Kumar, whose Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland constituency saw a big fall in crime, said: "There have been catastrophic errors in this persecution of a fine police officer."

He demanded Mr Mallon's immediate reinstatement and an audit of the Operation Lancet investigation, which has been dogged by delays and bungles.

Seven other detectives in the "Robocop" squad are also understood to have been cleared of using criminal means, including heroin dealing, to get information from the Teesside underworld.

But the chief constable of Cleveland, Barry Shaw, said that Mr Mallon and other officers would remain suspended while internal disciplinary proceedings were discussed with the area's police authority.

Mr Mallon, whose Middlesbrough police station was used by Tony Blair for Labour's final election photocall, was celebrating privately last night with his wife Carole, 45, and daughters Victoria, 18, and 15-year-old Lois.

He said: "I am naturally delighted that at last my name has been cleared though I do not believe I should ever have been suspended in the first place.

"I want to thank my family and the people of Teesside for their support over the past 2 years which has been of great help."

His hard-edged drive against all petty crime and anti-social behaviour, drawn from zero tolerance schemes in the United States, has been a powerful influence on changes introduced by the home secretary, Jack Straw.

In particular, Mr Straw's insistence in 1998 on crime reduction as a police performance indicator stemmed directly from his pre-election visit to Middlesbrough.

Mr Mallon had promised to cut crime by 20% in 18 months, a target he reached in half the time.

But the officer's high profile caused resentment at key levels in the Cleveland force which - his supporters say - triggered Operation Lancet. He was allegedly seen as a glory hunter and there was resentment at his view that better brains were more important to the police than extra resources and manpower.

Mr Mallon was suspended on December 1, 1997, seven months after posing with Mr Blair, his wife Cherie and the actress Helen Mirren, a Labour supporter.

Cleveland's assistant chief constable, Robert Turnbull, said that the superintendent and seven CID colleagues were accused of "alleged activity that could be construed as criminal".

Forty frontline officers were initially drafted into the inquiry which was eventually to enlist supervisors from four other police forces.

It centred on claims that the Robocop drive was as ruthless with legal niceties as it was with criminals - a vulnerable area given the inevitable wiles of detectives trying to tease information from hardened offenders.

The allegations, primarily of heroin-for-grassing deals, were based on evidence from convicted criminals which also fingered an astonishing 600 other officers, all of whom were given formal notice that they could face investigation.

Mr Mallon has always vigorously denied any wrongdoing and last year challenged Operation Lancet's managers to "put up or shut up" as their hunt for evidence began to appear increasingly futile.

He has been backed throughout by outraged public opinion in Cleveland and police colleagues, with 30,000 people signing a reinstatement petition within months and BBC Radio Cleveland listeners voting him Man of the Year, beating Mr Blair. The Cleveland branch of the Superintendents' Association also called early on for a public inquiry.

The inquiry bill will be met by council taxpayers in Cleveland, with Operation Lancet already been blamed for a 30% rise in the police precept.

And crime rates have risen to pre-Mallon levels.

Timetable

1996 Mallon appointed to Middlesbrough, Cleveland's crime hotspot. Zero tolerance wins attention. Crime falls 20% in nine months

October 1997 Two Middlesbrough detectives suspended over alleged trade of heroin for information on crime

December 1997 Mallon suspended for alleged failure to act on heroin allegations

March 1998 Five more detectives suspended, 58 under investigation

June 2000 crown prosecution service rejects all allegations of criminal behaviour by Mallon

webTitle: Guru of US right advises Hague

fields.headline: Guru of US right advises Hague
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: An American welfare guru, who is today advising William Hague on social policy, is a critic of homosexuality and unmarried motherhood and has described the poor as "the perpetrators of illegitimacy and abandonment, of family non-formation and malformation".
fields.body:
An American welfare guru, who is today advising William Hague on social policy, is a critic of homosexuality and unmarried motherhood and has described the poor as "the perpetrators of illegitimacy and abandonment, of family non-formation and malformation".

The Conservative leader is keen to take on board welfare theories promoted by Marvin Olasky, the Christian guru whose ideas influenced Republican presidential candidate George W Bush.

Among the ideas influencing Mr Hague are moves to shift help for the poor away from state welfare and towards local faith-based organisations which the Tory leader argues can better help people "tackle problems in their own way".

Professor Olasky has come under fire in the US for some of his proposals, amid claims that his view of the poor is a rightwing caricature of irresponsible teenage mothers, able-bodied but workshy men and drunks and addicts unwilling to tackle addiction.

In a 1995 interview, he said the poor in the US were the "victims and perpetrators" of illegitimacy, "alienation and loneliness; but they are not suffering from thirst, hunger or nakedness, except by choice, or insanity or parental abuse".

Policies put forward by Prof Olasky include supporting welfare programmes which help the "respectable poor", or bring those in need back to a fold defined in Christian terms.

Government-run assistance is counter-productive, he argues, because only charity that is directly personal, requires the able bodied to work and includes explicit spiritual counselling can succeed.

The visit is certain to lead to accusations that Mr Hague is searching for inspiration from the US religious right.

The Conservative leader will argue he does not want to create a religious right, but believes the meeting will permit him to look at social problems in a new way.

fields.headline: Sound move for orchestra
fields.trailText: The Barbican concert hall in London will close for four months next year, in a £6m attempt to solve the problems of its acoustic.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The Barbican concert hall in London will close for four months next year, in a £6m attempt to solve the problems of its acoustic.

The hall's uneven acoustic, which makes it hard for musicians and conductors to hear one another, has been bitterly criticised since the Barbican arts complex opened in 1982. A previous attempt, six years ago, which cost £500,000, improved but did not solve the problem.

The promised dramatic improvement in the acoustic will be a birthday present to the BBC Symphony Orchestra, which announced yesterday that it is celebrating its 70th anniversary by leaving the Royal Festival Hall to become orchestra in residence at the Barbican, along with the London Symphony Orchestra.

The Festival Hall has an equally notorious acoustic, and has just announced a project to tackle the problem as part of a £50m refurbishment.

The move is a big one for the orchestra which has given concerts at the Festival Hall since it opened for the Festival of Britain half a century ago.

Paul Hughes, the orchestra manager, said: "The chance of an improved acoustic is not the reason we have come, but it is another layer of cream on top of an already rather nice cake."

Off the record, the musicians are jubilant: they believe they have been taken for granted at the Festival Hall, where they say conditions back stage are primitive and uncomfortable.

fields.headline: Protect life - by whatever means
fields.trailText: When hundreds of Scottish children went to school yesterday morning they were met at the gates by adults handing out reading material. It was not, however, the sort of literature most parents would be happy to have their kids peruse over playtime snacks.
fields.body:
When hundreds of Scottish children went to school yesterday morning they were met at the gates by adults handing out reading material. It was not, however, the sort of literature most parents would be happy to have their kids peruse over playtime snacks.

The cover appeared innocuous enough: a cosy infantile rendition of a house with an over-large sun shining down from above, mummy and toddler stand guard in the foreground. Only the "why is abortion wrong?" title, in faux crayon, hints at what is to come.

Turn the page and the cartoons continue, but the language becomes altogether more adult. There's the passage on how terminations are performed, which describes the woman's cervix being dilated before "the child is cut to pieces with the curette knife". Or, if the pupil's stomach is strong enough to read on, they can be told that in an evacuation "the baby is manually crushed so he can fit through the cervix... a pliers-like instrument is used to crush the skull, legs and arms".

Distributing 50,000 of these leaflets to Scottish schoolchildren is the latest US-style tactic employed by the militant anti-abortion group Precious Life. The graphic confrontation of their message is nothing new - when they first formed in Scotland last autumn they managed to put off clients of an Edinburgh Brook centre to such an extent that it had to close for the day - but this is the first time Precious Life has taken its propaganda to the school gate.

And there is more to come. Now it has laid its foundations in Scotland - the first, serious, militant anti-abortion group on the British mainland - the group plans to travel south. A branch in Liverpool is just about established; on Saturday leaders of the Scottish HQ are off to London to meet activists there. It will be, according to Jim Dowson, the group's de facto leader, the start of a militant, UK-wide campaign.

Dowson has a long association with militancy. There's his defining trio of anti-Catholicism, loyalism and Orangeism - even the grand secretary of the Orange Lodge of Scotland, which has entirely dissociated itself from him, says he is a "zealot". He talks in the fiery vocabulary of a fanatic - abortion is akin to the holocaust, family planning officials are officers of the Gestapo.

Already Dowson's group, which he claims numbers 1200, regularly pickets family planning centres. Mostly male, middle-aged men, they stand in lines chanting slogans and bearing placards featuring aborted foetuses. The tactics yield an ironic result. "We find the numbers visiting our centres go up when these people protest; all the noisy chanting lets people know where we are," says Juliet Hillier of Brook.

The next logical step in Precious Life's campaign would be to picket clinics where terminations are performed, harassing doctors in the style so common in the United States. The problem is that abortion clinics don't really exist in Britain in the way they do in the US. "He would have to stand outside gynaecology wards in mainstream hospitals, which even to him must seem a bit futile," says Ann Marie McKay, director of the Family Planning Association Scotland.

But Dowson says he is prepared to do that, and he has other, more direct, plans. He has vowed to post on the internet the names and addresses of doctors who perform terminations; picketing the houses of surgeons, nurses and councillors will follow.

If you are involved in an industry where you are killing human beings you should be quite open about it. If doctors are not ashamed of what they do they shouldn't be worried about people confronting them," he says. Dowson has made such threats before. Shortly before Christmas, he announced he planned to step up his campaign, targeting pro-choice politicians and family-planning workers. Many senior figures admitted to being intimidated. "He is not prepared to allow anyone else to have their opinion," says McKay.

Those who know Dowson say his current foes have cause for concern. Perhaps that is why Scottish health minister Susan Deacon has come down hard on him. She warned militant anti-abortion groups to "back off" or face legal action. Until yesterday, the government's combative stand appeared to be working. Aside from bi-weekly picketing of the pregnancy advisory clinics, the group was largely quiet. Then came the leafleting campaign mounted by 46 volunteers in Glasgow, Lanarkshire and Stirling. Edinburgh is to get its turn today.

The impetus for the action is a Family Planning Association leaflet entitled "Abortion just so you know". Dowson claims it has been distributed to every school in Scotland. It has not: the pamphlet is for sale to teachers who want to include it in their sex education curriculum. "The pamphlet reduces the moral fabric of our society by enticing children into believing that abortion is nothing," he says. "We have a right to make sure they get the true facts."

So yesterday morning and afternoon, and again today, secondary school pupils, regardless of age or sex, were given the leaflets. Teachers provided the first reaction. "Parents and teachers would agree that their youngsters should be able to go to school without being accosted by pressure groups. This is wholly inappropriate conduct," said Ronnie Smith, general secretary of the EIS, Scotland's biggest teaching union.

"The young people they are approaching could be vulnerable, they could have had an abortion. That may be of no concern to them, but I find the prospect deeply worrying," says McKay.

But no matter what the criticism, Dowson plans to expand his activities in a militant campaign. He is now the public face of Precious Life and is unashamed of his extremism. "Gassing Jews in the 30s and 40s was legal, that doesn't mean it was right. We have to protect our children, by whatever means," he says.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Co-op acts on E coli outbreak
fields.body:
Co-op acts on E coli outbreak

A Co-op delicatessen is re-calling food after five confirmed cases of E coli poisoning and four more probable cases.

Three of the nine are in hospital in Greater Manchester. No source of infection has been identified, but the five adults and four children ate food bought from the Co-op Superstore in Hazel Grove.

Pigeon bait to poison falcons

Pigeons doused with poison and tethered to stakes have been found in what is thought to have been an attempt to kill peregrine falcons. Police yesterday launched an investigation into a case in Conwy valley, north Wales. The RSPB said it appeared disgruntled pigeon fanciers were waging a campaign against the falcons in the mistaken belief they were responsible for high death rate among racing pigeons.

Royal copyright row resolved

The copyright of the photographs of Prince William taken to mark his 18th birthday now lies with the prince, St James's Palace announced yesterday.

A row erupted two weeks ago over who owned the copyright of the pictures, taken by Daily Telegraph royal photographer Ian Jones, which led to the resignation of the Prince of Wales's press secretary.

Ben Nevis sold to trust

Britain's highest mountain was yesterday handed over to one of the country's leading conservation charities.

Duncan Fairfax-Lucy, whose family has owned the Ben Nevis estate for 170 years, sold it to the John Muir Trust for £450,000.

webTitle: MPs press ministers to restore pension link

fields.headline: MPs press ministers to restore pension link
fields.standfirst: Committee throws cold water on welfare campaigner Field's ideas
fields.trailText: An influential group of MPs will today call on the government to consider restoring the link between the basic state pension and average earnings.
fields.body:
An influential group of MPs will today call on the government to consider restoring the link between the basic state pension and average earnings.

The Labour dominated social security select committee says the move could pave the way for reform of the pensions system. At the same time the committee delivered a blow to former social security minister, Frank Field - a thorn in the side of the government since his sacking two years ago - by concluding that his plans for pensions reform would require employee national insurance contributions to be more than doubled. The estimate was made for the committee by the deputy actuary, the government's pensions number cruncher.

In a report to be published today the committee accepts that the national insurance fund is about to go into a permanent and large surplus as a result of benefits being linked to prices, and contribution income, based on earnings, rising at a faster rate.

It concludes that some of this surplus, combined with a modest increase in NI contributions, could lead to a restoration of the link between pensions and earnings. NI contribution rates for employers and employees would need to go up 3.2% by 2021, it says.

Such a move would delight campaigners for pensioners, including Labour stalwarts Lady Castle and Jack Jones of the National Pensioners' Convention who have argued that linking pensions to prices - particularly with low inflation - has seen the value of basic pensions fall as society has got richer.

The government has maintained that policies it has introduced, including the minimum income guarantee, will have seen it spend more on pensions than if it had restored the link with earnings in this parliament. The elderly received only a 75p increase in their state pension this year.

But the government will be comforted by the committee's attack on Mr Field's proposals.

In commissioned research on the proposals, the deputy actuary Andrew Young concluded the scheme would require national insurance rates to rise by between 9 -12%.

The committee said: "These contribution rates were in addition to national insurance contribution rates which would still be needed to fund the basic pension. Thus, an employee's total contributions would rise from the current 10% to 19-22% depending on the return from the investment."

fields.headline: EU 'to recognise Palestine'
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Palestinians expect France to lead the European Union in recognising a Palestinian state, even if it is formed by unilateral declaration, a Palestinian cabinet minister said yesterday.
fields.byline: Ibrahim Hazboun in Ramallah, West Bank
fields.body:
The Palestinians expect France to lead the European Union in recognising a Palestinian state, even if it is formed by unilateral declaration, a Palestinian cabinet minister said yesterday.

France takes over the rotating EU presidency next month. The Palestinian planning minister, Nabil Shaath, said it had become clear from his meetings with European officials, especially with the French, that "the Europeans are ready to accept the [Palestinian] state without connecting it to the peace solution".

Last year, the EU issued a declaration saying the Palestinians have an "unqualified right" to independence within a year, preferably - but not necessarily - through negotiations with Israel.

The Palestinians have said they would unilaterally declare a state in all of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, with east Jerusalem as a capital, if the deadline of September 13 for a peace treaty was not met.

Israeli military officials have warned that in such a scenario, clashes could erupt between Israeli and Palestinian troops.

webTitle: Barak's partners quit - but may come back

fields.headline: Barak's partners quit - but may come back
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Israeli political crisis exploded in Ehud Barak's face yesterday when the ultra-Orthodox Shas party carried out its eight-day-old threat to quit his coalition.
fields.body:
The Israeli political crisis exploded in Ehud Barak's face yesterday when the ultra-Orthodox Shas party carried out its eight-day-old threat to quit his coalition.

The resignation of its four cabinet ministers robs the prime minister of his parliamentary majority at the time he often calls the "moment of truth" for the peace process.

He had caved in on almost every point of Shas's ever-growing list of demands. But Shas, an amalgam of religious piety and the resentments of an underclass of Jews of Middle Eastern origin, could not be placated. It left the government despite winning promises of extra funds for its scandal-ridden school system and legalisation of its Channels of Holiness radio network, claiming that it was a question of honour.

"It is sad that even now, after three generations of neglect, Oriental Jews are still being deprived of their rights," the deputy treasury minister, Nissim Dahan, wrote in his resignation letter.

Judging by its past performance in government, the decision may not be final: the resignations do not come into effect for 48 hours and negotiations are due to continue.

"Anything could happen, it's all on the table. They know what we want," the Shas infrastructure minister, Eli Suissa, said. Yesterday that did not seem at all clear, however. Mr Barak's allies were confounded by the failure of their efforts to woo Shas back.

"I think overall we have managed to solve most of the issues - not all of them, but most of them, and so it seems to me very strange that they should resign over this," the finance minister, Abraham Shohat, said. "From this I conclude that the resignation stems from quite different sources."

These might include power struggles in Shas, whose new leader, Eli Yishai, is struggling to establish his credibility in an organisation bound absolutely to the dictates of the quixotic Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef.

Mr Yishai may also want to dissociate Shas from the hard decisions on the peace process that lie ahead. Many of its voters take a more hawkish line than their leaders on giving up land in the West Bank to the Palestinians.

But whatever its motives, or the eventual outcome of this game of political chicken, Mr Barak's government has been badly weakened at a time when he needs to muster maximum support.

Even if he manages to halt Shas's brinkmanship before it reaches the point of no return, it has damaged his credibility, and his ability to negotiate a deal with the Palestinians by the September 13 deadline.

Officials now say openly that they are losing hope of reaching a deal without the direct intervention of President Clinton, and are lobbying hard for a three-way summit next month to put pressure on the Palestinians to give in on such crucial issues as the status of Jerusalem, refugees' right to return, and the eventual size and borders of the their state.

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, is due to return to the region soon to try to prod the sides towards compromise. But US officials say they are too far apart to make a summit worthwhile.

The prime minister's office said yesterday that there would be "no surrender to Shas" and that Mr Barak would begin exploring other coalition possibilities, but the show of bravado does not ring true, given the frantic manoeuvring of recent days, and his evident desperation to keep his coalition intact.

Without Shas's 17 MPs he cannot make the concessions needed to reach a deal with Yasser Arafat before the Palestinian leader declares an independent state later this year.

webTitle: I'm standing by my Russell Crowe man

fields.headline: I'm standing by my Russell Crowe man
fields.trailText: No, Polly Vernon, it does not make you feel prettily fragile or vulnerable when your man stands up for you in a dodgy situation (My hero! G2, June 20). It makes you feel great. I am the kind of woman who positively forces men through doors in front of her to avoid that awful moment when he panics over the chivalrous instinct lurking beneath his Just Gay Enough exterior. However when my man stood up to a scarily aggressive driver who refused to deposit me and a bus load of teenage girl students at a reasonable safe distance from their desired deserted destination, we all thought he was a bloody hero.
fields.body:
No, Polly Vernon, it does not make you feel prettily fragile or vulnerable when your man stands up for you in a dodgy situation (My hero! G2, June 20). It makes you feel great. I am the kind of woman who positively forces men through doors in front of her to avoid that awful moment when he panics over the chivalrous instinct lurking beneath his Just Gay Enough exterior. However when my man stood up to a scarily aggressive driver who refused to deposit me and a bus load of teenage girl students at a reasonable safe distance from their desired deserted destination, we all thought he was a bloody hero.

I am delighted to wade in verbally when he needs a bit of back-up; it's something I am particularly good at. If he wants to come over all Russell Crowe and use his more physically developed attributes and exert his masculinity on the situation, that can be delightful too, as long as it doesn't get out of hand.

Let's not get at men for enjoying their masculinity; they are not all hooligans nor are they all responsible for thousands of years of female oppression. I do not believe men like defenceless women better. Standing up for your partner can be a turn-on whichever way you look at it.
Carolyn Carnaghan
Buckerell, Devon

webTitle: Freedom for some - death for others

fields.headline: Freedom for some - death for others
fields.trailText: In the wake of the horrendous deaths of 58 victims of crime, there is nothing wrong in the sombre reflection that we might all be wrong (Grim find of 58 bodies in lorry, June 20). The white paper which preceded the Asylum and Immigration Act 1999 emphasised concern about illegal migration. Its analysis went wrong. It confused issues. It focused on the victim and not the criminal. It associated asylum with economic migration. It failed to link global displacement to economic globalisation. In the implementation of the act, politicians became blinkered, with their minds set on the problems of local authorities and the inefficiencies of the Home Office.
fields.body:
In the wake of the horrendous deaths of 58 victims of crime, there is nothing wrong in the sombre reflection that we might all be wrong (Grim find of 58 bodies in lorry, June 20). The white paper which preceded the Asylum and Immigration Act 1999 emphasised concern about illegal migration. Its analysis went wrong. It confused issues. It focused on the victim and not the criminal. It associated asylum with economic migration. It failed to link global displacement to economic globalisation. In the implementation of the act, politicians became blinkered, with their minds set on the problems of local authorities and the inefficiencies of the Home Office.

We need a new analysis and a new solution, which faces up to the realities and accepts the scope of the issue. There must now be an independent review of our approach to migration and displacement. A fitting memorial to 58 human beings would be to take our heads out of the sand and face up to the issue which will dominate the coming century.
Vaughan Jones, Director, Praxis
director@praxis.org.uk

 The people who are really responsible for the deaths of 58 illegal immigrants are not criminal gangs, as the government would have us believe but the government itself. As long as the government and continues to criminalise what is a perfectly normal human activity, ie travelling the world to find work in order to improve your life, then incidents such as this will continue to occur. Clamping down further will simply invite people, wanting to find work, to adopt even riskier methods to get here. Why not let people do as they always have - travel the world in freedom to find work and a future? If Britain's economy were to collapse at some future point there would be mass emigration once more. Perhaps that's what we should hope for - no more economy, no more migrants?
Steve Bremner
Borehamwood, Herts

 For the past two decades the common mantra of western governments has been the free movement of goods and capital across national boundaries. Meanwhile these same governments have steadily criminalised the free movement of people.
Michael Ball
London

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Keep The Aspidistra Flying | Ed Wood | Bad Lieutenant | Agnes Of God
fields.body:
Keep The Aspidistra Flying
(Robert Bierman, 1997)
12noon, 4.30am, Sky Premier

Bierman's adaptation of George Orwell's novel about young poet Gordon Comstock's limp rebellion against the class system and the literary establishment is a quaint period piece. It's a handsomely mounted vision of the 30s, by turn elegant and squalid. Richard E Grant (pictured) makes a convincingly sullen, sexually frustrated Comstock, Helena Bonham Carter the nice middle-class girl who won't. But all his railing about his Art in the cruel copywriting world seems far away and long ago.

Ed Wood
(Tim Burton, 1994)
8pm, FilmFour

Affectionate portrait of the man known as the world's worst film-maker. Johnny Depp's endlessly energetic, utterly talentless Wood is an essay in heartache, and there's gobsmacking support from the likes of Bill Murray's transsexual Bunny Breckinridge, Vincent D'Onofrio's Orson Welles, and Oscar-winning Martin Laundau's sad and noble Bela Lugosi.

Bad Lieutenant
(Abel Ferrara, 1992)
12.05am, FilmFour

Harvey Keitel's detective isn't the guy you want to call when you've been burgled: he's up to his eyes in heroin, booze and gambling debts, and inclined to sexually humiliate teenage girls. He's a walking composite of human degradation, wriggling in a putrid New York. He's not nice. And then, astonishingly, the case of the raped nun offers a chance of redemption. Uncompromising, bravura work from director and star.

Agnes Of God
(Norman Jewison, 1985)
1.15am, Carlton Cinema

Jewison's overwrought religious drama is adapted by John Pielmeyer from his award-winning play. Very watchable performances from the three leading women: Meg Tilly's novice nun, apparently mother and murderer of an immaculately conceived child; Anne Bancroft as the mother superior convinced a miracle has occurred; and Jane Fonda's haggard, lapsed-Catholic psychiatrist deciding whether Sister Agnes is mentally fit to stand trial.

webTitle: No game for the other half

fields.headline: No game for the other half
fields.trailText: Perhaps many of the "supporters" who took part in last weekend's violence have as much interest in the game as I do - cursory. But I do have an interest in seeing that the violent behaviour that prevails amongst a section of our fans is eradicated (English clubs to ban thugs for life, June 20). Where were the representatives of the FA when glass and other missiles rain down on picturesque city centres? My guess is, safely ensconced within VIP hospitality suites giving bland messages of condemnation to the press.
fields.body:
Perhaps many of the "supporters" who took part in last weekend's violence have as much interest in the game as I do - cursory. But I do have an interest in seeing that the violent behaviour that prevails amongst a section of our fans is eradicated (English clubs to ban thugs for life, June 20). Where were the representatives of the FA when glass and other missiles rain down on picturesque city centres? My guess is, safely ensconced within VIP hospitality suites giving bland messages of condemnation to the press.

The FA should mount a very public campaign of re-education. What about an advertising campaign featuring our popular and well-paid England footballers? More than sweet FA needs to be done about this depressingly predictable sequence of events.
Christina Wortley
Cambridge cwortley@cup.cam.ac.uk

 I watched the England-Germany match with Dutch and French friends and secretly hoped England would lose and football and its fans would go home. I watched in awe as the Dutch fans celebrated their win over Denmark in an almost carnival atmosphere. There was no smashing, fighting or raised voices (unless you count renditions of Hup Holland and You'll Never Walk Alone).

The Netherlands were occupied by Nazi Germany. Britain wasn't. I've heard lots of anti-German jokes here but no Dutch fans boasting about arranged fights with Germans. An ugly nationalism has surfaced that is inherently racist and watered-down beer and a joint (Letters, June 20) is only a pacifying short-term solution.
Liz Hills
Breda, The Netherlands pvbavel@casema

 Why don't we grasp the nettle and introduce some proper deterrents. The "name and shame" policy by newspapers suggested in yesterday's letters is a good one; taking away their driving licence and writing to their employers is another one. Most of these people are employed, and losing their jobs will be more effective than any ban.
Hilary Baxter
Buckingham hbaxter@alacrity.co.uk

 Perhaps one way of stopping English football hooliganism would be only to allow male fans to travel if accompanied by a female adult.
Lucy Frith
Lancaster

 It is really sad and upsetting about England football fans. It was really nasty about what they said to David Beckham. There are children watching games and if the fans are swearing and fighting what example are they setting? Even children wouldn't behave like this.
Jodie Murray (aged 9)
Booker Hill School, High Wycombe, Bucks

 Build another arena: have a few beer stalls, broken seats, bottles about the place; let the people who want to fight go there. Don't need a referee or even a football - you could probably even sell tickets.
Lesley Raine
Leeds

 It's now a close call as to which I find more dull; the endless post-match analyses from Gary Lineker et al, or the people writing to you who talk constantly about their non-interest and non-support of England.
Rebecca Southwell
Bromsgrove, Worcs

 I am giving up your paper for the remainder of Euro 2000. I have to put up with my family talking football bollocks, my co-workers talking football bollocks, and now my favourite page, the letters page, is full of people talking football bollocks. See you when it's all over.
Christina Goddard
Warrington

fields.headline: ... or for the pundits
fields.trailText: Roy Hattersley is having a very bad Euro 2000. If Roy was a footballer, then he would be the Belgian goalkeeper. Hattersley abuses me in your pages for a story that appeared on the Mirror web site (Comment, June 20). I tried to write a piece about the residual animosity that exists in this country towards Germany. This is not the same as xenophobia, incitement to violence or beating up policemen.
fields.body:
Roy Hattersley is having a very bad Euro 2000. If Roy was a footballer, then he would be the Belgian goalkeeper. Hattersley abuses me in your pages for a story that appeared on the Mirror web site (Comment, June 20). I tried to write a piece about the residual animosity that exists in this country towards Germany. This is not the same as xenophobia, incitement to violence or beating up policemen.

I wrote a story about growing up in the shadow of the second world war and what that was like for those of us whose fathers fought in that war. I know that we are all Cappuccino drinkers now, but it is patently absurd to pretend that this country has the same relationship with the Germans as it does with the Swedes or the Chinese.

In the piece I said, "Something inside me has always cringed at the combat metaphors that get wheeled out for football matches," and "I happen to be one of those Englishmen whose stomach turns when he sees all those working-class boys belting out, God Save the Queen" and "Football matches - especially football matches against the Hun - are often an excuse for cheap patriotism." But your correspondent doesn't quote any of that - apart from one word, the ironic use of "Hun" - because it doesn't suit his tabloid-bashing thesis.

I also said, "It is not condoning xenophobia to say that it is perfectly understandable that a nation can bear a lingering animosity towards another nation." That animosity exists and I tried to write about it in a way that was infinitely more calm and reasonable than Hattersley's ham-fisted attempt.
Tony Parsons
The Mirror

 Hugo Young attributes English football hooliganism to tabloid-induced xenophobia imposed on a people alleged to be historically "military" (Comment, June 20). This is hard to reconcile with (a) the popularity of foreign footballers, many black and almost all fluent in English, in our leading clubs; (b) the absence of bad behaviour in Europe by Scottish or Welsh fans, English supporters before 1970 or English/British fans of rugby or any other sports; (c) the centuries-old aversion to a large standing army or to national service which made the English amongst the most peaceful peoples on earth.

Football hooliganism occurs uniquely when English clubs or teams play abroad. It is historically the product of post-imperial angst, and media-led consumerism following England's 1970 world cup defeat (by Germans). The ending of empire and a philistine culture of introverted decline has left them a world fit for Charlie Whelan to live in.
Kenneth O Morgan
Witney, Oxon

fields.trailText: From the viewpoint of most patients, the French health service is outstanding: they are free to go as often as they like to as many of the country's 94,000 GPs or 89,000 specialists as they like, ask for whatever treatment or medicines they like, and expect to get most of the cost reimbursed by the state.
fields.body:
From the viewpoint of most patients, the French health service is outstanding: they are free to go as often as they like to as many of the country's 94,000 GPs or 89,000 specialists as they like, ask for whatever treatment or medicines they like, and expect to get most of the cost reimbursed by the state.

But from the outside observer's viewpoint - as well as for successive French governments, faced with ballooning welfare budgets and healthcare deficits that have reached £4bn a year - the system is also expensive, complex, and very, very wasteful.

Founded, as was Britain's, just after the second world war, the biggest structural difference in the French system is that patients pay their doctor's and pharmacist's bills themselves, and then apply for a refund that ranges, depending on the treatment, from 40% to 100% of the total.

A major operation for a serious illness, for example, is fully reimbursed, whereas a regular consultation with a GP or médecin généraliste - which under France's standard, agreed-fee scheme costs just over £12 - is reimbursed at a rate of 70%.

While fine in principle, this system generates 1bn claim forms a year. French bureaucracy being what it is, at any one time up to 12m of them are likely to remain unpaid for longer than three months, causing considerable hardship to less well-off patients.

To make up the difference between the cost of their treatment and the state reimbursement, 87% of the French also pay monthly premiums - usually through their employer - to a network of non-profitmaking insurance firms known as mutuelles.

While fine for the majority, this system for years left most French people on low incomes unable to pay for proper healthcare. The Socialist-led government last year introduced a much-needed £900m safety net last year for the estimated 150,000 French people excluded from any form of healthcare, plus the 6m or so who cannot afford a mutuelle.

Providing a first-class level of care for minimal personal outlay, the French system, needless to say, is immensely popular with the French. It is, however, exceptionally expensive: France's healthcare budget is the third largest in the world, accounting for 9.8% of GNP compared with 14.2% in the United States, 10.4% in Germany and 6.9% in Britain.

Moreover, the system encourages waste and abuse on a massive scale. It rewards doctors who see patients as often as they can, because they get paid by the visit; and encourages doctors to prescribe cabinet loads of drugs, because that is what keeps French patients happy.

The most noticeable side-effect of the French system's generosity is its creation of a nation of prescription drug addicts. A recent health ministry report found that the French are now Europe's heaviest consumers of anti-depressants, tranquillisers and sleeping-pills, which they swallow at three times the rate of the Germans and the British.

By dint of some draconian cost-cutting measures, the social security minister, Martine Aubry, did succeed in cutting last year's healthcare deficit to £940m.

She now plans to start fining doctors who over-prescribe, to remove from the system hundreds of medicines judged "largely or wholly ineffective" by a panel of specialists, and in the longer term to educate patients and doctors into demanding and prescribing far fewer medicines.

The World Health Organisation may view France's health system as the finest on earth. That may be because it is also one of the most generous and expensive on earth - and unfortunately, France cannot afford to keep it that way.

fields.headline: Lilley's wobbly logic
fields.trailText:
Is the Peter Lilley extolling the virtues of patient choice (Curing the NHS, June 19), the same as the member of the Tory cabinet which introduced the purchaser-provider split that stopped me from referring my patients to the hospital of their choice? Choice was not "accidentally eroded by the last government's reforms", it was a central plank of them.
Dr Tim Pollard
Sutton, Surrey
fields.body:
Is the Peter Lilley extolling the virtues of patient choice (Curing the NHS, June 19), the same as the member of the Tory cabinet which introduced the purchaser-provider split that stopped me from referring my patients to the hospital of their choice? Choice was not "accidentally eroded by the last government's reforms", it was a central plank of them.
Dr Tim Pollard
Sutton, Surrey

 I too thought "early doors" was an Atkinsonism (Martin Kelner, Sport, June 19); but it seems to be an old music hall term. The galleries only had benches, not numbered seats. If you paid a few pence more than the normal entry price, you would be let in before everyone else and could thus obtain the best seats at the front. There's a 1911 poster in the bar at the London Coliseum, still, which reads "Gallery 1/-; Early Doors 1/6d".
Sean McEvoy
Brighton spm@varndean.ac.uk

 I am more fortunate than Leonard Jacobs (Letters, June 20), I saw the Wibbly Wobbly Walk performed - at the Players Theatre. The song is a regular at this music hall, to the great delight of the audience.
Viv Hayes
Old Woking, Surrey

 I've always been mystified as to why the The Wibbly Wobbly Walk is quoted at length near the beginning of Malcolm Lowry's Under The Volcano. It is described as "an absurd Pierrot" song and the lyrics strike me as being slightly sinister. I'm immensely pleased to discover the song actually exists.
Alasdair Reid
London alasdair.reid@arsenalfc.net

 The second volume of Lord of the Rings is The Two Towers, not The Twin Towers (Tolkien epic, June 19). Can't you English stop thinking about football for a moment?
Peter Talbot
Lisburn, Co Antrim

fields.headline: Taken for granted
fields.standfirst: Grant Mitchell turned him into soap's biggest star. And now Ross Kemp takes the lead role in his first major drama series, following his high-profile defection to ITV. Can he leave the Square behind?
fields.trailText: Grant Mitchell turned him into soap's biggest star. And now Ross Kemp takes the lead role in his first major drama series, following his high-profile defection to ITV. Can he leave the Square behind?
fields.body:
A couple of years ago, Ross Kemp was interviewed in Attitude, a trendy gay style magazine. The interview was one of Kemp's first attempts to move out from under the protective wing of the EastEnders press office and tackle interviews about his personal life.

The interview also marked a decision to leave the shadow of Grant Mitchell: to show that Ross Kemp wasn't a mindless, wife-beating thug, but a thoroughly charming man.

Now that Kemp has defected to ITV to the tune of £1.2m, the Attitude interview looks more cynical. In reality, it was step one of Kemp's plan to leave EastEnders, the beginning of Kemp's charm offensive: of sending out signals; widening the audience. And how better to begin than by embracing his gay fans - queers welcome in my pub anytime.

Kemp is ably advised when it comes to dealing with the press. His long-standing girlfriend is Rebekah Wade, editor of the News Of The World, and his brother, Darren, is a BBC journalist.

Kemp and his brother grew up in Brentwood, Essex, the sons of a retired detective superintendent (their mum was a hairdresser). Kemp always wanted to act, so he stayed off the dodgems, kept his nose clean and went to the prestigious Webber Douglas drama school. Since leaving, he's only ever been out of work for a total of five months.

The Kemp Brothers (like their Spandau Ballet namesakes) are a model of working-class achievement. Ross didn't smoke a cigarette until he was 23 - and probably only then for a part. Nowadays, he plays rugby and wears expensive casual clothing (Yves Saint Laurent shirts and Church's shoes).

Though well-connected, Kemp doesn't need any help. Like Grant, he can look after himself, but unlike Grant, he won't make a balls-up of it.

No surprise then that in next week's big ITV series debut, In Defence, Kemp plays it solid and dependable: more Martin Keown than Zinedine Zidane, but with enough menacing Grant moments to keep the old fans happy. If nothing else, Kemp has certainly proved - to those who may have doubted it - that he can actually act. That he's more than the sum of snarls.

Back at the BBC, EastEnders is suffering from the Big Man's absence. Dan is a poor imitation, and Phil will be off soon, undoubtedly growing weary of the retread storylines.

When Kemp finally decided to leave the Square, part of the reason lay in the fact that he'd seen the same plot lines come round two or three times already. "Audiences don't seem to mind it", he said in an interview. But actors do.

In 1997, Kemp used his position on the show to stop the proposed Christmas day storyline: Grant raping his wife, Tiffany. Kemp was looking out for Grant. Something he'd had to do for a decade.

It seems strange to me that people doubt the acting ability of Ross Kemp. When the BBC were looking for two Kray Brothers to take over the square (and nearly didn't give the part to Kemp because they couldn't find anyone that looked like his brother), they serendipitously fell upon the two greatest creations of modern drama.

Kemp is everything Grant isn't. He's sorted, he's successful; he's pleasant, gregarious, measured and happy. Grant, though, is like the rest of us. Psychopathic: no; violent: yes; unlovable: no; unknowable: perhaps.

When Grant cried, the world was truly unmanageable. The final straw, for all of us. When Grant stumbled moronically into yet another sordid emotional disaster, we stumbled with him. Born a fool each new day.

Yet in a decade of Grant's botched escapades - guns, arson, domestic violence, and sex with the mother-in-law - the sound of moral outrage against Grant rose barely above the quiet clicking of Mary Whitehouse's remote control to change channels.

Why? Because no matter how extreme, or how offensive, Grant was never less than totally emotionally honest. To deny the truth of Grant Mitchell would be to deny the fact that 200 England fans ran riot through Charleroi and felt good for once; that some men spend their lives in the garden shed or sit on the sofa for 26 years and never say a word to their wife.

Grant was an attempt to illustrate the unknowability of men, not least to themselves: far funnier and more poignant in a single grunt and shrug of the shoulders than 12 series of Men Behaving Badly.

I wish Ross Kemp well in his post-EastEnders career, but I cannot say I'm pleased for him. If ITV can buy Des and rebuild Match Of The Day around him, surely they can do the same for Ross. Now that would be a coup.

 In Defence begins on ITV next Monday at 9pm

webTitle: Controversial health list ranks Britain 18th in world

fields.headline: Controversial health list ranks Britain 18th in world
fields.standfirst:
The future of the NHS: special report

Full text of the WHO report
fields.trailText: France has the best health service in the world, while the UK ranks 18th out of 191 and the United States 37th, sandwiched between Costa Rica and Slovenia, according to a highly controversial report from the World Health Organisation.
fields.body:
France has the best health service in the world, while the UK ranks 18th out of 191 and the United States 37th, sandwiched between Costa Rica and Slovenia, according to a highly controversial report from the World Health Organisation.

It is the first time the WHO has produced such a league table, which will shame some governments and offend others because of their low ranking and clustering with nations they do not admire.

There had been political pressure on the WHO to abandon its radical and ambitious plans to publish the report, but after much soul searching it is understood that the director general, Gro Harlem Brundtland, took the decision a couple of months ago to go ahead and take the flak.

The World Health report in previous years has focused on levels of disease, with tables of significant indicators such as life expectancy, fertility and infant mortality in different countries. All the data came from the countries, and was accepted without question, even if there were doubts among officials about the accuracy of the cholera or TB rates.

But in the last two to three years, with Dr Brundtland at the helm, the organisation has collected its own figures, made its own analyses and come to its own conclusions. Dr Brundtland believes the WHO should be doing its best to make governments accountable to their people for the health service they provide.

"The main message from this report is that the health and wellbeing of people around the world depend critically on the performance of the health systems that serve them," said Dr Brundtland. "Yet there is wide variation in performance, even among countries with similar levels of income and health expenditure. It is essential for decision-makers to understand the underlying reasons so that system performance, and hence the health of populations, can be improved.

"The difference between a well-performing health system and one that is failing can be measured in death, disability, impoverishment, humiliation and despair," she says in the report.

"Dollar for dollar spent on health, many countries are falling short of their performance potential. The result is a large number of preventable deaths and lives stunted by disability. The impact of this failure is born disproportionately by the poor."

Virtually all countries can do better, says the report, based on estimates for 1997. While the UK does very well in providing healthcare free at the point of access to the entire population, it falls down on inequalities - affluent, middle-class people are more likely to live longer, disease-free lives than those who are worse off.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, was pleased with the UK's ranking. The report "provides a ringing endorsement of the principles of the NHS - free and fair care for all. The WHO analysis confirms our own analysis of the strengths of the NHS. The report shows we have much to be proud of," he said.

It also shows, he said, that there is a lot more to do to improve the way the health service responds to the changing needs of the public. "However, we are not prepared to trade off being fair and free for efficiency and responsiveness to the demands of patients."

One of the biggest success stories is Oman, placed 8th in the table. In 1970, child mortality was high but government investment has paid off - Oman tops a second table for the way in which expenditure on health succeeds in delivering disease-free life expectancy, above Malta, Italy and France. The UK is 24th; the US 72nd.

Money plays a big part in the success of any country in treating its sick, the WHO acknowledges. It suggests that there is a baseline investment of $60 (£39) per head per year, below which healthcare is not going to be adequate.

The bottom of the table is dominated by African countries, with war-torn Sierra Leone last. Healthcare systems in some of them are grossly overburdened by Aids. The WHO knows there is little these countries can do to improve their placing, but hopes that donor countries will take note.

The WHO freely acknowledges that its league table will not be completely accurate. It compares each country's system to what the experts estimate is the most that could be achieved in that country with the level of resources available. This methodology breaks new ground, but officials believe it is valid and will become more accurate in years to come as better data is accumulated.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What florists watch on television
fields.trailText: What florists watch on television
fields.body:
Sheila Downey:
"I've been trying to avoid the football, I'm afraid. I've been watching a bit of tennis but I've got a two-year-old and she wants to watch Tweenies videos all the time. She loves the Marmite advert, actually. She adores the music and dances along and sings it. Won't touch the product, mind you. Ooh, I'll tell you what I really like, it's Car Boot Sale Challenge. I find it absolutely fascinating, being a car boot sale freak myself."

Harriet Minlon:
"Not sure if I like much on television, you know. More of a books person, and the papers. Let me see... What's that one where they're all old and disgusting, that Northern one... Hm... Last Of The Summer Wine, that's it. I hate that, I find it extremely depressing, very Sunday afternoon. My mother used to watch it before she popped her clogs - oh, and Masterchef. Bloody awful man, Loyd Grossman, just so irritating, don't you think? It's a wonder he's not enormous, all that nice food he eats. That really depresses me."

Georgie Fay:
"I've got all the Friends videos and some Dennis Pennis, and, um, the Fast Show. That's TV, isn't it? I like Friends, especially Monica because I think she's so funny. I quite like Rachel, and I really like Ross - my boyfriend gets very uppity when it's on. Is he like Ross? No, he's more like... Les Dennis! [Breaks into fits of uncontrollable laughter]. I'm not going to be running off with some Neil Morrissey type, though, no chance. I think he's a moron. Unbearable! Urgh."

Jim Latham:
"Hello there. What do I watch? Gardening programmes, to see if they get it right. They often don't - sometimes that Titchmarsh bloke will put shade-lovers in direct sunlight, or vice versa. But they have to deal with some terrible spaces, don't they? It's not the way I'd do it, all very banal-looking. I believe in a bit more pomp, a bit more pizzazz. I like that Charlie Dimmock, I must say. She has the most risible taste in garden ornaments. Gigantic black plastic leaves to use as a water feature! Terrible."

fields.headline: Size doesn't matter
fields.trailText: Eat Dirt! / When I Get Older / Lock, Stock... And Spaghetti Sauce
fields.body:
So who'd have thought it? The human race has been stomping round the planet in imperialistic fashion for centuries now, putting paid to other species. Stands to reason we should get our come-uppance in the end. But it's not lions and tigers and bears who are now wreaking their revenge. It's bugs. And we're not talking caterpillars here.

Bacteria and humans have had a tense, but now it turns out symbiotic relationship ever since we evolved to join them. They massively pre-date us on earth. Any scientist will tell you bacteria are the most successful life form on earth, evolving rather more rapidly than we do to meet every challenge.

But in the last nanoseconds of the history of the planet, we have discovered their existence, thanks to Louis Pasteur, and decided to take them on. As Eat Dirt! (Channel 4, Tuesday) succinctly demonstrated, instead of being satisfied to clear out the real killer bugs that used to slaughter people wholesale like TB, by improving hygiene and water supplies as well as vaccinations, we have gone to war on the whole lot. And some of them, it is claimed, are friend, not foe.

The weapons of mass destruction are Domestos, Flash and lately, the programme told us, anti-bacterial handwashes too. There were some wonderful, flesh-crawling old ads from the 50s in the programme, demonstrating the not so subtle pressure on the post-war back-to-the-sink "housewife" to eliminate every last germ and prove to the neighbours she wasn't a sloven.

But in the war against the hidden enemy, we may be damaging ourselves. As bacteria is chased from the home and infections disappear from childhood, allergies are massively on the rise. Many (though not all) asthma researchers have gradually come round to the hygiene hypothesis - that our immune systems are not getting enough to do - and they are turning on our own internal organs instead. Children become sensitised to pollens and dust. Where are the allergies in infection-ridden parts of Africa, ask the scientists? Why is it that asthma is not a disease of pollution but of development?

Vaccines made from African dirt are now being developed and seem to have helped the breathing problems of adult asthmatics. Some very small early trials show similar injections may have a beneficial effect on multiple sclerosis and skin cancer - in both of which the immune system is damaged. We could be looking towards dirt injections in the early weeks of life alongside diphtheria and whooping cough. But you can't help wondering whether it wouldn't be a better idea to let children stuff their mouths with the stuff, as they seem to have a natural urge to do. And as the programme pointed out - it's the best excuse yet for throwing away the rubber gloves and putting your feet up.

Mind you, the bacteria paranoia is easy to understand. It's largely thanks to the end of deadly infections that we are now living into our 80s and 90s - if that is something to be thankful about. Watching When I Get Older (BBC2), you couldn't help wondering. This was the story of three people who had suffered a stroke - a much neglected illness that is the second commonest cause of death after heart disease and cancer, with 100,000 admitted to hospital every year.

It's the sort of subject matter that would have most of us reaching for the zapper. Who wants to watch elderly people recovering (or not) from illness? But it should have been compulsory viewing. It was the sort of human tale we shelter from, only to be forced to confront when it happens to someone we love. The three, Eileen, John and Frances, and their relatives, were brave, gutsy, determined, dignified and tragic all at the same time. John, who was driving a car and walking the hills by the end of it, and Eileen, quietly determined not to burden her family, were the success stories, but watching Frances in the nursing home desperate to get back to her own house made you wish she'd caught pneumonia and died in her sleep as people once did - not for nothing was it called the old man's friend.

Lock, Stock... And Spaghetti Sauce (Channel 4) offered light relief from all this human earthiness and tragedy. Four lads get the wrong consignment of videos and wipe out six grands worth of porn thinking they are dubbing wedding scenes. Unable to find the readies to pay off the heavies, they try making their own. It was sometimes funny, much too long - and I'd rather watch Pulp Fiction any day or night.

webTitle: More women delay starting their families

fields.headline: More women delay starting their families
fields.trailText: The changing face of family life over the past quarter century is revealed in figures today from the office for national statistics showing a sharp increase in the number of women in England and Wales delaying having children until their thirties, or not having them at all.
fields.body:
The changing face of family life over the past quarter century is revealed in figures today from the office for national statistics showing a sharp increase in the number of women in England and Wales delaying having children until their thirties, or not having them at all.

Conception rates for women aged 20-24 fell by 20% between 1976 and 1998. For women aged 30-34 they rose by 62% and for those aged 35-39 by 82%.

In 1976, 69% of live births were to women in their twenties and 20% to women in their thirties. But by 1998, 42% of births were to women in their thirties while the figure for women in their twenties fell to 48%.

Mothers giving birth now are nearly three years older than their counterparts in the early 1970s. Last year the average age was 29.

The review of changing trends over the past 25 years also showed increasing childlessness. One in five 40-year-old women today is childless, compared with one in 10 of the same age in 1980.

The proportion of births outside marriage rose from one in 10 in the 1970s to one in four today. Of those births, under 8% are registered by the mother alone.

A trend towards cohabitation has grown steadily over the past two decades. The proportion of never-married women under 50 who are cohabiting has trebled to three in 10 over this period.

The national statisticians estimate there are more than 1.5m cohabiting couples in England and Wales and this number is projected to double by 2021.

Since the mid-1980s the proportion of women under 50 in England, Wales and Scotland who are married has declined from two-thirds to just over half. The proportion not living with a partner as a couple stayed fairly constant at about one in five.

The number of one-parent families rose from 750,000 in 1976 to 1.6m in 1996. And the number of children in one-parent families increased from 1.3m to 2.8m over the same period.

Four out of 10 children were born outside marriage in 1999, compared with just one in 10 in 1979.

Abortions accounted for 16% of conceptions in 1976, rising to 21% in 1998. The proportion of girls aged 16-19 visiting family planning clinics increased from a minimum of 12% in 1988-89 to 22% in 1998-99. But the proportion aged 20-34 using these services fell from 21% to 12% over the same period.

The report included evidence of girls' earlier sexual activity. Among those born in 1931, 1% had first intercourse before 16, rising to 5% for those born in the 1950s and 24% for those born in 1974.

The national birth rate fell again slightly last year, with 622,000 live births, compared with 636,000 in 1998. If current fertility patterns persist, women are expected to average 1.7 children each - one of the lowest figures since wartime.

Women in the east London borough of Newham are the most fertile in Britain, with 92 live births per 1,000 women aged 15 to 44. The area with the lowest fertility was Cambridge, with 39 live births per 1,000 women.

In spite of the declining birth rate, the statisticians forecast that the population of England will rise from 49.5m in 1998 to 51.4m by 2008.

The fastest growing region will be London where the population is expected to grow from 7.2m to 7.7m by 2008, with particularly large rises in the north London borough of Barnet, and central areas such as Chelsea and Westminster.

Population Trends

 Births to women aged 35-39 up 82% over past 25 years

 Number of childless 40-year-olds doubles

 Proportion of women under 50 living with husband shrinks from two-thirds to just over half

 Proportion of children born outside marriage increases from 10% to 40%

 Unmarried couples expected to double to 3m by 2021

 Population of England forecast to reach 51.4m by 2008

fields.headline: The mothership has landed
fields.standfirst: A very odd inflatable
fields.trailText: In Paris they have the Louvre Pyramid. In London over the last weekend something equally novel but a little more amorphous disrupted the Georgian sobriety of Somerset House. Levity is the name of a vast PVC inflatable, covering 800 square metres, designed by Alan Parkinson after 19th-century anatomical drawings of jellyfish.
fields.body:
In Paris they have the Louvre Pyramid. In London over the last weekend something equally novel but a little more amorphous disrupted the Georgian sobriety of Somerset House. Levity is the name of a vast PVC inflatable, covering 800 square metres, designed by Alan Parkinson after 19th-century anatomical drawings of jellyfish.

From the outside it doesn't remotely resemble a jellyfish; I doubt that anything in the natural world comes in quite this combination of red, blue, green, yellow and steely grey. Levity is more like a circus tent that has undergone sinister genetic mutations: it has domes, turrets, teat-like protuberances and a central chamber with inverted teapot spouts. It looms ominously in the centre of what was until recently the Inland Revenue's car park: the Tellytubbies' mothership has landed, and they are after their tax refund.

The appeal of Levity is less the outside appearance than the way its insides engulf you - it is an inflatable to wander around, the stomach of a bouncy castle. There is a definite purity to it - after all, there is nothing to look at except air and daylight filtered through translucent plastic. Hidden speakers pump out an ambient soundtrack of sub-aquatic whispers and gurgles - music for manatees. What with the constant rush of air from the pumps that keep the structure aloft, the place has a strangely gastric atmosphere.

Levity feels something like a family-outing version of James Turrell, the American artist who captures light and frames it, or hangs it in the air like a vapour. If Turrell deals in the sublime, Levity offers a more accessible "wow" factor. The only time the colour here quite achieves the paradoxically vaporous solidity of Turrell's work is when you enter the red dome, and the colour briefly roasts your eyeballs like a hot gas. The effect is only brief, but it is quite unnerving. I found it so addictive that I had to keep retuning my pupils in the green and blue domes, then going back for maximum effect. There is a subtle touch in the central chamber, where the teapot spouts divert the daylight from outside and cast soft coloured glows on to the darkened grey dome: here it is a little bit Anish Kapoor.

Levity was only in town for four days, but over a longer period you wonder what social rituals might have evolved around it. People behave differently, slower perhaps, once they take off their shoes and walk inside - not least because the high concentration of oxygen in the pumped air makes them a little spacey. Men in white shirts and braces (Levity is a big draw with the Revenue people) sit cross-legged in the coloured alcoves or slide gently down the glowing walls. A group of young design types spread out picnic-style and hold a business meeting. Several people sprawl in erotic- infantile reverie: one woman curls up with a soft toy, out for the count.

This sort of edifice is all metaphors to all people. In a different context - at a festival, say - the prevailing mood would be New Agey and druggy, but pitching camp in the middle of Somerset House's sobriety makes you see the structure in a more pensive architectural light. On a balmy London summer afternoon, Levity is relaxing above all, but it needn't be just that. You might like to rent it for an orgy (the surfaces are wipe-dry, after all) or you could lock someone inside and see how long it took until they cracked.

Last week, though, Levity functioned mainly as a balmy playpen-cum-oasis for harassed city dwellers, a reminder that the "chill-out zone" now seems to have become the space that Londoners most fervently dream of. The Relaxation Zone at the Millennium Dome or the "Quiet Clubs" sketched out by Brian Eno at the Hayward Gallery's current Sonic Boom show are just the start of it. Other cities have cafes where you can lounge all day, but London requires more extreme artifice to block out the urban racket.

What I especially like about Levity is its precariousness. The sounds of the outside world are filtered out, but only just: you still hear the odd plane overhead, or a church bell ringing. You lean against the walls, feeling air-filled skin wobble beneath you: it could be, given the teething troubles of the Millennium Bridge, that the wobble is the thrill that Londoners are really crying out for. If you like, there's even a touch of memento mori about the experience: recline and lose yourself in primary-coloured bliss, but remember that there's just a thin PVC membrane between you and the Inland Revenue. They couldn't have chosen a better site.

 Levity is at Nottingham Castle Museum and Gallery (0115-915 3700), from September 27-October 1.

fields.headline: The unquiet American
fields.standfirst: Garry Winogrand's skewed pictures, full of nervous energy, changed photography for ever.  Geoff Dyer reports
fields.trailText: Garry Winogrand's skewed pictures, full of nervous energy, changed photography for ever. Geoff Dyer reports
fields.body:
You only need to see one of Garry Winogrand's photographs to know that he took hundreds of thousands more. He said he liked to work "in that area where content almost overwhelms form" and there are often several potential photographs contending for attention within a single image. People are always looking elsewhere, hinting at other incidents - other photographs - going on just beyond the frame. His apartment was crammed with images, swaying stacks of prints. When his friend Joel Meyerowitz visited, Winogrand would say "Here, take a look at this" and hand him 250 pictures at a time.

While most photographers are painstaking to the point of obsession about printing, Winogrand reckoned that "anyone who can print can print my pictures". To him, time spent in the darkroom was time wasted. Processing the material counted for less than the urgent task of amassing it. What mattered was being out on the streets. Like the street musician in John Ashbery's poem, he was someone "who, walking the streets /Wrapped in an identity like a coat, sees on and on... "

Winogrand tends to be grouped by historians with fellow Americans Diane Arbus and Lee Friedlander, partly because they were exhibited together in 1967, in a landmark show called New Documents at the New York Museum of Modern Art. The curator of that exhibition, John Szarkowski, announced that a "new generation of photographers has directed the documentary approach toward more personal ends". The classic documentary approach had been embodied by the overalled elegance of Walker Evans; the liberating influence on the new generation was Robert Frank's indifference to the traditional aesthetics of the camera.

Born in 1928, Winogrand picked up where Frank left off. A picture such as the one taken in Los Angeles in 1964, of a couple - the man has a broken nose - blurring by in an open-topped car, could almost be by Frank. Winogrand's mature style, though, cannot be mistaken for anyone else's, especially when he is on his home turf, in the streets of New York.

The kinetic energy of the city was equalled by Winogrand's own - "he would shake so much," Meyerowitz recalls, "the whole place shook" - and the two are fused in his apparently uncomposed compositions. Most of the pictures now on show in The Man in the Crowd: the Uneasy Streets of Garry Winogrand at the Photographer's Gallery, London, were made during the turbulent ascension of free jazz. Just as the history of modern jazz has involved the listener having to acclimatise to what seems unmusical, so Winogrand's visually dissonant arrange ments are not easy on the eye. The pictures are skewed and unsteady.

While some photographers want to be invisible, Winogrand, who died in 1984, was a big, dominant presence. Someone could always see what he was up to. His belligerent style of approach resulted in hostile glares from the people he accosted. The photos are jostled by what they depict. There is nowhere for our gaze to rest because in these pictures nothing is at rest - least of all Winogrand himself. He was a still photographer only in the strictly technical sense.

The patient working methods of certain photographers are evident in the calmness of their images. Winogrand had a Manhattan variant of patience, one compatible with being in a hurry. Commenting on the picture of an old man "stiffly stooping to pick up his cane", Winogrand said he clicked the shutter "at the moment best calculated to show the painful slowness of the man's action". It is Winogrand's speed - what the writer Colin Westerbeck called his "1200 ASA jitteriness" - that snatches this slowness.

We are used to looking for the visual rhymes that hold Cartier- Bresson's pictures together. In Winogrand's we have to peer at a mass of possibly distracting, possibly essential data for the tangled geometry that keeps everything momentarily in place. Even then we don't always find it. The reason for this is simple: it is not always there. Winogrand himself often didn't know how his pictures would turn out. What interested him were the possibilities of a given moment. "In the simplest sentence," he said, "I photograph to find out what something will look like photographed." That is why, even when you know his work well, you keep thinking that you have never seen anything quite like it. He is all the time challenging you to accept that great photographs can look like this.

Tiring to look at, his images are inexhaustible because there is so much happening in them. A famous photo from 1964, American Legion Convention, Dallas features, among other things, someone who looks like he has just crawled out of a picture of amputees begging in Benares; but he could also be a maintenance worker clambering out of a tight-fitting manhole. Either way he meets Winogrand's unjudging eye as calmly as Arbus's weirdos meet hers. But while Arbus isolates her people within the stare of an unblinking photographic cage, Winogrand's oddballs have to compete for space with a scrum of on-lookers. And the photographer is in among them, so that the world we see is the one they see. This was nicely hinted at by the title of Winogrand's posthumous retrospective.

Winogrand's sudden death has meant that this mass of figments can be seen in any number of ways. In the catalogue of The Man in the Crowd strict chronology has been juggled in the interest of a persuasive and compelling narrative of the 60s. At first the streets, though incident-packed, are civil. Gradually the mood darkens. A woman lies bruised and battered on the sidewalk. A sudden gust of wind catches passers-by in an explosion of litter. The streets become clogged with demonstrations and bloody confrontation. The last picture is of pandemonium. Public order has broken down. So too have the subtle contingencies of Winogrand's agile idea of pictorial order. Content is in the midst of overwhelming form, crowding it out of the picture.
