fields.headline: Over hyped and over here
fields.standfirst: Sam Mendes was right to warn against casting stars such as Jerry Hall on British stages - we're all getting fed up with them, writes  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: Sam Mendes was right to warn against casting stars such as Jerry Hall on British stages - we're all getting fed up with them, writes Lyn Gardner
fields.body:
When Sam Mendes warned last week that theatre's reliance on Hollywood stars meant it was in peril of being "held hostage by the lure of glamour," the instant reaction was, "Come off it." After all, it was Mendes, the artistic director of London's Donmar Warehouse and director of the Oscar-winning American Beauty, who got Nicole Kidman to strip off for The Blue Room and created the kind of media feeding frenzy normally seen only in the movies and royal scandals. Kidman was admired as much for her lack of cellulite as her acting abilities.

Mendes has now decided that not all publicity is necessarily good publicity. But perhaps the wunderkind of British theatre, who was directing home-grown stars like Judi Dench when he was practically still in short trousers is, once again, one step ahead of the pack.

The signs are that British audiences are no longer suckers for Hollywood bigshots who fancy adding a classy London theatre to their CVs. They're certainly not besieging the Savoy to see Donald Sutherland in the badly reviewed Enigmatic Variations, any more than they queued last year to catch Charlton Heston enjoying a London vacation that was only interrupted by his nightly shuffle through AR Gurney's appalling Love Letters.

Even Ralph Fiennes playing Richard II at the Gainsborough Studios has attracted nothing like the attention that accompanied his Hackney Empire Hamlet a few years back. In what has become known as the Battle of the Dicks, Fiennes lost out to Sam West, whose performance at Fiennes's old stamping ground, the Royal Shakespeare Company in Stratford-upon-Avon, is generally considered the finer. But Fiennes's much better reviewed Coriolanus shows signs of creating a bigger stir - an indication that Hollywood stars are no longer such a novelty and theatregoers are prepared to respond on merit.

Which brings us to Jerry Hall, the West End producers' latest ruse to get audiences into the theatre. Hall, who is better known for her relationship with Mick Jagger than for her acting experience, will be taking over from Kathleen Turner and taking off her clothes in the stage version of The Graduate.

This kind of celebrity casting is not entirely new. Emma Noble was in Popcorn and did not disgrace herself, although plenty of talented young actresses would have done it better - but if the public falls for Hall it could open the floodgates to a whole new genre of Hello-style productions. Anyone for Carol Vorderman giving us her Medea, Denise Van Outen as Lady Macbeth and the Duchess of York in Shopping and Fucking? So far we have been spared Madonna's threatened Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, but for how long?

Stars in themselves are no bad thing. Nobody in their right mind would have turned down the opportunity to see Kevin Spacey give the performance of a lifetime in The Iceman Cometh, and it is worth remembering that Fiennes and Julia Ormond - who is also London-bound - served long apprenticeships in the British theatre before they made it big in Hollywood. But we should worry when the casting is cynical, as it appears to be with Hall, or when, as with Kidman and The Blue Room, the star is so imposing that an undistinguished play is blown out of all proportion. The first revival of The Blue Room at the Bolton Octagon this year went by almost unnoticed.

Mendes bemoans the fact that star casting puts theatre on the front pages and turns theatre into an event. In an age of dwindling audiences, that is not such a terrible thing. But it is the nature of the event that is crucial. In their own ways The Lion King , De La Guarda and Frantic Assembly playing the old Battersea town hall are all events. None of those shows has a recognisable star in sight but all create their own theatrical excitement, that unexpected shiver down the spine. Kevin Spacey can do it; so can Ralph Fiennes. But Jerry Hall? As Sam Goldwyn once said on being offered what seemed a surefire deal: "Gentlemen, kindly include me out."

fields.headline: Timer admission in Lockerbie trial
fields.standfirst: Libya and the Lockerbie trial: special report
fields.trailText: The owner of a Swiss electronics firm yesterday admitted that a timer which prosecutors say was used in the bomb which blew up Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie could only have been supplied by his firm.
fields.body:
The owner of a Swiss electronics firm yesterday admitted that a timer which prosecutors say was used in the bomb which blew up Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie could only have been supplied by his firm.

Edwin Bollier, co-owner of the Zurich-based company Mebo, admitted under questioning by prosecution counsel that fragments from a timer discovered by police investigating the bombing were part of the MST-13 timer made uniquely by Mebo.

Mr Bollier has waged a campaign in the press and on the internet denying that the detonator was supplied by his firm. He had claimed that a Florida-based firm had supplied identical detonators to the CIA, but yesterday he admitted that would not have been possible.

The Swiss businessman told the Scottish court in the Netherlands that he had supplied 20 of the sophisticated detonators to the Libyan secret services in Tripoli in 1985 in the hope of winning a contract from the military.

When he supplied the first batch of MST-13 timers he went with Libyan officials to the desert city of Sabha and watched as they were used in explosions. "I was present when two such timers were included in bomb cylinders," Mr Bollier told prosecutor Alan Turnbull QC. Earlier he told the court he had met one of the Libyan accused while he was in Tripoli. He said he believed Abdelbaset Ali Al Megrahi to be a major in the Libyan military, and that he might even be related to Colonel Gadafy.

Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah are accused of planting the bomb on the New York-bound jumbo, killing all 259 passengers on board and 11 locals in the Scottish borders town in December 1988.

The court heard that Mebo had done regular business with Libya, and in 1985 the company supplied 20 of its MTS-13 timers to the country in anticipation of a larger order, which never appeared.

Mr Bollier said the order for the prototypes was placed by one of two men, Said Rashid and Ezzadin Hinshiri. The timers were taken to the headquarters of the Libyan secret services before being tested in the desert trials.

During his dealings with Libya, Mr Bollier told the court, he came into contact with Megrahi. He said the Libyan accused had set up a business under the name of ABH at Mebo offices in Zurich.

Megrahi, 48, and Fhimah, 44, have denied charges of conspiracy to murder, murder, and breach of the 1982 Aviation Security Act.

The trial, before Lord Sutherland, continues.

fields.headline: Summit smiles on City
fields.standfirst: But a mountain of euro business remains
fields.trailText: Yes it was, as Tony Blair said, something of a triumph for Gordon Brown. He may not wear black tie at the Mansion House, but in his successful battle against the withholding tax on cross-border savings he has proved himself a dear friend of the City of London.
fields.body:
Yes it was, as Tony Blair said, something of a triumph for Gordon Brown. He may not wear black tie at the Mansion House, but in his successful battle against the withholding tax on cross-border savings he has proved himself a dear friend of the City of London. He fought hard and, by some accounts, even resisted moves within Whitehall to compromise. Finally, yesterday, the Treasury's recipe became a policy option for the 15.

But we must not get carried away. The deal involved nudges and winks about lifting diplomatic sanctions against Austria. It is pretty conditional, too, with a seven-year delay till full implementation. The accord provides for member states to exchange information on financial holdings; but in this "globalised" world that can only work if reciprocal arrangements are agreed with non-EU jurisdictions, including Switzerland and eventually the United States. This is potentially a recipe by which progressive government can fight back against tax evasion even in a borderless world. One bonus is ending the cult of bank secrecy - which, among other things, prevented justice for Holocaust survivors for too many years. Yet the Blairite stand would look a lot more coherent if the government's latest statement of proposed rules on taxing offshore corporate accounts were clearer. What happens when Mr Brown's praise of "tax competition" is taken literally and companies threaten to vacate the United Kingdom? Step forward Chris Gent of Vodaphone, the man rewarded upfront in telephone numbers for being in the right seat at the right time when the lottery wheel of corporate restructuring turned.

While Mr Blair went to Portugal earlier this year in positive mien, brandishing proposals for e-commerce and internet employment, this time he found it hard to avoid Thatcherite "we bent them to our will" tones. Perhaps on tax harmonisation, holding out against the odds was justified. But there is a mountain of European business to be done over the next six months that will demand compromise and agreement if enlargement is ever to occur. To get through it the UK will not just have to play honest broker when the French and the Germans dispute, say, imbalance between population and voting strength. London benefits from "flexibility" as it hesitates over the euro: why should not pick-and-choose guide the future development of the union for everyone?

webTitle: New York casts a cold light on Hillary

fields.headline: New York casts a cold light on Hillary
fields.standfirst:
Now the charismatic Mayor Giuliani has dropped out, the focus is on the nature of the First Lady

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Now the charismatic Mayor Giuliani has dropped out, the focus is on the nature of the First Lady
fields.body:
The 35-year-old woman toying with a Starbucks coffee outside a twee clothing shop in the town just up the line from Pleasantville might be almost the stereotype of the Hillary Clinton supporter. Linda is a teacher, the mother of a nine-month-old girl, a liberal, a Democrat and someone who pays attention to politics.

Even if she did not, she could hardly avoid Mrs Clinton's attempt to win election to the Senate, living as she does in Chappaqua, a privileged settlement 35 miles north of Manhattan where the president and his wife bought a house six months ago.

The town's serenity is breached only by the engines of Jeeps, Volvos and BMWs, litter is as scarce as black faces and the sense of civic pride is palpable: it has nothing in common with the city except the people who work there by day and sleep here at night. Mrs Clinton tries to press all the buttons that might earn votes from the Lindas of New York state: better education facilities, improved health care, tax breaks for people who care for children. But it just isn't working.

"I'm not a huge fan of hers," Linda says. "And I've got to tell you that none of my female friends are huge fans either. She's been outspoken on issues where . . . look, I'm Jewish and she hasn't been real supportive. She pretends to be a little bit of everything.

"And I'd prefer someone who knows more about the city rather than someone who comes to Chappaqua and lives here for a few months and then says 'elect me'. If she wasn't the president's wife she'd never be able to run."

Indeed, Mrs Clinton says now that she started thinking about standing only because so many influential Democrats told her that she should do so, and their critics contend that one of the most unappealing aspects of the Clintons is that they reek of an air of entitlement.

This line has not exactly been ameliorated by the change in the complexion of the contest a month ago. Until then she was up against Rudy Giuliani, a star of the Republican party who laps up the credit for the transformation of New York, during his seven years as mayor, from a byword for crime, grime and edginess into what he trumpets ritually as "the safest large city in America".

But when Mr Giuliani, stricken by prostate cancer and an increasingly embarrassing personal life - he, too, has women problems - left the contest, the Republicans turned to an infinitely more obscure congressman from Long Island.

Suddenly it is no longer the most watched election since Bill Clinton first became president, no longer a clash between self-conscious liberalism and can-do Republicanism, no longer a run-off between two of the most polarising figures in American politics. Now it is Hillary Clinton against Rick Lazio; the most admired and reviled woman in United States public life against Rick Who? The race is all about her, and she is stuck.

When Mr Giuliani was still on the scene she could not get beyond the mid-40s in the polls: even during the periods when support leached from the mayor - say when yet another unarmed black man was shot dead by the police - it went not to Mrs Clinton but to the don't-knows.

The issue is the candidate

Against Mr Lazio, a fresh-faced 42-year-old almost unknown to the voters, she is still in a statistical dead heat.

"After a brief pause for intermission, we are back to a neck-and-neck race," the Democratic political analyst Jeff Plaut says. "I think it signifies that any race that involves Hillary Clinton is a race about her. "She could run against Mother Theresa or Muammar Gadafy and still get 46%."

Mrs Clinton should be confident of victory in New York city, where Democrats outnumber Republicans by five to one. But more than half the state's population lives outside the city, and here Mr Lazio leads her by 54% to 32%.

She is ahead - just - among women as a whole, but Mr Lazio is favoured by a margin of 50% to 37% by white women, a key swing sector which helped to elect her husband.

Organised women, as opposed to those drinking coffee on a new green bench in the high street, consider this is unfair to the candidate in the black trouser-suit, exuding compassion without actually giving too much away, surely one of the few "extreme leftwingers" to run for public office on a platform that includes support for the death penalty.

Diane Graszik, a member of Women for Hillary, greeted her ecstatically - 45 minutes late and no apology - at the offices of the teachers' union, a big supporter, on Park Avenue, Manhattan.

"She's a successful woman who shows that you can have it all. There's an envy thing and a threatening thing. Maybe the women who don't support her don't perceive that they could achieve what she has. If she was a man nobody would bat an eye."

Ms Graszik, programme director of the non-partisan Future Voters of America Inc, says: "She has so much to offer, she has her finger on the pulse and she has great connections. But I've even heard people say she's a wimp for not leaving her husband.

Peggy Noonan, author of The Case Against Hillary Clinton, says: "What matters is that Mrs Clinton's candidacy is aimed not at helping you but at helping her, not at advancing social justice but at keeping Hillary Clinton in power. That's the problem - not her politics but her."

She was asked at a meeting in Buffalo, on the extreme fringe of the state, if she could promise that she would not run for the White House in four years' time.

"Yes," she replied, "I want to be the very best senator I can be" - before switching her attention to technology, as though she were a guest changing the subject at a cocktail party. This is expected to stop short of criminal charges but to criticise Mrs Clinton for her alleged role in the dismissal of seven White House travel office employees, sent packing to make way for friends and relatives of the First Couple. The contents of Mr Ray's report will not be made public for at least three months: inconveniently close to Mrs Clinton's date with the voters in November.

webTitle: Monitor horrified at tales of violence

fields.headline: Monitor horrified at tales of violence
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The head of the Commonwealth team monitoring Zimbabwe's elections, the former Nigerian president Abdulsalami Abubakar, condemned the political violence sweeping the country yesterday and urged restraint ahead of the weekend vote.
fields.body:
The head of the Commonwealth team monitoring Zimbabwe's elections, the former Nigerian president Abdulsalami Abubakar, condemned the political violence sweeping the country yesterday and urged restraint ahead of the weekend vote.

"Zimbabweans should vote peacefully and according to their will. There is no need for violence, otherwise you are doing a disservice to the same people you aspire to lead," Mr Abubakar said.

He said he had heard horrifying tales of violence and intimidation across the country which were a matter of concern for his 44-member observer team in Zimbabwe to monitor the election.

"People have been beaten and I have been able to speak to some of those who have been beaten. This is coming from all the [political] parties concerned," he said.

Gen Abubakar held a two-hour meeting with MDC officials who gave him a graphic account of the violence against their supporters.

David Coltart, a lawyer and MDC candidate, said beatings and abductions of MDC supporters had risen since the weekend, and on Sunday alone 25 MDC supporters were abducted in Bulawayo and were still missing.

Another five disappeared on Monday evening, while others were dragged from their homes and publicly beaten in broad daylight, he said. Officials travelling with Mr Abubakar said the Nigerian general was horrified at the violence.

On Monday, the Zimbabwean home affairs minister, Dumiso Dabengwa, said he would deploy 20,000 police and 10,000 reserves to ensure peaceful voting. "We need to ensure that there will be sufficient security across the country," Mr Dabengwa said.

He said the deployment would be one of Zimbabwe's biggest security operations. The army would also be on standby for support.

fields.headline: No: 1660
fields.standfirst: Venerable Bede
fields.trailText: Venerable Bede
fields.body:
Age:
Venerable.

Can you be a little more precise?
Born around 672; died 735.

Occupation:
Monk, historian, seer who illuminated the Dark Ages.

Motto:
Where there's a quill, there's a way.

Appearance:
Not on a plinth.

Should he be?
His admirers reckon so: 20,000 have signed a petition calling for his statue to be erected on the vacant plinth in Trafalgar Square.

Sounds better than the usual disintegrating shark or dirty pair of knickers, so what's the problem?
The plinth is now the responsibility of London's mayor, and the Venerable Ken thinks Bede's majestic Ecclesiastical History of the English People was politically incorrect.

Insufficient space devoted to the Irish potato famine?
Don't be silly. The learned Livingstone, who says he read Bede about 30 years ago, objects to Bede's history being so preoccupied with Christianity. "Bede is really the church's airbrushed version of British history, because he ignores our pagan past."

What do the Bede backers say?
"The mayor's venture into medieval scholarship betrays his schoolboy knowledge of history."

A fair point?
Not really. No schoolboy now would even have heard of Bede.

What do we know about his life?
Not much. At the age of seven he was placed in a monastery in Wearmouth, Northumbria, and later moved to a monastery in Jarrow. He devoted his entire life to writing, teaching and singing in the church, producing innumerable books on theology, science, history and medieval soccer.

Medieval soccer?
That was a joke: I was worried I was losing you.

So what are his chances of being plinthed?
Low. The Bede-ites accuse Livingstone of displaying "a cavalier metropolitan bias" to the north east's great historian. The latest plan is to put an inverted resin copy of the plinth on the plinth, called Plinth.

Not to be confused with:
The Vulnerable Beard (Frank Dobson).

Most likely to say:
"Thegns ain't what they used to be."

Least likely to say:
"I can see the London Eye from up here."

fields.headline: Amnesty call for investor policy
fields.trailText: Amnesty International yesterday called on investors to help safeguard human rights in Saudi Arabia.
fields.body:
Amnesty International yesterday called on investors to help safeguard human rights in Saudi Arabia.

"Businesses can be key players in bringing about positive change," Amnesty spokesman Peter Frankental told delegates at a £1,000-a-head investment conference in London.

That was not always the case. Companies used to close their eyes to human rights violations. But in 1980, Mobil Oil withdrew financial support from US public service broadcasting after the film Death of a Princess showed the execution of a 17-year-old Saudi woman on her grandfather's orders.

"Over the last 18 months there seems to have been a change in the willingness of business to engage in human rights issues," Mr Frankental said. "Companies are open to much greater scrutiny than in the past, because of the internet and global media. There is a greater awareness by shareholders of what companies are doing, and more consumer concern," he said.

About 30,000 Britons work in Saudi Arabia and there are more than 90 UK-Saudi joint venture companies. With a growing, youthful, population and increasing unemployment, the kingdom is keen to encourage foreign investment.

Amnesty, which in March published a damning report on human rights practices in Saudi Arabia, argues that violations contribute to social instability and increase the risks affecting investment.

Companies which operate in the kingdom are likely to come under scrutiny with regard to the human rights aspects of their operations. In a booklet, Amnesty says: "Those companies that have an appropriate policy framework in place will be in a strong position to avoid damage to their reputation."

Several multinationals, including BP Amoco and Royal Dutch/Shell, have already adopted such policies.

Amnesty's checklist, which is designed to help companies formulate policies, includes procedures to protect the legal rights of employees, including their right to life; to ensure that the company's products are not used to violate peoples' right to life, liberty or personal security; guidelines to prevent collaboration with enterprises that use unpaid labour, renege on employment contracts or deny employees access to their travel documents and to protect employees' freedom of religion.

Foreign Office minister Peter Hain said investors in Saudi Arabia would have the British government's full backing. But he warned that bureaucracy and lack of openness could impede investment. "There are signs that investors are looking elsewhere. Foreign direct investment in the kingdom has fallen behind that in other markets," he said.

"Greater openness will improve mutual understanding, develop common values and increase respect for international standards, in the social , as well as the economic spheres."

webTitle: Racetrack vets told to hide work

fields.headline: Racetrack vets told to hide work
fields.trailText: Vets at racetracks were yesterday warned to be extra vigilant about shielding spectators from their work after horrified racegoers watched a veterinary surgeon saw the leg off a dead horse.
fields.body:
Vets at racetracks were yesterday warned to be extra vigilant about shielding spectators from their work after horrified racegoers watched a veterinary surgeon saw the leg off a dead horse.

The Jockey Club said it had launched an investigation after one of its vets, Keith Mason, began sawing up colt Midyan Blue in a horsebox after it fell in the 4.30 at Musselburgh, East Lothian, unaware that he could be seen by people in the hospitality area.

A club spokesman said no action would be taken against Mr Mason, described as one of the most conscientious members of his profession and "extremely upset" by the incident, but added that stringent guidelines had since been issued.

"It is not acceptable for any member of the public to have to witness such an incident," the spokesman added. "A note has already gone out to all vets reminding them that they cannot be too careful when carrying out such operations."

The club's veterinary adviser, Peter Webbon, had spoken to Mr Mason about the incident but the investigation would not be taken any further.

The leg was taken off the horse as part of a study being carried out at Liverpool University into why racehorses suffer fatal accidents, the spokesman said.

Press Association

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our obituary of the secret agent Kermit "Kim" Roosevelt, page 24, June 13, we said he was reported to have persuaded the Shah to pay the former prime minister of Iran, Mohammad Mossadegh, a generous pension, continuing to Mossadegh's death in 1967. Mossadegh's biographer (Farhad Diba, Mohammad Mossadegh: A political biography) says that notwithstanding any reports to the contrary, at no time did Dr Mossadegh need or receive a pension from the Shah. He says that, in fact, in all his ministerial roles, including that of prime minister, Dr Mossadegh took no salary whatsoever, choosing to donate it to the law library of the University of Tehran.

Mossadegh's biographer (Farhad Diba, Mohammad Mossadegh: A political biography) says that notwithstanding any reports to the contrary, at no time did Dr Mossadegh need or receive a pension from the Shah. He says that, in fact, in all his ministerial roles, including that of prime minister, Dr Mossadegh took no salary whatsoever, choosing to donate it to the law library of the University of Tehran.

In editing Professor Brendan O'Leary's letter, page 23, yesterday, we made it appear that Chris Patten recommended the disbanding of the entire RUC. Professor O'Leary says this is a false belief held only by "no" unionists. His original letter observed that Mr Patten recommended the disbanding of the RUC Reserve (whereas the police bill keeps the latter on a statutory basis).

In an item in The Loafer, a column in the Saturday Review (Books), page 10, June 17, we remonstrated with the novelist Matt Thorne for his temerity in allowing the blurb on the jacket of his new book to claim that a previous novel, Tourist, had been "longlisted" for the Guardian fiction prize. "We feel honour bound to point out," the Loafer declared, "that there never was any such thing as a Guardian Fiction Prize longlist. So Matt Thorne couldn't have been on it." In fact in a report in the Guardian on October 31 1998, referring to the Guardian fiction award, we said: "Some 30 books made the longlist. They were whittled down to 11, from which the six shortlisted titles were chosen. The five which narrowly missed out [included] Tourist by Matt Thorne ... " Profuse apologies to Matt Thorne.

The title of the film, the title song, and the stage show of the same name opening at the National Theatre is Singin' in the Rain, not Singing in the Rain (Guide, Monday June 19). The apostrophe is compulsory.

The golliwog was associated with Robertsons, not Robinsons (page 17, June 19, Strangers at the gate). An apostrophe is unnecessary.

Homophone corner (old favourites): 1) from page 2, G2, yesterday, "Coe is in poll position for the same treatment"; 2) from page 5, G2, yesterday, "That's why he seems so unphased."

webTitle: Police say rapist will strike again

fields.headline: Police say rapist will strike again
fields.trailText: Police investigating 13 sex attacks and a rape in West Sussex over a four year period have been contacted by six more women who might also have been the victim of the same attacker.
fields.body:
Police investigating 13 sex attacks and a rape in West Sussex over a four year period have been contacted by six more women who might also have been the victim of the same attacker.

Detective Chief Inspector Steve Scott said it was too early to say, but officers were interviewing the women.

The reward for information leading to the capture of the rapist, who has staged his attacks around Chichester and Bognor Regis, has increased to £20,000, he said.

Two attacks - including the rape - had been scientifically linked.

"This man will strike again unless he is caught," DCI Scott told a press conference.

The attacker, who threatens women with a knife and covers their faces with clothing, struck once in 1996, once in 1997, four times in 1998, four times in 1999 and four times so far this year.

All but one of his victims have been aged between 12 and 29 and he has been dubbed "the Thursday rapist" as 10 of the 14 attacks have happened on a Thursday night or Friday morning.

The attacks have been in homes or secluded areas, said Mr Scott, who warned women to be extra vigilant.

A reconstruction of the attack on a 12-year-old girl in Chichester in September 1999 will be shown on BBC1's Crimewatch UK tonight.

The attacker is described as white, aged 25-40, of medium build, with dark hair and stubble. He often wears a black leather jacket. He has been described as smelling of alcohol or petrol.

The attacker, who threatens women with a knife and covers their faces with clothing, struck once in 1996, once in 1997, four times in 1998, four times in 1999 and four times so far this year. All but one of his victims have been aged between 12 and 29 and he has been dubbed "the Thursday rapist" as 10 of the 14 attacks have happened on a Thursday night or Friday morning. The attacks have been in homes or secluded areas, said Mr Scott, who warned women to be extra vigilant. A reconstruction of the attack on a 12-year-old girl in Chichester in September 1999 will be shown on BBC1's Crimewatch UK tonight. The attacker is described as white, aged 25-40, of medium build, with dark hair and stubble. He often wears a black leather jacket. He has been described as smelling of alcohol or petrol. fields.headline: Driver in M-way crash 'was asleep'
fields.trailText: Three women soldiers were killed when a lorry ploughed into their minibus on the hard shoulder of a French motorway, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Three women soldiers were killed when a lorry ploughed into their minibus on the hard shoulder of a French motorway, an inquest heard yesterday.

The three women, Tanya Braithwaite, 18, Louise Jones, 21, and Emma Leverton, 19, were returning to England from their base in Germany in March 1998 to take part in an armed forces basketball tournament.

Other soldiers in the minibus told the inquest at Swindon central police station in Wiltshire that they believed the driver of the Dutch registered lorry had fallen asleep at the wheel, having earlier spotted him swerving erratically over the A16 near Calais.

The inquest heard how the minibus was shunted 300 metres along the road after the impact.

The bus had pulled over because the driver believed it was about to run out of fuel. The minibus driver, Tracey Cafferkey, who suffered bruising and whiplash, said: "I looked through my rear view mirror and could see a lorry heading in our direction.

"It was half on the hard shoulder and half in the lane. The next thing I knew the lorry struck the rear of the minibus."

The minibus contained seven basketball players based in Bielefeld, Germany. All were members of the 7th Transport Regiment of the Royal Logistics Corps and were heading for Calais to catch a ferry to England. They were due to take part in a tournament in Grantham, Lincolnshire.

The inquest continues.

fields.headline: Sister 'felt threatened by Tory'
fields.trailText: A former Tory minister who wined and dined two sisters later punched one in the face and then lay on top of her in the street, a court heard yesterday. Rod Richards allegedly left Cassandra Melvin, 23, in fear for her life and then hurled her against a car, fracturing her elbow.
fields.body:
A former Tory minister who wined and dined two sisters later punched one in the face and then lay on top of her in the street, a court heard yesterday. Rod Richards allegedly left Cassandra Melvin, 23, in fear for her life and then hurled her against a car, fracturing her elbow.

Tiffini Melvin feared "something horrible" had happened when she found the Welsh assembly member, who had earlier asked if they liked "older men", hunched over her sister as she lay on the pavement.

Richards, 53, of Radyr, Cardiff, denies causing grievous bodily harm.

The jury heard how the sisters met the former junior Welsh Office minister - who served under John Major - in a pub in Richmond, south-west London, on July 27 last year. Tiffini Melvin, 31, said he was very "forward" and asked her if she liked older men. Later, he cancelled his taxi and joined the sisters as they headed home and invited himself in for coffee.

Tiffini Melvin told the court she felt threatened by his behaviour and he was asked to leave. But he tried to force his way back in.

After trying to dial 999 Tiffini Melvin went to check on her sister and found her lying outside with Richards on top of her.

The trial continues.

webTitle: Farm shifts from beef to badgers

fields.headline: Farm shifts from beef to badgers
fields.trailText: A beef farming couple are selling their herd because it has proved more profitable to charge visitors to see a group of badgers living on their land.
fields.body:
A beef farming couple are selling their herd because it has proved more profitable to charge visitors to see a group of badgers living on their land.

Kevin and Anne Atkinson, who have been beef farmers for 10 years, started their badger watching business three years ago in order to diversify away from complete reliance on the crisis hit beef sector.

They spent £12,000 setting up the venture, including a purpose built hide on a hillside where visitors can see around 10 of the animals in the evenings.

Now it is so successful - and the beef business so bad - that they are selling their 24 cattle and devoting their time and efforts to the badgers.

They are also hoping to diversify further by opening up their 60 acre farm, near Tiverton in Devon, to school parties.

Mrs Atkinson, 43, said: "If we are to stay on the farm we have to produce an income from the land and in the current economic climate beef just doesn't do that any more.

"We had been struggling for years to make any money. It got to the point where we weren't making any money at all despite the subsidies.

"This [badger watching] business is going very well and we are already into profit which we are really pleased about."

Mr Atkinson, 45, said there had been three driving forces behind the decision to set up the badger watching business.

"The first was the need to diversify the farm income away from total reliance on the beef sector which was then severely depressed," he said.

"The second was simply a wish to share the magical experience of wild badger watching with others.

"The third was to offer those who wanted to know more a deeper insight into the complexities of the natural world."

fields.headline: Defectors dare Mugabe
fields.standfirst:
Independents pose a threat in Zimbabwe's national polls

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, calls them "Satans" and at a recent rally urged them to renounce their wicked ways. They are former loyalists of his Zanu-PF party who have broken ranks and are running as independents in this weekend's elections.
fields.body:
The Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, calls them "Satans" and at a recent rally urged them to renounce their wicked ways. They are former loyalists of his Zanu-PF party who have broken ranks and are running as independents in this weekend's elections.

Despite the threat of expulsion from the Zanu-PF party, none of the candidates has backed down as polling day draws near. Some were MPs in the last parliament, and a few were even on the policy-making central committee.

"It is normal to have dissent within a political party. You have the row between Blair and Livingstone," said Chen Chimutengwende, the information minister. "We are a democratic party and we have party primaries. People who lose always complain.

"If you've been in power for more than 10 years, you need renewal in government and the party, and a review of policies. Other people become ambitious and want positions," he said.

But political observers in Zimbabwe say the amount of dissent within Zanu-PF is unprecedented. They claim the party leadership has never used the candidate selection process to root out dissidents as fiercely as this year.

In the past, primaries usually involved local contenders and those who were defeated rarely ran for parliament as independents. This time more than 20 former loyalists are standing in the national elections

In many areas outsiders were parachuted in by Zanu-PF headquarters as candidates against the wishes of local activists, with allegations of stacked selection meetings with members brought in bus or lorry from elsewhere.

While previous arguments within Zanu-PF focused mainly on patronage and ethnic factions, this time there were many differences on policy. Even the taboo subject of Mr Mugabe's age - he is 76 - has been raised.

Patrick Chitaka, 46, is a former central committee member who did not run in the primary in the eastern city of Mutare because he suspected it was stacked against him.

Now running as an independent, Mr Chitaka says he wants to be part of a new political landscape in Zimbabwe.

"Zanu-PF has entrenched corruption and dictatorship, and has run out of ideas. Instead of the geriatric leadership retiring gracefully, they have brought economic ruin to this once beautiful country," he said.

In his office beside the beer hall he owns in Glenview near Harare, Clive Chimbi, a local businessman, is equally scathing about the stacked primaries. A Zanu-PF MP since 1995, Mr Chimbi found the boundary of his constituency changed by the delimitation commission appointed by Mr Mugabe.

"They brought people in for the primary who live in parts of the next-door constituency which have suddenly been added to mine. The aim was to strengthen the rival candidate against me," he said.

Confident of support from local voters, he refused to accept his de-selection and decided to stand as an independent. He makes the same accusations of Zanu-PF intimidation as are usually heard from the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), the main opposition party.

"The MDC is not strong in this constituency so all Zanu-PF intimidation is focused against me," he said, adding that his posters are torn down and his supporters are threatened.

His crime was to speak out against corruption in the party and the government. Now he is accusing Sabina Mangwende, the party candidate who replaced him, of trying to buy votes by promising people parcels of land for housing.

"She takes people out to a white-owned farm nearby, points out sections, and tells each of them to plant a stake for a residential stand. They each pay her $25. Next day she takes another group to the same sections. If I win the elections I'm going to try to ensure she gives their money back," he insisted.

"I want to play a liberal role in the next parliament," said Richard Nyandoro, who represented Highfield West in the last two parliaments for Zanu-PF. Now running as an independent, he angered the leadership with his outspoken role on parliamentary committees' inquiries into corruption.

"I called for the finance minister to resign because he did not run contract tenders properly," he said.

He is also critical of the way in which Mr Mugabe has chosen to fight the election after losing the referendum on a new constitution in the February campaign.

As a member of the party's central committee at the time, he knows - although it was never publicised - that the party set up a task force under its chairman, John Nkomo, to draw lessons from that defeat. The task force recommended that Mr Mugabe make it clear well before his term ran out in 2002 that he would not stand again, Mr Nyandoro said.

Although the issue was not formally discussed by the central committee, Mr Mugabe told one member who raised it: "Do you think if I resign the party will win the general election?"

Defiantly, he then launched Zanu-PF's election campaign on the issues he feels strongest about: taking land from whites and hostility to Britain and its colonial rule.

Confident of retaining his seat, this time as an independent, Mr Nyandoro said he would not join the MDC.

"They have no real programme, but the good thing is that for the first time we are going to have an opposition. That is progressive. In a one-party system you have no checks and balances."

fields.headline: 4,000-year-old treasure found in Indus Valley
fields.trailText: Archaeologists in India were last night examining a spectacular find of gold jewellery from a lost and stubbornly enigmatic civilisation, which flourished in the Indus valley more than 4,000 years ago before mysteriously dying out. The jewellery was left behind by the Harappans, India's first urban dynasty.
fields.body:
Archaeologists in India were last night examining a spectacular find of gold jewellery from a lost and stubbornly enigmatic civilisation, which flourished in the Indus valley more than 4,000 years ago before mysteriously dying out. The jewellery was left behind by the Harappans, India's first urban dynasty.

Between 3000 and 1700 BC they built a series of vast city states along the Indus river, in modern-day Pakistan and over the border into west India. The jewellery's discovery in the north Indian state of Uttar Pradesh suggests the Harappan empire was much bigger than previously thought.

The treasure was found last month under a mound of earth by a farmer. More than three tonnes of gold jewellery was discovered - only to be swiftly looted by villagers. Officials sealed off the scene and managed to salvage 10kg of gold jewellery, as well as pottery and burnt bricks.

Armed policemen have now been posted at the site in the village of Mandi and a reward has been offered to villagers to try to get the artefacts back. So far none of them have come forward. "Our aim is to save the antiquities. Otherwise they will sell them on the open market and the gold will be melted down," said AK Sharma of the state's archaeology unit.

Komal Anand, the director general of the Archaeological Survey of India, last night described the find as highly significant.

"Such a large collection of 2000BC Harappan jewellery has never been found at any other site in India. It indicates that the Harappans had started moving from the north for some reason," she said.

Experts say the jewellery is similar to other items recovered from Mohenjo-daro, a vast Harappan city in Pakistan which was discovered by the British in the 1920s. While the Harappans were sophisticated enough to build public swimming pools, and may have invented the bullock cart, they remain a mystery. Their script, which reads from right to left, has never been deciphered. Almost nothing is known about their religion. They were eventually superseded in 1700BC by the invading Aryans.

The Archaeological Survey of India also showed off 31 strange anthropomorphic figurines, which were dug up in the nearby district of Moradabad and date back to the Harappan period. The green copper figurines are unusual because they have one arm waving towards the sky, and one pointing downwards, Ms Anand said. "They are cult figures which may have had some religious or magical significance. We simply don't know".

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Nigeria braced for 'sharia' riots
fields.body:
Nigeria braced for 'sharia' riots

Troops and riot police have been sent to strengthen security in Nigeria's Kano state before the introduction of sharia law today, which officials fear could trigger violence. Islamic leaders said no part of the state would be exempt.

In the southern oil town of Warri, at least three people were killed and 200 injured when thousands of students clashed with troops yesterday.
Reuters, Kano, Warri

Israel in Turkey to talk water

An Israeli delegation has arrived in Turkey to talk about supplying Israel with water from a Turkish river, Milliyet newspaper said yesterday.

The officials were scheduled to meet the energy minister today to discuss exporting water from the Manavgat river. Israel has a chronic water shortage.
AP, Ankara

Italian released in Yemen

Yemeni tribesmen have released Alberto Alessio, an Italian archaeologist, and several of his Yemeni companions after holding them for four days, government sources said yesterday.
Reuters, Sana'a

webTitle: Gunmen kidnap key man in talks with Farc

fields.headline: Gunmen kidnap key man in talks with Farc
fields.trailText: Heavily armed gunmen kidnapped the brother of one of the lead negotiators in the Colombian government's peace talks with Marxist rebels after a day-time shootout in which two people were killed, authorities said.
fields.body:
Heavily armed gunmen kidnapped the brother of one of the lead negotiators in the Colombian government's peace talks with Marxist rebels after a day-time shootout in which two people were killed, authorities said.

The high-profile abduction on Monday came less than a week after Colombia's main rightwing paramilitary force had accused the victim's brother, Fabio Valencia Cossio, of being "excessively generous" to rebels and promoting their interests at the negotiating table.

Between six and 10 gunmen seized Guillermo Leon Valencia, 44, after a high-speed car chase and gunfight with his trio of bodyguards on a street in a residential sector of Medellin, police said.

General Alfonso Arellano, chief of operations for the national police, said one of the police bodyguards was killed in the shootout along with one of the kidnappers, who was armed with an Israeli-made automatic assault rifle.

There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the abduction of Mr Valencia, who like his brother is a politician and powerful leader of the centre-right Conservative party in north-west Antioquia province.

But it came just five days after the ultra-right United Self-Defence Forces of Colombia (AUC) issued a strongly worded statement accusing Fabio Valencia, Guillermo Leon's brother and a close ally of the Colombian president, Andres Pastrana, of siding with guerrillas in their slow-moving peace talks with the government.

In a statement referring to the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc), Latin America's largest and oldest guerrilla army, which opened talks to end Colombia's long-running civil conflict a year and a half ago, the AUC told Mr Cossio: "Not only have you been excessively generous with the Farc, you have also defended the interests of the subversives."

The conflict, which has taken 35,000 lives during the past decade, pits the Farc and two smaller insurgent groups against the military and paramilitary groups, which have killed leftists and suspected rebel sympathisers with impunity since the mid-1980s.

Nearly 3,000 abductions occurred last year in Colombia, Latin America's third most populous country with 40m people and with a reputation as the kidnap capital of world.

fields.headline: Agency 'fixed figures' on jobs
fields.trailText: The government agency in charge of regenerating rundown England misrepresented the official cost of creating thousands of new jobs, to pretend it was twice as efficient in spending public money, MPs reveal in a report published today.
fields.body:
The government agency in charge of regenerating rundown England misrepresented the official cost of creating thousands of new jobs, to pretend it was twice as efficient in spending public money, MPs reveal in a report published today.

English Partnerships, which spent £460m creating 700 projects, also gave half its staff performance related pay for meeting targets that were yesterday rubbished by MPs on the Commons public accounts committee.

One member, Alan Williams, Labour MP for Swansea West, told them: "It seems to us that you have been expert in presenting more effectively than it should have been the performance you were achieving because you grossly underestimated the costs per jobs for projects you were involved in."

MPs denounced the agency, saying its claim to spend £10,000 to create every job was less than half the real cost of £23,000, when other funding from the public sector, including cash from the European Union and local councils, was included.

The agency gets £300m a year from the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions and raises £160m a year from sales of surplus property and land. The worst examples include a £6.6m contribution towards a new housing, nursery, park and surgery development in Hulme, Manchester, which cost the agency £150,000 a job. fields.headline: Awaiting the world's dawn chorus
fields.standfirst: Colombia's Marxist guerrillas try to assess the response to Washington's plan to throw $1bn against the drugs trade, on which they depend
fields.trailText: Colombia's Marxist guerrillas try to assess the response to Washington's plan to throw $1bn against the drugs trade, on which they depend
fields.body:
For the 17,000 guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc) the day starts at 4am. It may be 36 years since they embarked on their attempt to bring revolution to the country, but there is no relaxation of the routine that has turned them into one of the biggest and best-armed guerrilla forces in history.

After exercises and morning parade, they stop for breakfast and the news. So sophisticated are some of their camps that they have their own televisions powered by generator.

"The news is discussed over breakfast at 6.30am," says Lucero Palmera, 26, who has been with Farc for nine years. "It might be a discussion about what is happening in Cuba or about Clinton's wife or about Israel. There is always a political focus to it. If there is no television, we listen to the news on the radio."

The guerrillas will be listening very closely to the news in the coming days and weeks as the world focuses on Plan Colombia, the agreement by which the United States will send more than £1bn-worth of military aid to the Colombian government, officially to crush drug trafficking but essentially to destroy the Marxist Farc.

Much of Farc's funding comes from cocaine and heroin, either, as Farc says, by "taxing" growers and traffickers or, as the US government says, from direct involvement in the trade.

The plan has raised fears of a big increase in the fighting and killing which plague Colombian society.

After breakfast, the camp is tidied up and, if necessary, defensive trenches are dug: a frequent task since they move position every five days, often marching all day to a new hide-out.

"There are no siestas in the afternoon," Ms Palmera says with a laugh - rather, there is study: "It could be anything. Philosophy, mathematics, history. This is a permanent daily school."

They bathe or shower from 4.30pm to 5pm and change clothes in readiness for "cultural hour" at 6pm. There may be singing, dancing, or a film show that has "a message", followed by a discussion about anyone from Pablo Neruda to Oliver Stone. They go to bed early, not least because they will each be doing two hours guard duty in the night.

What is striking about Farc now is the number of women in its ranks, currently about 30% and, according to a senior spokesman, Simon Trinidad, "increasing all the time".

Some Farc units are already headed by women commandantes, and most of its road-blocks in this 16,000 square mile area of Colombia, which has been temporarily ceded to Farc by the government as part of a peace initiative, are organised by women.

The Farc office in the centre of San Vicente, the unofficial capital of 'Farclandia' as the demilitarised zone is known, is run by Nora: a nom de guerre, as all the names of those in Farc are: a practice intended in part to protect their families, who are targeted by far-right paramilitary groups.

Nora has the task of dealing with problems brought to her by the townspeople of San Vicente, greeting visitors to the peace process - a busload of mainly black law students from Cali arrived while we were in town - and handling the press.

The guerrillas are allowed to form personal relationships and an array of contraceptives is made available. Abortions are also offered: Farc has a network of sympathetic doctors, who also treat its wounded.

Lucero Palmera has an eight-year-old daughter, who lives with her parents. "You have a choice to be a guerrilla or a mother. You suffer a lot and it's very hard for my family to explain to my child where I am - and it is very hard for me," she says.

She and Nora say there are obvious attractions for women in Farc: they are treated equally, escape the machismo elsewhere in Colombian society and, if they come from poor families, have the chance of an education which would otherwise elude them.

The young men of San Vicente, seeing female guerrillas strolling round their streets in uniform with their AK47s over their shoulders, make passes at them, she says. "You hear them saying 'Hey, bonita', and you might have an ice cream or a coffee with them, but we would not go drinking or dancing with them."

She has been in combat many times, she says, but has never taken part in a kidnapping. The money seized during kidnaps or paid in ransom for kidnap victims goes towards running Farc. Sometimes Colombian journalists are kidnapped to be taken to see the site of a massacre carried out by the paramilitaries, who wipe out villages considered sympathetic to Farc.

From its origins as a peasant guerrilla movement under Manuel "Tiro Fijo" (sure-shot) Marulanda in July 1964, Farc has evolved into this army which is neither well enough supported to take over the country nor small enough to be defeated militarily.

Mr Marulanda, who is still alive and in charge and the subject of a tall portrait in the San Vicente office, is a party to the painfully slow peace talks with the government.

When Farc previously re-entered conventional politics as a political party, Union Patriotica, in the 80s, it learned a painful lesson: 13 of its 18 elected mayors were assassinated and more than 3,000 members were killed, depriving the party of much of its intellectual leadership.

Only a few of those responsible for the killing, mainly carried out it is believed by the military, have been charged.

Since then Farc has been involved in many killings of its own. The night of our conversation it killed a policeman in the nearest town outside the zone, and his colleagues abandoned their post.

As night falls on San Vicente, the senior guerrillas drift back to their camps hidden in the countryside. At 4am a new day will begin, and with it discussions of the news reports containing, as they will this week, predictions that if the military aid package goes through, Colombia may become the Vietnam of the 21st century.

webTitle: New laws tighten grip on corruption

fields.headline: New laws tighten grip on corruption
fields.standfirst: MPs, lobbyists and business people will risk jail if sweeteners are given
fields.trailText: New tough laws which will make even the unaccepted offer of a bribe a criminal offence at home and abroad were announced yesterday by Jack Straw, the home secretary.
fields.body:
New tough laws which will make even the unaccepted offer of a bribe a criminal offence at home and abroad were announced yesterday by Jack Straw, the home secretary.

MPs accepting bribes will also face up to seven years in prison under the proposed changes following the Guardian's exposure of the "cash for questions " scandal which led to the resignation of disgraced ex-Tory ministers Neil Hamilton and Tim Smith.

If proposed laws had been in force at the time, it is likely that Mr Hamilton, Mr Smith, lobbyist Ian Greer and Harrods owner Mohamed Al Fayed could all have been prosecuted over the £50,000 paid in cash to the two Tory MPs to ask questions in the Commons.

The new laws will both redefine bribery and corruption and extend prosecution of British citizens caught offering or giving bribes to officials abroad to gain contracts.

The government has decided to bow to international pressure - particularly from America and countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development - to pursue British citizens abroad. Under the law they could be extradited to Britain to stand trial.

Ministers will also have the power under other legislation now going through parliament to seize encrypted emails and intercept mobile phone messages and conversations in pursuing companies suspected of authorising foreign nationals to bribe people abroad to get round the law.

Announcing the proposals in the Commons, Mr Straw told MPs: "Corruption is like a deadly virus. It has no boundaries. We need to fight it wherever it is found.

"For too long dishonest individuals have profited at the expense of undermining the integrity of professional and public life in this country. The international business community increasingly realises that a culture of corruption is a disincentive to investment and trade."

The new law will exempt corporate hospitality. It will also make clear that tipping people like taxi drivers, hairdressers, waiters, hotel staff or car park attendants to secure better services would also be outside the scope of the new corruption laws.

The inclusion of the phrase "trading in influence" - as a definition of corruption - suggests that a parliamentary lobbyist who regularly entertains a minister or civil servant, or invites them on expensive trips, might get caught under the new laws.

In this case, the law would target the lobbyist rather than the recipient - unless the person accepted a bribe. Ministers, however, emphasise that the law is not specifically directed at any reform of parliamentary lobbying.

The proposals, expected to be put before parliament later this year, will simplify and clarify the law embodied in the three corruption acts of 1889, 1906 and 1916.

The Home Office minister Charles Clarke said yesterday: "There is a greyish area at the bottom of what might be involved in this. It is a question of judgments that need to be made in this area."

The legislation will mean the right of parliamentary privilege, brought in to protect MPs' and Lords' freedom of speech, will no longer protect them from allegations that they acted corruptly in the Houses of Parliament.

"What we are doing is removing parliamentary privilege from MPs who seek to use membership of parliament to protect themselves from these allegations," said Mr Clarke.

"From now on there'll be no advantage in being an MP in protecting you from these charges."

The plans will also treat corruption in the public and private sectors in the same way for the first time.

The presumption of corruption for public servants contained in the 1916 act will be abolished so that prosecutors will have to prove they were motivated by a bribe just as they would in cases against those working in the private sector.

No charges will be able to be brought against any individual without the consent of government law officers - thus ruling out any private prosecutions.

webTitle: Scythe that reaps a harvest of praise

fields.headline: Scythe that reaps a harvest of praise
fields.trailText: Sixty wildflower acres and a Nissen hut were ranked with Turner landscapes and Wren churches yesterday as one of Britain's most valuable treasures.
fields.body:
Sixty wildflower acres and a Nissen hut were ranked with Turner landscapes and Wren churches yesterday as one of Britain's most valuable treasures.

The heads of both the National Trust and English Nature trekked from London to a Yorkshire smallholding to honour the work of Walter Umpleby and his scythe.

Tucked beyond the reach of slurry wagons and fertiliser sales agents, the patch of Malham Moor was declared the country's newest national nature reserve at a farmyard ceremony surrounded by swaths of wood cranesbill, melancholy thistle and the greater butterfly orchid.

Scientists have been astonished by the wealth of plants preserved by Mr Umpleby's "outstanding" management of one of the last true hay meadows in the northern uplands.

Martin Drury, director general of the National Trust, said: "We call this an agri-environmental benefit.

"But in truth it is a great national treasure, as fragile, rare and important to this country as an ancient building or work of art."

The survival of the meadows at New House Farm, almost 2,000ft above sea level, is due to Mr Umpleby's dogged use of traditional meadow management for 40 years, a period when 99% of the habitat in Britain succumbed to modern intensive farming. The crucial regime, maintained since Mr Umbleby, now 72, retired and sold the smallholding to the NT, involves a single mowing in July, prompt removal of the hay, and no soil nutrients apart from stall-litter from the flock of 65 sheep. "It's an irony that underfeeding makes the plant life richer," said Robert Forrester, director of the Yorkshire Wildlife Trust, who also joined the ceremony.

New House, which previously had the lower ranking of 'site of special scientific interest', will be inspected regularly to ensure that standards are kept - and Mr Umpleby will call by too. His scythe has been handed on to tenant farmer Roy Newhouse, 49, who said: "I'd like to think I will be here, using Walter's methods, at least until I'm 70."

fields.headline: Military tribute for murdered brigadier
fields.trailText: Defence chiefs, a former prime minister and current ministers yesterday joined about 900 mourners at the funeral of the murdered military attache Brigadier Stephen Saunders at Salisbury Cathedral.
fields.body:
Defence chiefs, a former prime minister and current ministers yesterday joined about 900 mourners at the funeral of the murdered military attache Brigadier Stephen Saunders at Salisbury Cathedral.

Brigadier Saunders was shot dead by terrorists on June 8 while driving to work at the British embassy in Athens.

Politicians and diplomats from Britain and abroad joined the brigadier's widow Heather and his daughters, Nicola, 15, and Catherine, 13, at the funeral which was held with full military honours.

The coffin, draped with the union flag, was carried from the hearse by six pall bearers before being met by a guard of honour from the soldier's former regiment, the Royal Gloucestershire Berkshire and Wiltshire regiment.

Among those attending the service were Geoffrey Hoon, defence secretary, Robert Key, shadow defence spokesman, Sir Edward Heath, former prime minister, General Sir Michael Walker, chief of general staff, and General Sir Mike Jackson, commander in chief of UK land forces.

A private family service and burial will take place today.

The urban guerrilla group November 17 claimed responsibility for the brigadier's killing, saying it was retribution for Britain's role in the Nato bombing of Yugoslavia last year.

A reconstruction of the murder in Athens last week had prompted new witnesses to come forward, said Constantine Bitsios, acting head of the Greek embassy in London.

Press Association

webTitle: 85% want Sellafield to stop sea discharges

fields.headline: 85% want Sellafield to stop sea discharges
fields.trailText: Nearly nine in 10 of British adults think British Nuclear Fuel's Sellafield plant in Cumbria should be stopped from discharging reprocessed radioactive waste into the air and sea, according to a poll conducted by NOP.
fields.body:
Nearly nine in 10 of British adults think British Nuclear Fuel's Sellafield plant in Cumbria should be stopped from discharging reprocessed radioactive waste into the air and sea, according to a poll conducted by NOP.

The poll, commissioned by Greenpeace two weeks ago and released to the Guardian, comes ahead of next week's crucial meeting of Nordic countries, which are expected to call on Britain to end reprocessing at Sellafield.

The findings are also likely to be used by Labour environmental activists working towards an end to Sellafield reprocessing at Labour's national policy forum on July 7.

The Ospar convention on marine pollution is being held in Copenhagen next week. Ospar's previous meeting two years ago called for discharges into the sea to be reduced to close to zero.

Even though the British and French governments can register a derogation next week, the vote would be a diplomatic blow for Britain, and significantly worsen the government's relations with Denmark and Ireland, the two countries pushing hardest for an end to discharging.

Ministers will also come under pressure at Westminster today when the backbench Labour MP David Chaytor presses the government "to bow to the inevitable" and accept that the economic and environmental case for an end to reprocessing is overwhelming.

He said that by 2010 Britain would, on current trends, have 110m tonnes of plutonium for which it would have no use.

Mr Chaytor also pointed out that Germany, one of BNFL's chief customers, had only last week voted to end nuclear power over the next 20 years. He also claimed the Japanese general election this weekend would see an increase in the number of MPs opposed to reprocessing.

The detailed poll for Greenpeace showed only 11% of Britons say discharges should be allowed - with another 4% saying they do not know. The other 85% are against it.

Support for a ban dropped to 64% when job losses were taken into account and support for continuing rose to 27%.

Nearly 90% accepted that the UK government should stop importing foreign nuclear waste; and 72% said Sellafield should continue properly managed storage of nuclear waste on land.

BNFL is already reeling from the news that its workforce falsified safety data on fuel rods bound for BNFL's Japanaese customers. Contracts with the Japanese and others have either been lost or threatened - and the crisis has led the government to postpone the privatisation of BNFL.

The poll was conducted by NOP Solutions between May 26 and 28 among 1,005 people aged over 15.

webTitle: Italian resort towns hit by green slime

fields.headline: Italian resort towns hit by green slime
fields.trailText: Miles of sticky slime is washing up on to Italy's Adriatic coast in an epidemic that is revolting tourists, threatening fishermen and baffling scientists.
fields.body:
Miles of sticky slime is washing up on to Italy's Adriatic coast in an epidemic that is revolting tourists, threatening fishermen and baffling scientists.

The green sludge, known as mucilage, has been sighted on beaches from Trieste in the north-east to Pescara in central Italy.

Tourist authorities in the town of Grado, in the gulf of Trieste, are trying to avert a travel boycott by offering refunds to holidaymakers covered by the gelatinous substance.

The phenomenon is not pollution but harmless organic matter made up primarily of sugars exuded by micro-algae and bacteria, according to Attilio Rinaldi, director of Icram, the environment ministry's sea research institute. Its cause remains uncertain but scientists are blaming an unusually warm winter that has raised water temperatures by 5C (9F) above the average.

The mucus was first recorded in 1749 and Mr Rinaldi suspects it is a natural cycle that recurs every dozen or so years. Italian and Croatian researchers are in the process of a £2m study of the phenomenon, and hope to provide an answer by 2002.

Another theory blames the Po river's reduced volume; it is pouring less than 1,500 cubic metres (400,000 gallons) of water a second into the sea, which has altered the chemical balance of coastal waters. "It's an absolutely natural phenomenon but, like cancer, we're a long way from coming up with a solution for it," one researcher told Italy Daily.

Tour operators are threatening to redirect clients away from the affected areas unless a solution is found, raising fears of a repeat of 1989, when the slime ruined the tourist season.

Scientists say the best short-term hope is regional tourism's other enemy, the high speed bora winds - cold northern gales that blow from the mountains to the east coast of the Adriatic - which whip up sand.

A 60mph blast last weekend reduced temperatures and dispersed mucus from the gulf of Trieste. However, temperatures are expected to rise again this weekend.

A recent report by the National Health Institute warned that the substance may not be totally harmless. It may absorb toxins in the water and prolong the life of agents that cause disease, resulting in mild illness from eating fish or swimming.

webTitle: Governor in sex case faces jail

fields.headline: Governor in sex case faces jail
fields.trailText: Prosecutors demanded an 18-month prison sentence yesterday for the disgraced former governor of Osaka in the biggest sexual harassment case Japan has ever seen.
fields.body:
Prosecutors demanded an 18-month prison sentence yesterday for the disgraced former governor of Osaka in the biggest sexual harassment case Japan has ever seen.

"Knock" Yokoyama, a former comedian who came to power on a promise to clean up the city's scandal-tainted politics, has admitted molesting a female student during an election campaign last year.

At a hearing at the Osaka district court, prosecutors said he was guilty of a "shameful act on an unprecedented scale for a man in his position".

His 22-year-old victim - a former member of his election team - has testified that the governor groped her for about 30 minutes in the back of a campaign truck.

Prosecutors said this proved that Mr Yokoyama had abused his authority to carry out a "vicious crime".

The judges were also asked to take account of the fact that the governor attempted to bribe and bully his victim. Mr Yokoyama offered the woman designer bags in return for her silence. When she spoke out - an unusual step in Japan, where shame prevents many women from complaining about harassment - he initially accused her of lying and lodged a counter claim in the courts.

"The accused has shown no respect for the dignity of the victim," the prosecutors said. "He only apologised and admitted his guilt at the last moment to win leniency."

The court must decide on a fitting sentence for Mr Yokoyama. Eighteen months in prison would be one of the most severe punishments ever handed down to a former governor, but it is well short of the maximum penalty, which is seven years in prison.

Mr Yokoyama's lawyers are likely to repeat the former governor's claim that he was unaware that his actions were causing his victim any suffering.

"She did not resist much when I slipped my hand inside her pants," he has said.

In pleading for leniency, they will also argue that Mr Yokoyama has been punished enough. As well as being forced to step down, a civil court has ordered him to pay 11m yen (£67,000) in damages, the largest award in a sexual harassment case in Japan.

The district court's decision is the subject of intense interest in Japan because sekuhara (sexual harassment) has only recently been recognised as a serious offence.

In the past 10 years, there have been only about 100 harassment suits, but in a sign of changing attitudes the government passed new laws last year to try to stamp out workplace molesting.

webTitle: Hain sidesteps demand to explain position on US missile project

fields.headline: Hain sidesteps demand to explain position on US missile project
fields.trailText: The government yesterday sidestepped demands from the Tories to explain its attitude to highly controversial US plans for a national anti-missile shield which will involve upgrading the Fylingdales early warning radar system and America's eavesdropping centre at Menwith Hill in north Yorkshire.
fields.body:
The government yesterday sidestepped demands from the Tories to explain its attitude to highly controversial US plans for a national anti-missile shield which will involve upgrading the Fylingdales early warning radar system and America's eavesdropping centre at Menwith Hill in north Yorkshire.

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, pressed for an urgent Commons debate on the project.

"It's an issue of huge importance, indeed comparable to the deployment of cruise missiles in the 1980s," he told MPs.

However, Peter Hain, the foreign office minister, insisted it was too early to make a decision on an "untested, unproven" system.

He said that the system was "vulnerable to decoys and all sorts of other technological devices" and when the Americans decided to proceed, the government would consider it.

Despite strong opposition from Russia and many of America's European allies - notably France and Germany - the US defence department is determined to go ahead with the project to protect itself against what it once called "rogue" states and now calls "states of concern". They include Iraq, Iran, North Korea and Libya.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, has acknowledged that Britain could be a target of such states if Fylingdales and Menwith Hill formed part of the US project.

webTitle: Airlines test device to trace mobiles

fields.headline: Airlines test device to trace mobiles
fields.trailText: Airlines are testing warning devices in their cockpits to locate active mobile phones after tests by the civil aviation authority revealed that mobiles were a threat to the safety of aircraft.
fields.body:
Airlines are testing warning devices in their cockpits to locate active mobile phones after tests by the civil aviation authority revealed that mobiles were a threat to the safety of aircraft.

Tests carried out by the CAA on board two aircraft found that phone transmissions produced interference levels which could disrupt aircraft systems.

The tests back up the existing CAA ban on the use of mobile phones on aircraft while the engines are running.

The CAA said last night: "We are not happy with the present state of affairs. Tougher measures are being taken by airlines, but if they do not work, we will have to consider alternatives, including extra shields in the cabin to stop interference in the cockpit."

The CAA, Britain's regulatory authority for the industry, dismissed suggestions that passengers should be forbidden to take mobiles on board. "But we have to face the fact that accidents happen and that mobiles which are switched off and stowed in the holds can turn themselves on, and pose a threat to safety."

The CAA's tests found that interference levels varied with small changes in the location of the telephone and that passengers in the path of the transmission reduced the signal. This meant that the number of passengers could affect the level of interference.

webTitle: Shearer bows out in slow motion

fields.headline: Shearer bows out in slow motion
fields.trailText: Roy Collins reports on Alan Shearer's last game in an England shirt.
fields.body:
Alan Shearer, in his final game wearing the three lions, was at least spared the ignominy that befell Gary Lineker in his last match in 1992, pulled off by Graham Taylor as England crashed out of these championships to Sweden.

Unlike Lineker, Shearer remained on the field to the end. But in many ways it was just as humiliating a farewell and Shearer knows he will figurein the post mortem on another disastrous European excursion.

There were so many other clearly culpable players that one could not point the finger for last night's defeat at Shearer alone. But Kevin Keegan's illogical decision to stick with him as both first-choice striker and captain seriously undermined England's campaign here.

Shearer, as captain, seemed to have an unhealthy influence on whom the manager picked to play alongside him. And when he announced a few months ago that he would retire after this tournament, it seemed like a selfish plea to keep him in the side. Keegan stood by him to the end, refusing to substitute him last night and deluding himself by stating after the win over Germany that Shearer had once again made fools of his critics. He had not. He merely made the most of the single opportunity that came to him in a game in which he spent most of his time acres from the danger area.

Last night, his penalty apart, he did not have a shot, let alone on target, a remarkable statistic for an apparently indispensable forward.

Shearer in truth was effectively finished as an England striker long before his official retirement, after a series of operations left him a shadow of the man who was so deadly during Euro 96.

On the one occasion he got the ball near goal Shearer, knowing the game was up, threw himself to the floor and was booked for diving. It was a sad end to an international career for a man who last night joined Nat Lofthouse and Tom Finney as England's joint-fourth most prolific striker ever.
