webTitle: Keegan's luck runs out at last

fields.headline: Keegan's luck runs out at last
fields.standfirst: Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: England were within two minutes of reaching the quarter-finals when Ioan Ganea won the game for Romania with the second penalty of the evening.
fields.body:
In the end England threw themselves out of the European Championship. Just when it seemed that Kevin Keegan's team had survived the best of Romania's attacking efforts to hold on for the draw that would have taken them to the quarter-finals, Phil Neville needlessly gave away a penalty and it was all over.

Thus penalties and England remain synonymous with failure in major international tournaments. At least this time nobody missed one in a shoot-out; in fact Alan Shearer, given a chance to bring the scores level from the penalty spot in the first half, took it as coolly as you like.

England were seldom as composed as this. For long periods of the match, and especially in the second half, they wore an air of desperation as Romania's superior passing and movement swept through their midfield as though Keegan's men were not there. Indeed this was often the case.

The fateful lunge by the younger Neville which sent Viorel Moldovan tumbling as the Romanian striker tried to cut past the Manchester United full-back near the left-hand byline was an aberration waiting to happen. Neville did not need to make such a challenge in that situation, but he panicked and was done for.

As Ioan Ganea, one of the Romanian substitutes, whacked the ball past Nigel Martyn the collective breath of England's supporters was taken away. You could hardly blame them. This was the cruellest of low blows.

Yet it was difficult to contest the justice of the victory which will take Romania to Brussels on Saturday to meet Italy in the quarter-finals. For much of last night's match they were the more accomplished, better organised, more composed team. Whereas Romania usually knew what they were about, with England it was more a case of guesswork.

As to the luck England were always going to need, it was just about even. In a bizarre prologue David Seaman hurt a leg during the warm-up and was replaced by Martyn, who was lost when Romania scored their first goal and at fault with their second. Against that England scored twice in seven minutes at the end of the first half after Romania lost Gheorghe Popescu, their best defender.

In some ways last night's match was reminiscent of the 3-2 defeat England suffered against Portugal in Eindhoven in their opening game. England's failure to hold an advantage was again down to shortcomings in midfield and defence.

Keegan could have become the first man in charge of England to get them out of the group stage in a European Championship played abroad. He failed because his players never mastered the art of closing a game down when ahead.

Last night England defended with the determination they had shown in holding on a 1-0 lead against Germany here three days earlier. The difference was that Romania were far more likely than that wretched German side to find the skill and wit to break England down. Perhaps it would have been kinder had they not allowed Keegan's spirited but ingenuous team to get so close to the result they needed but did not really deserve.

At least there will be no illusions about how much still has to be done before England can seriously be considered a significant force again in international football. Beating Germany for the first time in a tournament for 34 years may have stirred hearts but intelligent heads are more urgently needed, on and off the field.

Last night's performance was no more profound than most of England's previous European Championship matches. They looked what they were, a team that had struggled to qualify and then begun the tournament proper on borrowed time.

Individually there were some limited successes: Martin Keown again sound in defence, Paul Ince strong at the back of the midfield, Paul Scholes the astute provider of a goal for Michael Owen which briefly recalled memories of England's recovery against Argentina in the last World Cup.

Yet David Beckham was never the influence he had been against Portugal and Germany. The longer the match progressed, moreover, the more Shearer and Owen became isolated as Dorinel Munteanu took over the conductor's baton from the suspended Gheorghe Hagi and orchestrated the game to a Romanian tune.

Keegan had called for better passing from his players but did not get it. Romania's build-ups were quicker, slicker and more imaginative. Their players did not have to glance up to see where colleagues were; they knew.

After 22 minutes Cristian Chivu gave Romania the lead in bizarre circumstances. A corner had been half-cleared and the England defence was slow to react when Chivu gained possession.

For once Keown was not around to close down the danger as Chivu clipped the ball towards the far post, where Moldovan was lurking. In the event all Moldovan had to do was watch the ball strike the inside of the post and rebound across the goalline with Martyn a hapless spectator.

All England groaned but after Popescu had been forced off after a tackle with Beckham there was a crack in the ramparts. In the 40th minute Shearer slipped the ball inside to Ince, who was brought down by Chivu's clumsy tackle. In went Shearer's penalty and the point England sought looked on again.

Indeed first-half stoppage-time left the predominantly English crowd convinced that they would get through with three. Scholes gained possession midway inside the Romanian half and caught the defence moving up too late with a lob which Owen touched past the advancing Bogdan Stelea and tapped into the net.

The second half quickly dispersed English optimism. Within three minutes Martyn, partly impeded by Keown as he went to meet Dan Petrescu's cross, punched the ball out weakly and straight to Munteanu, who drove Romania level once more.

The rest, for England, was all about sweat and substitutions until Phil Neville's error and Ganea's composure with the penalty brought Romania the win they deserved, leaving Keegan to wonder how much kudos there was left from beating the Germans. That triumph now looks a mite hollow.
